abstract: Sebastian Eustache, keeper of the theatrical and drinking saloon, Nos. 515 and 517 Fourth-street, gave bail in $300 before Justice BRENNAN yesterday to answer a complaint for giving a dramatic entertainment on Sunday. Warrants were issued for the arrest of Edward Hannam and Otto Hoym, proprietors of the New-York Stadt Theatre, and James Connor and _____ Sich, of the Volks Garten, No. 45 Bowery, on a similar charge. Frederick Hellberg and John Reed were likewise required to find bail in $300 to answer a charge of gambling in a game called Tivoli, at the Volks Garten. The following-named parties were arrested for selling liquor: John Dudliss, No. 108 Avenue D; Henry John, No. 58 Avenue B; John McGann, No. 180 Rivington-street; Michael McCoy, No. 77 Cannon-street; Thomas Kerrigan, No. 169 First-avenue; Louis Taegg, No. 93 Delancey-street; Mich. McCoy, No. 289 Rivington-street; John Fuller, No. 129 Bowery; Henry Schwartz. No. 57 Pike-street; John Gostar, corner of Broome and Cannon streets; Thomas Gleason, No. 284 Seventh-avenue; Thomas Mulligan, No. 384 Seventh-avenue; Laurence Byrne, corner of Sixth-avenue and Thirtieth-street; August Newman, corner of Twenty-ninth-street and Eleventh-avenue, and James Wallace, No. 238 First-avenue. Most of the accused were made to furnish a surety in $100 for their appearance to answer, although in some cases the bail was fixed at $300.

abstract: Messrs. BOWEN and BERGEN met at Headquarters yesterday afternoon. A resolution was passed, reestablishing the roundsmen abolished by the old Board. Two roundsmen are to be appointed from the patrol force for each Precinct, and the sergeants are hereafter to be appointed from such roundsmen.
lead_paragraph: Messrs. BOWEN and BERGEN met at Headquarters yesterday afternoon. A resolution was passed, reestablishing the roundsmen abolished by the old Board. Two roundsmen are to be appointed from the patrol force for each Precinct, and the sergeants are hereafter to be appointed from such roundsmen.

abstract: AFFAIRS AT QUARANTINE -- The Legislature, at its last session, was forgetful enough to adjourn, without making any appropriation for Quarantine purposes, and the consequence is, that no settled plan has been adopted to prevent the introduction of pestilence among us from foreign ports, during the near approaching season. The Commissioners of Emigration now have no jurisdiction over the matter at all, and the Board which was, is without money. Should there be no way discovered by which the necessary funds to sustain the floating Hospitals can be raised, there is but one resource, and that a disagreeable one to the Staten Islanders. The sheds still stand within the inclosure at Tompkinsville, and they are the only place in which the sick can be cared for. Even to use these sheds, money is required for medical attendance and nursing, and of this, as is understood, there is none to be had. It is rumored Congress will be applied to, to pass a law, making Sandy Hook a permanent quarantine, and the Staten Islanders, still fearful of their old neighbor, are about requesting their representative in Congress to push this matter and get it through, if possible, before the end of the present session.

abstract: The delay of the Common Council in awarding the Central Paris Commissioners sufficient funds to carry on the work has retarded the progress of the Park to a great extent. The appropriation of a quarter of a million of dollars was only allowed last week, and the money has not yet been paid over. There are at present but 700 men engaged, but as soon as the needful is forthcoming the force will be more than doubted, so that full 1,500 men will be employed within a few weeks.

abstract: Our latest news from Charleston only confirms each party in previously-expressed opinions. Those determined to defeat DOUGLAS say that he is used up, while his friends argue the reverse. Several gentlemen who arrived this evening from Charleston say the nomination of Mr. DOUGLAS is out of the question, as the determination is to defeat him or break up the Democratic Party. The whole contest, however, is completely overshadowed by the news from England of HEENAN's victory. Q.

The whole contest, however, is completely overshadowed by the news from England of HEENAN's victory. Q.

abstract: -- The "Special Artist" of one of our illustrated papers, recently visited Washington, and one of his objects was to sketch the interior of Judge DOUGLAS' house. The Judge was not at home, but the artist, as he sat in the library, pulled out his sketch-bock and commenced taking notes. But his occupation was interrupted by the entrance of the Judge's mother-in-law, who peremptorily ordered "Crayon" to leave the house. The poor artist attempted to explain the nature of his mission, but the lady disdained to listen. Taking Crayon by his arm, she escorted him to the front door, and to accelerate his departure, placed her hand upon his shoulders, and landed him at once in the middle of the street. Where will this muscle-mania end?

abstract: The long-threatened disruption of the Convention at Charleston came at last yesterday. The indications early in the session pointed to that event as inevitable. Mr. BUTLER's resolution, barely reaffirming the Cincinnati Platform, was of course voted down; but in the voting a question was raised whether the recommendation to vote as a unit, which the New-Jersey Convention had addressed to its delegates, was equivalent to instruction. The President ruled that it was; and an appeal being taken, the decision was reversed by a decided majority, and so two votes for DOUGLAS set at liberty. This victory was followed up by the adoption of the minority report by a very large majority, averaging upon each resolution 272. Upon the attainment of this result, the delegates from Alabama, Louisiana, Mississippi, Florida, Texas and South Carolina, with a portion of the Arkansas delegation, after protesting against the action of the majority, retired, and repairing to St. Andrew's Hall, organized a separate body. A ticket, consisting of DAVIS and EVERETT, is said to be a favorite among them. A portion of the California delegation will probably attach itself to this movement, and it is not entirely certain that some Pennsylvania, Delaware and Virginia members may not take the same course.
lead_paragraph: The long-threatened disruption of the Convention at Charleston came at last yesterday. The indications early in the session pointed to that event as inevitable. Mr. BUTLER's resolution, barely reaffirming the Cincinnati Platform, was of course voted down; but in the voting a question was raised whether the recommendation to vote as a unit, which the New-Jersey Convention had addressed to its delegates, was equivalent to instruction. The President ruled that it was; and an appeal being taken, the decision was reversed by a decided majority, and so two votes for DOUGLAS set at liberty. This victory was followed up by the adoption of the minority report by a very large majority, averaging upon each resolution 272. Upon the attainment of this result, the delegates from Alabama, Louisiana, Mississippi, Florida, Texas and South Carolina, with a portion of the Arkansas delegation, after protesting against the action of the majority, retired, and repairing to St. Andrew's Hall, organized a separate body. A ticket, consisting of DAVIS and EVERETT, is said to be a favorite among them. A portion of the California delegation will probably attach itself to this movement, and it is not entirely certain that some Pennsylvania, Delaware and Virginia members may not take the same course.

abstract: Will of John G. Boker. -- This will has been fully published, and the public are already advised of the disposition made of his property by the testator. Mary Ann Dean (formerly Boker) was not remembered in the will, and makes no objection to its distributions. It is stated that she resides in Wiliamsburgh, living happily in the care of a faithful husband. Dean is reported to be employed at a fair salary, and contented without a share in the estate of his father-in-law.

abstract: The Tribune and Express are waging a pleasant little warfare concerning the West Washington Market affair. The only points which neither of them ventures to touch, however, are the merits of the case and the interest of the City in the disposition that may be made of it. This seems to be regarded as a matter of very trifling consequence quite beneath the consideration of either combatant. The Tribune has a double object in view.
lead_paragraph: The Tribune and Express are waging a pleasant little warfare concerning the West Washington Market affair. The only points which neither of them ventures to touch, however, are the merits of the case and the interest of the City in the disposition that may be made of it. This seems to be regarded as a matter of very trifling consequence -- quite beneath the consideration of either combatant. The Tribune has a double object in view. Its first, and most difficult undertaking, -- upon which no one less sanguine and visionary would have ever ventured, -- is to "shame the Express into telling the truth." Its next task -- which may be easier, but is quite as profitless -- is to show that, "if the City has been swindled, the responsible parties are Democrats." The Express, on the other hand, contents itself with exclamation points, small capitals and a general howl. These exhaust its rhetoric, and habitually serve instead of logic. It seems to have a confused notion that, as the State is now in Republican hands, whatever mischief has ever been done within its limits is to be charged to the Republican account.

abstract: The Police Commissioners have accomplished a much-needed reform, in closing the Station-houses against the Aldermen who go the rounds at night for the purpose of discharging from custody their pet bullies and blackguards who fall into the hands of the Police. The facility with which these personages were permitted to release their friends from the operation of the law has been, for some years back, one of the greatest of the many scandals which afflicted this unhappy City. It is bad enough to have such men intrusted with a share of the Government; but it is still worse to allow them grossly to abuse the magisterial powers with which traditions, derived from a more decent age, have unhappily invested them.
lead_paragraph: The Police Commissioners have accomplished a much-needed reform, in closing the Station-houses against the Aldermen who go the rounds at night for the purpose of discharging from custody their pet bullies and blackguards who fall into the hands of the Police. abstract: The notable devotion to dramatic music which characterises our present opera-going public cannot be better illustrated than in the avidity with which every opportunity of paying homage to works really large and meritorious is seized. There was a time when "Don Giovanni" failed to remunerate the enterprise of management; when its vast agglomerative characteristics, musical and otherwise, were regarded with disfavor. Now it is one of the most certain operas in the repertoire, and distrusted only by managers who fear that its splendors will dim any subsequent production of less lustre. MEYERBEER, who is the best known representative of the new school, is already a favorite here. His principal works have been received with enthusiasm, and although inordinately expensive to produce -- when compared with others of the Italian repertoire equally celebrated -- have never failed to pay a handsome dividend to the enterprising manager who produced them. In this, as in many other respects, we approach the French standard of taste, and yearn obviously towards things that are not only good in themselves but pleasant and satisfying to all the senses. We require in the present day dramatic effect, pictorial illusion, correct costumes and good music.

abstract: Really it must seem strange to you, when, on the night of the third day's session, I begin my letter by saying there is literally nothing new. Why it is so is beyond my comprehension, but the fact is patent that a slower set of men, or a set which can more truthfully claim the title of a "deliberative body," never heretofore existed.

abstract: The Convention made progress yesterday. It took, indeed, a long stride towards the performance of the business which called it together. It adopted a PLATFORM, and thus set forth the basis on which it proposes to conduct the Presidential Canvass. All that remains is the nomination of a candidate; and even that has been greatly facilitated by the action already taken.

abstract: COMMON COUNCIL -- COST OF THE FERRY WAR. -- A regular meeting -- and the last -- of the present Board of Aldermen, was held last evening. Considerable routine business was transacted, when the following report was presented: The Committee on accounts of the Special Committee on Ferries report, that they have made such examinations and find the accounts correct. The amount expended in the conducting of the suit instituted by the Attorney-General against the corporate authorities of the City of New-York, and in various injunctions, and in the efforts to pass the bill to reduce the rates of ferriage to one cent, is $9,617 85, and under assurances and indications which justified a belie that the object would be accomplished. The prosecution of the suit has been attended with very valuable results thus far, and there is every reason to hope that still further advantages will follow. The great point, that the governmental powers over the ferries still rest with the Legislature, has been established by the decision of Judge HOGEBOOM, as well as the power of the Legislature to regulate the rates of ferriage and against the lessees of the ferries. The results are of inestimable value to the citizens of Brooklyn, and encourage the belief that, with proper exertions hereafter, they will be emancipated from the burden of undue oppression created by the improper action of the New-York Common Council; and that the management of the ferries will be placed by the Legislature in the hands of impartial Commissioners, who will license and protect the interests of all equally. Signed -- ROBERT FURY, CHARLES JENKINS, CHARLES FRANKS. The report was accepted, and the Board adjourned to Thursday evening next.

abstract: The frame stables in the rear of No. 281 West Thirty-eighth-street, owned by WM.R. DAVIDSON, were burned at 1 o'clock yesterday morning, with those adjoining, occupied by RYAN & WEHMANN, and the cooper's shop of CONRAD MILLER. Three horses, three wagons, two ice-carts, and five sets of harness, belonging to Mr. DAVIDSON, valued in the aggregate at $1,200, were burned. Messrs. RYAN & WEHMANN likewise lost three horses, worth $400, and Mr. MILLER suffered a loss of $110. None of these parties had their property insured. The fire is supposed to have been kindled by an incendiary.

abstract: The Society of the Church of the Puritans resumed, last evening, their discussion of the difficulties which have sprung up between Dr. CHEEVER and the Trustees of that Church, of which he is pastor, because of the sending of Miss JOHNSON to Great Britain for the purpose of collecting funds to sustain him and his adherents as exponents of the Anti-Slavery cause. The lecture-room, where the meeting was held, was crowded. Dr. GEORGE H. WHITE was moved to the Chair. The prefatory prayer was made by Rev. JOEL BLACKMAN.

abstract: The inquest on the body of the female who was found gagged and sunk with a barrel of pitch at the York-street dock, on the 14th of April last, was concluded last night before Coroner MORRIS, at the Station-house in Jersey City. The announcement of the fact caused great excitement, and hundreds of people called at Dr. QUIDOR's office to view the head, which had been severed from the body and preserved in alcohol. Some of these called from motives of curiosity; others, thinking that that they might recognize it as is that of some person with whom they were acquainted, and of the whole number about forty persons were of the impression that the description which had been published answered in some respects that of missing friends. No person was known to have been missed from Jersey City, and the impression prevailed that the victim and perpetrators of the crime belonged in New-York. Coroner MORRIS accordingly applied to Deputy Superintendent CARPENTER to assist in unraveling the mystery, and Officers ELEER and YOUNG were detailed for the purpose. On the Tuesday following the discovery of the body, a genteel appearing young man called upon Dr. QUIDOR and asked to look at the head, stating that the description answered perfectly with that of his wife, with the exception that instead of one ear having been torn out, where they had been pierced for earrings; both had been torn out, but that one of them had been healed up, leaving a slight scar. The Doctor, on examination, discovered a scar as stated. The young man then departed, but returned again on the following day, and requested that the body might be exhumed -- stating, further, that, if it was the body of his wife, there would be found a small scar on the right groin, caused by an abscess; a peculiar, thick toe-nail on the right toe, and large bunions on the large toe-joints. Dr. QUIDOR, accompanied by Coroner MORRIS and the young man, proceeded to the New-York Cemetery and caused the remains to be exhumed, when the marks were all found as described. The young man, who is known as "Boston Charley," stated that he had not lived with his wife for over two years; that she had resided at the Brandreth House, St. Denis Hotel, and other places, living a fast life. These facts were communicated to Deputy CARPENTER, and furnished a clue for the officers to work upon, and by which means they tracked Mrs. RICHARDSON for a period of over two years, during which time she lived in magnfficent style at the St. Denis; next to the house in Astor-place; from thence to the St. Julien Hotel; next to a private house in University-place; from there to the Lafarge House, whence she went on board the steamship Cahawba on the 12th of January, for New-Orleans, which was the last positive information they had of her. The hotel books revaled the fact that a wealthy young gentleman, of family and high standing in the community, had paid Mrs. RICHARDSON's hotel bills, the suite of rooms and board amounting to about $40 per week.

abstract: The Comptroller having effected the necessary arrangements with the owners of the new building occupied jointly by the Daily News and Frank Leslie's Magazine, for the use of the upper floors, to be occupied by the City Inspector, (who declined, on the score of personal danger, to occupy the rooms in the new miscalled building recently erected on Centre-street,) that official moved into his new quarters yesterday, and hereafter, until another hegira comes around, all the bureaux connected with this Department will be under one roof.

abstract: We have several times felt called upon to animadvert upon the manners and morals of the New-York Bar, or of members of it, with some severity. The Bar of New-York is much like the City. There are nowhere to be found more straightforward, fair-minded lawyers -- more high-toned gentlemen -- than are many of its members. And yet every now and then the public is outraged by some performance on the part of a lawyer, some mean advantage, some breach of faith, some act of indecorum, unchecked by the Court or by public sentiment, or some villainy discovered, but not punished, which reminds one of the terrible understratum of dishonesty, immorality and shamelessness which underlie our social system and make its foundations insecure.

abstract: The enlargement of the circulation of the TIMES is at the present moment so rapid as to render it imperative that advertisements intended for the daily issue should be sent in at the earliest possible moment. Announcements which fail to reach the office before nine o'clock P.M., lose all the advantages of classification under the heads to which readers are accustomed to refer. It is, therefore, quite as important to the advertisers as to ourselves, to have that hour the latest for the reception of their notices.

abstract: Michael Lynch was so seriously injured on the 20th inst., by failing from a scaffold at the new building corner of Reade and Church streets, where he was employed, that he died yesterday at the New-York Hospital....Joseph Hoffman, a German, 30 years of age, was almost instantly killed yesterday morning, by falling through the hatchway on the fifth story of No. 100 Walker-street. Coroner SCHIRMER investigated both cases.

abstract: This Court met yesterday morning, pursuant to adjournment, Judge SUTHERLAND presiding. There were no cases ready for trial, but the unhappy youth, Henry Karples, Jr., was brought forward for sentence. This young man has occupied the attention of this Court, and that of the General Sessions, for several months. He was employed as a clerk in the service of the well known flour merchants, Hecker & Brothers, and his crime against them and society at large, was the embezzlement of 971 parrels of flour, during a period of twenty months, from October, 1857, to June, 1859 -- the value of said flour being $6,495. He is of highly respectable connections, and his case, in consideration of the position which he occupied, his youth, (he is not yet 21 years of age,) his education and former good character, has been one of much general interest. His punishment, unfortunately, is not limited to himself. He has a wife, to whom he was married about two years since, and to his ambition to compete, in the household expenses of the conjugal state, with richer men than himself, the commission of his offence is due.

abstract: Rev. John McDowell, D.D., of Philadelphia, has resigned his office as Secretary of the Board in Princeton Theological Seminary, which he has held for 48 years, on account of increasing infirmities of age. Rev. Dr. J.L. Janeway was elected in his place. The Directors recommended the appointment of Rev. Dr. Dabney, of Virginia, and Rev. C. Wistar Hodge, son of Rev. Dr. Hodge, to Professorships in the Seminary, thereby supplying the chair of the late lamented Prof. Addison Alexander, and also creating a new Professorship.

abstract: We see it is asserted with a great deal of confidence that Gov. MORGAN proposes to leave the vacancy on the Police Commission, caused by Mr. PILSBURY'S resignation, unfilled. Upon what authority this announcement is made we are not aware; we trust, however, that it is entirely without foundation. The law intends that the Commission shall consist of three persons; we do not think that Gov. MORGAN ...
lead_paragraph: We see it is asserted with a great deal of confidence that Gov. MORGAN proposes to leave the vacancy on the Police Commission, caused by Mr. PILSBURY'S resignation, unfilled. Upon what authority this announcement is made we are not aware; we trust, however, that it is entirely without foundation. The law intends that the Commission shall consist of three persons; we do not think that Gov. MORGAN is likely to violate its spirit and defeat its intent by enacting that it shall only consist of two. That he has no shadow of right to do this directly, everyone will grant; and it ought to be equally clear that he has no greater right to do it indirectly -- by a refusal to exercise a power devolved upon him by law. The power of appointment was not conferred upon him as a mere right, or as a privilege -- as something purely personal in its character -- to be exercised or waived at his discretion. It is a duty imposed upon him, and he is just as much bound to perform it, as he is to discharge any other function of the Executive office.

abstract: The split in the Democratic party at Charleston is an event of very marked importance. It marks a step in the history of the country decidedly in advance of any taken hitherto, and from which there is not likely to be any retreat hereafter. It shows conclusively that the political power of the Confederacy must pass to the North, -- that the numerical majority, the preponderant wealth and population of the Union, -- is about to assert its rightful authority over the political institutions of the country also. For a long time past we have had a United South, -- we are about to have a United North also.

abstract: Our references to the Charleston Convention must hereafter be placed in the dual number; for Charleston has two Conventions, the proceedings of which claim equal attention. The Southern Seceders, who on Monday afternoon bade solemn farewell to their fellows, and, taking up their cross, fashioned, doubtless, after the symbol of the Scottish tutelar Saint, repaired to St. Andrew's ...
lead_paragraph: Our references to the Charleston Convention must hereafter be placed in the dual number; for Charleston has two Conventions, the proceedings of which claim equal attention. The Southern Seceders, who on Monday afternoon bade solemn farewell to their fellows, and, taking up their cross, fashioned, doubtless, after the symbol of the Scottish tutelar Saint, repaired to St. Andrew's Hall, on the same evening met in conclave not unlike the primitive seceders from heaven, conferring over their deed and its momentous consequences. Mr. JOHN C. PRESTON, of South Carolina, spoke with great eloquence and at much length upon the subject, regarding the bolt as "a great occasion -- a movement of the constitutional lovers of the Republic." He was succeeded by Mr. YANCEY, of Alabama, who counseled delay, that the Southern delegates who still lingered in the Douglas Convention might yet consider, repent and withdraw. Only when Mr. DOUGLAS should be placed in nomination would the time for Southern action arrive. Mr. BAYARD, of Delaware, thought the spirit which ruled the regular Convention was less the spirit of Black Republicanism than of plunder. A call of the States was ordered when, in response to the State of New-York, a Wood delegate stated that his colleagues were present and prepared to sustain the policy of the seceders; and Mr. FISHER, of Virginia, when that State was named, declared that he would not be alone; and that he had invited Mayor "WOOD to attend. Maryland made no response; two Delaware delegates were present, with a minority of the South Carolina delegation. The Monday evening meeting closed with an adjournment to the open air, where Mr. YANCEY addressed delighted multitudes. The National Convention met yesterday at the usual hour; when, prior to the commencement of business, a member of the Georgia delegation announced that after anxious consideration, he, with a number of his colleagues, felt constrained to enter their protest against the platform, and retire. Twenty-four arose at once and left; four others followed, declaring they never would abandon the majority; while eight retained their seats. The Arkansas delegation then bolted, leaving FLOURNOY alone behind; and the entire representations of Tennessee, Virginia, and North Carolina, with portions of those from Maryland, Delaware, and Kentucky, asked and procured leave to retire for consultation. Mr. COHEN, of the Georgia relict, obtained the floor, declaring his early and late devotion to the party, and his intention not to desert it "until the last feather should be laid on the camel's back, when he would be the foremost to go." Mr. FLOURNOY, of Arkansas, denounced the bolt as uncalled for, or at least premature, and expressed the opinion that it would fail to obtain the sanction of the great body of the Southern people. These apologetic and explanatory remarks were cut short by Mr. MONTGOMERY, of Pennsylvania, who wanted to hear no more of the bolters; but did greatly desire to proceed to business. The great struggle of the day was on a motion to abolish the two-thirds rule; Messrs. STUART and RICHARDSON advocating that measure, and Messrs. BIGLER and BUTLER opposing it. The contest prevented the attainment of a ballot. The bolting Convention succeeded in effecting an organization in the afternoon, choosing Mr. BAYARD, of Delaware, for President.

abstract: The enlargement of the circulation of the TIMES is at the present moment so rapid as to render it imperative that advertisements intended for the daily issue should be sent in at the earliest possible moment. Announcements which fail to reach the office before nine o'clock P.M., lose all the advantages of classification under the heads to which readers are accustomed to refer. It is, therefore, quite as important to the advertisers as to ourselves, to have that hour the latest for the reception of their notices.

abstract: Messrs. WETHERED BROS. state in the TIMES of the 26th, what had been before mentioned by our correspondent "Franklin," that their process consists in mixing wet and dry steam, thus securing the advantages of superheating without injury to the cylinder from excessive heat and dryness. Hon. JOHN WETHERED read a paper on ...
lead_paragraph: Messrs. WETHERED BROS. state in the TIMES of the 26th, what had been before mentioned by our correspondent "Franklin," that their process consists in mixing wet and dry steam, thus securing the advantages of superheating without injury to the cylinder from excessive heat and dryness. Hon. JOHN WETHERED read a paper on combined steam before the Institute of Civil Engineers at London, March 2T, in which the advantages of the process were fully and fairly set forth. We think there is no mistake about its value. The abstracts of that paper, as given by the London Press, do not state the precise manner in which the superheating is accomplished -- how the pipes or vessels are arranged so as to receive heat enough, without at any time being exposed to excessive heat.

abstract: Ladies were debarred from visiting the Japanese corvette while it lay in San Francisco. But two French ladies were determined to see the decks of the foreign ship; the feminine lexicon, like that of youth, contains "no such word as fail." Accordingly, by the connivance of their husbands, they donned the distinguishing articles of the masculine uniform, and clambered up the ship's sides.
lead_paragraph: -- Ladies were debarred from visiting the Japanese corvette while it lay in San Francisco. But two French ladies were determined to see the decks of the foreign ship; the feminine lexicon, like that of youth, contains "no such word as fail." Accordingly, by the connivance of their husbands, they donned the distinguishing articles of the masculine uniform, and clambered up the ship's sides. As Frenchmen, they were received with remarkable politeness, and carried on a lively conversation with the Admiral -- the only drawback being that neither could understand the other's language. But when they prepared for departure, and extended their hands to the Admiral in leave-taking, that distinguished Japanese perceived a rat, and summoning an attendant presented the pseudo gentlemen with a variety of magnificent hair-pins, bracelets and furs, remarking that though a Japanese he was still a man, and could detect the pressure of a lady's hand. The unfair visitors blushed and acknowledged the -- trowsers.

abstract: A letter from Haverhill, Mass., says: One of the most striking movements of the times in this vicinity is that existing in the temperance cause. For more than eight years no effort worthy the name of one, has been made here. A moral power has recently been brought to bear for the revival of the cause, and with the most gratifying success. The effort was first commenced late in the Winter by Mr. Adams, and the result thus far has been the establishment of three large and powerful organizations embracing male, female, and juvenile membership, which is bringing back much of the spirit and enthusiasm of the old Washingtonian movement.

abstract: DESTRUCTIVE FIRE IN ORANGE FIVE PERSONS BURNED TO DEATH. Between 4 and 5 o'clock on Monday afternoon a blacksmith shop in Orange, occupied by JONATHAN HOBS, caught fire. The upper part of the building, originally intended for a store room, had been used by HOBS as a dwelling for his family, which consisted of his wife and six children, two of whom were twins, only a few weeks old.
lead_paragraph: DESTRUCTIVE FIRE IN ORANGE -- FIVE PERSONS BURNED TO DEATH. -- Between 4 and 5 o'clock on Monday afternoon a blacksmith shop in Orange, occupied by JONATHAN HOBS, caught fire. The upper part of the building, originally intended for a store room, had been used by HOBS as a dwelling for his family, which consisted of his wife and six children, two of whom were twins, only a few weeks old. The flames caught near the stairway leading to the upper room, thus cutting off all escape, and before they could be rescued, Mrs. HOBS, with the twins, and another one of her children, and the daughter of a neighbor were fatally burned. Engine Companies Nos. 7 and 9, and Hose Carriages Nos. 1 and 4 from Newark, were on the spot and assisted in taking the remains from the ruins. HOBS, it is said, was in Newark after the fire, and stated to several persons that his wife and six children had been burned to death, when it was impossible for him to have known the particulars of the fire. The little girl who was rescued, before death put an end to her sufferings, stated that HOBS set fire to a pile of shavings near the stairway, locked the door and ran away. He was arrested on Monday night, at about 11 o'clock, in Freemantown, and is now in custody, awaiting the investigation of the Coroner's jury.

abstract: The leading journal of Great Britain, the voice, as it is not unfairly assumed to be, of the ruling classes of moral and civilized England, exults exceedingly in the morality and civilization of HEENAN, SAYERS, and the shouting thousands who hallooed those champions on to batter each other out of the human face divine on the 17th of April last.
lead_paragraph: The leading journal of Great Britain, the voice, as it is not unfairly assumed to be, of the ruling classes of moral and civilized England, exults exceedingly in the morality and civilization of HEENAN, SAYERS, and the shouting thousands who hallooed those champions on to batter each other out of the human face divine on the 17th of April last. It speaks of their encounter as of a close of America with England on some glorious field of fame. It philosophises upon their patient rivalry in brutal violence and dumb endurance, in language which might justly be applied to the martial constancy of the English Guards at Inkermann, or to the heroic enthusiasm which carried a KANE and a FRANKLIN beyond the icy gateways of the Frozen Zone. This organ of English sense and English decency, having first ascertained that, however badly the British Champion had been pummeled in the fight, he was not to be absolutely published to the world as beaten on an English heath by a Yankee invader, gravely announces that "nations, without great qualities, could not have brought together two men willing to pass through such an ordeal as the terrible fight" at Farnborough.

abstract: Two colored men, named respectively Allen Graff and Josiah Hay, alleged to have recently escaped from Maryland, were captured in this City on Monday by Maurice O'Keefe, John Dugan and John Corrigan, three of the Deputies of United States Marshal Rynders, who had received a particular description of the fugitives, and who were employed for the purpose of arresting them. They were brought before United States Commissioner BETTS on Monday; ...
lead_paragraph: Two colored men, named respectively Allen Graff and Josiah Hay, alleged to have recently escaped from Maryland, were captured in this City on Monday by Maurice O'Keefe, John Dugan and John Corrigan, three of the Deputies of United States Marshal Rynders, who had received a particular description of the fugitives, and who were employed for the purpose of arresting them. They were brought before United States Commissioner BETTS on Monday; particular pains having been observed to keep the matter a profound secret in order to avoid excitement. On being brought into the presence of the Commissioner, Hay appeared very much overcome and excited. He sat with his head leaning upon his breast and wept constantly. The other man, Graff, was less agitated, and on being asked if he desired to have counsel, said something which was interpreted "No." Afterwards he said he wanted to go home. Both appeared to be field hands, and to have had little time away from their "home" in which to try the "experiment of freedom."

abstract: A portion of our German fellow-citizens are reserting to practices for the evasion of the new Sunday law, which will prove neither creditable nor serviceable to their cause. Those of them who sell beer object very strenuously to being curtailed of that privilege one day in the week, and have formed two associations for the purpose of contesting the validity of the law and disarming the vigilance of the Police.
lead_paragraph: A portion of our German fellow-citizens are reserting to practices for the evasion of the new Sunday law, which will prove neither creditable nor serviceable to their cause. Those of them who sell beer object very strenuously to being curtailed of that privilege one day in the week, and have formed two associations for the purpose of contesting the validity of the law and disarming the vigilance of the Police. A meeting of the parties concerned was held at the Stadt Theatre on Saturday, and was attended by nearly forty of these gentlemen. A tariff of 20 cents a barrel, or thereabouts, was imposed on the Sunday sales of lager, to be collected on Monday morning, and expended on lawyers, Courts, &c., and to protect the confederates in violating the law.

abstract: A dispatch in one of the morning papers from Washington states that "a private letter, received in this country from one of the firm of WETMORE, WILLIAMS & CO., at Shanghai, announces that Mr. TOWNSEND HARRIS, our Consul-General to Japan, is dead." We understand that Messrs. WHTMORE & CO., of this City, have letters from their correspondent in Japan to the 23d of February, and that they make no mention either of the death or Illness of Mr. HARRIS, with whom the correspondent referred to is very intimate. It is not likely that any later intelligence than this has been received in this country. The rumor in question is therefore probably without foundation.
lead_paragraph: A dispatch in one of the morning papers from Washington states that "a private letter, received in this country from one of the firm of WETMORE, WILLIAMS & CO., at Shanghai, announces that Mr. TOWNSEND HARRIS, our Consul-General to Japan, is dead." abstract: A question has lately occupied the attention of the Georgia Judiciary, as to whether the  marriage ceremony could be performed by an excommunicated clergyman. The question arose in this wise: A bill had been filed by JAMES F. DUPREE ...
lead_paragraph: -- A question has lately occupied the attention of the Georgia Judiciary, as to whether the marriage ceremony could be performed by an excommunicated clergyman. The question arose in this wise: A bill had been filed by JAMES F. DUPREE and wife, in, equity, against URIAH ARKEN, for account and distribution; to which the defendant pleaded that the plaintiffs were not legally married, the marriage ceremony having been performed by a minister who had previously been excommunicated from the Church, and deprived of the credentials authorizing him to act in that capacity. To this plea a demurrer was filed. The case having been decided in favor of the plaintiffs, appeal was taken, when the Supreme Court decided that the marriage was legal, confirming the decision of the Court below.

abstract: The Buffalo Express, which started by rejoicing over the injuries inflicted on New-York City by the passage of the Railroad bills, as a just punishment for its hostility to the Pro Rata scheme, now changes its tone.
lead_paragraph: The Buffalo Express, which started by rejoicing over the injuries inflicted on New-York City by the passage of the Railroad bills, as a just punishment for its hostility to the Pro Rata scheme, now changes its tone. It protests against our assumption that Buffalo has no interest in the local affairs of our City. On the contrary, it insists that Buffalo "has an interest in every improvement that tends to public accommodation" in New-York, and "especially in its facilities for street locomotion." Whether the Express means to say that the representatives of Buffalo in Albany have an "interest" in the specific bills passed, we do not know, but it goes on to say:

lead_paragraph: How frequently of late has the commercial public been called upon to mourn the untimely loss of its most popular and efficient members. In no case, however, have there been regrets more sincere than those which are called forth by the unfortunate accident which, last week, deprived a large circle of friends of the presence of JOHN O. WOODRUFF, Esq. To mention his loss, is to awaken the sorrow and sympathy of the mercantile public not only in New-York, St. Louis and New-Orleans, with which cities his house was directly connected, but also with their correspondents throughout the West and South.

abstract: Alderman BOOLE, whose exertions on behalf of the City are untiring, offered a resolution on Monday, that a Committee of two, one from each Board of the Common Council, be appointed, to travel whithersoever they pleased, in company with "a savant," to be selected by the New-York Sanitary Association, in ...
lead_paragraph: Alderman BOOLE, whose exertions on behalf of the City are untiring, offered a resolution on Monday, that a Committee of two, one from each Board of the Common Council, be appointed, to travel whithersoever they pleased, in company with "a savant," to be selected by the New-York Sanitary Association, in search of sanitary regulations, applicable to this City. The resolution, we are sorry to say, was laid over, but we trust it will at a very early day be taken up and acted upon. We think there are, at least, two members of the Common Council who are fairly entitled to a pleasant tour to Europe this Summer, at the expense of the City, and if we know anything of the feelings of the tax-payers, they will be delighted to concur in the proposal. The only hesitation about it which can find a place in any well-balanced mind, will be due to the fact that the deputation will not be able to rid themselves of the reflection that they are traveling with other people's money, and they may thus be led to deny themselves many little comforts. We acknowledge that New-York can learn a great deal from European cities in the matter of sanitary science; and we must say we think a pair of Common Councilmen would be just the fellows to bring us home all we ought to know. Their great familiarity with European languages, and with the ways of European society and governments, and their scientific attainments, would at once place them in the most agreeable relations with European officials; while the habits of observation, skill in classification of facts, and severely judicial tone of mind acquired by rigid training and great culture, would of course render their report a most invaluable contribution to the work of sanitary reform.

abstract: The devout believers in the Papal infallibility, whose faith is apt to increase in the direct ratio of their distance from the immediate sphere of the Papal authority, take a very high tone with the miserable skeptics who venture to doubt whether VICTOR EMANUEL II. will be much the worse for the excommunication by implication to which he has just been subjected.
lead_paragraph: The devout believers in the Papal infallibility, whose faith is apt to increase in the direct ratio of their distance from the immediate sphere of the Papal authority, take a very high tone with the miserable skeptics who venture to doubt whether VICTOR EMANUEL II. will be much the worse for the excommunication by implication to which he has just been subjected. They assure this incredulous world of railways and telegraphs that the effects of the Papal bull are not the less sure because they are spiritually accomplished; that PIUS moves in a mysterious way his curses to perform; and that although the liberated Italians may escape the tax-gatherers and the torturers of St. Peter, they will none the less be overtaken, sooner or later, by the avenging terrors of the Church.
headline: {'main': 'The Effects of Excommunication.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Effects of Excommunication.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: An Express reached this place on the 11th inst. from Lieut. abstract: If the constantly recurring catastrophes by fire, tempest and explosion, which characterize our water transit, fail by reason of their very familiarity to demand legislative interference if the often-repeated tale of horror is too threadbare to excite the popular demand for reform, it is still likely that a marked improvement will arise from another source.
lead_paragraph: If the constantly recurring catastrophes by fire, tempest and explosion, which characterize our water transit, fail by reason of their very familiarity to demand legislative interference -- if the often-repeated tale of horror is too threadbare to excite the popular demand for reform, it is still likely that a marked improvement will arise from another source. The restlessness of our locomotive people is crowding our ocean and inland steamers, and demanding new lines and wider accommodations every year; almost every man is a traveler; the law-making public is legislating � not for the forlorn inmates of ratinfested hospitals and tinder tenement houses, but for itself. On its own head will fall the penalties of neglect and indifference.

abstract: VENERABLE BRETHREN HEALTH AND APOSTOLIC BENEDICTION! We can scarcely express in words the rejoicing and gladness which your letter of the 19th January afforded us, in the midst of our greatest sadness and tribulation. You hastened, venerable brethren ...
lead_paragraph: VENERABLE BRETHREN -- HEALTH AND APOSTOLIC BENEDICTION! We can scarcely express in words the rejoicing and gladness which your letter of the 19th January afforded us, in the midst of our greatest sadness and tribulation. You hastened, venerable brethren, to write to us immediately on your meeting for the celebration of your Provincial Council, in order that assembling together under the invocation of the Holy Spirit, and in mutual consultation, you might provide still more for the welfare of the Dioceses committed respectively to your Episcopal zeal and guidance. For in your letters shine forth on every side bright evidences of your great attachment and special devotion to us, and of your reverence, love and obedience to this chair of St. Peter, and, in like manner, your bitter sorrow on account of our tribulations, universally known, brought on by the counsels and intrigues of men who, hostile to this Apostolic See, and opposed to the civil principality which belongs to it, by sacrilegious daring have attempted to destroy the patrimony of St. Peter, and to extinguish entirely its rights, as well divine as human. These they hope and labor to destroy utterly. Most grateful to us has been this evidence of your great sympathy, so truly worthy of Catholic prelates, and so worthy to be distinguished by praise and publication,

abstract: The enlargement of the circulation of the TIMES is at the present moment so rapid as to render it imperative that advertisements intended for the daily issue should be sent in at the earliest possible moment. Announcements which fail to reach the office before nine o'clock P.M., lose all the advantages of classification under the heads to which readers are accustomed to refer. It is, therefore, quite as important to the advertisers as to ourselves, to have that hour the latest for the reception of their notices.

abstract: The body of the woman who was found murdered at the York-street dock, has been further identified by four persons as that of Mrs. ADA RICHARDSON. On Tuesday evening the proprietor of the Lafarge House, accompanied by his book-keeper and bartender, called at Dr. QUIDOR'S house, during his absence, and desired to view the head.
lead_paragraph: The body of the woman who was found murdered at the York-street dock, has been further identified by four persons as that of Mrs. ADA RICHARDSON. On Tuesday evening the proprietor of the Lafarge House, accompanied by his book-keeper and bartender, called at Dr. QUIDOR'S house, during his absence, and desired to view the head. Upon seeing it they at once positively identified it. The proprietor of the hotel stated, however, that Mrs. RICHARDSON entered her name on the books as Mrs. NEWTON. He said also that he could bring a number of ladies from his house who would be able to identify her. A young gentleman from Boston called yesterday, and, after viewing the head, said that it resembled in every respect that of ADA RICHARDSON. He had known her for two years in Boston, having seen her almost every day in the streets, and that she was well known there. It will be recollected that the detectives, in tracing up the affair, found Mrs, RICHARDSON'S name booked on the steamship Cahawba, for New-Orleans, on the 12th of January last. The two barrels of pitch were also found to be missing between Saturday, the 12th, and the Monday following. Further efforts are to be made in hopes of ferreting out the perpetrators of the crime, in order to bring them to justice.;

abstract: Rev. John James, of Missouri, entered a complaint last Saturday against James Duffy, the keeper of the notorious ticket swindling office, No. 109 West-street, charging him with having defrauded him out of the sum of $250 by false representations in the sale of passage-tickets by the steamer to California, whither the reverend gentleman desired to go. Mr. James alleges that, believing Duffy's to be the genuine office, he paid $600, as he supposed, for three first-class tickets, but, on presenting them on board the steamer, he learned that they only entitled him to the accommodations of the steerage, and that they could have been purchased for $350 at the office of the Steamship Co. As one of the provisions of the act passed by the last Legislature to prevent frauds in the sale of passenger tickets, makes it a misdemeanor, with a penalty upon conviction of imprisonment for not less than six months or more than two years, to charge more than the regular price for a ticket, whether the offender, be an authorized agent or not, a warrant was issued for the arrest of Duffy and one Charles Gilmour, his clerk, but both of them had placed themselves without the pale of the law by fleeing to Jersey City. Under these circumstances the complainant made a supplementary affidavit, based on another provision of the act in question, which declares that ticket offices of the description [complained of shall be proceeded against and broken up as disorderly houses. In the afternoon Capt. Hart, with two of his officers, went to the place for the purpose of arresting all persons they might find there; but its occupants had departed, and its doors were closed. So, after watching it a couple of hours without having observed any one enter, the Police postponed their business.
lead_paragraph: Rev. John James, of Missouri, entered a complaint last Saturday against James Duffy, the keeper of the notorious ticket swindling office, No. 109 West-street, charging him with having defrauded him out of the sum of $250 by false representations in the sale of passage-tickets by the steamer to California, whither the reverend gentleman desired to go. Mr. James alleges that, believing Duffy's to be the genuine office, he paid $600, as he supposed, for three first-class tickets, but, on presenting them on board the steamer, he learned that they only entitled him to the accommodations of the steerage, and that they could have been purchased for $350 at the office of the Steamship Co. As one of the provisions of the act passed by the last Legislature to prevent frauds in the sale of passenger tickets, makes it a misdemeanor, with a penalty upon conviction of imprisonment for not less than six months or more than two years, to charge more than the regular price for a ticket, whether the offender, be an authorized agent or not, a warrant was issued for the arrest of Duffy and one Charles Gilmour, his clerk, but both of them had placed themselves without the pale of the law by fleeing to Jersey City. Under these circumstances the complainant made a supplementary affidavit, based on another provision of the act in question, which declares that ticket offices of the description [complained of shall be proceeded against and broken up as disorderly houses. In the afternoon Capt. Hart, with two of his officers, went to the place for the purpose of arresting all persons they might find there; but its occupants had departed, and its doors were closed. So, after watching it a couple of hours without having observed any one enter, the Police postponed their business.

abstract: GILMORE'S Brass Band made every one homesick this mornning, at the opening of the Convention, by playing "Home, Sweet Home." Then our drooping spirits were revived by "Hail Columbia" and "Yankee Doodle."

abstract: The steamship Canada, from Liverpool on the 21st ult., with Queenstown advices by telegraph to the 22d, arrived at Halifax last evening. Among other matters thus received, we learn that no decision had been rendered by DOWLING, the referee in the late contest for the Championship; but that in answer to the statement of that person, to the effect that the Americans had interposed and con  strained him to terminate the fight, GEO. WILKES ...
lead_paragraph: The steamship Canada, from Liverpool on the 21st ult., with Queenstown advices by telegraph to the 22d, arrived at Halifax last evening. Among other matters thus received, we learn that no decision had been rendered by DOWLING, the referee in the late contest for the Championship; but that in answer to the statement of that person, to the effect that the Americans had interposed and con strained him to terminate the fight, GEO. WILKES had addressed a letter to the London Times, denying the statement broadly, and claiming the belt for the American Champion. Both combatants epuciate the idea of the battle being drawn, and assert their wish for a fresh encounter. Large sums of money have been contributed on the London and Liverpool Stock Exchanges and elsewhere for the benefit of SAYERS. In a contest between the American LYNCH, and the Englishman SHAW, for the Championship of the "Light Weights," the latter had been victorious. Parliamentary proceedings lacked interest. The command of the Great Eastern had been assigned to Capt. VINEHALL, of the Peninsular and Oriental Company's service. The Count DE MONTEMOLEN, we learn from Spain, with his son and his secretary, had been arrested. The report that the Emperor of France will visit Savoy this Summer is confirmed.

abstract: The letters of our correspondents in Utah, published yesterday, present an interesting picture of the existing state of things in Mormondom. The figure which the United States cut in the affairs of the Territory, is a mixture ...
lead_paragraph: The letters of our correspondents in Utah, published yesterday, present an interesting picture of the existing state of things in Mormondom. The figure which the United States cut in the affairs of the Territory, is a mixture of the comical and the absurd, which if it could be well put on the boards of a popular theatre, would make the fortune of the enterprising manager. We sent an army out, two years ago, to reduce the Mormons to subjection enforce our laws, and make our Courts respected. It has been so far successful in its mission as to put an end to all open rebellion; but there is no other mode of setting Governments at defiance, in which our fellow-citizens of that region do not still indulge. Not that the presence of the army is disagreeable to them; they are, on the contrary, so anxious to have it stay that a careless observer might come to the conclusion that they were penitent sinners, kissing the rod which has been the instrument of their chastisement and salvation. Their devotion to the ministers of our will is, however, due neither to loyalty nor to fear, but to that common-place instinct which makes every man who has cabbages for sale glad to find a purchaser. The camp is a good market for vegetables and forage; the profits of the Mormon farmers on the sales of these articles to the troops are said to reach half a million of dollars per annum; and under the circumstances they are, as our correspondent naively informs us, "very desirous the army should remain."

abstract: CONVICTED OF CARRYING A SLUNG-SHOT. � JAS. MCCLOSKEY. who is proprietor of a liquor saloon in Ferry-place, South Brooklyn, was convicted in the Court of Sessions, yesterday, of carrying a slung-shot. At an early hour on the morning of Nov. 8 last he was found by Officer OAKES, of the Third Precinct Police, making a disturbance at the door of a house in Carroll-street, and, upon being remonstrated with, he attempted to strike the officer with the weapon indicated. He was sentenced to be imprisoned one year in the State Prison at Sing Sing.
lead_paragraph: CONVICTED OF CARRYING A SLUNG-SHOT. � JAS. MCCLOSKEY. who is proprietor of a liquor saloon in Ferry-place, South Brooklyn, was convicted in the Court of Sessions, yesterday, of carrying a slung-shot. At an early hour on the morning of Nov. 8 last he was found by Officer OAKES, of the Third Precinct Police, making a disturbance at the door of a house in Carroll-street, and, upon being remonstrated with, he attempted to strike the officer with the weapon indicated. He was sentenced to be imprisoned one year in the State Prison at Sing Sing.

abstract: The vicissitudes of human affairs were never more signally illustrated than by the short and brilliant episode in the career of "His Honor the Mayor," which commenced on the first Tuesday in last December, and has now terminated on board the new and powerful steamship James Adger, bound for this port, with "His Honor" and a large cargo of fruit and vegetables on board.
lead_paragraph: The vicissitudes of human affairs were never more signally illustrated than by the short and brilliant episode in the career of "His Honor the Mayor," which commenced on the first Tuesday in last December, and has now terminated on board the new and powerful steamship James Adger, bound for this port, with "His Honor" and a large cargo of fruit and vegetables on board. The Hundred Days which ended with the sunset of Waterloo contain nothing half so exciting, and nothing which places the vanity of earthly honors in such marked relief. Our readers may all remember the shaky condition in which the Union found itself last November -- what a gulf yawned at our feet, when FERNANDO WOOD and his 30,000 men marched up and snatched us from its dangerous brink. They may remember that "His Honor" frequently expressed the opinion that our only chance of salvation lay in choosing him for Mayor -- that the South had set its heart on seeing him placed in that dignified position -- and that our choosing him without further demur was the only indication of love for our "common country" which they would for one moment accept as genuine.

abstract: MICHAEL LAZARUS, a middle-aged German, residing at No. 5 Ridge-street, died very suddenly about a month since, as was supposed at the time of cholera morbus. The undue haste with which the body was interred, and other singular circumstances attending the matter, excited the suspicions of the friends of the deceased that he had been poisoned, and they applied to the authorities for permission to exhume the remains. Accordingly the body was disinterred, and the stomach and intestines were removed by Dr. ZINKER, who has subjected them to a thorough analysis, which has, we understand, resulted in the discovery of quantities of arsenic. No persons have as yet been arrested on the charge of having administered the poison, but certain parties are suspected, and the Police have them under surveillance. Coroner SCHIRMER is to commence an investigation of the case at the Eighteenth Ward Station-house, at 8 o'clock this morning.

abstract: A regular annual meeting of the Society was held last evening, Vice President GEORGE FOLSOM in the Chair. From the annual reports presented, it appeared that the resources of the Society during the year, including balance on hand, were $2,179.79; expenses, $2,001.40. Two thousand volumes have been added to the Society during the year, besides a valuable collection of maps, pamphlets and statistics.
lead_paragraph: A regular annual meeting of the Society was held last evening, Vice President GEORGE FOLSOM in the Chair. From the annual reports presented, it appeared that the resources of the Society during the year, including balance on hand, were $2,179.79; expenses, $2,001.40. Two thousand volumes have been added to the Society during the year, besides a valuable collection of maps, pamphlets and statistics. The paper of the evenig was read by HENRY B. MILLANO, M.D. He estimated that nearly one-sixth of the deaths among the human race occur from consumpion. From statistics extending over a considerable period, he found that one death in every 5 7-10 occured from consumption. In New-York, from 1804 to 1820, one death in every 4 3-10 was caused by consumption; from 1820 to 1835, one in 5 4-10; from 1835 to 1850, are is 6 5-10; 1-13 to 1859, one in 8 46 1[???]; in Brooklyn, 1848 to 18[???], one in 8 11 100. Of leather in the army, be found that the greatest number of cases of consumption was from 6 9-10; to 3 2-10 annually for every thousand men, between latitudes 26° and 25° characterised by high temperature, copious rains and, excessive moisture. The smallest number of deaths was 1 3-10 per thousand men in New-Mexico, characterized by high land and dry atmosphere. While consumption is rare in countries of high latitudes, it is curious that in tropical countries the proportion of deaths is often too small to be calculated. In all Judea, in forty-three years only 29 died of consumation. The theory that the sea air may prevent, as welt as cure, consumption, is supported by statistics. In the British army out of 14,590 men, 51 died of censumsion; while out of 12,512 men is the navy only 19 died of that disease. Consumption is not necessarily more prevalent in large than in small cities. Among the trades and professions, the folllowing order of mortality by consumption was mentioned: The greatest was among tailors, shoemakers; next came blacksmiths, gardeners, bakers, butchers and lawyers. The mortality among tailors being four times that of the lawyers. The greatest mortality by consumption among males is said to be in the city. There is greater liability to consumption between the twentieth and thirtieth years of age than at any other period of life. The general conclusion was that humidity of the atmosphere is favorable and dryness unfavorable to the generation of the disease, but moist salt water is not calculated for its development. Want of exercise, and air, tend to produce it; lack of light does not. It is more prevalent among females than among males. There are no reasons for the conclusion that the disease is either on the increase or decrease.

abstract: The Charleston Convention has abandoned the attempt to nominate a Democratic candidate for the Presidency. The failure is due partly to the disorganized condition of the party, and partly to the blind blundering of the Convention itself. The contest between the two sections of the Union has at last penetrated the Democratic Party, and rendered it impossible for the two wings to agree upon a declaration of principles.
lead_paragraph: The Charleston Convention has abandoned the attempt to nominate a Democratic candidate for the Presidency. The failure is due partly to the disorganized condition of the party, and partly to the blind blundering of the Convention itself. The contest between the two sections of the Union has at last penetrated the Democratic Party, and rendered it impossible for the two wings to agree upon a declaration of principles. When the majority adopted its platform the minority seceded. Thereupon the delegates who remained, and who constituted the rightful Convention, resolved that a vote of two-thirds, not of the actual body, but of the whole original number, should be essential to a nomination. In other words, the seceders were still to be counted, and to have all their original weight as members of the Convention! Upon what ground of reason or of common sense, the majority, and especially the delegates from this State, thus put themselves, bound hand and foot, into the power of the seceding minority, it is not easy to conjecture. The result was to give the South the victory. They have controlled the Convention, and prevented the nomination of any candidate. Whether, on reassembling at Baltimore, they will harmonize their differences, remains to be seen.

abstract: The Inaugural Message of Gov. BUCKINGHAM, on resuming the gubernatorial chair of Connecticut for another term, was delivered on the 2d instant. The Governor reports a balace of $15,000 in the State  Treasury, with an aggregate indebtedness of $434,142.
lead_paragraph: The Inaugural Message of Gov. BUCKINGHAM, on resuming the gubernatorial chair of Connecticut for another term, was delivered on the 2d instant. The Governor reports a balace of $15,000 in the State Treasury, with an aggregate indebtedness of $434,142. The State Prison management has been such as to secure a net profit of $1,667 during the past year. The treasury of the State Reform School also shows a balance of some hundreds of dollars in favor of the State. The State Normal School has 231 pupils. The number of school districts in the State is 1,638. and there are 1,785 schools, employing 1,950 teachers. The Message recommends the passage of a Registry law, and a regulation requiring electors to read before voting. It is also recommended that additional laws be passed for the protection of property. Caution in the exercise of the pardoning power is likewise recommended. In relation to the disputed boundary between Connecticut and New-York, the Governor concurs in the recommendation of the Connecticut Commissioners, that a proposition be made to the State of New-York that each State appoint an arbitrator, and that the two appoint a third, neither of whom shall be a resident of either State, and that the joint Commissioners present the surveys and facts connected with the subject to the consideration of said arbitrators; that they, or two of them, shall recommend such a line as may to them appear just and proper to be established as the boundary between the two States.

abstract: The enlargement of the circulation of the TIMES is at the present moment so rapid as to render it imperative that advertisements intended for the daily issue should be sent in at the earliest possible moment. Announcements which fail to reach the office before nine o'clock P.M., lose all the advantages of classification under the heads to which readers are accustomed to refer. It is, therefore, quite as important to the advertisers as to ourselves, to have that hour the latest for the reception of their notices.

abstract: BAPTIST MARINERS' SOCIETY. The earliest of the May anniversaries was held last evening in Dr. GILLETTE'S church, known as Calvary Church, in Twenty-third street, it being the third annual celebration of the American Baptist Mariners' Society. The audience was quite small, not more than one hundred persons being present.
lead_paragraph: BAPTIST MARINERS' SOCIETY. -- The earliest of the May anniversaries was held last evening in Dr. GILLETTE'S church, known as Calvary Church, in Twenty-third street, it being the third annual celebration of the American Baptist Mariners' Society. The audience was quite small, not more than one hundred persons being present. The Chair was occupied by PETER BALEN, Esq., the President of the Society. After prayer by Rev. Dr. GILLKTTE, and reading of Scripture by Rev. J.R. STEWARD, the Secretary, Capt. FRISBIE read his report. Though the funds of the Society were of small amount, its success during the past year had been very great. In the Baptist Mariners' Church of this City three sermons were preached every Sunday, the services being attended by about 500 seamen while the average attendance on week days was 60 seamen. During the year 233,356 pages of tracts had been distributed, besides 120,151 religious books and papers. The Society were benefiting seamen belonging to thirty different nations, and especially in Sweden were its labors valuable. Dr. MULTERSVAND had sent very cheering reports to this country. He had suffered much persecution, and had been driven from his post of duty by ruffians, but he had persevered in his endeavors to convert souls, and had fought the good fight, What the Society needed were more colporteurs, more missionaries of those already employed, and more money to sustain them. After an original hymn, commencing "The way of God is on the sea," had been sung, the meeting was addressed by Rev. Dr. HISCOX, of the Stanton-street Baptist Church. Rev. A.H. BURLINGHAM, of the Twenty-fifth-street Church, Rev JOSEPH STOCKBRIDGE, Chaplain of the Navy-yard, and Rev. J.R. STEWARD. A collection was taken up, and the audience separated. This is a new Society, but its prospects are considered by its members and friends to be very cheering.

abstract: The Conference of the Methodist Church North has just commenced its session, with no little state and ceremony, at the City of Buffalo. Almost at the moment when its proceedings was opening with all due solemnity, a young man, one of the ministers whom this body had commissioned to preach the truths and to practice the life of Christianity among the people, was standing in the felon's dock to hear the last stern sentence of the law pronounced upon himself for the crime of murdering his own wife.

abstract: A correspondent writing to the NEW-YORK TIMES, a few weeks since, from the West Coast of Africa, details some startling facts. They are startling only to people away from the West Coast; are not at all so to me, for I am assured of their truth by personal observation and general experience on the so called "Slave Coast." The writer has stated truth, but not the whole truth. I have some additional suggestions to make that may be of value.

abstract: We publish a letter in another column concerning the West Washington Market controversy. The writer commends the TIMES for its "Vigorous exposure and denunciation of public abuses," but protests vehemently against our advice that the City should compromise the State claim to certain lands in its possession, and to back rents for their use, instead of contesting it further in the Courts of law.
lead_paragraph: We publish a letter in another column concerning the West Washington Market controversy. The writer commends the TIMES for its "Vigorous exposure and denunciation of public abuses," -- but protests vehemently against our advice that the City should compromise the State claim to certain lands in its possession, and to back rents for their use, instead of contesting it further in the Courts of law. "Civis" desires to protect the City against enormous losses. So do we. He proposes one way of doing it, and we propose another. We believe ours to be the best: -- but we submit his to the public judgment, and advise our readers carefully to examine both, and judge between them.

abstract: -- A number of youths are in durance at Washington, to answer for having disturbed religious worship in the churches of the capital. Their favorite occupation, for several Sundays, has been an effort to break up the services by throwing stones and lumps of ice through the church windows; and it is added, as "a singular fact," that the offenders come from families of the highest respectability. Respect for the parents has caused the church officers to refrain from prosecution until the evil has become too serious to be longer winked at. The only wonder is, that these errant young gentlemen have contented themselves with pummeling the windows of a church: had they aped Congressional manners to the fullest extent, each would have dirked or killed a man or two. They have failed to profit as they might have done by the brilliant examples daily set them.

abstract: For the present the curtain has fallen upon the proceedings of the National Democratic Convention. Yesterday morning, as soon as the Conven  tion had reassembled, Mr. RUSSELL, of Virginia offered a resolution that it adjourn to meet at Baltimore on June 18th, in order to afford States which were not represented an opportunity to fill up their delegations.
lead_paragraph: For the present the curtain has fallen upon the proceedings of the National Democratic Convention. Yesterday morning, as soon as the Conven tion had reassembled, Mr. RUSSELL, of Virginia offered a resolution that it adjourn to meet at Baltimore on June 18th, in order to afford States which were not represented an opportunity to fill up their delegations. A point of order was raised that action could not then be taken on the resolution but this was overruled by the Chair, and a motion to suspend the order to ballot was carried by yeas 199, nays 51. Various amendments were proposed by the opponents of the resolution to adjourn, but it was finally carried by 195 ayes to 55 nays. Gen. CUSHING then addressed the delegates, lauding them for the mutual forbearance they have displayed, and asking the pardon of those whom he might have offended by hasty expressions extorted by the exciting scenes through which they had passed. Immediately after the adjournment the wearied delegates took their departure for home. The seceders assembled at noon, about forty delegates being present. After a brief debate on the subject, Mr. JACKSON withdrew his resolution declaring it expedient for the Convention to express its preference for candidates for President and Vice-President. A motion was then made by Mr. BURROWS, of Arkansas, to appoint a Standing Committee to prepare and issue an address to the Democrats of the Union. This, too, was soon withdrawn, and a discussion sprang up as to whether the seceders, by the course they had taken, meant it to be understood that they were willing to dissolve the Union. Among others, Mr. HILL, of Georgia, utterly repudiated any such intention. Mr. YANCEY was drawn out by this denial and a sharp colloquy ensued. After a protracted debate in which speculations were freely indulged regarding the probable action of the National Convention, the Seceders adjourned without making any nomination.

abstract: No new facts were elicited by Justice WELSH, yesterday, in the case of Daniel Lewis, charged with having caused the death of Wm.H. Lyons, an Adams Express driver. abstract: Two female corpses have recently been found floating in the decks of New-York within a single week. One of them was at once buried out of sight, under the highly Bunsbyan verdict of "found drowned;" the other, having been once identified in the most emphatic terms as the body of a certain Mrs. RICHARDSON, by several persons who had lived in the most intimate relations with the unfortunate woman upon whose mutilated remains they believed themselves to be looking, seems now about to be rejected again into the chaos of the anonymous dead, by evidence going to prove that Mrs. RICHARDSON is now or was very lately alive and well in the City of New-Orleans. As an instance of mistaken identification, this of Mrs. RICHARDSON, should it prove to belong to that category, will be hardly less curious than the celebrated case of MARTIN GUERRE, in which a man's wife, sisters and nearest friends positively recognized an imposter as their relative, lived with him for years in their native village, maintained his identity in a trial at law, and were only convinced of their error when the original MARTIN GUERRE himself walked into the Court and confronted his deceptive "double." But however interesting to the philosophical student of criminal law it may be to find that so little reliance is to be placed even on the direct evidence of a woman's husband and lover as to her personal identity, the dropping down again of the veil of absolute mystery, which had for a moment been supposed to be lifted from this case, will hardly tend to allay the general alarm and anxiety which has been excited in New-York by the discovery that human beings can be thrown into our docks and moored there to barrels of pitch, stolen from the wharf for that purpose, with really less danger of interruption from watchmen or detection by the Police, than would attend the unlawful dumping of a load of ashes into the East River.

But however interesting to the philosophical student of criminal law it may be to find that so little reliance is to be placed even on the direct evidence of a woman's husband and lover as to her personal identity, the dropping down again of the veil of absolute mystery, which had for a moment been supposed to be lifted from this case, will hardly tend to allay the general alarm and anxiety which has been excited in New-York by the discovery that human beings can be thrown into our docks and moored there to barrels of pitch, stolen from the wharf for that purpose, with really less danger of interruption from watchmen or detection by the Police, than would attend the unlawful dumping of a load of ashes into the East River.

abstract: A CONSTABLE CONVICTED OF ASSAULT AND BATTERY. � Constable MICHAEL SLATTERY of the Seventh Ward, was convicted in the Court of Sessions yesterday upon an indictment for assault and battery, committed upon the person of a woman named BRAINARD. SLATTERY had a warrant against JOHN BRAINARD, and after calling at his house several times and being told each time that "he was not in," one night late resolved to satisfy himself of the truth of these statements. Miss BRAINARD came to the door in answer to his call, and denied that the person was in the house that, the officer was seeking. He pushed his way into the house and was resisted by Mrs. and Miss BRAINARD, but he found the man he was after. Miss B. swore that SLATTERY knocked her down and dragged her by the hair of the head, and when Mrs. B. interfered she was treated in a similar manner. He also took Miss B. to the Station house and locked her up, leaving Mrs. B. alone in the house bleeding and in an insensible condition. There is another complaint against the same party for false imprisonment.
