abstract: Coroner SCHIRMER yesterday investigated the circumstances attending the death of LAZARUS MICHAELS, supposed by his friends to have been poisoned. The evidence showed that the deceased had been in a state of great despondency for some time previous to his death, in consequence of his failure to obtain ...
lead_paragraph: Coroner SCHIRMER yesterday investigated the circumstances attending the death of LAZARUS MICHAELS, supposed by his friends to have been poisoned. The evidence showed that the deceased had been in a state of great despondency for some time previous to his death, in consequence of his failure to obtain employment; that he had expressed his fears to an acquaintance that he might be expelled from a benevolent society to which he belonged, because of his inability to pay his dues, adding at the same time that he would destroy himself were it not for the helpless state in which his wife and children would be left. The day he died this acquaintance again saw him, and he refused to tell what had caused his illness. Dr. ZENKER, who analyzed the contents of the stomach of deceased, deposed to finding arsenious acid and the yellow sulphuret of arsenic, in sufficient quantity to cause death. The jury rendered a verdict that MICHAELS died from the effect of arsenic taken intentionally.

abstract: JAPANES[???] EMBASSY. � The Uni[???]ed States Naval Commissioner, charged with the care of the Japanese Embassy, by the President, have engaged for their occupancy, while sojourning in the Federal Metropolis, a suite of about sixty rooms at Willards' Hotel. The Messrs. WILLARD are now busily engaged in fitting them up for their reception, their mode of living being in many respects essentially different from that of American or European travelers. Their reception here will, no doubt, be one of the most interesting occasions ever witnessed. The magnificent iron steamer Philadelphia, Capt. WM. SMITH, belonging to the Norfolk and Seaford Company, out at present under control of Commodore MATTINGLY, of the Washington and Richmond route, has been chartered to convey the Embassy from Norfolk to Washington. It is stated that they will land with military honors at the Washington Arsenal, where preparations are now progressing to give them a proper reception on their landing. All the Government troops now here, in cluding a battalion of marines and the ordnance men at the Arsenal, as well as the Washington Light Infantry, and probably several other District volunteer corps. will form a portion of the escort. It is understood that unless the Roanoke should be intercepted by some Government vessels, bearing contrary orders, she will proceed to New-York, as heretofore indicated, but where orders await her to pro[???]eed immediately to Norfolk. The Philadelphia will be there in readiness to receive the Embassy. It is but fair to state that the coutracts for their transportation and accommodation, evince a liberal spirit on the part of our enterprising citizens, the Messrs. WILLARD, and the managers of the Philadelphia, � States and Union, May 5.

abstract: When the opposition members of the French Corps Legislatif undertook to deal with the Pope's remonstrances against the annexation of the Emilia to the Italian Kingdom as a practical matter of pressing political importance, Baron DUPIN cut them short with the sarcastic and expressive statement that in his opinion "Providence had passed to the order of the day." The Emilia had decided its own destinies; the question of the Papal suzerainty had been settled by the specific argument of facts, and it was hardly worth while to discuss, in the French Assembly or elsewhere, the merits of a step already taken by the only people competent to say whether it ought or ought not to be made.

abstract: A steamer has come in from Palermo just in time to allow of my giving the reports of two consuls. They say that the city was quiet; the shops not open; and they write, on the 12th, the insurgents were in  occupation of all the neighboring places except Monreale. Engagements occurred daily, in which losses were incurred on either side. The troops were expecting reinforcements, when they could advance, but not till then.

abstract: The enlargement of the circulation of the TIMES is at the present moment so rapid as to render it imperative that advertisements intended for the daily issue should be sent in at the earliest possible moment. Announcements which fail to reach the office before nine o'clock P.M., lose all the advantages of classification under the heads to which readers are accustomed to refer. It is, therefore, quite as important to the advertisers as to ourselves, to have that hour the latest for the reception of their notices.

abstract: One of the most brilliant houses of the season witnessed the third performance of "La Juive," last evening, at the Winter Garden. The spontaneous and discriminating applause which was bestowed on the various morceaux shows that the opera is already enjoyed by the public. When it becomes better known there cannot be a doubt that it will be one of the most popular in the repertoire.

abstract: PERILS OF THE GREAT EASTERN. � We had hoped that the management of the Great Eastern had undergone a thorough and radical reform, and that a brighter day was dawning upon this unfortunate ship. We find, however, that the Directors are back again at their old follies. They have actually applied to the Common Council of New-York for information as to the capacity of the harbor, and upon the motion of the celebrated and indefatigable BOOLE, in whom all foreigners find so fast a friend, a "Committee" has been appointed to supply the necessary facts. Unless the Chamber of Commerce or the Pilot Commissioners interfere, we greatly fear the result of all this will be the stranding of the huge vessel upon some portion of the bay, and her final disposal at auction as old iron. The knowledge of the harbor possessed by the Common Council is limited to that portion of it which lies between the Battery and Randall's Island, and has been acquired by numerous excursions, and divers personal explorations of the bottom performed in moments of high-wrought convivial enthusiasm. Nobody but the men who made the leviathan the laughing-stock of the world last Spring would think of navigating her upon data furnished by the BOOLKS and BAGLEYS of the City Hall.
lead_paragraph: PERILS OF THE GREAT EASTERN. � We had hoped that the management of the Great Eastern had undergone a thorough and radical reform, and that a brighter day was dawning upon this unfortunate ship. Unless the Chamber of Commerce or the Pilot Commissioners interfere, we greatly fear the result of all this will be the stranding of the huge vessel upon some portion of the bay, and her final disposal at auction as old iron. The knowledge of the harbor possessed by the Common Council is limited to that portion of it which lies between the Battery and Randall's Island, and has been acquired by numerous excursions, and divers personal explorations of the bottom performed in moments of high-wrought convivial enthusiasm. Nobody but the men who made the leviathan the laughing-stock of the world last Spring would think of navigating her upon data furnished by the BOOLKS and BAGLEYS of the City Hall.

abstract: The Paris correspondent of the Times says; "It is generally believed that the Prince of Monaco has refused to barter his principality with the Emperor LOUIS NAPOLEON for a seat in the Senate and an annual income of [???].200,000 Rentes, which are said to have been offered to him as the price of the annexation to France. The Prince, unlike VICTOR EMANUEL, will not part with the cradle of his family, and will remain an independent sovereign. Roquebrune and Mentone, which separated from Monaco after the Revolution of 1848, are to be annexed to France by virtue of the treaty between VICTOR EMANUEL and LOUIS NAPOLEON."

abstract: CARELESS BLASTING. � Yesterday morning somemen engaged in blasting rock at the Bergen Cut, at tended to their business in so careless a manner that a portion of the rock was thrown a distance of 300 feet, going through the roof of the house of BENJAMIN MILLS, breaking one of the rafters and endangering the lives of the inmates. A storehouse adjoining was also greatly injured by the falling rocks. A complaint was made before Justice BEDFORD, of Jersey City, and JOHN MULLIN, the contractor for the work, and CHARLES MCNEAR, the foreman, were arrested and held to bail to await the action of the Grand Jury.
lead_paragraph: CARELESS BLASTING. � Yesterday morning somemen engaged in blasting rock at the Bergen Cut, at tended to their business in so careless a manner that a portion of the rock was thrown a distance of 300 feet, going through the roof of the house of BENJAMIN MILLS, breaking one of the rafters and endangering the lives of the inmates. abstract: HUDSON COUNTY COURT. ï¿½ The Grand Inquest of Hudson County completed its labors yesterday morning and brought in ten bills of indictment. Soon after 12 o'clock the following persons were arraigned and made their pleas as follows: JULIUS SCHOFER, guilty to a charge of grand larceny in stealing goods and money from his employer, JOHN HOPPER, of Hoboken; JAMES WILLIAMSON, not guilty of passing counterfeit money; JOHN RODMAN, same offence, not guilty. The Court then adjourned to Monday next. The criminal business will be taken up about the middle of next week.
lead_paragraph: HUDSON COUNTY COURT. � The Grand Inquest of Hudson County completed its labors yesterday morning and brought in ten bills of indictment. The Court then adjourned to Monday next. The criminal business will be taken up about the middle of next week.

abstract: The New-Orleans Picayune reports the trial of Ramon Martinez, keeper of a coffee-house, by a jury of slaveholders, on two separate charges of selling liquor to slaves. It was shown by the evidence that negroes were admitted into a back room, and by an ingenious contrivance, as soon as any one came into the coffee-house, a bell was rung, the alarm given, and the darkies let out by a back door. The jary found a verdict of guilty in both cases, and sentenced the accused to the forfeiture of his license, and $500 fine in each case.
lead_paragraph: The New-Orleans Picayune reports the trial of Ramon Martinez, keeper of a coffee-house, by a jury of slaveholders, on two separate charges of selling liquor to slaves. It was shown by the evidence that negroes were admitted into a back room, and by an ingenious contrivance, as soon as any one came into the coffee-house, a bell was rung, the alarm given, and the darkies let out by a back door. The jary found a verdict of guilty in both cases, and sentenced the accused to the forfeiture of his license, and $500 fine in each case.

abstract: A short time since, a young man named Lewis H. Lawson was arrested on a charge of burglary, and one Mr. Wilcox presented himself at the District-Attorney's office, and offered to become his surety, stating that he owned five lots of ground in Ninety-sixthstreet, worth $6,500, which was unincumbered.
lead_paragraph: A short time since, a young man named Lewis H. Lawson was arrested on a charge of burglary, and one Mr. Wilcox presented himself at the District-Attorney's office, and offered to become his surety, stating that he owned five lots of ground in Ninety-sixthstreet, worth $6,500, which was unincumbered. He asserted also that he had bought the property in question from one Roberts alias Lawson, a resident of Chicago. III., through Charles G. Thompson, a broker at No.95 Nassau-street, and at the same time produced the deed. The clerk, Mr. H.W. Allen, was not satisfied with these representations, and Mr. Wilcox went away, promising to return with proof of their correctness, Meantime, two gentlemen named Van Heuvel, who own a great deal of real estate up-town, appeared before the District-Attorney and complained that several of their lots had been fraudulently transferred by some unknown persons, and an examination showed that the identical land which Wilcox had stated belonged to him was part of that which the Messrs. Van Heuvel claimed. It subsequently transpired that Thomas Lawson, a man employed as copyist in the law office of Ex-Senator Westcott, in Clinton-place, had been engaged, it is alleged, in forging deeds, transferring up-town lots to which he had not the shadow of claim to persons who have not yet made themselves known. Lawson was arrested at his residence in Clinton-street, by Detectives Hampson and Devoe, and an examination of the charge against him was yesterday had before Justice WELSH. It is believed that the accused has forged deeds, transferring property to the value of $100,000, and in the progress of the investigation a deed, dated Jan. 3, 1860, was produced which purported to dispose of 57 of the Messrs. Van Heuvel's up-town lots for the sum of $55,000, to Ephraim R. Roberts, alias Lawson, by David S. Pike and Henry W. Morris � the two last-named individuals existing, it is believed, only in the imagination of the prisoner, Thomas Lawson. It was shown at the examination which took place before Justice WELSH, that Lawson, under the name of Roberts, gave a deed for a lot in Ninety-fourth-street, near Ninth-avenue, to one James M. Aldon for $500. The deed was dated Feb 29, 1860, and was acknowledged before Henry Farrington, Notary Public. Mr. Wm. H. Stansbury deposed that Lawson, on the 20th ult., accompanied by two other men, ca[???] to his office, and by making the prescribed affidavit induced him to write an acknowledgment or deed purporting to be from Ephraim R. Roberts to Smith Wilson, to which Lawson signed the name of the grantor. Three similar transactions were testified to by Henry Farrington, a Commissioner of Deeds, as having occurred during last February between the accused and himself. On the strength of these affidavits Lawson was committed for trial, to answer four separate charges of forgery. In consequence of other developments which were elicited during the progress of the examination, the magistrate issued warrants for the arrest of Charles G. Thompson, and his son Charles P. Thompson, brokers, lately having an office at No. 85 Nassau-street, who are alleged to be implicated in the forgeries, and the young man was arrested last evening, and committed pending an examination.

abstract: Three parts of this work have appeared since we first called attention to it, in which Mr. CASSELL'S promises, both as to the letter-press and engravings, are entirely fulfilled. Each part contains, on an average, fourteen large engravings, each nearly filling a page, and double that number of smaller ones; the drawing of which is not simply good, but of a rare degree of excellence. They are all executed by the best artists in England and France, and are certainly such as rarely, if ever, appear in so low priced a work as the Illustrated Bible. The print is large enough and clear enough for the oldest and weakest eyes, and the marginal references, commentary and footnotes are copious and carefully prepared. Nobody who is in want of a family bible is ever likely to have an opportunity of procuring one in which so much beauty is combined with so much use at so low a price, so good as Mr. CASSELL now offers to the public. The work will be completed in forty-eight parts of 32 pages each, and costing only fifteen cents, so that the volume will not cost over eight dollars.

abstract: That resolution appointing a committee of two of the Common Countil to take a Summer trip, in company with "a savant," under pretence of discovering the best method of making New-York healthy, has, we see, been referred to the Committee on Arts and Sciences. If the "art" of swindling be amongst the arts of which this latter body takes cognizance, we think we know how this little scheme will be disposed of. It is so barefaced that, if it succeeds, we should not be at all surprised if Mr. BOOLE moved for the appointment of a standing committee on the philosopher's stone, with power to travel through all the mineral districts of the globe, and draw, ad libitum, on the Comptroller until the article in question was discovered and fully tested.

abstract: The Springfield Republican, of the 26th, tells of the following curious freaks played by electricity: "About 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, during the heavy snow-squall prevailing at the time, a singular phenomenon was observed at the telegraph-office in this city. A strange ticking noise was heard coming from the 'switen,' where most of the wires running through the office are connected. The sound was loud and similar to that produced by steam raising the lid of a kettle of boiling water, in escaping. The operator commenced 'testing' the various wires, and found that the noise proceeded from a wire that was 'open' or disconnected in the Springfield office, and running only to Hartford, where it was also open. From this wire the operator received a shack that completely paralyzed his arm, and at the same time a spark of intense brilliancy was emitted from the end of one of fiugers. This noise and the heavy current upon the wire disappeared simultaneously with the squall. There was nothing about the switch that could have vibrated so as to produce the sound, and even if there had been, electricity was never before known to make such a noise under like circumstances. Upon calling the attention of the Hartford operator to the fact, [???]e tested, and reported similarly, adding that there must be something peculiar about that wire, for his arm was nearly broken."

abstract: A letter from Brownsville, Texas, to the New-Orleans Delta, is going the rounds of the public journals, concerning matters on the Mexican frontiers. It was copied into the TIMES of the 1st, on the 3d made its appearance in the Herald as an original letter from Matamoras, and turns up in so many quarters and shapes as to suggest the suspicion that it has been put into circulation with some specific purpose.

abstract: In our report yesterday of the proceedings of the Methodist General Conference at Buffalo, it was stated that a Committee on Slavery had been appointed, consisting of one member from each delegation. As this Committee will have under consideration the most important question likely to come before the Conference, it may be well to give a view of the relation of the Methodist Church, North, to the entire subject. We conceive this to be the more important from the fact that the controversy now rife in this great denomination is erroneously supposed by many to be precisely parallel with the contest waging between North and South in the field of politics.

abstract: The Globe states that the rival combatants, SAYERS and HEENAN, have left town, and that, accompanied by their friends, they will meet at Epsom, and discuss the question of the renewal of the fight. "The referee has advised them to make it a 'drawn battle;' and he is inclined to believe that they will act on his advice; but he will not make any formal decision this week. Neither SAYERS nor HEENAN is so much 'punished' as the first reports in the papers induced the public to believe."

abstract: Mr. WENDELL PHILLIPS, in his lecture on the "Lost Arts," essays to prove that our modern knowledge of science and art is but a revival of the wisdom of Egypt, and only a partial revival at that. He argues that the builders of the Pyramids knew many great secrets that yet remain sealed to this generation, which vaunts itself so boldly upon its superior genius; demonstrates that an Egyptian color-mixer produced enduring tints which Paris cannot equal: that the [???]ie Canal was foreshadowed by a smaller ditch that tapped the Nile; that railroads are as old as Thebes; and, in short, that Egypt originated and we imitate. A curious illustration of Mr. PHILLIPS' theory is to be found in Dr. F[???]UCHTWANGER'S book on the History of Gems. According to the wise orator, everything the nineteenth century owns is thousands of years old, and according to the learned Doctor, as the earliest mention of precious stones is in the Bible, so we find that "the Hebrews borrowed the names of their gems from the Egyptians." Accepting these authorities, each being excellent in his way, it is clearly impossible to avoid a candid admission that the Pyramid-men knew almost everything, and that the becoming attitude of the moderns is one of profound humility. We are certain of but two original inventions of this century � a New-York Common Council and a New-York daily newspaper: for we take leave to doubt if even Mr. PHILLIPS will contend that Thebes was cursed by the prototype of the former, or blessed with the enterprise of the latter; and Dr. FXUCHTWAN[???] certainly will not controvert the proposition, for his business lies with Gems.
lead_paragraph: Mr. WENDELL PHILLIPS, in his lecture on the "Lost Arts," essays to prove that our modern knowledge of science and art is but a revival of the wisdom of Egypt, and only a partial revival at that. He argues that the builders of the Pyramids knew many great secrets that yet remain sealed to this generation, which vaunts itself so boldly upon its superior genius; demonstrates that an Egyptian color-mixer produced enduring tints which Paris cannot equal: that the [???]ie Canal was foreshadowed by a smaller ditch that tapped the Nile; that railroads are as old as Thebes; and, in short, that Egypt originated and we imitate. A curious illustration of Mr. PHILLIPS' theory is to be found in Dr. F[???]UCHTWANGER'S book on the History of Gems. According to the wise orator, everything the nineteenth century owns is thousands of years old, and according to the learned Doctor, as the earliest mention of precious stones is in the Bible, so we find that "the Hebrews borrowed the names of their gems from the Egyptians." Accepting these authorities, each being excellent in his way, it is clearly impossible to avoid a candid admission that the Pyramid-men knew almost everything, and that the becoming attitude of the moderns is one of profound humility. We are certain of but two original inventions of this century � a New-York Common Council and a New-York daily newspaper: for we take leave to doubt if even Mr. PHILLIPS will contend that Thebes was cursed by the prototype of the former, or blessed with the enterprise of the latter; and Dr. FXUCHTWAN[???] certainly will not controvert the proposition, for his business lies with Gems.

abstract: Here is a book admirably calculated to hit a universal passion. Everybody, except a very few preternaturally sensible persons, has a fondness more or less decided for personal gossip; even the chatter of common society about men and events is not without its attractions for most people.
lead_paragraph: Here is a book admirably calculated to hit a universal passion. Everybody, except a very few preternaturally sensible persons, has a fondness more or less decided for personal gossip; even the chatter of common society -- about men and events -- is not without its attractions for most people. of the greatest Philosopher of his age, a Minister of one of the leading European States, an intimate and favorite of a great King, nothing is lacking, certainly, which can stimulate the curiosity of the world at large. Whether that curiosity will be rewarded or not, is another question.

abstract: THE SLAVER CASE AND THE UNITED STATES MA[???]SHAL's DEPUTIES. � The conduct of two attaches of the United States Marshal's office, in permitting a suspected slaver to depart from this port on Wednesday afternoon, after information of her character had been laid at the United States Marshal's Office, will probably be investigated this morning before Judge SMALLEY, in the United States District Court. The brig Storm King cleared on Wednesday at the Custom house for the coast of Africa, and proceeded to sea in tow of the steam-tug Jacob Bell. Suspicions were excited that she was bound on a slave cruise, and one of the officers from the Custom-house gave information at the United States District Attorney's office. Here the officer was sent to hunt up Deputies JOSEPH THOMPSON and DONNELL, who were supposed to be on board of the Charlotte E. Tay, a suspected slaver at the foot of Tenth-street, as they alone were authorized, in the absence of the Marshal, to detain a vessel. Deputies THEODORE RYNDERS and HENRY MANN, went to Pier No, 10, but THOMPSON and DONNELL had left, and, without waiting to obtain the proper signature to the warrant of arrest, they set out in pursuit of the Storm King on board of the steam-tug Relief, and overtook the vessel going through the Narrows. Here they boarded the suspected orig, and a sharp altercation ensued, during which, it is said that pistols were drawn. A sudden turn of affairs, however, took place, for, after a brief conversation in the cabin, the Officers permitted the vessel to proceed. and, on returning to the City, reported to Mr. DWIGHT at his residence, that the Storm King could not be found. The facts coming out, the two attaches were suspended by Mr. THOMPSON, the acting Marshal, and the proper affidavits were yesterday, made for bringing the affair before the Court.

abstract: The mails by the steamship Canada, which arrived here last evening from Boston, bring interesting additions to the telegraphic abstract. The prize-fight, still engrossing public attention, provokes continued discussion in the London papers; the English party persisting in the claim of a victory for SAYERS. Testimonials of every possible description, with no end of money, sent to the English champion, attest the popular conviction of his success. In the House of Commons on the 19th inst., an interesting discussion upon the Continental relations of England was provoked by a motion and speech of Mr. HORSMAN. Lord JOHN RUSSELL took occasion to review the recent history of British diplomacy, justifying the scope and details of the commercial treaty; and while regreting the acquisition of Savoy, referring to the possible results of an approaching Conference to remedy any mischiefs the act might involve. From Naples, we have abundant evidence that revolt is a-foot throughout the rural districts of Sicily, while the royal troops are shut up in the towns, not daring to leave the shelter of the walls. Rumors were generally current, but not credited in proper quarters, that GARIBALDI was about to pass into Sicily to place himself at the head of the insurgents. In their present unorganized condition, they can hardly hope to make headway against the large forces which the Government are flinging into the island. Gen. LAMORICIERE is devoting himself assiduously to the development of the Papal army. He derives great assistance from Gen. GOYON, the French commander, who has also sold him a large quantity of munitions and material of war. It is thought the French troops will leave at an early day.

abstract: Another of those interminable ticket-swindling cases which invariably occur prior to the sailing of every California steamer, came up yesterday before the City Marshal. The victim was a Buffalo gentleman, who probably has not yet availed himself of the new facilities for getting early New-York papers via the Newspaper Express, consequently he met a confiding friend, who, in consideration of an instantaneous attachment, agreed to procure him a steerage passage in the Northern Light, notwithstanding that the regular office was closed. Greeny accepted the offer of his new-found friend, and had to pay $158 for a ticket worth $140. Of course he discovered the cheat too late to remedy the damage, and went to the Mayor's office for redress. The obliging Marshal took his affidavit, and informed him that if he would lose his passage and his $140 by remaining a week to prosecute the offender he might getback his $10. Buffalo thought that wouldn't pay well, and concluded to sail for California to-day ï¿½ an experienced if not a wiser man. Innocent people can't help thinking that the swindlers must be in league with the regular office, else how can they get genuine tickets to sell?
lead_paragraph: Another of those interminable ticket-swindling cases which invariably occur prior to the sailing of every California steamer, came up yesterday before the City Marshal. The victim was a Buffalo gentleman, who probably has not yet availed himself of the new facilities for getting early New-York papers via the Newspaper Express, consequently he met a confiding friend, who, in consideration of an instantaneous attachment, agreed to procure him a steerage passage in the Northern Light, notwithstanding that the regular office was closed. Greeny accepted the offer of his new-found friend, and had to pay $158 for a ticket worth $140. Of course he discovered the cheat too late to remedy the damage, and went to the Mayor's office for redress. The obliging Marshal took his affidavit, and informed him that if he would lose his passage and his $140 by remaining a week to prosecute the offender he might getback his $10. Buffalo thought that wouldn't pay well, and concluded to sail for California to-day � an experienced if not a wiser man. Innocent people can't help thinking that the swindlers must be in league with the regular office, else how can they get genuine tickets to sell?

abstract: The advent of a strange mission is near at hand. The Embassy from the Court of Yeddo is now probably at Panama, and may be expected to arrive off our harbor, to proceed thence to Washington, within the ensuing two weeks. It may be well to refer briefly to the history of our intercourse with this mysterious people, before we are called on to shake hands with them in the social circles of Washington and New-York.

abstract: THE TIMES FOR CALIFORNIA, designed for circulation in Spanish America, California, Oregon, Washington, British Columbia and the Sandwich Islands, and embracing a complete Digest of American Events and Events in Europe during the past fortnight, will be issued THIS (Saturday) MORNING, in ample time for the steamship Northern Light, which sails for Aspinwall at 12 M. The Mail closes at the Post-office at 10-1/2 A.M. Price of the paper, in a stout wrapper, ready for mailing, 5 cents a copy. Agents will send in their orders as early as possible.

abstract: At the stated meeting of the managers of the American Bible Society, held in the Bible House on Thursday, resolutions of respect to the memory of the late NAJAH TAYLOR, one of the members of the Board, were adopted. Seven new auxiliary societies were recognized, of which two are in Texas, and one each in Pennsylvania, Ohio, Illinois, Wisconsin, and Kansas. Letters were read from Rev. Mr. THOMPSON, Societies Agent for Mexico, informing of improved prospects for Bible distributions beyond the Rio Grande; from Rev. L.S. JACOBY BREMEN, giving a statement of expenditures on account of this Society, and of distributions of the Scriptures in Germany; from Rev. C.C. CARPENTER, Missionary on the coast of Labrador, asking a grant of Bibles for distribution there; from Wm. ROPES, Esq., Boston, inclosing a communication from St. Petersburg, proposing to this Society to print an edition of 20,000 copies of the R[???]val Esthonian Testament and Psalms; from Rev. Dr SCHAUFFLER, Constantinople, and Rev. Mr. BERGNE, Corresponding Secretary of the British and Foreign Bible Society, proposing a union of the two Societies for the revision of the Turkish Scriptures. Grants of books were made to the Galveston Bible Society, in Texas; to Mr. THOMPSON, for Sale and distribution in Mexico; to the Presbyterian Board of Publication; to the pittsburgh conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church; to Rev. C.C. CARPENTER, for distribution on the coast of Labrador; to the Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions; to the American Mission at Amoy. China; to Agent BLISS, for sale and distribution in Turkey; to J.S. P[???]IRSON Esq., for distribution in foreign ports by officers of vessels; besides many smaller grants. The receipts for April were $33,376 71; the issues, 58,493 volumes.

abstract: Gen. Paez has re[???]eived a letter from an intiuential gentleman in Caraccas requesting him to accept the recall of the Venezuelan Government. The writer says: "We want you, we want you to give us not that peace which follows in the train of victory, for that we already have, but that peace in our hearts and homes which can only be the result of brotherly conduct. Come to us, then, General, and bring with you that great 'olive branch' of which Venezuela is so greatly in need to-day, and which your arm alone has power to wield. All, all, will gladly accept it."

abstract: Of course our City Government would not be representative if it did not catch the moving mania from the people. Unlike most movers however, the City Inspector has found better quarters. With some new carpets, office-furniture, and a general cleaning, the place looks so well, that one would almost be willing to die, or have a birth in the family, or establish a nuisance, or do anything to have the fact recorded in such a nice office. The lack of ventilation, however, is in violation of all the rules of hygeine, and Mr. DOWNING, the Superintendent of Sanitary Inspection, is to have the sashes removed.

abstract: We have already referred to the importance of reforming our Patent Office, and to some of the vital and essential features of good and useful laws, which the present bill before Congress entirely ignores. abstract: CHURCH DEDICATION. -- The ceremony of dedicating the Third Reformed Dutch Church, which has just been erected at the corner of South Third and Erie streets, took place yesterday. The building is 62 feet front, 88 feet deep, built o brick, with brown-stone trimmings, in the Ionic style of Grecian architecture. The audience floor contains 138 pews, and the gallery 42, and will accommodate altogether about 1,000 persons. The basement, when completed, will be set apart for the Sunday School meetings, Bible Class, &c. The interior of the church is finished and furnished in an elegant style. The entire cost will be about $33,000. In the morning the sermon and dedicatory services were by the pastor, Rev. C.F. WELLS, and Rev. Dr. TAYLOR, of Bergen. In the Afternoon and evening sermons were preached by Rev. Dr. CAMPBELL, of New-Brunswick, and Dr. BETHUNE, of New-York.

abstract: We translate to-day from our foreign files a correspondence which the future historian of our times, let us hope, will peruse with half incredulous amazement. Thanks to the liberal and open spirit which roles in the domestic as well as in the foreign policy of the Sardinian Government, the letters exchanged between PIUS IX. and VICTOR EMANUEL II.
lead_paragraph: We translate to-day from our foreign files a correspondence which the future historian of our times, let us hope, will peruse with half incredulous amazement. Thanks to the liberal and open spirit which roles in the domestic as well as in the foreign policy of the Sardinian Government, the letters exchanged between PIUS IX. and VICTOR EMANUEL II on the subject of the annexation of the Roman Legations to Sardinia, have been fearlessly published to the world. The Roman Pope and the Italian King stand forth in this correspondence, each in the light of his own ideas, to be judged by the present age and by posterity. The vague and paltering generalities of denunciation behind which Pope PIUS shrouds his notions of justice, propriety, and public right, in his preposterous Bull of Excommunication, find no place in these direct communications with the Prince whose conduct he assumes to judge. VICTOR EMANUEL and COUNT COVOUR, by the firm and dignified clearness with which they put the whole case of the Legations before the Papal Government, drive PIUS and ANTONELLI into the necessity, so dreadful to the wily clerical mind, of answering flatly to the point. And we repeat, that in the faith which no lover of his race can willingly resign -- that those who pretend to represent the "author of justice" and the religion of truth may one day be shamed by the enlightened intelligence of the world out of the lust of earthly power and the hypocrisies of temporal ambition -- we find ground for hoping that it will be difficult for our children to believe that the name of the "Vicar of Christ" was ever subscribed to these epistles from the Vatican. Anything more intemperate in tone, more shameless in its disregard of simple historical truth, and more insolently scornful of human rights and their political guarantees, than the letters of PIUS IX., it would be hard to find, even in the medjaeval archives of the Papacy. VICTOR EMANUEL sets before the Pope, in language equally explicit and respectful, the absolute necessity which the position of Italy imposes upon every Italian sovereign, of consulting the irrepressible wishes and yielding to the legitimate demands of the Italian people. He reminds the PIUS of 1860 that the PIUS of 1847 was the first Italian Prince who recognized this necessity; and urges him, by every consideration which ought to move a Christian and patriot, to throw the weight of his authority with and not against the righteous movement of the times. The Pope in reply has nothing but insolence for the sovereign who counsels him, and contempt for the people in whose name that sovereign pleads. He will roll back the tides of the ocean, stop the sun in mid-heavens, thwart the glorious crystallization of Italy into a great Power lighted by libery and ruled by law[???] and he will excommunicate anybody and everybody who dares to interfere with him in these feasible and laudable enterprises. BONIFACE himself, flying before the Colonnas whom he had outraged, was not more obstinate or more insane; but the world was quit of BONIFACE with no great damage to the Church which he misruled. PIUS IX. is dragging the chair of St. Peter down with himself into that most hopeless of all abysses -- the abyss of universal contempt. In the great days of the Roman Church, the Popes maintained themselves against earthly monarchs because their temporal weakness was strengthened by the stand they took for the laws of heavenly justice against the superstitions and the brutality of military force. VICTOR EMANUEL and PIUS IX. reverse the picture. The temporal weakness of the Papacy is married now to a moral corruption and a political ignorance which it is hardly safe to exhibit to the Nineteenth Century, in open contrast with the armed loyally and the powerful moderation of a great people and their elected king.

abstract: INTERESTING SURGICAL CASES AT THE CITY HOSPITAL?Calling at Dr. WEIR, Resident Surgeon of the New-York Hospital, yesterday, to learn the result of the application of the new method of arresting hem...  orrhage, an account of which was published in the TIMES last week, we found that the stump of the arm amputated had almost wholly united by first inteniton. Looking around the ward we noticed two patients whose condition was unusually interesting; ...
lead_paragraph: INTERESTING SURGICAL CASES AT THE CITY HOSPITAL?Calling at Dr. WEIR, Resident Surgeon of the New-York Hospital, yesterday, to learn the result of the application of the new method of arresting hem... orrhage, an account of which was published in the TIMES last week, we found that the stump of the arm amputated had almost wholly united by first inteniton. Looking around the ward we noticed two patients whose condition was unusually interesting; the one, PATRICK FOLAN, convalescent from a frightful wound, which many at the time considered fatal. He was at work int he Bergen Tunnel when a rock gave way from above and struck his right shoulder taking away his arm. Being of an excellent constitution he survives, -- perhaps to add still more to the number of his escapes. He has been confined several times within a year for broken ribs, legs and arms. He says at one time his knee-pan �was broken in three halves," an expression which will indicate his nationality. The other, GEO. BAKER, with fracture of the spine, producing paralysis of the lower parts of the body. He was mate of the brig Benjamin Delano, and on April 12th was in the top overhauling the signal hailiards, when he fell over, striking the rigging in his descent. He is in pretty good spirits, though his friends scarcely hope for his recovery. In the same ward is OWEN KELLY, who dislocated his hip six months ago, while in the Bay of Biscay, without having it set. The surgeons of New-Orleans told him that the socket of the hip had been filled up in consequence of the long time that had elapsed since the accident occurred, and that there was no remedy. He has been in the straight apparatus here for live weeks, and now uses the limb, which is gradually resuming its natural place and appearance. In the main house, Dr. DELL informs us, LETITIA KNEE, who was accidentally shot by a pistol on the morning of April 10, will save her finger, though it will be much shortened. NERONIQUE MARCHAND, a bright child of 13 years, is the only one of the sufferers by the Elm-street catastrophe now remaining in the Hospital. She fell from the fifth story, and received a compound fraction of the thigh. She is still confined to the bed, though the limb is in a prosperous condition. Of the others of her friends who left the fifth story with her, FRANCIUS VOPEL left the Hospital as soon as her burns were healed, and a few days ago she left for Paris, where she hopes to recover from her extreme nervous irritability. Mr. BERNARD, who received no external injuries by the fall, having no means to enable him to remain in the Hospital, has been living with acquaintances at No. 192 Mulberry-street, on credit. He still suffers much, but is now earning a little by his trade, the needle. MARGARET LUCY, whose skull was somewhat fractured by a stove which fell upon her as she "was helping her husband take it up stairs, on the 31st of March, obtained permission to visit her friends last week, and has not been heard from since.

abstract: steam frigate Roanoke having received orders to proceed to this port with the Japanese Embassy, it was deemed advisable on the part of the Navy Department to order a bark to intercept her at the Narrows, on her arrival, with instructions to proceed to Hampton Roads, and from there take the steamer Philadelphia for Annapolis, Maryland. The bark left on the 3d inst. in command of Mr. TELANT, of the Brooklyn Navy Yard, and will lay off and on until the arrival of the Roanoke, when official instructions will be given her.
lead_paragraph: steam frigate Roanoke having received orders to proceed to this port with the Japanese Embassy, it was deemed advisable on the part of the Navy Department to order a bark to intercept her at the Narrows, on her arrival, with instructions to proceed to Hampton Roads, and from there take the steamer Philadelphia for Annapolis, Maryland. The bark left on the 3d inst. in command of Mr. TELANT, of the Brooklyn Navy Yard, and will lay off and on until the arrival of the Roanoke, when official instructions will be given her.

abstract: On Saturday WILLIAM BURNS, a man 27 years of age, who was employed as a slater on the roof of No. 96 Morton-street, slipped off and struck upon his head in the area-way, receiving such injuries that his death speedily resulted. Deceased resided with his family at No. 60 West Washington-street, where Coroner JACEMAN held an inquest upon the body.

abstract: Rev. H.H. GARNET preached, last evening, in Shiloh Presbyterian Church, upon the subject of African Civilization. After the usual introductory exercises, Mr. GARNET took his text in Isaiah, 57th chapter and 14th verse: ï¿½He that putteth his trust in me shall possess the land." He said that the whole duty of man and the happiness of life were summed up in three things: First, the worship of the true and living God; second, in home and country; and third, in the faithful discharge of duty to our kindred and to all mankind. He that truly worshipped God loved his home and country, but if the enjoyment of life and liberty were inseparably connected with these, then there were millions who were homeless. It was among the first duties of a people to seek a home and a country, and the colored people, of all others, should say with FRANKLIN, "where liberty dwells there is my country." Here they were merely sojourners among strangers, without a home, mere tenants at will, and subject to the bitterest wrongs and outrages. Duty to themselves, to their offspring and race, as well as to God demanded that they should not be content to remain forever in a condition of thraldom and of moral and civil degradation, when the opportunity to rise was held out to them. Emigration was one of the grand instruments of civilization, and the Gospel required that Christians should carry civilization and a pure Christianity to those who sit in the dark places of the earth. The example of the Pilgrim Fathers was referred to. But for emigrants were needed -- not the wicked and profane, the proud and scornful, the faithless and unbelieving, the lazy and timid, the ignorant and superstitious; but men and women of strong faith in God, of industry, and possessed of true Christian intelligence. He concluded by answering various objections to the scheme. The house was well filled, and the deepest attention was manifested thoughout.

abstract: EAST NEW YORK versus QUEEN's COUNTY. --  The Queen's County Club -- a new organization --  having challenged the East New York Club, barring several players; the match was played at East New York on Saturday. The match was a very pleasant one and well contested; HALL, SUYDAM, SEABURY, DARE, and HADRINS, being Americans, and playing very well Indeed. SUYDAM, who is very young, batted finely -- making 16 runs -- and is a promising player. A celebrated English cricketer, Mr. HAMPSHERE. played for Queen's County, but was not allowed to bowl. Four Americans played on the East New York side -- VAN SULEN, C. WALDEN, HOAGLAND, and FURMAN. Quite a number of cricketers were on the ground, and a fine dinner was furnished for them at REI[???]'s Howard House. Some complimentary speeches were made, on giving up the bali. and Queen's Queen's County men left with cheers. The score stood as follows:

abstract: I see by the newspapers since I arrived from England, that there appears to be some ill feeling expressed towards me in this country for the part I took in the late fight between SAYERS and HEENAN. For the opinion entertained of me by the fighting fraternity I care but little, but I do wish to have myself placed in a proper light before the public, and with that object in view I address you these lines.

abstract: The annual sermon of the American and Foreign Christian Union, preparatory to the anniversary meeting on Tuesday next, was preached last night a the Tabernacle Church, (Dr. THOMPSON's,) corner of Thirty-fifth-street and Sixth-avenue, by Rev. Dr. HAGUE. The reverend gentleman announced the subject of his discourse to be "God's covenant against Paganism," and read his text, Psalm xxv., 14: "The secret of the Lord is with them that fear him, and he will shew them his covenant." A cloud of gloomy mystery, the preacher said, overhung the moral con. omy of the world, but Christianity was uplifting the veil. It was, indeed, strange that a new and even a worse Paganism should have arisen upon the ruins of the old, and that after a pure religion had been specially revealed at Bethlehem, the majority of our species should be slaves of a degrading superstition -- of an "oppressive Churchianity" of the dominant Church of Rome. Under a new name, a worse than the old Pantheon was restored in Rome. Instead of a Pagan Pontifex, there was a Papal one. Far nobler was it to adore the demigods of old Rome than to bow down to an image which was called God's mother. God forbid that one should cast censure on the splendid mythology of Greece and Rome, and look with an eye of commendation on that modern Paganism taught in the Papal Church. The Mahomedans were, in the score of morality, superior to Catholics, and the Empire of Japan stands higher, to-day, in the scale of civilization than Italy, Spain, or Portugal. The Pope's power was gone. He excommunicated Sardinia, but VICTOR EMANUEL laughed at the foolish old man, and bade him mind his own business. The reverend preacher eulogized the American and Foreign Union, and said that in Italy the people were crying for Bibles. A great field was before them, in which to work, and the secret of their strength was that God was with them. After prayer and benediction by Rev. Dr. CAMPBELL, the audience separated. The anniversary meeting of the Society will be held at St. Paul's Methodist Church, in Fourth-avenue, on Tuesday evening, when the report of the Secretary will be read, and several influential ministers, among whom is Rev. Dr. CHINIQUY, of the Canada Mission, will deriver addresses.

abstract: Count DE MONTEMOLIN and his brother FERDINAND and their vallet were arrested at Amposta, near Tortosa, at 2 o'clock on the morning of the 21st. The gendarmes surrounded the house, and after having vainly demanded admittance, one effected an entrance through the window. The Princes were dressed, and declared themselves at the disposal of the gendarmes.

abstract: The anniversary sermon before this association was preached last evening by Rev. T.S. HASTINGS (pastor of the Carmine-street Church,) the anniversary and business meeting being held in the Winter season. The Church of Rev. Dr. ADAMS, corner of Madison-avenue and Twenty-fourth-street, was filled with an appreciative audience, who were well repaid by an eloquently-delivered sermon. The exercises of the evening were opened by a hymn from the choir, and, after a prayer by Rev. Mr. MARTIN, Rev. Mr. HASTINGS was introduced -- the chosen preacher for the occasion. His text was taken from 1st Samuel, from the 4th to the 13th verses, and was an elaborate, careful and eloquent sermon, proving the necessity of the Bible to controvert error and infidelity, and tracing its Divine origin and influences, and claiming that no work ever penned by human hands had so long and so successfully resisted the attacks made upon it, not alone by unbelievers, but by believers who chose to interpret its meanings to suit their own views. The sermon, at the instance of the Society, will be printed in pamphlet form, and at the request, as well of the preacher as of the officers of the Society, any attempt at a report is withheld.

abstract: THE SUNDAY LIQUOR LAW. -- Nearly all of the places where liquor is sold, were closed yesterday, in obedience to the law. A few of the more venturesome, however, kept open as usual, and in consequence a majority of them found themselves in a prison at night. About a dozen arrests. The Police have so little work to do in tins line in the city that they have commenced extending their operations into the country districts. Detective FOLK yesterday arrested SIMONSON, the proprietor of a bar-room in New Lotts, for violating the law, and he was locked up in the cells at the City Hall. An attempt was made to get out a writ of habeas corpas but the attempt failed. The cases of the parties arrested one week ago for violating the Sunday law will be disposed of before Justice CORNWELL to-day.

abstract: Judge SMALLEY, of the United States District Court, and Deputy-Marshal THOMPSON deserved well of their country on Saturday, by making an example of two deputies, who were convicted of gross misconduct with regard to the Storm King, which lately sailed from this port under strong suspicions of being fitted up for a slave voyage to the Coast of Africa.
lead_paragraph: Judge SMALLEY, of the United States District Court, and Deputy-Marshal THOMPSON deserved well of their country on Saturday, by making an example of two deputies, who were convicted of gross misconduct with regard to the Storm King, which lately sailed from this port under strong suspicions of being fitted up for a slave voyage to the Coast of Africa. It appears by the affidavits read by the Assistant District Attorney in making the motion for their dismissal, that, acting on the information of a Custom-house officer named DEGRAW, as to the character of the vessel, he sent a process for her arrest and detainer to Deputy-Marshal THOMPSON, who is Acting-Marshal during the absence of Mr. RYNDERS -- who has been serving his country in Charleston -- by DEGRAW, telling him that THOMPSON was to be found on board a certain vessel in the North River; that DEGRAW went to the vessel in question and inquired for THOMPSON, and was addressed by a person who said he was a Deputy Marshal, who took the papers and said it was all right; that this person was Deputy Marshal MUNN, who thereupon departed in search of another Deputy, whom he named "Dory" -- a term of endearment, it appears, applied by his colleagues to THEODORE RYNDERS, Esquire, a brother of the great "Captain" -- and promised that they would attend to it.

abstract: There was a large open-air meeting of the citizens of Castleton, S.I., on Saturday evening, at the village of Factoryville, to consider what proceedings should be taken with reference to the theft and destruction of the ballot-box on Wednesday last, the evening of the town election. The general indignation at the outrage was made apparent by the presence of men of all parties, and addresses were made by Col. NATHAN BARRETT, GEORGE W. CURTIS and LOT C. CLARK..

abstract: The annual sermon on the occasion or the Twenty-third Anniversary of the "Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church in the United States" was preached at Dr. SPRING's Church, in Fifth-avenue, last evening, by ELIJAH R. CRAVEN, D.D., of Newark, New-Jersey. Previous to the sermon, Rev. Dr. WILSON, the Secretary of the Board, read an abstract of the annual report, from which it appeared that the receipts from all sources during the past year have been $237,982 28, being an advance over last year of $7,901 71. In last year's report there were included over $19,000 more of the fund for repairing losses in India, and of Government appropriations for Indian schools, than is contained in this year's report; so that the actual increase of receipts from ordinary sources, over last year, is upwards of $25,000. The expenditures have been $234,037 73, leaving a balance on hand of $3,944 55. The number of missionaries sent out during the past year has been 44, which, with 22 others received in connection with that branch of the Choctaw Mission formerly under the American Board, makes the whole number added to the missionary force during the year 66 -- being double the number in service during any previous year. The reports from the various missionaries regarding the success of their labors are generally very favorable, in view of which the Board invoke the continued prayers and material aid of the Church.

abstract: In the House of Lords on the 24th the Marquis of NOEMANBY brought forward a resolution complaining of secret correspondence having been carried on between Lord COWLEY, the British Ambassador at Paris, and the Home Goverment, having reference to important matters on the Savoy question, and declaring it injurious to public service to have questions ...
lead_paragraph: In the House of Lords on the 24th the Marquis of NOEMANBY brought forward a resolution complaining of secret correspondence having been carried on between Lord COWLEY, the British Ambassador at Paris, and the Home Goverment, having reference to important matters on the Savoy question, and declaring it injurious to public service to have questions of moment referred to in private correspondence unless there is also public record of the same. Lord COWLEY stated that he regarded the motion as a censure upon himself, and had come from Paris expressly to defend his course. He asserted that his first information relative to the intentions of France was received privately, and the matter of the opinion of WALEWSKI and the communication was of such a nature that he was unable to include them in public dispatches. The first official intimation he had was in February last, and he then forthwith laid it before the Government. He denied that any communication of importance had been withheld.

abstract: The London Spectator, one of the oldest and most respectable of the English weekly journals, vind[???]cates prize-fighting with great zeal and earnestness, denouncing the "secret instigators of the police" who tried to stop it, declaring that "public decorum degenerates into pharisaical affectation" when it makes such an outcry about fighting and glorifying the splendid qualities shown by both combatants. "Depend upon it," says the Spectator, "there are many things which are more dangerous to society and more hsrrible than prize fights." It glories greatly in the chivalry of the whole affair, and regrets patronizingly that HEENAN showed little of it in selecting his position so that the sun should fall in the eyes of his antagonist. It contrasts this with the historical fact that "PEARCE would not hurt JEM BELCHER's remaining eye when he had his rival at a disadvantage," but judiciously ignores the fact that SAYERS devoted himself to the pleasant task of blinding HEENAN, as the only change of beating him. The Saturday Review, the organ of the most pretensions class of cultivated Englishmen, writes in a similar vein of the ring. No respectable journal in this country has yet said a syllable in vindication of this brutality.

abstract: Application of Joachim Spier. -- This was a writ of habeas corpus, returnable before Judge BRADY of the Common Pleas. The relator is a journey man carpenter, residing at No. 552 Ninth-avenue. The petition sets forth that about six weeks ago Jacob Meyer came to his house and offered him a dollar per week for the services of his boy, a lad of nine or ten years of age. The offer was accepted, and the boy went to learn the trade of a butcher, that being the occupation of the employer. Meyer, however, it is alleged, did not pay the dollar a week for the labor of the lad -- refusing not only to pay the hire, but also declining to give up the boy, as he was requested to do by the relator. This application was to recover possession of the child.

abstract: A telegraghic dispatch announces that delegates are to be chosen in Georgia to represent the Democrats of that State in the Baltimore Convention. This indicates the course that will probably be pursued in all the Southern States whose representatives seceded from the ...
lead_paragraph: A telegraghic dispatch announces that delegates are to be chosen in Georgia to represent the Democrats of that State in the Baltimore Convention. This indicates the course that will probably be pursued in all the Southern States whose representatives seceded from the Convention at Charleston. New men will be chosen in their places, so that while the se[???]eding delegates will hold a Convention of their own at Richmond, the "national" Democrats will be represented in the National Convention at Baltimore. This will transfer to the Southern States the intestine strife which led to the explosion at Charleston. The Democratic Party in each of these States will be divided, -- the nationals on one side and the secessionists on the other. At Baltimore it is quite likely that DOUGLAS may secure the nomination. His friends announce their purpose to insist upon it: -- the new delegates from the South will probably be in his favor, -- and he bids fair to reap the advantage of the continued and relentless hostility of the Administration. With all these odds in his favor, his chances must be considered good.

abstract: The death of Hon. abstract: Another meeting of the merchants in favor of the establishment of a Produce Exchange was held at noon on Saturday, May 5, at No. 35 Pearl-street Mr. R.H. ELRDELL acted as Chairman, and Mr. ALFRED BARRETT, as Secretary. The minutes of Thursday's meeting were read. Mr. W.D. MANGAM presented a report from the majority of the Committee, appointed to confer with Mr. MEAD in reference to the purchase of the property which had been recommended as suitable for the business of an Exchange as also to select names of a Board of Trustees. The report was to the effect that the property, bounded by Pearl, Whitehall, Water, and Moore streets, could be purchased for $155,000, and clear possession thereof obtained on the 1st day of June; that the property was mortgaged to the extent of $75,000 -- thus: $40,000 at 6 per cent., $20,000 and $15,000, respectively, at 7 per cent, per annum; that the mortgages for $40,000 and $20,000 had matured, but would be continued, or renewed; that the one for $15,000 had two years to run; that the purchase-money should be paid at the rate of 25 per cent on the delivery of the deed, 25 per cent. in sixty days from the date of such delivery, and 50 per cent, within thirty days from the date of the last payment; that Mr. MEAD would take, as part payment $20,000 worth of the stock of the proposed organization; that he would require no interest on the several installments; that he would give the subscribers to the Produce Exchange the refusal of the property, on these terms, until the 15th of May; and that the majority of the Committee recommended to have the capital fixed at $75,000. This report made no mention of names of Trustees, as the parties who prepared it were not willing to offer any such recommendation. Mr. E.W. COLEMAN presented a minority report, explanatory of the reasons why no general decision had been arrived at in reference to the selection of Trustees, and recommending the following list of names as the choice of the minority of the Committee:

abstract: The steamship Bohemian, of the Montreal line, from Liverpool on the 25th ult., calling at Queenstown the following day, reached Farther Point last evening, The news is of interest. HEENAN, the American champion in the recent fight, had addressed a letter to the Referee in the late contest, ...
lead_paragraph: The steamship Bohemian, of the Montreal line, from Liverpool on the 25th ult., calling at Queenstown the following day, reached Farther Point last evening, The news is of interest. HEENAN, the American champion in the recent fight, had addressed a letter to the Referee in the late contest, demanding the belt or a new trial; and citing the authorities of the Prize Ring to sustain the justice of his claim. The American shipmasters at Liverpool had cbntributed handsomely to a purse for HKENAN's benefit. There is no thing of moment in our English advices. The suppression of the Sicilian insurrection is reported from Naples; and from Spain we learn of the capture of COUNT DE MONTEMOLIN and his nephew-What disposition should be made of the noble captives is a question of hardly less perplexity to the Spanish Press than to the Spanish Government. The news from China is that the rebellion continues to spread with alarming rapidity.

abstract: Just before midnight on Saturday, the cheering and unusual noise on the pier at the foot of Roosevelt-street, induced coxswain Simley and boat's crew No. 8 of the Harbor Police, to land and ascertain its cause, when they found that the prototype of the "great international mill" was in course of representation by moonlight, before an audience of two hundred or more thieves, loafers and other sporting men. The combatants were Charles Cann and Thomas Mullen, two Fourth Ward ruffians, ambitious of pugilistic fame, who had fought four rounds in artistic style, and were just coming to "time" for the fifth when the Police broke into the ring and secured them. The seconds, referee, bottle-holders and all the spectators precipitately fled at the irruption of Officers, and the fight will probably be considered a "drawn one." The principals, each bearing the marks of the other's prowess, were yesterday morning taken before Aldermen SMITH, acting-Justice at the Tombs, and fined $10 each for disorderly conduct. As, however, all their funds had been wagered and placed in the hands of stake-holders, who had deserted them in their trouble, they were consigned to the cells for non-payment of the penalty.
lead_paragraph: Just before midnight on Saturday, the cheering and unusual noise on the pier at the foot of Roosevelt-street, induced coxswain Simley and boat's crew No. 8 of the Harbor Police, to land and ascertain its cause, when they found that the prototype of the "great international mill" was in course of representation by moonlight, before an audience of two hundred or more thieves, loafers and other sporting men. The combatants were Charles Cann and Thomas Mullen, two Fourth Ward ruffians, ambitious of pugilistic fame, who had fought four rounds in artistic style, and were just coming to "time" for the fifth when the Police broke into the ring and secured them. The seconds, referee, bottle-holders and all the spectators precipitately fled at the irruption of Officers, and the fight will probably be considered a "drawn one." The principals, each bearing the marks of the other's prowess, were yesterday morning taken before Aldermen SMITH, acting-Justice at the Tombs, and fined $10 each for disorderly conduct. As, however, all their funds had been wagered and placed in the hands of stake-holders, who had deserted them in their trouble, they were consigned to the cells for non-payment of the penalty.

abstract: The presentation of the Annual Report of the Society designated as above, and the delivery of the annual sermon in its aid, occurred last evening in the Dutch Reformed Church, corner of Fourth-street and Lafayette-place. At the close of the prepatory devotions, Rev. Dr. PENNEY, the Corresponding Secretary, submitted the report. He congratulated the Society on the fact that they had commenced to recover from a long season of prostration, beginning so far back as 1855. The Society's efforts, were he said, mainly confined to the City and its vicinity, and its work was principally done through the agency of three converted Hebrews, employed as colporteurs, to visit Jewish families and distribute tracts amongst them.

abstract: For whatever color of truth can be found in the charge brought against the "institutions" of the United States by Earl GREY, that the great mass of the people never know who their member is in any legislative body, the City of New-York, as now administered, is mainly responsible.
lead_paragraph: For whatever color of truth can be found in the charge brought against the "institutions" of the United States by Earl GREY, that the great mass of the people never know who their member is in any legislative body, the City of New-York, as now administered, is mainly responsible. There are very few decent citizens of New-York who can tell without referring to a �Manual� who is their representative, either in the Board of Aldermen, in the Common Council, in the State Legislature or at the Federal capital. We venture to say that two-thirds of the constituents of any member of either branch, are in blissful ignorance of the splendid figure which these municipal statesmen are making in public life. Each citizen knows, as a matter of fact, that he lives in a certain Ward, and he presumes that those provisions of the Charter are regularly carried into execution, which direct the election of a certain number of Aldermen and Common Councilmen to represent it in the City Government. But more than this he does not often know; and his ignorance has now lasted so long that in the majority of instances he has ceased to care. Who selects the candidates -- who works to secure their election -- what their antecedents are -- what are their claims and qualifications -- who it is that showers �tickets� into his house on their behalf for a week before the election, -- he cannot pretend to guess, and rarely takes the trouble to inquire. And when the Booles and the Bagleys, immediately on entering office, begin to rig out roving sanitary commissions, lavish �municipal hospitalities� on Turks and Japanese, accept proposals to pilot the Great Eastern, build monuments to national heroes, and release ruffians from station-houses, fully two-thirds of the population are utterly unable to say what quarter of the City it is to which these great men owe their appearance in public life.

abstract: ANNIVERSARY OF THE JERSEY CITY SABDATH SCHOOL. -- The fifth anniversary of the Jersey City Sabbath-schools took place yesterday afternoon, and was participated in by about 3,000 children. The schools assembled as follows: Schools -- First Presoyterian, 250 scholars; First Reformed Dutoh, 150; York street Methodist, 200; Mission, 125; Almshouse, 25. Total, 750 Addresses were delivered by RALPH WELLS and Mr. PARDE, General Agent for the Sunday-school Union.

abstract: The Young Men's Christian Association met last evening in Rev. Dr. ADAMS' Church, in Madisonsquare, for the purpose of celebrating the eighth anniversary of the foundation in this City of that organization.
lead_paragraph: The Young Men's Christian Association met last evening in Rev. Dr. ADAMS' Church, in Madison-square, for the purpose of celebrating the eighth anniversary of the foundation in this City of that organization. At the close of the opening prayers and hymns, Mr. S.G. GOODRICH,[???] the President, read the annual report, from which it appears that the Association, notwithstanding the fact that it had been attempted to be choked by some hard substance, is still alive. The rooms of the Association, he said, had been better attended throughout the past year than previously. The number of active, associate, life, and honorary members, now amounted to 948, of whom 181 had been entered as new members during the past year. Delegates from a great many churches had attended the Society's monthly meeting, and good boarding-houses, and promising situations had been procured for many young men through the instrumentality of the Association. The only regret was that the Association was weak, because of the fact that it was now in debt.

abstract: The Opinione, of Turin, publishes the demand of the public prosecutor at the Court of First Instance at Bologna, in the case of the child MORTARA. The following is the conclusion: -- "Considering the violent invasion of the public officers into the b[???]se of the two Israelites, MOMOLO and MARI[???]NNE MORT[???]RA, on June 23, 1858, at Bologna, for the purpose of taking away their young child EDWARD, under the pretext that he was baptized; considering that the child, by means of the public force, was immediately transported to Rome, where he was shut up and sequestered in the College of the Catechumens; we demand that the Father PIERRO GAETANO FELETTI should be judged in virtue of the Arts. 440 and 444 of the Code of Procedure, and condemned by the Arts. 133 and 200 of the Penal Code of Sept. 20, 1832, (Art. 133. One year to three years' hard labor; Art. 200. One year to three years' imprisonment,) against magistrates who have abused their office, and against any one who arbitrarily arrests and imprisons any individual, and to the payment of damages and interest to the parents of the child as well as costs."

abstract: By the arrival of the Isabel from Port-au-Prince we learn that on the 8th ult., at 5 1/2 A.M., and on the 10th at 10 1/2 P.M., two severe shocks of an earthquake were experienced at that place, and for the three following nights slight shocks were felt. Several buildings fell. Some were slightly and others badly damaged. All the families residing in brick tenements fled to wooden shanties or to their country seats, but the greater portion slept in the streets. Many who were afraid to remain stationary walked the streets all night. The citizens formed a procession and paraded through the place, saying prayers as they went. Since then no shocks had been felt.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the Isabel from Port-au-Prince we learn that on the 8th ult., at 5 1/2 A.M., and on the 10th at 10 1/2 P.M., two severe shocks of an earthquake were experienced at that place, and for the three following nights slight shocks were felt. Several buildings fell. Some were slightly and others badly damaged. All the families residing in brick tenements fled to wooden shanties or to their country seats, but the greater portion slept in the streets. Many who were afraid to remain stationary walked the streets all night. The citizens formed a procession and paraded through the place, saying prayers as they went. Since then no shocks had been felt.

abstract: The Councilmen are in their glory. They are about to keep open house at the cost of the City, and entertain, not indeed angels unawares, but princes with malice prepense.
lead_paragraph: The Councilmen are in their glory. They are about to keep open house at the cost of the City, and entertain, not indeed angels unawares, but princes with malice prepense. A petition was yesterday evening handed in to these august Conscripts, praying them to bid the Prince of Wales come and see us. The petition, which is signed by a number of respectable citizens of New-York, will be found elsewhere in our columns, and is quite a curiosity in its way. We had not supposed that there existed in the whole world any competent rival of the Court Scribes who compose Her Britannic Majesty�s speeches from the throne. Those orations have long been regarded as a fitting part of the solemn but slightly rheumatic pageant with which the Sovereign of Britain opens and closes the sessions of Britain�s Parliament; their clumsy periods and hopeless involutions pairing most aptly with the fat cream-colored horses which lug along the gilded royal coach, and with the hyperbolical liveries of the attendant train.

Dr.Cox,spoke briefly of the progress of the Society, as an appropriate introduction to the report, which, on the conclusion of his remarks, was read by Rev. H. LOOMIS, one of the Secretaries. The report stated that �at an early period in the operations of the American Society, agents were sent out to the Southern ports, and to the cities of the West, to awaken an interest of the cause. The result has been the establishment of a large number of local societies, and two or three of a more general character. The receipts into the treasuries (not in[???]luding the Boston branch, not yet reported,) have been, for the year. $72,640 79. The receipts into the Treasury of the parent Society are $48,436 84[???] an increase over last year of $20,961 48. The disbursements during the same time have been $72,970 26; from the Treasury of the parent Society, $48,216 93, [???]eaving the present floating debt about $5,000. The stations occupied by these Societies combi[???]ed, are on the Labrador coast, Norway, Denmark and Sweden, France, China, Sandwich Islands, Chill, [???]eru, San Francisco, New-Orleans, Galveston, Mobile, Richmond, Philadelphia, Boston, Portland, and the principal cities on the lakes, rivers and canals of the West. More than one hundred sailors have been furnished with ma[???]ll libraries to take with them into the forecastle at sea. More than $[???],000 expended in this way have been furnished by Sunday Schools for ten-dollar libraries, to be placed in the bands of these sea-missionaries. Amount deposited by boarders in bank, and sent or carried to friends, n[???]arly $27,000. These figures te[???] the story of its continued usefulness.

abstract: Charles Reeves vs. Edward Hogan. This was an action against the defendant for damages alleged to have been sustained by the plaintiff, by reason of certain language claimed to have been used by defendant in public, concerning plaintiff's character.
lead_paragraph: Charles Reeves vs. Edward Hogan. -- This was an action against the defendant for damages alleged to have been sustained by the plaintiff, by reason of certain language claimed to have been used by defendant in public, concerning plaintiff's character. The parties both have stands in Washington Market, and have for some time been at variance. The plaintiff charged that defendant publicly stated of him that he was a thieving son of a --, and had robbed two or three men, and he (defendant) could prove it. The defendant denied that he had used such language concerning the plaintiff, but the jury were satisfied to the contrary, and gave a verdict for the plaintiff for $50 and costs.

abstract: CORONER's INQUEST. -- Mr. HIRAM FREER, a blacksmith residing near New-Paltz Landing, Ulster County, was found dead, on Saturday, in the Wallkill Creek, a short distance below the New-Paltz Bridge. He was about 40 years of age, and leaves a wife and family. The cause of his death is unknown.

abstract: At the regular meeting of this Board yesterday, the usual routine of petitions was gone through, with, and a large number of reports and resolutions from the Board of Aldermen were appropriately referred. A report quietly laid over, but which involves vast interests, was one in favor of widening Grand-street from Broadway to Varick-street, by taking off twenty-five feet from the southerly side, and to extend the street from its present terminus to Canal-street.

abstract: From marks of violence found upon the body of JOHN COLLINS, a laborer, who died in Bellevue Hospital on Sunday, as was supposed in consequence of an attack of delirium tremens, it is feared that he may have been maltreated by parties at present unknown. The Coroners are to investigate the case....Coroner JACKMAN held an inquest on the body of Mr. JOHN MURRAY, who died in consequence of injuries received by falling from the stoop of his house, No. 43 Perry-street, while laboring under an attack of dizziness....The body of a man, apparently a sailor, that had been a long time in the water, was found yesterday, at the foot of Oliver-street, East River. Coroner GAMBLE held an inquest, but the remains were not identified.....The same Coroner investigated the manner of the death of another unknown man, who had been found in the North River, at Twenty-ninth-street. Deceased was dressed as a laborer, and his remains were much decomposed. In both instances the verdict was "supposed drowning."
lead_paragraph: From marks of violence found upon the body of JOHN COLLINS, a laborer, who died in Bellevue Hospital on Sunday, as was supposed in consequence of an attack of delirium tremens, it is feared that he may have been maltreated by parties at present unknown. The Coroners are to investigate the case....Coroner JACKMAN held an inquest on the body of Mr. JOHN MURRAY, who died in consequence of injuries received by falling from the stoop of his house, No. 43 Perry-street, while laboring under an attack of dizziness....The body of a man, apparently a sailor, that had been a long time in the water, was found yesterday, at the foot of Oliver-street, East River. Coroner GAMBLE held an inquest, but the remains were not identified.....The same Coroner investigated the manner of the death of another unknown man, who had been found in the North River, at Twenty-ninth-street. Deceased was dressed as a laborer, and his remains were much decomposed. In both instances the verdict was "supposed drowning."
