abstract: The political prize-fight at Charleston was renewed yesterday at Washington. The Democrats on this side the water have this advantage of the champions on the other, they can have a fresh "mill" whenever they like. If the result upon one trial is not satisfactory they can try again. The "drawn battle" which closed the proceedings at Charleston satisfied nobody.
lead_paragraph: The political prize-fight at Charleston was renewed yesterday at Washington. The Democrats on this side the water have this advantage of the champions on the other, -- they can have a fresh "mill" whenever they like. If the result upon one trial is not satisfactory they can try again. The "drawn battle" which closed the proceedings at Charleston satisfied nobody. So, without waiting for Richmond, JEFFERSON DAVIS renewed the contest yesterday in the Senate. He made a very long speech in support of the resolutions which were rejected in the Convention, and in denunciation of DOUGLAS and his platform.

abstract: In Part I. of the Trial Term of the Superior Court. A.R. Dyett, Esq., yesterday announced the death of that venerated member of the New-York Bar, George Griffin, Esq., and, after making a few eulogistic remarks of the usual character on such occasions, moved that the Court adjourn. The motion was seconded by Theo. Stuyvesant, Esq. Justice HOFFMAN then remarked that he had had the pleasure of a long and familiar acquaintance with Mr. Griffin, and that he was, both in professional and private life, a gentleman of the highest and purest character. In accordance with the wishes of the Bar, the Court was then adjourned.

The motion was seconded by Theo. Stuyvesant, Esq. abstract: The Twenty-third Anniversary of the union Theological Seminary was held last evening at the Mercer-street Presbyterian Church, (Rev. Dr. CLARKE's.) A large audience was in attendance. The various Professors in the Seminary occupied seats in the pulpit, Rev. Dr. SKINNER, Professor of Pastoral Theology, acting as Chairman. Several other eminent divines, among whom we noticed Rev. Dr. ADAMS, Rev. Dr. ASA D. SMITH, and Rev. Dr. LAMBERT, also occupied seats on the platform. The exercises were opened by prayer from Rev. Dr. LAMBERT. Brief essays upon the following subjects were delivered from the pulpit by members of the Graduating Class:

abstract: By a telegram from the Galway steamer D[???], at Newfoundland, we learn that the visit of H.R.H. the Prince of WALES, to this Continent, is fixed for the first week in July. He will be attended on his voyage by a half-dozen steamships of the Royal Navy, and that he will land first at St. John's, Newfoundland, which Government has made arrangements to give him a suitable reception, and sail from thence to Halifax, Nova Scotia, where the English North-American fleet, under Admiral MILNE, has been ordered to rendezvous to receive him, and after a short stay there, the entire fleet will proceed to Quebec.

abstract: At Dr. POTTS' church, corner of Tenth-street and Fifth-avenue, the twenty-seventh anniversary of the New-York Magdalen Female Benevolent Society was held last evening.
lead_paragraph: At Dr. POTTS' church, corner of Tenth-street and Fifth-avenue, the twenty-seventh anniversary of the New-York Magdalen Female Benevolent Society was held last evening. The attendance was not large, scarcely one hundred persons being presentr The object of the society, as described in its own minutes, is "the promotion of moral purity, by affording an asylum to erring females, who manifest a desire to return to the paths of virtue, and by procuring employment for their future support." The Asylum is located in Eighty-eighth-street, between Fourth and Fifth avenues.

abstract: Patrick Levy, Joseph, Christopher, Matthew, William and Andrew Holliwood, became so noisy on Sabbath morning, in consequence of frequent potations, that Mr. James Reid, an old gentleman residing at No. 146 West Eighteenth-street, next door to the revelers, felt obliged to remonstrate with them. They were so exasperated at his interference that they rushed upon him and beat him with sticks and stones, and finally knocked him down upon his own door-step, finishing the assault by thrusting a dinner-fork into his cheek, and cutting him with a table-knife. His injuries were very severe, though not fatal. Justice KELLY committed his assailants for examination on a charge of felonious assault, William Reid, son of the wounded man, having entered a complaint.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. ROSSINI'S opera of "Moses in Egypt" was revived here last evening, after a long and undisturbed slumber. The work is by no means ...
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- ROSSINI's opera of "Moses in Egypt" was revived here last evening, after a long and undisturbed slumber. The work is by no means a novelty in New-York, having been played by the Seguin Troupe at the old Park Theatre, and subsequently in Italian by the forces under MARLI. In another shape -- as an oratorio -- it has been illustrated more or less successfully by almost every choral society in the City. The special merit of the present version is its excellent stage dress. Good scenery, good dresses, and much general propriety of mise-en scene have been expended on it, and successfully as regards all that related to the eye. We doubt very much if a greater degree of general excellence in these very satisfactory respects could be attained in any theatre of Europe. The success of "Moses," however, does not rest entirely on such matters. The music, without being difficult, demands careful treatment at the hands of artists who must possess all the facility of ROSSINI's exploded school, with some of the vigor of the modern one. There are moments when it approaches to declamation, and when vocal force and dramatic intelligence are as much needed as the mere ability to sing triplets, or any other purely Rossinian conceit. Sufficiently cast, therefore, the opera is not an unfruitful one in its opportunities; successes -- at rare intervals -- have been made in it.

abstract: Hon. SAMUEL BEARDSLEY died at his residence in Utica at 12 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning. He was born in Otsego County, and commenced the study o[???] law in Rome, Oneida County, with Hon. JOSHUA HATHAWAY, for many years Surrogate, and one of the County Judges. After having been admitted to the Bar, he commenced practice in Rome, where he remained until 1825, when he removed to Utica, and farmed a copartnership with Hon. GREENE C. BRONSON. For some months he acted as District-Attorney of Oneida County, and in 1827 received the appointment of United States District-Attorney for the Northern District of New-York, which office he held until elected to Congress in 1831. He occupied his seat there until 1836, and on the appointment of his old partner, GREENE C. BRONSON, to a Justiceshid in the Supreme Court, he was made Attorney-General. He resigned this office to take a seat on the bench of the Supreme Court, and in 1847 was advanced to the Chief Justiceship. Besides these positions, Judge BEAEDSLEY occupied that of State Senator in 1823. While in Congress, he was for three terms Chairman of the Committee on the Judiciary. On retiring from public life, he took up his residence in Utica, where he remained until the time of his death, with the exception of a year or two, when he had an office in this City.

abstract: Mr. ANTHONY yesterday presented to the Senate a remonstrance against any alteration in the patent laws, which should take away from patentees the right of appeal from the decision of the Commissioner.
lead_paragraph: Mr. ANTHONY yesterday presented to the Senate a remonstrance against any alteration in the patent laws, which should take away from patentees the right of appeal from the decision of the Commissioner. A bill was passed to settle the titles to lands set apart for the half-breeds in Kansas. The resolutions of Mr. DAVIS, which have already furnished the topic far protracted debate, came up. Mr. DAVIS himself spoke at length in their support. He alluded to cotton as the great bond of Union between the North and South; said the South demanded protection because it was her right, as well as the duty of the General Government to extend it. He thought Congress had the power to establish governments temporarily in the Territories, and declared it as his opinion that the election of a Republican President would be in itself an overt act, which the South would be perfectly right in considering cause sufficient for a dissolution of the Union. Some remarks of Mr. DAVIS brought out Mr. BROWN, who repudiated any sympathy with Mr. DOUGLAS. By way of demonstrating his sincerity, he offered as a substitute for the second and third of the resolutions, of which he is the author, one declaring it to be the duty of Congress to pass such laws as shall extend to slave-property the same protection which other property enjoys. Mr. CLINGMAN followed Mr. BROWN, but before he had concluded, the Senate adjourned. The House passed, without debate, a bill reported by Mr. BURLINGAME from the Committee on Foreign Affairs, authorizing the appointment of a full Minister to Sardinia, at a salary of $12,000, with a Secretary, at $1,800 per annum. On the motion of Mr. GROW, the debate on Territorial affairs was postponed until Thursday, in order to take up the Tariff bill, that some of the members of the House might set themselves right on that question before leaving for Chicago. It was also resolved to close the debate at 1 o'clock to-day. Messrs. SHERMAN, GROW, BLAIR and STEVENS spoke at length in favor of the measure. Mr. SCHWARTZ, of Pennsylvania, took occasion during the course of the debate to defend himself from the attacks of the Constitution.

abstract: A loud call was made in the German papers of Saturday, for a rally of "Importers and Dealers in Wines and Liquors, Brewers," and Lager-bier-dom generally, as well as "every German whose means will allow," at the Stadt-Theatre, in the Bowery.
lead_paragraph: A loud call was made in the German papers of Saturday, for a rally of "Importers and Dealers in Wines and Liquors, Brewers," and Lager-bier-dom generally, as well as "every German whose means will allow," at the Stadt-Theatre, in the Bowery. The object of the meeting was, to gain strength for the �Anti-Sunday Association,� and to settle the principle that �what is lawfully allowed on so-called week-days shall be allowd on the so-called Sunday.� The moderate sum of $1 is received for membership until the 15th May, when $3 will be charged.

abstract: Of all sanitary reformers, Dr. WINSHIP, of Boston, will probably become the most popular. For he advocates nothing that goes against the grain of our humanity. In particular he takes stand against those two old dogmas which inculcate the hygienic necessity of rising from the table hungry, and from bed sleepy. He says, never rise from table unsatisfied; never get out of bed so ...
lead_paragraph: -- Of all sanitary reformers, Dr. WINSHIP, of Boston, will probably become the most popular. For he advocates nothing that goes against the grain of our humanity. In particular he takes stand against those two old dogmas which inculcate the hygienic necessity of rising from the table hungry, and from bed sleepy. He says, never rise from table unsatisfied; never get out of bed so long as you have any inclination to lie there. And the Doctor's prescription is not only pleasant but sensible. If one is to rise from eating hungry what use of sitting down at all? And in relation to early rising, our sympathies have always been with the boy, who, when his father attempted to cut off his morning nap with that rusty old saw about the bird and the worm, replied that it served the worm right -- he hadn't any business to get up so early. As regards the distinguished author of the saying that four hours of sleep were enough for a man, five for a woman, six for a child, and seven for a fool, we have always inclined to think that he was entitled to avail himself of the latter clause and sleep a good seven, for which reason he felt no compunction in curtailing the sleep of others. Dr. WINSHIP's teachings are much more agreeable.

abstract: There was a large meeting of "the friends of the American Tract Society, in behalf of its religious and benevolent interests," in the Reformed Dutch Church, Lafayatte-place, last evening. lead_paragraph: There was a large meeting of "the friends of the American Tract Society, in behalf of its religious and benevolent interests," in the Reformed Dutch Church, Lafayatte-place, last evening. The Chair was occupied by HIRAM KETCHUM, Esq., who, in a few remarks in relation to the national character of the Society, introduced Mr. EASTMAN, one of the Secretaries who read a report recapitulating the doings of the Society since its organization, and stating that it has issued nearly 16,000,000 of volumes, 210,000,000 of tracts, and more than 50,000,000 copies of its periodicals.

abstract: One of the most accomplished members of the New-York Press, Col. T.B. THORPE, of the Spirit of the Times, last evening exhibited to a company of his friends and colleagues, a most unique and interesting work of art, a literal picture of Niagara as it is. That Col. THORPE is an artist in spirit has long been known to the reading world. We owe to Mr. DERBY, who kindly opened his house to receive both the painting and the painter's friends, the knowledge that Col. THORPE is an artist by the hand as well as by the heart. He has studied Niagara as Niagara deserves to be studied, year after year and month after month, from all possible points of view, and under every changing influence of season and of light. The result of his studies was a conviction that Niagara might be painted for the popular eye in the fullness of its characteristic beauty -- with all the splendor of rushing water -- all the mystical majesty of rising misty vapor -- all the grandeur of cloven ravines -- and all the solemnity of river deeps too profound to be stirred by breeze or keel.
lead_paragraph: One of the most accomplished members of the New-York Press, Col. T.B. abstract: This begins to be a very serious question. While the commercial centre creeps towards Union-square, the residential quarters stride by the half-mile towards the Central Park. And as population and business increase in a much greater ratio than the means of transit, the demand for some radical improvement in our City locomotion is becoming imperative.
lead_paragraph: This begins to be a very serious question. While the commercial centre creeps towards Union-square, the residential quarters stride by the half-mile towards the Central Park. And as population and business increase in a much greater ratio than the means of transit, the demand for some radical improvement in our City locomotion is becoming imperative. The average time occupied in getting down town, including that wasted in waiting for vehicles, or going afoot in default of a chance to ride at all, can hardly be less than three-quarters of an hour. In a few years the distance will be doubled, and since the speed of horses is limited by nature, while that of steam in the streets is limited by law, the time is likely to be doubled also. Two hours and a half to three hours in getting to and from business! One could better go fifty miles into Jersey. The entire upper part of the island offers every advantage to residents, except accessibility. Any respectably-rapid means of communication would give it the highest advantage in this regard also, over the Long Island and New-Jersey suburbs, since these only communicate with the business centre by a most dilatory and disagreeable transhipment in ferries and omnibuses. A Long Island Railroad bridge over the East River, and a New-Jersey tunnel under the North River, would indeed remedy the difficulty, but we do not anticipate immediate relief in these directions.
headline: {'main': 'How to Get Down Town.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'How to Get Down Town.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

lead_paragraph: The Sixteenth Anniversary of the Ladies' Home Missionary Society, having under their charge the Five Points Mission, was celebrated last night, in the Academy of Music. A large number of the friends of the cause were present. Several tiers of seats upon the stage were occupied by about 300 children, of various ages, ranging all the way from "knee-high to a chaw of tobacco" up to a very respectable size, and presenting -- with their bright faces, neat clothes and shiny shoes -- a very refreshing spectacle.

abstract: The enlargement of the circulation of the TIMES is at the present moment so rapid as to render it imperative that advertisements intended for the daily issue should be sent in at the earliest possible moment. Announcements which fail to reach the office before nine o'clock P.M., lose all the advantages of classification under the heads to which readers are accustomed to refer. It is, therefore, quite as important to the advertisers as to ourselves, to have that hour the latest for the reception of their notices.

abstract: A day of real May weather in May, such as the sentimental poets sing of, no rational New-Yorker ever expects to see. Borrowing its name from the mother of Mercury, this falsely fascinating month, the very thought of which is so enchanting in mid-winter, seems to have borrowed with the mother's musical name, something of the son's sly and deceitful nature. Our days of May oscillate between the chills of November and the heats of July. Of the two extremes the second is certainly at once the most timely and the most tolerable; and everybody accordingly rejoiced in the sudden Summer which on Sunday overcame the metropolis. Everybody and everything. The trees felt the grateful change, and brightened almost visibly with every genial moment, into a brighter glow of vernal foliage. The turf in pent-up city areas and unkempt city squares rejoiced in a brief semblance of green fields and rural meadows. If ever here was what the farmers call a day of "growing weather," it was yesterday. This we could all of us see by merely walking the streets, or looking at the flower-pots in the house-windows. It was only in the Central Park, however, that the glory of the growing could be fully appreciated. There, on the slopes and lawns which are emerging with so steady and artistic a development into a new world of sylvan beauty; on the little borders of turf which brighten the roadsides; on the budding boughs of the young trees, the fruitful presence of the sun made itself delightfully visible.

abstract: Everybody has heard of DOWB, that immortal type of nepotism in the administration of English affairs. DOWB, less widely known as DOWBIGGIN, had the felicity to be the nephew of Lord PANMURE, the Secretary-at-War of Great Britain at the crisis of the Crimean struggle, and his afectionate uncle telegraphed to the British commander before Sebastopol, that whatever ...
lead_paragraph: Everybody has heard of DOWB, that immortal type of nepotism in the administration of English affairs. DOWB, less widely known as DOWBIGGIN, had the felicity to be the nephew of Lord PANMURE, the Secretary-at-War of Great Britain at the crisis of the Crimean struggle, and his afectionate uncle telegraphed to the British commander before Sebastopol, that whatever he did or did not do to maintain the honor of England, he must "not forget to take care of DOWB." The English were beaten at the Redan, and came home in the train of the victorious French rather more crestfallen than it was quite becoming for "conquerors" to be. But DOWB was made a Colonel; and his name has taken its place in history.

abstract: The first case that has arisen under the Sanitary section of the Metropolitan Police Act, relative to insecure buildings, was disposed of yesterday. On Friday last Sergeant LORD, of the Sanitary Squad, made a complaint before Justice KELLY, at the Second ...
lead_paragraph: The first case that has arisen under the Sanitary section of the Metropolitan Police Act, relative to insecure buildings, was disposed of yesterday. On Friday last Sergeant LORD, of the Sanitary Squad, made a complaint before Justice KELLY, at the Second District Court, to the effect that the premises No. 652 Broadway were in a very insecure condition, the front and rear walls being cracked, and the centre of the building having settled as much as 6 1/[???] inches from a level. Mr. THOS. C.M. PATON, the assignee of the lessee of the premises, was at once summoned before the magistrate, and yesterday an examination into the matter was made.

abstract: The annual address before this Society was delivered last night at the Broadway Tabernacle by Proi. AUSTIN PHELPS, of Andover Theological Seminary. This was in substance os follows: Since the Corresponding Secretary has given his whole time to the services of the Society, two years and ...
lead_paragraph: The annual address before this Society was delivered last night at the Broadway Tabernacle by Proi. AUSTIN PHELPS, of Andover Theological Seminary. The services were opened with prayer by Rev. Mr. LINDSLEY, of Greenwich, Conn., after which the Seventh Annual Report was read by the Secretary. This was in substance os follows: Since the Corresponding Secretary has given his whole time to the services of the Society, two years and one month, it has had 54 churches under its care -- 8 only having been previously received. Of these, 62 in all, 1 has been dropped at its own request. Previous to May 1st, 1858, there were 7 houses of worship completed. The Treasurer had paid bills on 24 sanctuaries during the past year. On the 21st of November, there was under appropriation $4,913.28. From May 1st 1859 to May 1st 1860, $9,872.1J was paid into the Treasury, making the available resources $14,785 41. Of this amount $6,400 has been paid to the 24 churches above mentioned. The remainder has been pledged to 21 houses of worshsp. The Trustees acknowledge the receipt of donations varying from $200 to $300, for which they were grateful.

abstract: A resolution, providing for an expedition to observe the total eclipse of the sun in July, was offered in the United States Senate yesterday, and after ineffectual opposition on the part of a Georgia Senator, was passed by a large majority. Mr. CLINGMAN subsequently resumed his remarks in ...
lead_paragraph: A resolution, providing for an expedition to observe the total eclipse of the sun in July, was offered in the United States Senate yesterday, and after ineffectual opposition on the part of a Georgia Senator, was passed by a large majority. Mr. CLINGMAN subsequently resumed his remarks in opposition to the resolution of Mr. DAVIS, commenting on the schism in the Democratic faith, but predicting an early return to unity. For himself, he was ready to support any good Democrat, whether it be DOUGLAS, HUNTER or JOHNSON. Mr. BENJAMIN, of Louisiana, made a speech advocating generally the principles enunciated by the Mississippi Senator, but dissenting from some of his extreme inferences. Mr. DOUGLAS expressed his desire to reply to Mr. DAVIS as soon as practicable; and after the friends of the Homestead bill had vainly endeavored to bring that measure to a vote, the Senate closed its deliberations in Executive Session. The House, in Committee of the Whole, listened to Mr. HOUSTON, of Alabama, in an argument against the Tariff bill. Mr. HOUSTON declared that the act of 1857 had not been sufficiently tried; that its revenue was annually increasing, and that in another year it would meet the economical wants of the Government. Mr. MORRILL, of Vermont, explained the leading provisions of the bill; and Messrs. TAYLOR and MILLSON endeavored to amend it by increasing the duty upon sugar. A desultory conversation ensued upon the demand of the Republicans that a vote be taken. They urged the necessity of the vote on the ground of the approaching Convention at Chicago calling away large numbers of that party. The Democrats resisted the vote because but few of their party were present, and because but two had yet spoken against the bill. Every attempt at a call of the House resulting in the want of a quorum, at 8 o'clock the House adjourned.

abstract: The anniversary celebration of the American Temperance Union was held last night at the Church of the Puritans, (Dr. CHEEVER's,) in Union-square. The attendance was not very large, and there were certainly more ladies than gentlemen present. A letter from G.M. BRIGGS, the President of the Society, was read, in which he regretted that sickness prevented his attendance.
lead_paragraph: The anniversary celebration of the American Temperance Union was held last night at the Church of the Puritans, (Dr. CHEEVER's,) in Union-square. The attendance was not very large, and there were certainly more ladies than gentlemen present. A letter from G.M. BRIGGS, the President of the Society, was read, in which he regretted that sickness prevented his attendance. Mr. CORNING, in consequence, was called to the Chair. Prayer was offered by Rev. Dr. CHEEVER, and, after a brief address from the Chairman, who regretted the failure of the Maine Liquor law, but saw in recent legislation in this State, and in the rapidly-onward-marching progress of public opinion, decided cause for hope that the traffic in rum was drawing near its end, the Annual Report was read by the Secretary, Dr. MARSH. This report represented the Society in being in a most flourishing condition. During the past year, 5,000 drinking houses had been closed, and donations exceeding in amount $1,400 had been received. The cause of Temperance was everywhere progressing. Gen. SMITH offered a resolution that the report should be published, and Dr. STEPHEN H. TYNG seconded it in a long and characteristically humorous speech. The fight of the advocates of Temperance with the rum-sellers, he said, had been from the beginning like going down to the wolf's den to murder him, or to bring him up alive. In that beginning it was not thought inconsistent for those who denounced the rum-seller -- ladies as well as gentlemen -- to drink their port wine and Nayau after dinner. Then came those who denounced the drunkard, who would not drink the port wine, but had nothing to say against cider and beer. The question before the Society now was, how to overturn the power of the enemy, and dispose of all the wolves of the flock. The question must be met in its broadest aspect, and, as that noble mother in the time of the Revolution told her son, that if he was wounded in battle the wound must not be in his back, so there must be no wound in the back parts of the members or friends of this Society. There must be no going back, no reversing. Onward and ever onward, and, if to fall was inevitable, to fall nobly fighting. True it was that the enormity of liquor-selling seemed greater every day, and yet never, in the thickest of the fight hitherto, did victory seem so near. The foes of the cause were men of vast rotundity, lager-bier sellers, corpulent persons, whilst its friends were "snivelling persons," Independents, Baptists, Episcopalians, Methodists, and other individuals who agreed with them, that intemperance was a crime and a curse. But a thousand of these rotund enemies could be scared to death by one of these "sniveling parsons." If politicians were left to deal with the matter, the rum party would have its own way -- Republicans and Democrats being alike corrupt in such an instance, but honest men had also to talk about it, and by-and-by the rum party must go down. The last year was the heaviest year of warfare they had seen. The license system was such that a man who would pay ninepence might kill his (the speaker's) son, and if the father knockep the fellow's teeth down his throat, he might, for this act, spend six months in the Tombs. The fellow need not take out his license, but he can get his essential oil, or if he takes out his license, he may scatter his infernal poisons wholesale on the authority of that license. The day would come when LYMAN BEECHER's six sermons, preached in 1806 or 1807, which roused the nation then, would be looked upon within veneration. It was a fact which had come to his (Dr. TYNG's) knowledge, that distillers of liquors, who owned princely houses, owned also one hundred rum shops, and placed green young men in them to scatter poison over the City. Their retribution was sure to come, for to doubt it was absolute atheism; otherwise everything would really be going to the devil.

abstract: We must say we think the gentlemen who have been inciting the Common Council to a seizure of the Prince of Wales and his party, are bound, since they have moved in the matter at all, to see him safely out of their hands. Their signatures to the petition which we published yesterday, and on which the municipal authorities are acting, make them at least ...
lead_paragraph: We must say we think the gentlemen who have been inciting the Common Council to a seizure of the Prince of Wales and his party, are bound, since they have moved in the matter at all, to see him safely out of their hands. Their signatures to the petition which we published yesterday, and on which the municipal authorities are acting, make them at least morally responsible for the treatment he is to receive. We think the presentation of any such document to the Common Council was, in the first place, exceedingly ill-judged. If our leading citizens wished to testify their respect and good will for the Prince, they might have forwarded the expression of it to Lord LYONS, who would have transmitted it to the proper quarter, with such explanations as would give it its proper value in the eyes of the British nation. Their putting forward the Common Council as the representative of the City on such an occasion, with the full knowledge which they all possess of what the Common Council is, is something even more reprehensible than thoughtlessness. A reception organized directly by themselves would have been in the highest degree satisfactory to everybody concerned; but a reception organized and carried out by the Common Council will be in the last degree disgusting. We warn them that "hospitalities" cannot be inflicted upon the Prince and his suite with as much impunity as upon the Turks and Japanese. The latter are entirely ignorant of our manners and usages, and entirely unable to judge of a man's social standing amongst us by his behavior and appearance. If a Common Councilman should shoot a quid into one of their eyes, or pour a glass of whisky on their heads, or punch them in the ribs with his elbow, there would be no difficulty in persuading them that it was an act of attention only paid to persons of the highest rank by the most polished members of our aristocracy. When BOOLE and VAN TINE were cramming the Pasha with pig, and dragging him about the City in a dirty hack, the unfortunate wretch very probably thought that this was the giaour mode of expressing affection and good will, and submitted with set teeth.

abstract: There are numerous combinations to resist or evade our laws, and to defend those who do both. The Liquor interest, in its various ramifications; is thus protected. There are "Liquor Dealers' Associations," and "Lager-beer Dealers' Societies," and "German Anti-Sunday Law Associations," ,  Against such a power, with ample funds unscrupulously employed, ...
lead_paragraph: There are numerous combinations to resist or evade our laws, and to defend those who do both. The Liquor interest, in its various ramifications; is thus protected. There are "Liquor Dealers' Associations," and "Lager-beer Dealers' Societies," and "German Anti-Sunday Law Associations," &c., &c. Against such a power, with ample funds unscrupulously employed, what protection have the wronged and over-drugged public? Our Laws? But what if their enforcement is forestalled by able counsel, packed juries, venal courts, or a subservient magistracy? What if policemen have a blind side for unlicensed comer dram-shops? Or, if they are faithful in complaining of offenders, what if a District-Attorney should pile up 30,000 complaints in his office -- a monument of official neglect? Or, what if a few convictions are bad, an appeal taken, and the argument never should be reached? Or, if a decision is likely to be adverse, what if a little lobbying should secure just legislation enough to put everything at loose ends again? Or, if perfectly explicit statutes are enacted, what if Judicial and Executive officers should be stimulated to quarrel just enough to nullify all efficient action, and let offenders go on in their iniquity?

abstract: The forty-fourth anniversary of the New-York Sunday-school Union was celebrated throughout the City yesterday, in twenty different churches, and by not less than 30,000 children of both sexes. Notwithstanding the unfavorable weather, the turn-out of juveniles was larger than on any previous year, and the sight of their happy faces, as they danced along the street, to and from their various places of meet ...
lead_paragraph: The forty-fourth anniversary of the New-York Sunday-school Union was celebrated throughout the City yesterday, in twenty different churches, and by not less than 30,000 children of both sexes. Notwithstanding the unfavorable weather, the turn-out of juveniles was larger than on any previous year, and the sight of their happy faces, as they danced along the street, to and from their various places of meeting, would have delighted the hearts even of those-Godless heathen, the Japanese Ambassadors. They would have seen, had they been present, one of the "Institutions" of the Metropolis, not set down in the programme of the Common Council, but which would nevertheless have indicated to their minds the theory on which our Christian civilization starts the rising generation, however much it might differ from the practical results in the final bringing-up.

lead_paragraph: ITEMS. -- The house of Mr. ST. JOHNS, No. 328 Gold-street, was entered by thieves yesterday morning who carried away a variety of wearing apparel .... Post-office boxes have been placed on the lamp-posts in the most public positions throughout the City.... There are at the present time 280 convicts in the Kings County Penitentiary -- 104 having been admitted during the last month....The Board of Assessors has organized for the present year by electing CLINTON W. RILEY President and GEORGE L. THATCHER Secretary....The distillery of J.H. BRUNDAGE & CO., on First, near South Seventh-street, was damaged by fire on Monday to the extent of $3,000. The loss is covered by insurance.....Rev. N. WEST will be installed as pastor of the Second Presbyterian Church this evening....The body of an infant, which had evidently died from want and exposure, was found in a lot yesterday morning in State, near Smith-street....Counterfeit $5 bills on the Bank of the Commonwealth, Pa., were circulated in this city Monday evening....A sailor named JOSEPH MADISON was brought before Justice CORNWALL, charged with beating a woman named CAROLINE JOCELYN, with a slung shot, at a beer shop on Union-street, near Hamilton-avenue. The complainant being unable to attend Court on account of her injuries, the accused was committed for examination.

abstract: ANNUAL MEETING OF THE MERCANTILE LIBRARY ASSOCIATION. The members of the Mercantile Library Association held their annual meeting last evening in the lecture-room of the library building. There was a large attendance the body of the room being occupied by young members of the Association, and the platform by several members of the Board of Directors. GEO. W. BLUNT, Esq., presided. The annual report was first read.
lead_paragraph: ANNUAL MEETING OF THE MERCANTILE LIBRARY ASSOCIATION. -- The members of the Mercantile Library Association held their annual meeting last evening in the lecture-room of the library building. There was a large attendance the body of the room being occupied by young members of the Association, and the platform by several members of the Board of Directors. GEO. W. BLUNT, Esq., presided. The annual report was first read. It gave the present number of books in the library as 50,000; the number of members as 5,668, of whom 4,086 were those who had paid an initiatien fee of $2 -- the remainder the $5 initiation fee. The receipts during the year from all sources had been $10,612 92, and the disbursements $10,558 92. Included in the receipts was the donation of $10,000 from the the late SETH GROSVENOR. Mr. MORGAN and Hon. JOHN COCHRANE had been made honorary members during the year. Four honorary members had died during the year, Prof. DENISON OLMSTED, THEODORE SEDGWICK, WASHINGTON IRVING and NAJAH TAYLOR. Suitable tribute was paid to the memory of these gentlemen, as also reference to the character and usefulness of the late R.B. BROWN, formerly President of the Association. The Committee appointed at a recent meeting to prepare a history of the Association was discharged. A proposition to add $1 to the initiation fee called out an exciting discussion, with a confusion of hisses and cheers and stamping of feet, characteristic of the meetings of the Association preceding their annual elections. On the vote being taken the proposition was lost, over two thirds who were present voting against it. It was after 11 o'clock when the meeting adjourned, which took place till Friday night.

abstract: FUNERAL OF LIEUT.-Col. CHARLES H. SANDFORD. Yesterday, the funeral of Lieut.-Col. CHARLES H. SANDFORD, eldest son of Maj.-Gen. SANDFORD, who accompanied Gen. PAEZ to Venezuela, and died there in February, 1859, took place at Trinity Chapel, in West Twenty-fifth-street. The remains arrived in the City a few days previous. The Eighth Company of the National Guard, and the officers of the First ...
lead_paragraph: FUNERAL OF LIEUT.-Col. CHARLES H. SANDFORD. -- Yesterday, the funeral of Lieut.-Col. CHARLES H. SANDFORD, eldest son of Maj.-Gen. SANDFORD, who accompanied Gen. PAEZ to Venezuela, and died there in February, 1859, took place at Trinity Chapel, in West Twenty-fifth-street. The remains arrived in the City a few days previous. The Eighth Company of the National Guard, and the officers of the First Division, in full uniform, marched to the house of Gen. SANDFORD, in Twenty-second-street, and escorted the remains to the church. The pall-bearers were officers of the Major General's Division Staff. The chapel was nearly filled with the military and the friends of the deceased. The services of the Episcopal Church were read by Revs. Dr. HIGBEE and MORGAN DIX, of Trinity Church, assisted by a chair, who chanted the anthem in a most impressive manner. The coffin was made in the English fashion, covered with black cloth, with elaborately chased silver mountings. The military cap, accoutrements, and sword of the deceased were placed on the lid, and a simple inscription on the plate gave the date of his birth and death. At the conclusion, of the services, the body was taken to Trinity Cemetery, accompanied by his relations and immediate friends only, the military presenting arms as it was borne from Trinity Chapel. Among those present we noticed Gen. PAEZ, and Generals Hall, Spicer, Ewen and Gates, with Colonels Van Buren, Lefferts and Portley, and Majors Hallock and Pond, and Lieut. Stone all of the State Militia. The respect paid yesterday at the obsequies of Col. SANDFORD showed that his worth and memory were highly cherished by his civic and military friends.

lead_paragraph: -- The London Spectator is exercised. Some anonymous author has published a work entitled Famous Boys, and how they Became Great Men, dedicating it "to youths and young men as a stimulus to earnest living." First on his list he has placed HORACE GREELEY and JAMES GORDON BENNETT. To this the Spectator takes exception. It thinks that both gentlemen, BENNETT especially, are "drefful great men," but at the same time does not think that either of them should be held up as a model to show English youths how to accomplish the end of earnest living.

abstract: Mr. YANCEY, of Alabama, was one of the most conspicuous of the actors in the Charleston Convention. lead_paragraph: Mr. YANCEY, of Alabama, was one of the most conspicuous of the actors in the Charleston Convention. He represented the extreme Southern wing of the Democratic Party, and made a very long and elaborate speech in support of the Southern Platform. He burst into tears at the very thought of a disruption, and completely overcame those sentimental gentlemen, Capt. RYNDERS and JOHN COCHRANE, by the fervor of his eloquence and the depth of his emotions. He was very desirous of harmony in the ranks of the Democratic Party. Nothing but that could save the country from convulsion and ruin. Out of regard for the Union, therefore, he besought the Convention to accept the Southern Platform, and carry on the Government upon the principles of the Southern States.

abstract: HOW DEMOCRATS STEAL SLAVES. -- The Boston Atlas and Bee, of yesterday, states that a fugitive slave came as a passenger to that city by the S.R. Spaulding, which brought the Democratic Delegation from Charleston. The Atlas says his name is NORRIS; he is about 35 years old, is decidedly African, and belongs to the estate of THOMAS DIXON, Georgia, of Mason and Dixon's line fame. He was second engineer on a tow-boat running between Savannah and the River Tiber, South Carolina. He was regarded as a good hand, reliable, safe and all that, and had performed a great amount of hard labor for his masters. NORRIS looks as though he could do much service ye, even in a northern atmosphere, where he proposes to spend a few years or more, having taken his liberty in his own hands. Though not as bright looking as some negroes we have seen, he is yet sufficiently smart to have successfully played a card or two that will not be thought to be so bad. The tow-boat, it seems, had extended somewhat its regular trip and visited Charleston, in the harbor of which city it remained for a while. NORRIS, no doubt, had the freedom of the city, after a fashion. He appears to have made a practical use of the privilege extended to him. It is pretty certain that he went on board the Spaulding several times; that as a boatman he was a sort of boon companion with the crew and hands for the time; that he concluded to take passage, and finally that he did take passage. It seems that he got a good position on board, (in the fore part,) that he was not discovered, and that he arrived in Boston without putting the captain or anybody else either to the trouble or expense of stopping other vessels bound South or elsewhere. For his quiet conduct he is to be commended, and his example should not be forgotten by those who in the future take passage, under similar circumstances, from a Southern port. Immediately on stepping ashore he went to one of the depots of the Underground Railroad, and was at once forwarded to Canada.

It is pretty certain that he went on board the Spaulding several times; that as a boatman he was a sort of boon companion with the crew and hands for the time; that he concluded to take passage, and finally that he did take passage. It seems that he got a good position on board, (in the fore part,) that he was not discovered, and that he arrived in Boston without putting the captain or anybody else either to the trouble or expense of stopping other vessels bound South or elsewhere. For his quiet conduct he is to be commended, and his example should not be forgotten by those who in the future take passage, under similar circumstances, from a Southern port. Immediately on stepping ashore he went to one of the depots of the Underground Railroad, and was at once forwarded to Canada.

Dr. DE WITT, Chairman of the Executive Committee. After specifying the elementary principles of ...
lead_paragraph: The business meeting of the American Tract Society was held yesterday, at 9 o'clock, A.M., in Dr. HUTTON'S Church. In the absence of the President, Hon. THOMAS S. WILLIAMS, the meeting was called to order by Hon. WM. C. ALEXANDER, Vice-President. Prayer was offered by Rev. Dr. BURCHARD, of New-York. An introductory statement was read by Rev. Dr. DE WITT, Chairman of the Executive Committee. After specifying the elementary principles of the institution -- first, the union of Evangelical Christians for the diffusion of truths held by them in common; secondly, the spread of the cardinal doctrines of the Gospel. Dr. DE WITT stated that during the past year these principles had received unmistakable evidences of the divine approbation, that the efficiency of the colportage system bad been much increased, and that although the constitution had been lately subjected to new and severe tests, it had never been more impregnably established than when, as now it was made to harmonize differences respecting topics which had dissevered churches, societies and parties.

abstract: The United States frigate Roanoke, from Aspinwall on the 26th ult., with the Embassy dispatched by the Court of Jeddo to Washington, arrived at Sandy Hook last evening. Her Commander was then intercepted by dispatches from the Navy Department directing him to proceed at Hampton Roads, where a vessel would be in readiness to receive his illustrious, but outlandish passengers,
lead_paragraph: The United States frigate Roanoke, from Aspinwall on the 26th ult., with the Embassy dispatched by the Court of Jeddo to Washington, arrived at Sandy Hook last evening. Her Commander was then intercepted by dispatches from the Navy Department directing him to proceed at Hampton Roads, where a vessel would be in readiness to receive his illustrious, but outlandish passengers, and convey them to their destination. The Roanoke sails for Virginia accordingly this morning. The Japanese party appears to be equally gratified with the courtesy and respect with which it is treated, and with the novelty of its surroundings. The landing at Panama, that marvellous business of passing by rail across the Isthmus, the ceremonious reception on board the Roanoke, and the hospitality prepared for them there have been alike objects of satisfaction and gratitude. The officers express themselves as greatly pleased with the strangers, whose manners are the perfection of politeness and dignity. The account of the voyage and its incidents, furnished by the special reporter of this paper, will be read with lively interest.

abstract: The Associated Alumni of the Union Theological Seminary met in the Chapel of the Institute yesterday afternoon, at 3 o'clock, to celebrate their Eighteenth Anniversary. Prayer was offered by the President ...
lead_paragraph: The Associated Alumni of the Union Theological Seminary met in the Chapel of the Institute yesterday afternoon, at 3 o'clock, to celebrate their Eighteenth Anniversary. Prayer was offered by the President Rev. A.S. FREEMAN, of Haverstraw. The minutes of the last meeting were read and adopted. The following officers were elected for the coming year: President, Rev. SAMUEL W. FISHER, D.D.; Vice-Presidents, Rev. Messrs. W. Clift and C.P. Mills; Recording Secretary, Rev. H. Belden; Corresponding Secretary, Rev. L.P. Ledonx. The Alumni then proceeded, according to custom, to recount the "battles, sieges, fortunes they had passed" since their last meeting; and each member was expected to reveal, among other Items of information, any additions which had been made to his family.

abstract: The People of the State of New-York vs. James Bowen, et al -- This is an action brought by the Attorney-General, to restrain the defendants, as Corporators of the Metropolitan Gas Company, from organizing and operating under a charter granted in 1855. The action is based upon the ground that the act of the Legislature incorporating the Company is void, because it was not signed by the Governor until after the Legislature adjourned. This is claimed under Article 4; sec. 9, of the Constitution of the State The complaint also sets up other reasons: That the Company did not, within a year from the time of its incorporation, nor has it yet, gone into operation; that the act under which it was formed is void, because it establishes and fosters a monopoly, granting exclusive use of the streets of the City (if permitted by the Common Council) for the pipes of the Company. At the Special Term of the Court, Justice SUTHARLAND decided these questions adversely to the People, and the case now comes before the General Term on appeal from that decision. The questions involved were now argued at great length, and decision was reserved. The issues are really between the Manhattan Gas Company and the defendants, they alone being parties in interest.
lead_paragraph: The People of the State of New-York vs. James Bowen, et al -- This is an action brought by the Attorney-General, to restrain the defendants, as Corporators of the Metropolitan Gas Company, from organizing and operating under a charter granted in 1855. At the Special Term of the Court, Justice SUTHARLAND decided these questions adversely to the People, and the case now comes before the General Term on appeal from that decision. abstract: The Sunday schools connected with the various Universality Churches in New York and vicinity held their Anniversary yesterday afternoon, at Rev. Dr. CHAPIN'S Church, in Broadway. The weather showed itself no respector of persons or creeds, and did not treat the Universalist children with any more consideration than was shown to the young Evangelicals who celebrated under the auspices of the "Union" on the previous day.
lead_paragraph: The Sunday schools connected with the various Universality Churches in New York and vicinity held their Anniversary yesterday afternoon, at Rev. Dr. CHAPIN'S Church, in Broadway. The weather showed itself no respector of persons or creeds, and did not treat the Universalist children with any more consideration than was shown to the young Evangelicals who celebrated under the auspices of the "Union" on the previous day. They did not mind, the weather, however, any more than did the orthodox lambs, but turned out in full force, with their banners and ribbons; and, as one of the gentlemen who addressed them remarked, "their beaming [???]ces and sunny smiles amply compensated for the lowering sky and the absent solar rays." Neatly a thousand scholars were in attendance, representing five schools in New-York, two in Brooklyn and one in Williamsburgh, all of which are connected with Universalist churches, except one Mission School in this City. The whole number of Sunday-School scholars under the [???] of the Universalist den[???] New-York and vicinity is said to be about fifteen hundred.

abstract: The annual meeting of this Society was held last evening at Clinton Hall, Rev. Dr. DE WITT in the Chair, and after the presentation of the regular report by Rev. Dr. PINNEY, was addressed in truly eloquent terms by Hon. W.C. ALEXANDER, of New-Jersey, who urged in warm terms the claims of the Association to the support of every philanthropist. He was followed by Corn. FOOTE, U.S.N., who, after defending a book he had written, against the assaults of HENRY WARD BEECHER, narrated his experience during many years of service on the coast of Africa, and which had brought him to the conclusion that Liberia was the most suitable place for African colonization and civilization.

abstract: The friends of DOUGLAS controlled the Charleston Convention. They dictated the platform and had a majority in favor of their candidate. Their firmness broke up the Convention. A part of the Southern delegates had dictated terms to that body in advance,  and when they found their orders disobeyed they seceded and set up for themselves.
lead_paragraph: The friends of DOUGLAS controlled the Charleston Convention. They dictated the platform and had a majority in favor of their candidate. Their firmness broke up the Convention. A part of the Southern delegates had dictated terms to that body in advance, -- and when they found their orders disobeyed they seceded and set up for themselves. Both sections adjourned without doing anything; -- but both are to try again by-and-bye. The Seceders meet at Richmond on the 11th of June, -- the Nationals at Baltimore on the 18th. What will they do?

abstract: The anniversary exhibition of the pupils of the Institution for the Blind took place at the Academy of Music yesterday afternoon, attracting an audience of over two thousand persons.
lead_paragraph: The anniversary exhibition of the pupils of the Institution for the Blind took place at the Academy of Music yesterday afternoon, attracting an audience of over two thousand persons. All the larger pupils, numbering 180, were present, the girls tastily dressed in white. The whole number in the Institution is 205. As in former years, the public exercises consisted principally of vocal and instrumental music, interspersed with examinations of classes in the English branches. A piano solo by Miss MARY K. DELOSS, and a song by Miss MARY JANE HEATH, were very creditable performances, and were deservedly applauded. The band, composed wholly of the b[???]nd, played better than they have done for some years, showing excellent proficiency. Its members continue under the instruction of Mr. REIFF. The teacher of vocal music is Mr. LASON, who has tutored the children in the performance of difficult choru[???]es. In his absence, owing to illness, Mr. TIMM played the accompaniment. The classes in grammar, geography, arithmetic and familiar science, were successively examined, acquitting themselves fairly.

abstract: The Triennial Convention of the Brotherhood of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States was held yesterday at 11 A.M., in St. Ann's Church, Eighteenth-street, between Fifth and Sixth avenues. The meeting was very thinly attended, not more than thirty persons being present. Tne services were opened with the customary forms of Episcopalian worship; Rev. Dr. WELLS, of Boston, and Rev. GEO.
lead_paragraph: The Triennial Convention of the Brotherhood of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States was held yesterday at 11 A.M., in St. Ann's Church, Eighteenth-street, between Fifth and Sixth avenues. The meeting was very thinly attended, not more than thirty persons being present. Tne services were opened with the customary forms of Episcopalian worship; Rev. Dr. WELLS, of Boston, and Rev. GEO. LEAKIN, of Baltimore, the officiating clergymen. The discourse was delivered by Rev. THOS GALLAUDET, Rector of St. Ann's, his text being a portion of the 17th verse of the 2d chapter of 1 Peter, "Love the brotherhood." Dr. GALLAUDET considered this injunction one of the most important given by the apostles. Love to God and our neighbor should always temper our regard for our own welfare. It was to further this object that this organization was devised. He represented this Brotherhood as being simply a body of young men gathered together to visit the sick, succor the needy, invite those who otherwise would be disposed to violate the Sabbath to attend divine service, and other wise to advance the cause they had e[???]sed. The body should consist of at least 500 young members; they should number a proportion of those who labor for bread where God has placed them, It should be conducted upon the mutual-benefit system, but not so much so as to lead to selfishness. It should rather be made a sort of Church Exchange, where all may mingle together and communicate freely. Such organizations should be established in all the larger cities; they should always bear the noble objects of their creation in view, and so labor as some day of attain grand results. Dr. GALLAUDET said that, despite all obstacles, they had steadily held on their way for ten years. The existence of the Brotherhood was a proof that young Christians desired to work, were willing to leave [???] speculations, and enter the working ranks. The Christian Church is the one grand society that outstrips and overshadows all others. Jesus is its corner stone, and it is for his glory that all should chiefly labor. The Brotherhood should love the ministers of the Church and endeavor to support their efforts; they should also love the sacraments of the Church, and disseminate clear views in relation to these sacraments, doing away with the idea that communion is only meant for those who have nearly reached perfection. On the contrary, it is meant as an aid for those who are struggling on. Again he enjoined upon the Brotherhood to so love each other as to cause the unconverted in all parts of the earth to exclaim: "See how those Christians love one another," and to go forth from this day determined to make this organization more perfect than ever as a means for glorifying God and doing good to men. The services closed with the administering of communion.

abstract: In the United States Court, on Tuesday morning, Judge SMALLEY charged the Grand Jury concerning their duty in regard to presenting the officers engaged in the recent arrest and discharge of a slaver leaving this City. He read the statute of 1881, empowering the Court to punish such offences, summarily, without resorting to presentment by the Jury; but added that, in the present case, although the facts were fully before him in the form of affidavits, he preferred the matter should first be submitted to the Jury.

abstract: -- The London Spectator glorifies President BUCHANAN greatly for having made a stand in defence of the Constitution of his country by protesting against any inquiry into his official conduct on the part of Congress. It notices with satisfaction that "public journals in London which have not been distinguished by their sympathy with America, or with JAMES BUCHANAN in particular -- nay, the most ministerial organs in the British capital -- are as hearty and as emphatic in their approval of the President's course as if he had been an Englishman."

abstract: The Baltimore Constitutional Convention achieved the object of its meeting, yesterday, by nominating for President JOHN BELL, of Tennessee,  and for Vice-President, EDWARD EVERETT, of Massachusetts. Upon the first ballot, the strength of Mr. BELL was so clearly apparent, that upon the second, nearly all the delegates hastened to record their votes for him; and he was declared the unanimous choice of the Convention.
lead_paragraph: The Baltimore Constitutional Convention achieved the object of its meeting, yesterday, by nominating for President JOHN BELL, of Tennessee, and for Vice-President, EDWARD EVERETT, of Massachusetts. Upon the first ballot, the strength of Mr. BELL was so clearly apparent, that upon the second, nearly all the delegates hastened to record their votes for him; and he was declared the unanimous choice of the Convention. Mr. EVERETT was subsequently, and by acclamation, named for the second office. Prior to the balloting, the Committee upon Business reported a preamble and resolutions adverse to the utterance of any declaration of principles; pronouncing the Constitution itself a sufficient platform with which to go before the people. The proceedings were marked with exemplary harmony, notwithstanding some of the advocates of Gen. HOUSTON bear their disappointment impatiently. Hopes are entertained that for BELL, and EVERETT, should the Democracy not reunite, nearly all the Southern States may be carried; and even should the Democratic schism be repaired, North Carolina and Louisiana are counted upon.

abstract: The annual business meeting of the American Bible Society was held at 9 o'clock yesterday morning, at the Bible House, Hon. THEO. FRELINGHUYSEN in the Chair, supported by a number of Vice-Presidents. After prayer by Rev. WALTER CLARKE, the President appointed Francis Hall, Dr. Butler, James Brown, Wm. W. Chester and Horace Holden to nominate candidates for the office of Managers.
lead_paragraph: The annual business meeting of the American Bible Society was held at 9 o'clock yesterday morning, at the Bible House, Hon. THEO. FRELINGHUYSEN in the Chair, supported by a number of Vice-Presidents. After prayer by Rev. WALTER CLARKE, the President appointed Francis Hall, Dr. Butler, James Brown, Wm. W. Chester and Horace Holden to nominate candidates for the office of Managers. The Committee retired, and soon after reported the following Managers for the next four years: Norman White, William Forrest, Frederic S. Winston, Ralph Mead, Archibald Russell, Frederic H. Woolcott, James W. Dominick and William E. Dodge, with Henry J. Baker to fill the vacancy occasioned by the death of Najah Taylor. A motion was then carried that the new Board of Managers should meet on the third Thursday of May to organize. A motion was also carried, inviting strangers in the City to visit the Bible House and view its workings. The President then declared the meeting adjourned to the second Monday in May, 1861. The assembly then proceeded in a body to the Academy of Music, where the anniversary exercises were held.

abstract: Joel W. Foote, residing at No. 174 West Twenty-first-street, and Cornelius Totten, a real-estate broker, having an office at No. 12 Wall-street, were yesterday arrested and detained for examination on a charge of having been engaged with Charles G. Thompson, Charles P. Thompson, Smith Wilcox, Albert S. Wells, Hamilton W. Shipman and Thomas Lawson in the recent alleged fraudulent sales of up-town lots. Within a few days, Emiliano Bergomini and Dominico Cella, both Spanish gentlemen, who formerly were joint owners of a farm in Orange County, New-Jersey, have sworn to the fact that during the month of last January they were induced, by an advertisement in the daily papers, to visit the office of Charles G. Thompson, who represented himself to be a real-estate broker, for the purpose of disposing of their property. At the interview, Thompson agreed with Mr. Bergomini to exchange the farm for certain lots in Ninety-fifth and Ninety-sixth streets, which he said belonged to Lawson, whom he represented to be a person of vast wealth, nearly connected with George Law, and an intimate associate of Ex-Senator Wescott. Subsequently Thompson visited the farm in question, appraised its value at $6,000, and the necessary papers required in a legal transfer of the up-town real estate were made out and furnished by Thompson, Lawson and Shipman, who in turn received from the Spaniards a deed of the Jersey farm. Mr. Bergamini not long afterwards ascertained that the lots in Ninety-fifth and Ninety-sixth streets, which had been with such facility deeded to himself and friend, were the property of the Messrs. Van Henvel, and that Thompson and Company had not the shadow of a claim to them. So frequently has the farm which Mr. Bergamini once owned passed from one sharper to another that, so far, he has failed to discover the original deed. Another gentleman, also an owner of property in New-Jersey, has been victimized in a similar manner, and he is now preparing the necessary affidavits against the accused, who in this instance disposed, it is said, of the real estate of F.B. Cutting, Esq., without that gentleman's assent. The younger Thompson is also made the subject of a charge of perjury, preferred by the District-Attorney. It is alleged that he lately went bail for his father, who had been arrested on a complaint for false pretences, and swore before Justice Quackenbush that the house and lot No. 96 East Twenty-sixth-street, valued at $12,000; was his property. It has since transpired that the owners of the house and lot are Messrs. Nunns & Clark, piano-forte dealers, and that Thompson had no claim to the property. The case is still under investigation by Justice WELSH, and the testimony against the parties in custody is said to be very strong, while many others are suspected of complicity in the transactions.

abstract: It is perfectly natural that the conservative statesmen and publicists of England should feel seriously alarmed at the rapid extension of the basis of political representation in English society, and not very unnatural, therefore, that they should eagerly seize upon every symptom of disease and disorder in the political system of the United States, to hold it up as a warning of the perils which are inherent in the absolute practice of popular ...
lead_paragraph: It is perfectly natural that the conservative statesmen and publicists of England should feel seriously alarmed at the rapid extension of the basis of political representation in English society, and not very unnatural, therefore, that they should eagerly seize upon every symptom of disease and disorder in the political system of the United States, to hold it up as a warning of the perils which are inherent in the absolute practice of popular government. The wisest thinkers will always be the slowest to pronounce upon the share which this or that political institution may have played in the development of national greatness and prosperity; and as England has unquestionably made enormous progress in the substantial elements of individual well-being and general liberty, under the curious and complex forms of her actual Constitution, it is no positive indication either of political blindness or of social prejudice, that Englishmen of intelligence should shrink from adventuring upon changes, both political and social, so grave and radical as may be expected to follow upon any near approach to that almost universal enjoyment of the right of suffrage which prevails in the United States.

abstract: After much tribulation, we have at last one Presidential Candidate fairly in the field. The Union Convention at Baltimore yesterday nominated JOHN BELL, of Tennessee, for President, and EDWARD EVERETT for Vice-President. Two more respectable names could not be found in the country, nor will any one doubt that in their hands the Government would be administered with ability, dignity and the most conscientious devotion to the honor and welfare of the whole country.

abstract: Mr. BUCHANAN'S appointment of CALHOUN BENHAM, the second of Judge TERRY in the duel with BRODERICK, to the office of DistrictAttorney in San Francisco, is a fresh illustration of his contempt, we will not say for public opinion, but for common decency. It is a crime to fight a duel, even if it prove a bloodless duel, or to assist another in fighting one; ...
lead_paragraph: Mr. BUCHANAN's appointment of CALHOUN BENHAM, the second of Judge TERRY in the duel with BRODERICK, to the office of DistrictAttorney in San Francisco, is a fresh illustration of his contempt, we will not say for public opinion, but for common decency. It is a crime to fight a duel, even if it prove a bloodless duel, or to assist another in fighting one; but when the conflict eventuates in a very cool and deliberate murder, the offence receives the last degree of aggravation. The guilt of causing BRODERICK's death rests, of course, in the first instance on TERRY, but in the second on BENHAM, who seems to have assisted in the matter with a very hearty good will, and to have hated BRODERICK with a very hearty hatred. He stands at this moment, in the eye of the law in California, in the position of an accessory to a murder. That he may not be tried for it, and will certainly not be convicted of it, is a circumstance which, though it may furnish consolation to himself, does not in the least improve his position as a candidate for public employment. And if there is any position in the public service for which his antecedents render him peculiarly unfitted, it is that of an officer whose duty it is to put the laws in force against criminals. Mr. CALHOUN BENHAM could not enter a Court and appeal to a jury to punish willful offences against society without either amusing them by his impudence, or enraging them by his hypocrisy; and any community which could witness such a spectacle without shame, would be much too far gone in iniquity for either Courts or laws to do it much good.

abstract: COMMISSIONERS OF EMIGRATION. The Commissioners of Emigration held their weekly session on Wednesday afternoon, at Castle Garden. A full Board present Mr. VERPLANCK, the President, in the Chair. Mr. VERPLANCK asked how much was owing to different counties of the State for supplies furnished emigrants, and the care of them during detention by sickness, in passing through their counties.
lead_paragraph: COMMISSIONERS OF EMIGRATION. -- The Commissioners of Emigration held their weekly session on Wednesday afternoon, at Castle Garden. A full Board present -- Mr. VERPLANCK, the President, in the Chair. Mr. VERPLANCK asked how much was owing to different counties of the State for supplies furnished emigrants, and the care of them during detention by sickness, in passing through their counties. It was stated in reply that on the 1st of January the indebtedness was $19,600, and that the present indebtedness was probably one-half more. It was urged by Mr. VERPLANCK that the entire amount ought to be ascertained at once, and the debts paid. No action was, however, taken in the matter. A communication was received from Dr. GUNN, the Health Officer, renewing his application for $1,200, to cover the amount incurred by him for house-rent. He takes the ground that, inasmuch as his predecessors in office were furnished with a house free of rent, he should be relieved from rent-paying. The communication was laid on the table. An application was submitted by Commissioner CRABTREE to send back to Galway, at the expense of the Commission, an emigrant recently arrived, who was sick with consumption. It was suggested that, in case of granting the application, there would soon come pouring in all sorts of petitions from all sorts of emigrants, complaining of all sorts of diseases, as pretexts for getting home again. The application, notwithstanding this fling of opposition, was referred to the Vice-President with power. The weekly statement gives the number of emigrants arrived during the past week as 5,277, making the total arrivals since the 1st of January 19,005 -- an increase of 5,554 over the arrivals for the same period last year. The present number of inmates on Ward's Island and in the Marine Hospital is 719. During the past week there has been received for commutation of passengers $8,754, making the aggregate receipts for commutation since the beginning of the year $93,501 67, leaving, after deducting total disbursements, the present balance in the treasury $24,508 53.

abstract: We deeply regret that we are obliged to announce the death of Mr. S.G. GOODRICH, more widely known as "Peter Parley," the pseudonym under which he acquired his reputation. He died very suddenly, at his residence in Ninth-street, of disease of the heart. Mr. GOODRICH was a native of Connecticut, and was born in 1793, though no one would have judged from his appearance that he was so nearly seventy years old.
lead_paragraph: We deeply regret that we are obliged to announce the death of Mr. S.G. GOODRICH, more widely known as "Peter Parley," -- the pseudonym under which he acquired his reputation. He died very suddenly, at his residence in Ninth-street, of disease of the heart. Mr. GOODRICH was a native of Connecticut, and was born in 1793, -- though no one would have judged from his appearance that he was so nearly seventy years old. He had a vigorous constitution, which he preserved to the last by care and regularity in his mode of life. He began life as a publisher, first in Hartford and afterwards in Boston, -- and edited in the days of Annuals one of the most celebrated of them, the Token, from 1828 to 1842. His greatest success, however, was achieved in compiling books for children, -- designed to convey instruction in natural history, travels, biography, and various branches of science and art, by simply-written narratives and anecdotes, copiously illustrated by engravings. He wrote as "Peter Parley" telling stories to children, and for many years the series of works thus published, extending to over forty volumes, had an enormous circulation, both in this country and abroad. They introduced a class of books which have since become universal. In 1841, he established a periodical called Merry's Museum, based upon the same general plan, which he continued until 1854. In 1857, he published two volumes of Recollections, -- containing an immense amount of exceedingly interesting memoranda concerning men and events in Connecticut, and forming one of the most readable books of the day. Mr. GOODRICH was appointed American Consul at Paris under Mr. FILLMORE, and held that office for several years. He performed its duties with great fidelity, and enjoyed the respect and esteem of all with whom he came in contact. He published several works while there calculated to diffuse a more general knowledge of America and its institutions, and upon his return prepared an elaborate and admirable illustrated History of the Animal Kingdom, which was issued last year in two large and elegant volumes. He was a man of great diligence, and continued to prosecute his literary labors to the latest period of his life.

abstract: COURT OF SESSIONS. The Grand Jury came into Court yesterday and presented twenty-eight indictments, fourteen of which were for selling liquor without a license. JOHN ROBSON, indicted for forgery in the fourth degree, was arraigned and pleaded guilty. CHARLES JONES pleaded guilty to an indictment for keeping a gambling house, and several persons indicted for selling liquor without license pleaded guilty, and were fined ten dollars each.
lead_paragraph: COURT OF SESSIONS. -- The Grand Jury came into Court yesterday and presented twenty-eight indictments, fourteen of which were for selling liquor without a license. JOHN ROBSON, indicted for forgery in the fourth degree, was arraigned and pleaded guilty. CHARLES JONES pleaded guilty to an indictment for keeping a gambling house, and several persons indicted for selling liquor without license pleaded guilty, and were fined ten dollars each.

abstract: The Academy of Music was well filled, last night, to witness the ninth anniversary of the Five Points House of Industry. About 250 children, male and female, including a small sprinkling of colored juveniles, represented the good work which Mr. PEASE, with his coadjutors, has been doing for the City during the past year.
lead_paragraph: The Academy of Music was well filled, last night, to witness the ninth anniversary of the Five Points House of Industry. About 250 children, male and female, including a small sprinkling of colored juveniles, represented the good work which Mr. PEASE, with his coadjutors, has been doing for the City during the past year. A very admirable sight they were, cleanly in apparel, though a few of them disdained the conventionalism of shoes and stockings. A raised platform, of very slight construction, had been erected in the rear of the stage, but as soon as they were seated thereon, and before the commencement of the exercises of the evening, it gave way with a crash that alarmed the audience, and sent the children pell mell to the floor. Fortunately none were hurt, though all were a good deal frightened. The officers of the Society, and the police in attendance, soon restored order, cleared away the ruins, and made new seats for the little ones, who, when their alarm subsided, seemed to enjoy the accident. The smallest children, who speedily became very sleepy -- their ages ranging from three to six years -- were displayed in semi-circular order, near the footlights, and detained there in opposition to their desire to retire into private life. The ceremonies were commenced by a lively clapping of five hundred little hands, at a signal given by a lady teacher, followed by a hymn sung by half the number of little voices. Of all the singers who have sung on that stage -- PICCOLOMINI, GAZZANIGA, PATTI, will forgive us -- no one has ever more deeply touched the hearts of an audience than did one little girl, who led the rest, and when the chorus, "I'll be a good child, indeed I will," was given more heartily than artistically by the infant crowd, there were many moist eyes among the auditors. Prayer was offered by Rev. Mr. GANST, after which the annual report was read by Mr. ARCHIBALD RUSSELL, the President. It was quite encouraging. After the expenditure of $2,612 for the Society's farm in Westchester County, the current expenses of the Institution, amounting to $16,981, and the payment of the principal on the debt of the building, amounting to $20,311, there remained cash in hand $116. Of meals given gratuitously, there had been in the last year no less than 276,862. Of articles of clothing given away, 12,000; pairs of shoes, 1,200; sent to situations, 372; to their friends, 130. The meeting was addressed by Rev. COTTON SMITH, of the Church of the Ascension, in Tenth-street; Hon. JAS. A. BRIGGS, of Ohio, and Hon. HENRY J. RAYMOND. A collection was taken up, and the audience separated.

HOUSTON for the Presidency, with EDWARD EVERETT for Vice-President. Though the current had, during the night, set strongly against HOUSTON, his supporters had been very busy. It was understood that a damaging break had been made against HOUSTON in the New-York delegation, and that BELL would receive ten to fifteen votes from that state.

abstract: The Mobile Register says: "Through the courtesy of Mr. Justice HESSEE, a member of the National Executive Committee, we are enabled to copy the original dispatch in which Mr. DOUGLAS withdrew his name from before the Cincinnati Convention, when Mr. BUCHANAN had reached an absolute majority of the electoral vote. The principles which it establishes, the precedent which it sets, and the unselfishness and generosity which mark it, lend it a peculiar interest at this time and form a contrast not over-flattering to some of Mr. DOUGLAS' competitors."

abstract: The enlargement of the circulation of the TIMES is at the present moment so rapid as to render it imperative that advertisements intended for the daily issue should be sent in at the earliest possible moment. Announcements which fail to reach the office before nine o'clock P.M., lose all the advantages of classification under the heads to which readers are accustomed to refer. It is, therefore, quite as important to the advertisers as to ourselves, to have that hour the latest for the reception of their notices.

lead_paragraph: ALEXANDER MCKENZIE, a middle-aged Scotchman, was committed to the Almshouse, Black well's Islands, on the 7th inst., as a pauper, and assigned to a wayo on the third floor of the building. The next day he was found sick, and, towards evening, while in ace inform, he got out of bed and leaped from the balcony, which exteres around the building, striaing, in his descent, the balcony of the story below, which had the effect of partially breaking the force of the fall. He lose from the ground, and ran a distance of twenty [???]ods before he was secured. His death resulted twenty-four hours later, when a post-mortem examination showed that he had died from inflammation of the lungs, and that, his tearful leap had not injured him at all. Coroner O'KEEFE held an inquest upon the body, and the jury closed their verdict with a recommendation that the Commissioners of Public Charities have suitable bars paced to the windows of the hospital wards, in order to guard against accidents to patients suffering under sudden attacks of delirium.
