abstract: In pursuance of the call for the meeting of sympathy with the colored persons imprisoned in Philadelphia for participating in the recent attempt to rescue fugitive slaves, 43 persons, five of them white, gathered in Shilah Church last evening. The exercises were opened with prayer, and addresses were delivered by Rev. M.M. GARNETT and others, the former of whom, however, was the only one who seemed to remember the actual purpose of the meeting, which was to raise funds to pay the counsel fees and expenses of the nine colored men now under indictment for attempting to rescue a fugitive slave. The other speakers limited themselves to a general abjurgating of the Constitution, Slavery and the Fugitive Slave law. A meeting is to be held on Monday night, at 7 1/2 o'clock, in the church of Rev. Mr. RAY, Sullivan street, of those opposed to the "African Civilization Society."

abstract: The intelligence of the death of Baron BRUCK, the Austrian Finance Minister, is followed by the astounding announcement that he killed himself because recent investigations had led to the discovery that he was guilty, along with others, of great peculations and embezzlements. The Wiener Zeitung officially announces that on the 20th inst. Baron BRUCK gave evidence respecting the frauds committed by Gen. EYNATTEN, the head of the Austrian Commissariat Department, who hung himself after he had been arrested, in consequence of the detection of his peculations and frauds during the war in Italy. "Baron BRUCK's examination," says the official journal, "gave rise to further inquiries, which would probably have led to his complicity with other witnesses and accused parties." So the Emperor FRANCIS JOSEPH, by an autograph letter, removed Baron BRUCK from his office, which was temporarily intrusted to Councilor PLEUER. The Imperial letter was delivered to the guilty Minister on Sunday evening last, and on Monday morning Baron BRUCK was found bleeding to death in his bed. He had partly cut his throat, and had severed the arteries of his wrists, and his death appears to have been caused by the consequent hemorrhage, though it seems to be suspected that he had likewise taken poison.

abstract: JOHN C. BELL, the Assemblyman from Eldorado County, is dead. Last Wednesday noon he stood in the Sergeant-at-Arms'room, adjoining the Chamber where the Assembly was in session, the door between the two rooms being open, talking in a low voice with another member. Dr. STONE, a lobby member, whose business at the capital was to procure a division of Eldorado County, stepped up and joined in the conversation.
lead_paragraph: From Our Own Correspondent.

abstract: Complaints were made yesterday before Justice CONNOLLY against Henry Van Velsor and John Harden, the alleged proprietors of a gambling-saloon at the [???] corner of Hudson and Duane-streets, and Robert Sutton, Anthony Reminger and George Jerv[???] the [???]ept [???] keepers of a similar establishment at No. 1[???]8 Chatham-street. The complainant in the case is Joseph Marsh, residing at No. 50 Park-street, who confesses that within the past two months he has lost $175 at the game of fato in the bouses of the accused. Dissatisfied with his luck, he determined to reform his habits, and is now exerting himself to break up all the unlawful places of the character complained of. The accused were arrested, and required to give bail in $5[???]0 each for trial.

abstract: INDECORUM IN COURTS OF JUSTICE. -- The dull monotony of decent and orderly behavior which usually characterizes our Courts of law, was Thursday varied by a strong gust of personal slang quite worthy of Congress. During the progress of a trial in the Court of Common Pleas, the counsel being, on one side, a lawyer of extensive criminal practice and of some legislative experience, and on the other a German, the crowded audience enjoyed a pungent feast, which reflected anything but credit on the actors, or the Court that tolerated the fray. For a time the merits of the cause on trial were entirely forgotten, and counsel joined, without interference from the Bench, in a Congressional brush, in the course of which the expressive and elegant epithets of "Dutchman," "Pettifogger," "Tombs Skinner" and "Fellow," were mutually applied, with the same flippant gusto with which lawyers usually allude to their "learned friend" "the learned counsel," and similar expressions of legal etiquette.

abstract: The People ex rel. Walter W. Price vs. Spencer H. Smith. -- It will be remembered that in this case, which was tried at the Circuit, before Justice JAMES, the Court held that as the defendant, who had the majority of votes, was a non-resident of the military district in which the election was held, he was not entitled to the office of Colonel. The election was therefore set aside.

abstract: A meeting in behalf of the above Society was held yesterday morning in Rev. Dr. ADAMS' Church, Madison-square, WM.E. DODGE, Esq., in the Chair. A very large audience was in attendance. The exercises were opened with prayer from Rev. Dr. FERRIS. One of the Secretaries of the Board, Rev. GEORGE W. WOOD, read a statement of the results of missionary labors connected with the Board during the past year together with a summary of the total results since the organization of the Board fifty years ago. According to this statement, the field of missionary labor has extended over the four continents of the globe and most of the islands of the Pacific. Fifteen unwritten languages have been reduced to writing by the Board, and the Bible, in whole or in part, has been translated into more than twenty. Upwards of 50,000 converts have been added to the Christian Church, the larger portion during the last fifteen years. The average yearly number of converts for the last ten years has been 1,500. The number of ordained missionaries now in the service of the Society is 172, of whom 9 are physicians. The laborers in the various fields, including unordained missionaries, number 389. Besides these, there are 881 native laborers in the service of the Board.

abstract: MERCANTILE LIBRARY ASSOCIATION. Last evening the discussion on the subject of increasing the annual dues of the members of the Mercantile Library Association was resumed in the Lectureroom at Clinton Hall. The Chair was occupied by GEO. W. BLUNT, Esq., who filled it on Tuesday evening last the occasion of the annual meeting at which time the consideration of the matter in question had been postponed.
lead_paragraph: MERCANTILE LIBRARY ASSOCIATION. -- Last evening the discussion on the subject of increasing the annual dues of the members of the Mercantile Library Association was resumed in the Lectureroom at Clinton Hall. The Chair was occupied by GEO. W. BLUNT, Esq., who filled it on Tuesday evening last the occasion of the annual meeting -- at which time the consideration of the matter in question had been postponed. A proposition to amend the by-laws to the effect that the yearly dues of those who did not come within the category of "merchants' clerks" should be increased, was debated, and voted down by a heavy majority. Mr. WOOD offered a resolution asking the appointment of a committee of seven, with power to examine into the fiscal condition of the Association, and report at a next meeting to be held two weeks hence, as to the necessity of increasing the annual dues. It gave rise to a long discussion, and resulted in not passing -- the prevailing expression evincing a want of faith in the ability of any committee to harmonize the extremely conflicting sentiments on the subject, and a desire to arrive at a decision then. A motion followed, proposing that the dues of regular members be increased $1 per year. This resulted in a long and spirited debate in the course of which it became evident that the friends and opponents of the measure were pretty equally divided as to numbers, and the question having been taken, it was found to have been lost by a constitutional vote -- 142 having declared in its favor and 128 against it. The meeting immediately afterwards adjourned sine die.

abstract: The past has been a week of festivities in Florence and in other cities of Tuscany. The visit of the King to this new portion of his dominions has been made the occasion of a general outbreak of joy. Florence, during the few years that I have known it, has been many times decorated with festive ornaments, but it has never worn so gay and graceful an aspect as on this last most happy occasion.
lead_paragraph: From Our Own Correspondent.

abstract: The political condition of the country is as completely chaotic as the most zealous lover of disorder could possibly desire. At no period within twenty-five years has there been so complete a rupture of all the bonds that usually hold parties together, or such an entire uncertainty as to the prospects of a pending Presidential election.
lead_paragraph: The political condition of the country is as completely chaotic as the most zealous lover of disorder could possibly desire. At no period within twenty-five years has there been so complete a rupture of all the bonds that usually hold parties together, or such an entire uncertainty as to the prospects of a pending Presidential election. The Democratic Party which has preserved a form of nationality longer than any other, has at last been rent asunder by the same influences which have destroyed all other political organizations. Whether it can come together again, even in form, is a matter of great doubt: but even if it does, it cannot fail to lose nearly all the moral strength which it derived from its former union. It is becoming evident that the Southern Democrats do not intend to abandon their ground, or to waive their demands upon the party at large. The tone and language of their leading organs and their public men, show conclusively that they will insist upon the distinct recognition of slaves as property under the Federal Constitution, and upon the duty of all departments of the Federal Government to protect that property wherever it may be. We see nothing to indicate a purpose on their part to waive this demand. They may possibly consent to say nothing of it in their Platform, provided the candidate shall be a man sufficiently pledged by his life and opinions to its recognition. But the Northern wing of their Party cannot concede such a candidate, or such a platform, without the certainty of disaster and ruin in every Northern State. The only chance they have of preserving anything of their local ascendancy, is by resisting to the last extremity every attempt to fasten upon them the responsibility for such a creed.

abstract: In the House of Commons on the 27th, Lord JOHN RUSLELL explained the present position of the negotiations for a Congress on the Savoy question. He stated that the French Government thought the Congress could not meet until the Sardinian Parliamen had ratified the cession of Savoy, and that they demurred to the proposal that there should be no civil or military occupation of Savoy until the decision of the Conference was arrived at. The Prussian Government held the same views as the English Cabinet, but the other Powers had not been communicated with.

abstract: The Southern Delegates in the Convention present, as their patriotic and triumphant ultimatum, what every Black Republican and Squatter Sovereignty Democrat in the whole Union may support. This is, certainly, a most remarkable way of vindicating the rights of the South! And when do they propose to present this august "ultimatum?" Why, after the nomination of President and Vice-President of the United States is completed. By a resolution, which they voted for, the Convention determined that no nomination for President or Vice-President should be made until the Convention had first settled the platform of principles upon which the nominations should rest. The Convention, after six days' agitation and debate, has adopted the platform upon which it proposes to put its nominees. That platform is Squatter Sovereignty. The resolutions, affirming the rights of the South, have been rejected; and now, after both platform and nomination shall be completed -- and not before -- these heroic vindicators of the rights of the South propose to introduce into the Convention the miserable cheat invented by New York "as the ultimatum of the South." Suppose that this ultimatum was rejected (of which, however, there is not the slightest probability), what would they do? Go out of the Convention? The Convention will go out itself; for, having accomplished by their aid all it came to do (made a platform and nominated candidates on it for the Presidency), of course it will adjourn. The only danger is, that the Convention, having finished its business, may adjourn without considering the grand "ultimatum of the South," and thus get out before the delegates from Virginia, Tennessee and Kentucky. There may yet be a pretty race.
lead_paragraph: The Southern Delegates in the Convention present, as their patriotic and triumphant ultimatum, what every Black Republican and Squatter Sovereignty Democrat in the whole Union may support. This is, certainly, a most remarkable way of vindicating the rights of the South! And when do they propose to present this august "ultimatum?" Why, after the nomination of President and Vice-President of the United States is completed. By a resolution, which they voted for, the Convention determined that no nomination for President or Vice-President should be made until the Convention had first settled the platform of principles upon which the nominations should rest. The Convention, after six days' agitation and debate, has adopted the platform upon which it proposes to put its nominees. That platform is Squatter Sovereignty. The resolutions, affirming the rights of the South, have been rejected; and now, after both platform and nomination shall be completed -- and not before -- these heroic vindicators of the rights of the South propose to introduce into the Convention the miserable cheat invented by New York "as the ultimatum of the South." Suppose that this ultimatum was rejected (of which, however, there is not the slightest probability), what would they do? Go out of the Convention? The Convention will go out itself; for, having accomplished by their aid all it came to do (made a platform and nominated candidates on it for the Presidency), of course it will adjourn. The only danger is, that the Convention, having finished its business, may adjourn without considering the grand "ultimatum of the South," and thus get out before the delegates from Virginia, Tennessee and Kentucky. There may yet be a pretty race.

abstract: The arrival of the Asia places us in possession of the following report of some very extraordinary legal proceedings before the Queen's Bench in London, arising out of the great fight. A rule nisi, calling on Mr. DOWLING, the referee, to show cause why a mandamus should not issue directing him to deliver the champion's belt to JOHN C. HEENAN, was obtained by Mr. EDWIN JAMES, Q.C., some weeks ago, and the matter came up for argument the day before the steamer left Southampton, before Lord Chief Justice CAMPBELL and a full bench. The Court was thronged to suffocation, not only by the sporting fraternity, but by the most distinguished members of all the professions, as well as the leaders of politics and fashion. Amongst those who were accommodated with seats on the bench, our reporter noticed Mr. Gladstone, Lord Palmerston, Archbishop Whately, the Benicia Boy, the Marquis of Westminster, Geo. Wilkes Esq., the Duke of Argyle, Alfred Tennyson, Jack Macdonald, the Duchess of Sutherland, Lady Ellsmere, Mr. Dallas, Mr. Stuart Mill, the political economist, and several others of equal respectability. In fact, the extreme politeness of the Judges was the means of subjecting themselves to considerable inconvenience, as their lordships could with difficulty use their pens. There was a very large attendance of the Bar. Mr. Edwin James, Q.C., Mr. Scoville, Q.C., Mr. Roundell Palmer, Q.C., and Sir Richard Bethell, appeared for the Benicia Boy; the Attorney and Solicitor-General, Sergeant Wilkins, and Mr. Robinson, Q.C., for the Referee. TOM SAYERS, Mr. DOWLING, and one of his seconds, were in Court, but sat beside the Attorney-General in the inner bar.

abstract: A NEW ROMAN CATHOLIC CHURCH IN ALBANY. -- The Church of St. Joseph, in Albany, the handsomest parish Catholic church in the world, is to be dedicated on Sunday by Bishop MCCLOSKY. Archbishop HUGHES is to preach in the morning and Archbishop FITZPATRICK in the evening. The corner-stone of this church was laid four years ago. The painting and marbleizing of the channel sanctuary and station -- the architectural adornings of the main altar, with its seraphims and various sculptures, are said to surpass anything of the kind in this country.

abstract: -- Our Government offices have some queer appendages; but "they do these things better in France." For in the budget of the Imperial Printing-office, which is now before the Legislative Body, a conspicuous item may be seen, and this item is -- cats. To the curious an explanation is offered as follows: The department has vast stores of paper, printed and unprinted; to preserve these stores from the nibblings of rats and mice, cats are brought into requisition, and their food and the salary of their keeper is the item to which allusion has been made. But about the cats -- thereby hangs a tail. On one occasion they came near becoming what a certain Southern paper would style "the teterrima causa of all belli" between the Directors of the Printing-office and the Director of the Archives. The latter had an artificial pond in his garden which he kept stocked with rare aquatic birds; the cats pitched into the birds, and then the archives man pitched into the cats. The keeper of the feline stock perceived that his numbers grew "small by degrees and beautifully less," and at last discovered the cause. The Director of the Printing-office said he wouldn't have his cats killed; the Director of Archives said he wouldn't allow his birds to be devoured, and an internecine war was all but declared between the two officials, when a compromise was effected which resulted in insuring safety and life to both cats and birds. What an army of cats it would require to keep nibblers away from the public printing at Washington!
lead_paragraph: -- Our Government offices have some queer appendages; but "they do these things better in France." For in the budget of the Imperial Printing-office, which is now before the Legislative Body, a conspicuous item may be seen, and this item is -- cats. But about the cats -- thereby hangs a tail. On one occasion they came near becoming what a certain Southern paper would style "the teterrima causa of all belli" between the Directors of the Printing-office and the Director of the Archives. The latter had an artificial pond in his garden which he kept stocked with rare aquatic birds; the cats pitched into the birds, and then the archives man pitched into the cats. The keeper of the feline stock perceived that his numbers grew "small by degrees and beautifully less," and at last discovered the cause. The Director of the Printing-office said he wouldn't have his cats killed; the Director of Archives said he wouldn't allow his birds to be devoured, and an internecine war was all but declared between the two officials, when a compromise was effected which resulted in insuring safety and life to both cats and birds. abstract: As a great many emphatic and veracious Southern gentlemen have assured the country that the election of Mr. SHERMAN to the Speakership of the House of Representatives would have been instantly followed by the dissolution of the Union, and the advance of Governor WISE upon Washington at the head of the Harper's Ferry militia, we ought, of course, as good patriots, to rejoice that so great a calamity was averted, and that in Mr. PENNINGTON we found a happy delivery from our peril. But the part which was played by the member from Ohio, in a scene which yesterday diversified the dull monotony of Legislative business, might almost provoke us to regret that the official mace does not repose in hands which would use it so effectually upon the pates of the vulgar and the refractory among our senatorial sages.

abstract: The Asia, bringing European files and correspondence to April 28, and telegraphic advices by way of Queenstown to the 29th, reached this port in time to admit an outline of the news into a portion of our edition of yesterday morning. There is nothing of striking interest. The late fight continues to engage attention in England, and a renewal of the combat will take place, it is understood, as soon as SAYERS is in fighting condition. In the meantime the golden shower continues to fall upon that hero -- members of the House of Commons having contributed Â£200 to the growing fund. At the Newmarket races, the late antagonists had met, and associated upon the most friendly terms. The frauds of PULLINGER, late Cashier of the Union Bank, were undergoing careful investigation. The peculator had been brought up before the Magistrates for investigation on the 27th, but the matter had been postponed for a week. Rumors of a fresh attempt upon the life of the Emperor of France, on the occasion of the fete of the Empress, were transmitted from Paris, but were not credited. The death of Baron BRUCK, the Austrian Minister of Finance, proves to have been suicide. The recent investigation into official peculation had involved the Baron, who had been suspended from office. He at once put an end to his life by cutting his throat. The new Governor of Hungary, Gen. BENEDEK, is not well received by the liberal party in that country, who recognize in his unvarying devotion to the House of Hapsburg anything but a pledge of concession to the views of the progressives. Rumors of a change in the Austrian Cabinet obtained currency. Baron HUBNER, who represents the Liberal party, had been summoned to form a new Cabinet, into which Count RECHBERG would only find admission upon the abandonment of his ultra-conservative views. The remaining intelligence from the continent lacks importance. The news from Japan is to the effect that affairs remain extremely unsettled, and that the lives of the foreign residents are not regarded as secure.

abstract: The tenth anniversary of the American Swedenborg Printing and Publishing Society, and the third of the American New Church Association, a sister organization, were jointly celebrated Thursday evening in the small but elegant church edifice in Thirty-fifth-street, belonging to this still comparatively unknown body of Christians. Mr. T. HITCHCOCK, Secretary of the Board of Managers of the first-named Society, gave a synopsis of its doings during the past year. They had sold 1,892 volumes of SWEDENBORG's writings, the proceeds of which amount to $1,073 35; and the receipts from dues and donations increase this sum by $731. Although the operations of the Society might appear to be insignificant the members were not discouraged, as the result of their labors was to be looked for in the future rather than the present.

abstract: FIREMEN's PARADE. -- The Hudson Fire Department paraded on Thursday evening, to receive Eagle Hose Company No. 2 on their return from New-York with their new carriage. The companies turned out in large numbers and went to Hoboken, where they were received by the Fire Department of that city and escorted to the ferry to meet the expected company, which soon arrived, and was received amid deafening cheers and a blaze of fireworks. The procession then moved through the principal streets and dispersed at a late hour.

abstract: Rev. Ralph Sanger, D.D., died at Cambridge, Mass., May 6, aged 74. He was a tutor in Harvard College in 1811, and in 1812 was settled over the Unitarian Church at Dover, Mass., a post which he occupied for 47 years. He was the father of Ex-Judge Sanger, or Boston.

abstract: There is nothing more agreeable than being in no way responsible to anybody for anything you do. Next to this in comfort is being responsible only to those who either do not care what you do, or, caring, cannot conveniently call you to account, or are not likely to do so immediately. Any man who can treat himself to either of these luxuries, has the world at his feet, and may turn life into a carnival. A thorough-going despot, after he has been doing something peculiarly outrageous, always calls attention to the fact that he is responsible to nobody but God and his own conscience, and thus leaves his fellow mortals no sort of pretext for desiring an inspection of his accounts. He does not, of course, pretend to be certain that there will not prove to be a balance against him at the final reckoning; but to a worthy man whom he has robbed or bastinadoed, or an innocent woman whom he has publicly flogged, this affords only a modified consolation. In fact, it would require human nature to be very much more malignant and fanatical than it is for it to find comfort, under an odious tyranny, in looking forward to the confusion of the tyrant at the Judgment Day. A Sicilian, or Venetian, of enlarged views and strong faith, may possibly find his misery lightened by reflecting upon the sorry figure which FRANCIS JOSEPH or FERDINAND will cut when report of the various acts of their administration to the only court from which there is no appeal; but, in the meantime, the mass of the people would prefer a constitution and a responsible ministry.
lead_paragraph: There is nothing more agreeable than being in no way responsible to anybody for anything you do. Next to this in comfort is being responsible only to those who either do not care what you do, or, caring, cannot conveniently call you to account, or are not likely to do so immediately. Any man who can treat himself to either of these luxuries, has the world at his feet, and may turn life into a carnival. A thorough-going despot, after he has been doing something peculiarly outrageous, always calls attention to the fact that he is responsible to nobody but God and his own conscience, and thus leaves his fellow mortals no sort of pretext for desiring an inspection of his accounts. He does not, of course, pretend to be certain that there will not prove to be a balance against him at the final reckoning; but to a worthy man whom he has robbed or bastinadoed, or an innocent woman whom he has publicly flogged, this affords only a modified consolation. In fact, it would require human nature to be very much more malignant and fanatical than it is for it to find comfort, under an odious tyranny, in looking forward to the confusion of the tyrant at the Judgment Day. A Sicilian, or Venetian, of enlarged views and strong faith, may possibly find his misery lightened by reflecting upon the sorry figure which FRANCIS JOSEPH or FERDINAND will cut when report of the various acts of their administration to the only court from which there is no appeal; but, in the meantime, the mass of the people would prefer a constitution and a responsible ministry.

abstract: I am assured, says the London correspondent of the Manchester Guardian, that the umpire's de[???]on will be carried out, and that SAYERS and HEENAN will meet again. May they have a fair-field and no favor, and may your correspondent "be there to see." SAYERS' arm is still painful. It seems that the casing of the large muscle of the forearm is ruptured, and that it will be some time before this will heal and recover its tone. HEENAN's nose is permanently broadened, and TOM's sign manual is indelibly imprinted upon his left cheek in a scar very much in the shape of an inverted capital T. A few well healed scratches on both heroes alone remain to tell of their doughty encounter. It may be interesting, however, to know that "The Boy" died this day week of erysipelas in the head -- at least some ingenious person said so, and society was convulsed for two hours by the idle rumor.

abstract: THE RESCUE OF CAPT. FARNHAM. -- There being some misapprehension in regard to the recent release of Capt. FARNHAM, and his subsequent surrender and reincarceration in jail, we are requested to state what occurred after Mr. United States District-Attorney COUPER discovered that the former was with his friends at the Pulaski House. Mr. COUPER having notified the friends of Capt. FARNHAM that he must return to jail, they requested that Mr. C. would suspend any action in arresting him that night, pledging their words that if he would do so they would have him forthcoming the next morning, and would apply for a bail for him. Mr. COUPER consented to that arrangement. At 2 o'clock the following day, the application for bail not having been made, Mr. C. made a requisition on the Mayor of the City for a police force to take Capt. FARNHAM, whose friends then applied to Mr. C. to bail him. The morning having elapsed without an application for bail having been made, Mr. COUPER refused to listen to any such application until Capt. F. first surrendered. The latter having surrendered himself into the custody of the jailor, in the presence of Mr. COUPER, the services of the police were not brought into requisition -- Savannah News, May 5.

abstract: MURDER IN CONNECTICUT -- RUM AND JEALOUSY. -- At Pequonnock, Conn., May 6, an Irishman named MICHAEL DALEY, 60 years old, killed Mr. JAMES O'NEIL. DALEY procured an axe, went to where O'Neil was lying, either asleep or stupefied with liquor, and struck him, as he confessed, four blows on the head, any one of which would probably have proved fatal. The cause is variously stated. All agree that the parties were intoxicated, and DALEY on Sunday night told several gentlemen that on the previous night. O'NEIL came to his house, took his wife from her bed and compelled her to go down stairs with him. Mrs. DALEY testified at the examination that no one had insulted her.

abstract: -- Dr. TYNG says: "Around every church there is a field of local labor and usefulness among children who are neglected by others, and for whose soul no man cares. Here arises a local field for benevolence in this relation. These may be gathered into the nursery of the church already established, and thus perhaps saved by the Lord's blessing for ever, and made to carry the blessings of salvation to the families from which they came. And our whole experience shows us how appropriate and successful this class of religious effort has been made in this relation, and how richly and surely a church so laboring and sowing gathers a harvest and wages unto eternal life. Or this aggressive action may be carried on in the establishment of mission or branch schools in neighboring and convenient localities."

abstract: The splendor of the scene presented the night before last at the bal costume given by the Emperor at he Hotol d'Albe, and which, for the last few weeks,  has been the great topic of expectation, was such as has scarcely ever been surpassed. The persons invited began to arrive at about nine, but before an hour had elapsed the rooms were filled.
lead_paragraph: The splendor of the scene presented the night before last at the bal costume given by the Emperor at he Hotol d'Albe, and which, for the last few weeks, has been the great topic of expectation, was such as has scarcely ever been surpassed. The persons invited began to arrive at about nine, but before an hour had elapsed the rooms were filled. The Emperor made his entry shortly after eleven in a black domino, which he only removed during the evening to substitute for it a blue one. The Empress, who arrived soon after, was attended through the rooms by Prince DE METTERNICH. Her Majesty also wore a domino, which, to the general surprise, she never took off; report having affirmed that she was to appear as Diana, the Huntress. Her Majesty only remained a short time. The costume of the Princess MATHILDE was of a most unusual description, as the texture of her skin was completely darkened to represent a copper-colored Indian, and to suit a curiously picturesque attire, lightly fastened together. The Princess CLOTILDE showed exquisite taste in a most charming costume of a Bergere in the time of LOUIS XV. Prince NAPOLEON appeared in a domino. The guests were received by the Duke and Duchess DE TASCHER LA PAGERLE, whose courtesy and attention were unceasing.

abstract: The simultaneous arrivals of the Canadian in the St. Lawrence, and the Fulton at this port, furnish European intelligence to the 3d inst. There is little of interest in the details. On the 3d inst. a vote that was expected to decide the fate of the measure ...
lead_paragraph: The simultaneous arrivals of the Canadian in the St. Lawrence, and the Fulton at this port, furnish European intelligence to the 3d inst. There is little of interest in the details. The Reform bill continued to occupy the attention of the British House of Commons, the Ministry succeeding thus far in carrying all their points. On the 3d inst. a vote that was expected to decide the fate of the measure was to be taken. No new developments had occurred in regard to the Savoy question. A rumor, however, prevailed that France had offered to compensate Switzerland for her imaginary claim upon the neutral provinces by the payment of 50,000,000 francs. The Sardinian Chambers had declined to act upon the treaty until the boundary survey had been completed. Affairs in Central Italy remained unchanged. The insurrection in Sicily had been so far repressed as to replace the royal troops in possession of the towns seized by the insurgents, the rural districts in the meanwhile remaining in revolt. The concessions promised by the crown of Austria to Hungary had been promulgated, and, it was hoped, would at once quiet the rising storm of popular feeling. Gen. BENEDEK, the new Governor, had issued a proclamation to the Hungarians in a conciliatory tone. There is nothing from the North of Europe. The treaty between Spain and Morocco had been finally adjusted, the latter Government hastening those payments for which Tetuan was to remain in Spanish hands as a pledge, so as to recover possession of that town at an early period.

abstract: This feature of a dictionary, though little esteemed by some, we are disposed to think, when properly executed, one of very great importance. It is nothing new, however. BAILEY's English Dictionary, one of the most celebrated, was thus illustrated early in the last century. A neat cut or diagram will often give a better definition of a term than a page of letter press. WORCESTER's pictures are scattered through the vocabulary. WEBSTER's are in a body by themselves. In respect to size, completeness, mechanical execution, and variety of subjects, WEBSTER's are unquestionably the best. WORCESTER's, though many of them are well enough, are, on the whole, a failure. They are very small, many of them are obscure, and the assortment ill proportioned. Ornithology, somehow achieved a singular monopoly in their allotment. Of 973 cuts in all, 324, or one-third, are birds or fragments of birds; and of this 324, no less than 191 are merely heads or bills of birds. Botany has 144; Quadrupeds, &c., the same; Fishes, 77; Mathematics and Mechanics, together, about 100; Architecture, 80; Miscellaneous, Domestic Arts, &c., 70, and Physical Science, a few. Reptiles and Insects are as rigorously excluded as from Ireland. -- New-Englander.

abstract: That BOOLE is a luxury, and not a necessity, few rational persons in New-York, We think, will venture to deny. He and his illustrious colleagues of the Common Council are clearly of no more use to the City than the brown-stone statue of WASHINGTON, which their taste has secured for the Park.
lead_paragraph: That BOOLE is a luxury, and not a necessity, few rational persons in New-York, We think, will venture to deny. He and his illustrious colleagues of the Common Council are clearly of no more use to the City than the brown-stone statue of WASHINGTON, which their taste has secured for the Park. We maintain BOOLE for his beauty; and so far as anything in the way of practical municipal work goes, for that alone. He and his fellows have a sort of historical value, like the beef-eaters of the British monarch: and we have no doubt the Turkish Pachas, young British noblemen, Southern senators, and other distinguished foreigners, who have, from time to tune, enjoyed the privilege of gazing upon and associating with BOOLE and his brethren, have been quite as much edified and excited by the experience as the traveler in London is by the spectacle of the burly old vagabonds who lounge about the Tower in red tunics, all ablaze with the arms of HARRY the Eighth.

abstract: ORDINATION SERVICES AT DR. BURCHARD'S CHURCH. Religious services of more than usual interest were held last evening at the Thirteenth-street Presbyterian Church, the occasion being the ordination of Rev. ARTHUR T. PIERSON to the work of the Gospel ministry. The house was well filled at the hour appointed, and the services were commenced by an appropriate anthem from the choir.
lead_paragraph: ORDINATION SERVICES AT DR. BURCHARD'S CHURCH. Religious services of more than usual interest were held last evening at the Thirteenth-street Presbyterian Church, the occasion being the ordination of Rev. ARTHUR T. PIERSON to the work of the Gospel ministry. The house was well filled at the hour appointed, and the services were commenced by an appropriate anthem from the choir. Rev. Dr. HUTTON then read the 4th chapter of 2d Corinthians: "Therefore seeing we have this ministry, as we have received mercy, we faint not." After the opening prayer by the same, Rev. Dr. OWEN gave out the 517th Hymn, "Go preach my gospel [???]aith the Lord," which was admirably sung by the choir, the congregation joining. Rev. S.D. BURCHARD, D.D., then delivered a sermon from the 11th chapter of Hebrews, 39th and 40th verses: "And these all having obtained a good report through faith, received not the promise: God having provided some better thing for us, that they without us should not be made perfect." The topic of the discourse was the serial and progressive character of Divine Revelation, as shown --[???]. By chronology; 2. In the facts with which the system of Revelation is connected, and which it reports; 3. By the series of events which mark the Biblical dispensation in the Patriarchal, Mosaic and Christian history; and 4. By the advance in the quality and quantity of religious ideas which it contains. In the absence of Rev. R.D. HITCHCOCK, Rev. Dr. CLARK read the constitutional questions to the candidates, offered the prayer of consecration, and each of the ministers then gave the right hand of fellowhip. Dr. CLARK followed with a brief charge, and the interesting services were concluded by singing and the benediction.

abstract: If the rumors of the death of Mr. TOWNSEND HARRIS should unfortunately prove to be true, neither the Government nor the country will find much to console them for his loss in reflecting upon the way in which they have rewarded his services, and the recollection of any neglect ...
lead_paragraph: If the rumors of the death of Mr. TOWNSEND HARRIS should unfortunately prove to be true, neither the Government nor the country will find much to console them for his loss in reflecting upon the way in which they have rewarded his services, and the recollection of any neglect or injustice he may have suffered at our hands will only be still further embittered by considering how rarely such persons as Mr. HARRIS are to be found in our diplomatic corps at all. We are represented abroad mainly either by broken-down adventurers craving a livelihood, or would-be aristocrats in search of" good society." It is not often that a man of Mr. HARRIS' capacity and devotedness gets a chance, even if he were ever so willing, of serving us in foreign countries either with honor or profit. Still less frequently does anybody who renders any country such substantial advantages meet with so little return as has so far rewarded the exertions of our Commissioner in Japan. Mr. HARRIS' claims upon the national gratitude are easily stated, and are not in the least doubtful.
headline: {'main': 'Our Japanese Diplomacy and the Gratitude of Republics.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Our Japanese Diplomacy and the Gratitude of Republics.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: When the first Embassy departed from these shores to the unknown City of Peking the expedition created almost as much sensation as would have been occasioned by a voyage to the moon. We are now dispatching an Ambassador to the same country under very different conditions; but it happens that at this moment an Embassy is on its way, probably to London, which is at least as extraordinary as the first British mission to China.

abstract: The testimony of a witness at a trial in the Court of Common Pleas, last week, gives us a very pleasing view of the promptitude and energy with which injustice is administered in some of our inferior criminal courts. Very inferior and very criminal, indeed, these courts must be, if the testimony of the aforesaid witness is to be taken as a fair sample ...
lead_paragraph: The testimony of a witness at a trial in the Court of Common Pleas, last week, gives us a very pleasing view of the promptitude and energy with which injustice is administered in some of our inferior criminal courts. Very inferior and very criminal, indeed, these courts must be, if the testimony of the aforesaid witness is to be taken as a fair sample of their proceedings. And that it may be so taken can hardly be doubted, we think, by any one who has ever seen our Police Courts at their work. The cadis of the people decree justice and judgment on a code, of which the essence is "a word and a blow, the blow coming first."

abstract: The woman Amelia Morrell, alias Sarah Fann, a noted shoplifter, indicted for grand larceny, and bailed in April in the sum of $2,000, and who afterwards fled to Canada, forfeiting her bonds, was brought into Court yesterday morning by officer Rosenberg, of the Twenty-sixth Precinct, who pursued her to Canada and arrested her. She pleaded a second time Not Guilty to the charge preferred against her, and was ordered to be committed without bail.

abstract: The mysterious rumors which have been floating for some time between Washington and New-York, of serious defalcations chargeable to the account of a leading Federal officer in this City, yesterday took shape and substance. Mr. ISAAC V. FOWLER, who for nearly eight years has administered the affairs of the Post-office in this City, left his residence on ...
lead_paragraph: The mysterious rumors which have been floating for some time between Washington and New-York, of serious defalcations chargeable to the account of a leading Federal officer in this City, yesterday took shape and substance. Mr. ISAAC V. FOWLER, who for nearly eight years has administered the affairs of the Post-office in this City, left his residence on Sunday, and has not since been seen. The Assistant Postmaster-General, with other functionaries of the Government, has come on to New-York to investigate the condition of the office under Mr. FOWLER's supervision; and the Marshal of the District has received a warrant for his arrest on the charge of embezzling the public funds. This charge is preferred under a statute of the United States which makes "a failure to pay over or produce the public moneys intrusted" to a person in Mr. FOWLER's position "prima facie evidence of embezzlement." It is not to be understood, therefore, that Mr. FOWLER has been proved guilty of any intention ultimately to defraud the Treasury. We make this explanation for the sake of such faint palliation as it may put upon the conduct of a man whose frank and generous nature had so won upon all with whom he was brought into contact that his bitterest political opponents will hear of his fall with deep and unmixed sorrow.

abstract: The passengers by the Southern Lake Shore line left Buffalo this morning, and reached Chicago at 9  o'clock this evening. abstract: The Japanese Ambassadors have survived the perils of their journeyings, and are now, with their treaty-box, safely sheltered in their quarters at the Capital. At 4  o'clock, on Sunday afternoon, they were transferred from the Roanoke to the Philadelphia, and in ten minutes afterwards were at Old Point, where they were received with salutes and music.
lead_paragraph: The Japanese Ambassadors have survived the perils of their journeyings, and are now, with their treaty-box, safely sheltered in their quarters at the Capital. At 4 o'clock, on Sunday afternoon, they were transferred from the Roanoke to the Philadelphia, and in ten minutes afterwards were at Old Point, where they were received with salutes and music. After partaking of refreshments, the Ambassadors reembarked on the Philadelphia, and steamed up the Potomac. Off Mount Vernon the vessel stopped, and while the band played plaintive music, the interpreter told them to whom the honors were paid. About 11 1/2 o'clock, yesterday morning, the Philadelphia appeared in sight of the multitude which thronged the Navy-yard at Washington. Mayor BERRETT, in accordance with the precedent which allows municipal courtesies to be tendered before national, went on board the vessel and welcomed the distinguished guests to the city. Then the treaty-box was passed to a small boat, and the Japanese followed. On landing at the Navy-yard, Capt. BUCHANAN welcomed them in the name of the President. No formal reply was made, and a procession was immediately formed to escort the Ambassadors to their quarters. First of all was the President's mounted guard; then came the Japanese in hacks; then the treaty, and last of all the marines and the District militia. A dense crowd thronged the avenues through which the procession passed, and it was not until 2 1/4 o'clock that the guests were allowed to retreat from the gaze of curious thousands to the privacy of their apartments.

abstract: The DAY-BOOK establishment, in obedience to the demands of an increasing business and circulation, in this day removed from No. 40 Ann-st. to more commodious quarters, at No. 162 Nassau-street opposite the City Hall. We have now one of the most public and central locations in the City, and being in the immediate vicinity of all the large newspaper offices, we trust our City patrons may find our removal to contribute to their convenience, while our out of town friends will certainly hereafter have no excuse for not being able to find the DAY-BOOK OFFICE.

abstract: The "Old Dominion Society," an association of residents of this City who are Virginians either by birth or parentage, held their first anniversary celebration last evening in the Copper Institute. The hall was barely more than filled to one-third of its capacity.
lead_paragraph: The "Old Dominion Society," an association of residents of this City who are Virginians either by birth or parentage, held their first anniversary celebration last evening in the Copper Institute. The hall was barely more than filled to one-third of its capacity. The particular event which the meeting was meant to commemorate was the settlement, on the 13th of May, 1607, of Jamestown, Va., by the English. Mr. WM.M. PEYTON occupied the chair.

lead_paragraph: ITEMS. -- SARAH CONNOLLY, colored, residing in North Seventh-street, was severely burned Sunday night by the explosion of a fluid lamp....An inquest was held at Ray Ridge a few days since, on the body of an unknown man taken from the water in that vicinity. The deceased had light hair and woro a moustache, and had on a thick brown coat, black cloth vest, and patent-leather shoes....The man who died in the Second Precinct Station-house Sunday evening has been identified as CORNELIUS MCDEVITT, a peddler of jewelry.....JOSEPH SCHERWIG, of No. 71 Mangin-street, died in Moore-street Sunday night of apoplexy. He visited this city to dine with a friend, and was on his way home when death overtook him....A boy named THOMAS DOWNEY, 13 years old, had his leg severely crushed between the string-piece and fenders as a Fulton ferry-boat was entering the slip yesterday. He was taken to the City Hospital.

abstract: An adjourned meeting of the Society of Dr. CHEEVER'S Church was held in the lecture-room of the Church last evening, to continue the discussion of the points of controversey between the trustees and the pastor, Rev. GEO. H. WHITE occupied the ...
lead_paragraph: An adjourned meeting of the Society of Dr. CHEEVER'S Church was held in the lecture-room of the Church last evening, to continue the discussion of the points of controversey between the trustees and the pastor, Rev. GEO. H. WHITE occupied the Chair. Rev. Mr. BLANKMAN being entitled to the floor, proceeded to read from manuscripts a lengthy address, evidently prepared with great care, in support of the Anti-Cheever side of the controversy. He repudiated the idea, to which the friends of Dr. CHEEVER had given currency, that the cause of the opposition to Dr. CHEEVER was that he had preached against Slavery. This, he said, was not so. The true origin of the difficulty was in the appeal of Dr. CHEEVER and his party for foreign aid to sustain the Church. He commented very severely upon the letter of Dr. CHEEVER to Mr. SPURGEON, and the egotism of the writer as therein displayed. Dr. CHEEVER had said that the cause of Zion throughout the world did not rest upon the Tract Society in Nassau-street, and yet one would suppose from the tenor of this letter that it did rest upon the Church of the Puritans and upon the preaching of Dr. CHEEVER. The course adopted by Dr. CHEEVER, and his friends tended to the establishment of a perfect despotism. On the principles laid down by them, there was nothing to hinder a pastor who should turn Roman Catholics, from transferring the whole property of the Church over to the Papish Hierarchy, while the congregation were turned out of doors.

His comedy of the "Overland Route," which has been running in London ever since the beginning of February, and which began its career in New-York at Wallack's Theatre last night, is the most ingenious and creditable piece of work he has given us since "Still Waters Run Deep."

abstract: A letter from Paris tells a strange story of a recent discovery in science, culminating in a melancholy denouncement. A governess in private families had under her charge a little Russian boy, who had been born deaf and dumb. The gentle disposition of the boy greatly endeared him to the governess, who devoted much of her time to developing ...
lead_paragraph: A letter from Paris tells a strange story of a recent discovery in science, culminating in a melancholy denouncement. A governess in private families had under her charge a little Russian boy, who had been born deaf and dumb. The gentle disposition of the boy greatly endeared him to the governess, who devoted much of her time to developing his intelligence, and enabling him to keep pace with her other pupils. After many sleepless nights, and many experiments, the lady finally resolved that sulphuric ether was the talisman to be employed in opening the world to her poor little prisoner. Its application proved perfectly successful; numerous other experiments indicated that the grand secret had been discovered, the Mouthy on Prize was awarded to the lady; and she rapidly rose from poverty and dependence to wealth, and fame as a benefactor of her race. But, alas! the sudden transition was too much for a mind so long overburdened by study and devotion to a single object; the reason of the poor lady gave way, and she has since been conveyed, a hopeless maniac, to a maison de sante, at Montmartre.

abstract: The Irish emigration to this country which it was supposed, a year or two ago, would abate under the influence of great prosperity at home, has again set in with such violence that the English Press begins to prophesy the total transfer, at no distant period, of the Celtic population ...
lead_paragraph: The Irish emigration to this country which it was supposed, a year or two ago, would abate under the influence of great prosperity at home, has again set in with such violence that the English Press begins to prophesy the total transfer, at no distant period, of the Celtic population to America, and the filling up of their ancient seats by a new "plantation" of Englishmen and Scotchmen. The London Times contemplates this result with great apparent satisfaction, and seeks to reconcile the departing exiles to their change of residence by the comforting assurance that America is the real home of their race. Considering what the condition of Ireland now is, as compared with what it was forty years ago, and considering, especially, the enormous advances it has made in material prosperity within the last ten years, the phenomenon which we are now witnessing, of this emigration of an entire people, famous for their strong local attachments, is one of the most remarkable in history. It is rendered all the more remarkable too, by the fact that, no matter how much political considerations may have done to set the stream flowing towards our shores fifty years ago, they have had little or nothing to do with the fullness and rapidity which mark it in our own day. We can no longer learn from stump orators or debating societies the real reason for the Irish peasant's quitting his home in the "old country." The political condition of the Irish Catholic has for some years ceased to be a whit worse than that of the English Protestant Dissenter. In some respects it is even better. He has supplied to him by the Government a good system of secular education for his children -- a luxury which the Methodist and Congregational masses of Great Britain are not likely to enjoy for many a day; and of late he has enjoyed an amount of Government patronage which the English Dissenter need not hope for. A large proportion of the Irish Judges are Catholics, as well as the representatives of the present Government at the Bar. The best legal appointments in the colonies, still in the gift of the Crown, have been for the last ten years bestowed on Irishmen. Irish Catholics muster largely on the rolls of the local magistracy. They have begun to muster largely at the mess tables of the army. They fill the corporations of the cities almost exclusively; they are represented in the House of Commons by a compact and clamorous body, which knows how to make itself formidable to the strongest ministry that now-a-days ever finds itself in office. In fact, the tendency of all the liberal Administrations of England for many years past has been to visit on the Irish Protestants those measures of proscription from which their Catholic countrymen once suffered. It is well known in Dublin that with Whigs, or Peelites, or Radicals in office in Downing-street, a Protestant's chances of a "berth" or of promotion are almost as small as a Catholic's used to be forty years ago. The tremendous power which the Emancipation Act raised into existence -- the power of a turbulent and ill-educated clergy over hosts of ignorant and fanatical voters -- is a power which has to be conciliated at any cost. Even the "Protestant Conservatives," under the "chivalrous" Earl of DERBY, have succumbed to its might. At the general election which preceded the peace of Villafranca, the combination between the priests and the Tories, for the purpose of bringing about a coalition with Austria against France, for the protection of the Pope and the concordat, was made manifest at every hustings from the Giant's Causeway to Cape Clear. In short, as far as the relations of the Irish Catholic with the Government are concerned, he has only the Church establishment to complain of; and this burden, as we have said, is one which presses with equal weight on the shoulders of the English Dissenter. In all other respects he stands on the same footing as any other British subject. Habeas corpus and trial by jury are now his birthright; and as to the liberty of the Press, the Dublin Nation is astounding evidence that the Irish Press is the freest Press in the world. In no other country would a newspaper be allowed, as this is, to preach insurrection every week, and to make common cause, on every possible opportunity, with the bitterest foreign enemies of the Powers that be, without either receiving any notice from the law or the mob.

abstract: The startling developments connected with the alleged Post-office defalcations in this City, and the sudden disappearance of the widely-known and universally popular head of that department, Mr. ISAAC V. FOWLER, continue to be the theme of discourse in all places of public resort throughout the City, as well as in the more private and social circles where that gentleman has so long moved a welcome guest.
lead_paragraph: The startling developments connected with the alleged Post-office defalcations in this City, and the sudden disappearance of the widely-known and universally popular head of that department, Mr. ISAAC V. FOWLER, continue to be the theme of discourse in all places of public resort throughout the City, as well as in the more private and social circles where that gentleman has so long moved a welcome guest. No tidings of the whereabouts of Mr. FOWLER have yet been received, and the United States Marshal, who has a warrant for his arrest, has thus far been utterly unable to obtain any clue to his movements since he left the Post-office at 8 o'clock on Saturday evening. Various rumors are afloat as to his having fled to this or that locality, comprising the whole territory from the "beach of Rockaway" to "John Brown's tract;" while other reports have it that he has not left the City at all; -- out whatever may be his place of concealment, it is pretty certain that he is in the "hands of his friends," and that he will remain there until the issue of the movement, which is said to be making among his intimate personal and political associates, to compromise his difficulties by a settlement of the Government claims, shall have been determined. That a compromise with the Government could be thus effected would hardly seem probable in any event, but in this case, and in this stage of the case, if the statements of those who represent the prosecuting branch of the Government are to be relied on the thing is utterly impossible. The additional developements that are making by those officers sent on from Washington to investigate the affairs of the New-York Post-office, are said to indicate such an extensive series of peculations and frauds, and to implicate so many others in the guilt of the defalcation, that any compromise of the matter is out of the question. Among the chief of those implicated is the Assistant Postmaster, Mr. CALDWELL, who, yesterday, resigned his position. It is said that his duties, as Cashier, rendered it impossible that the frauds could have been perpetrated without his knowledge. A deficit has also been discovered in the department for the sale of stamps, but the exact amount has not yet been ascertained. It is somewhere between $1,500 and $2,000; but as the clerk of this department has been off duty at various times, and is not therefore known to be the guilty party, his name is for the present withheld. A thorough investigation into all the departments is in progress, which will probably develop the whole extent of the frauds, so far as means exist of ascertaining them.

abstract: The American brig Townsend Jones arrived here in April, 1858, with a cargo of arms and munitions of war. Nothing was accomplished for the sale of these articles until the revolution commenced in 1859. The Government then suspected that a bargain was under way for the transfer of these dangerous implements to the Rebel party, who held Coquimbo and Caldera. There cannot be much doubt that some ground for the suspicion existed.

abstract: The Scriptures warn us to take heed to ourselves when all men speak well of us; and the friends of Mr. DOUGLAS may, therefore, be excused for the strength of the faith which they evidently repose in the star of their leader. If to be vilified is to be recommended to the protection of the higher powers, the Senator from Illinois is decidedly in the way of victory. A better-abused man has not recently been known in our public affairs. The fanatics of New-England and the secessionists of the Gulf States, agreeing in nothing else, agree in denouncing the champion of Popular Sovereignty. At one of the Anti-Slavery meetings which took place in this City last week, Mr. GARRISON held up Mr. DOUGLAS' bill for the punishment of conspiracy in one State against the peace and rights of other States, as the last and most devilish invention of American despotism. He called upon his followers to meet this issue presented by the Western Senator, in defence of Southern wickedness; and was instantly answered by an enthusiastic female disciple, who leaped up in the aisle and cried out that if "GARRISON would get a bundle of JOHN BROWN's pikes, she would help him cram them down Mr. DOUGLAS' throat," -- by way, we suppose, of vindicating that freedom of speech which Northern Abolitionism so vehemently demands for everybody who agrees with its own notions. Almost at the same time Mr. DAVIS, of Mississippi, was setting forth in the Senate the disloyalty of Mr. DOUGLAS, in refusing the South its natural right of going wherever it liked and carrying the United States army with it. All that Mr. YANCEY had said before at Charleston to persuade the Slaveholding States that their only safety lay in pursuing a policy which must lead them to choose between defeat in the Union and civil war out of it. Mr. DAVIS reported at Washington, and so ejected the Illinoisian Senator from the South precisely as Mr. GARRISON had before cut him off from the North. If Mr. GARRISON, therefore, really represents the North, and if Mr. DAVIS and Mr. YANCEY really represent the South, Mr. DOUGLAS certainly occupies a very lonely and lamentable position.

abstract: Judge SMALLEY, we are glad to see, has pronounced against the attempt to introduce into the Federal Courts, in the Hicks case, the absurd rule, so stringently enforced in our State Courts, that the mere fact of a man's having read the comments or reports of a newspaper, on the commission of a crime, shall disqualify him for acting as a juryman on the trial.
lead_paragraph: Judge SMALLEY, we are glad to see, has pronounced against the attempt to introduce into the Federal Courts, in the Hicks case, the absurd rule, so stringently enforced in our State Courts, that the mere fact of a man's having read the comments or reports of a newspaper, on the commission of a crime, shall disqualify him for acting as a juryman on the trial. That such a doctrine should have ever secured recognition in the United States, the country of newspapers par excellence, is, perhaps, one of the oddest and most unaccountable of the oddities of Anglo-Saxon law. It would be natural and reasonable enough if promulgated in Austria or Russia, where newspapers rank as unavoidable nuisances, the general use of which it is one of the first duties of the Government to discourage. But in America every man reads the newspapers who knows how to read at all, or who is fit to take part in any judicial proceeding. When a great crime is committed which causes a general sensation, everybody reads the report of it -- if he knows how to read; and if he does not know how, he is not fit to sit on a jury. So that the question with which every man on the panel is assailed in the State Courts, on a criminal trial, by the prisoner's counsel, as to whether he has read the newspaper reports touching the prisoner and his offence, is in reality equivalent to asking him: "Are you so stupid and ignorant that, living in New-York, you cannot read or understand a daily paper? Or if you read one, are you such a piece of eccentricity, as without any motive in the world, carefully to avoid perusing any allusion it contains to a subject of which every man and woman around you is talking?"

abstract: Coroner JACKMAN, yesterday morning, made an investigation into the circumstances attending the death of ROBERT C. MACDONALD, the murderer. The evidence corroborated the statement of the case which has been given in the TIMES, the only additional point of interest having been developed in the testimony of THOMAS JEFFERSON LONAN, the colored...
lead_paragraph: Coroner JACKMAN, yesterday morning, made an investigation into the circumstances attending the death of ROBERT C. MACDONALD, the murderer. The evidence corroborated the statement of the case which has been given in the TIMES, the only additional point of interest having been developed in the testimony of THOMAS JEFFERSON LONAN, the colored waiter at the Metropolitan Hotel, who carried the deceased his meals. He deposed that MACDONALD had repeatedly asked him to bring him poison, and on one occasion had offered to give him $10 if he would obtain a quantity of strychnine. He never accepted to the request, however, and informed the keepers of the matter. The physicians of the prison deposed that the health of deceased had not been very good for some time, and that he had two or three times been furnished with a small quantity of creosote, as a remedy for toothache, but that in the aggregate it would not have been sufficient it taken at one time, to produce death. The inquest was concluded without having revealed the agency through which the poison was obtained.

abstract: We ventured, in commenting some weeks ago upon the approaching reception of the Japanese by the Municipal authorities, to conjecture that the fame of our Common Council and their "hospitalities" had spread through Eastern Europe and Asia, and had perhaps reached the ears of the Japanese, secluded though they have been from the rest of the world. Testimony to the correctness of our supposition is daily turning up.
lead_paragraph: We ventured, in commenting some weeks ago upon the approaching reception of the Japanese by the Municipal authorities, to conjecture that the fame of our Common Council and their "hospitalities" had spread through Eastern Europe and Asia, and had perhaps reached the ears of the Japanese, secluded though they have been from the rest of the world. Testimony to the correctness of our supposition is daily turning up. We have always doubted, and doubt still, whether MOHAMMED PASHA would say much when he got home about the humiliating treatment which he received at the hands of Messrs. BOOLE and VAN TINE, but some of his retinue have doubtless been blabbing about the ham sandwiches and sherry; and the malignity of the New-York "Medjlis" towards foreigners must long ere this have become a common topic in every village from Anatolia to the shores of the China sea. It only needs very little familiarity with Oriental life to know how gossip of this sort flies from tribe to tribe, carried sometimes by caravans, sometimes by couriers, sometimes by strolling dervishes or bashi-bazouks, sometimes no man can guess how. Instances occurred in the Russian war of 1828, of news reaching Constantinople in this way from places a thousand miles off, two days in advance of the Tartar express, riding as fast as horse could gallop. The various incidents of the late mutiny in Hindostan were the subject of common chit chat on the shores of the Caspian and the Black Sea, long before the news was flashed from Marseilles by the Overland Mail. The tale seems to travel in the air -- and none know whence it comes and whither it goes. We presume it must be in some such way as this that the fame of our Common Council has reached Jeddo, unless, indeed, Lord ELGIN, finding himself baffled in his efforts to induce Japan to send an embassy to England first, was malicious enough to forward reports of "BOOLE, his proceedings," with short biographies of the members of the Council, to the sacred Emperor. However it be, the Washington correspondent of the Tribune testifies that the Ambassadors know all about the New-York Common Councilmen, and will be prepared for Mr. VAN TINE and his colleagues. We hope this is true. "Forewarned, forearmed." If Amphitryon BOOLE be engaged in looking up "hospitalities" of a more than usually disgusting sort, as some article of food which no Japanese can touch without instantly disemboweling himself, we advise him to desist. The known readiness of the Japanese to resort to the "happy dispatch," in case of flagrant insult, renders it doubly necessary for the public to keep an eye on the "Committee of Reception." It is an extraordinary proof of the politeness of our Oriental guests, that none of them should have opened their abdomens, when they were hustled and jostled, and pushed and squeezed by a mob of gaping idiots, on their arrival at the enlightened capital of the Union. They will go through a good deal more of this sort of thing before they make their escape from Washington, and may find their natural instincts of decency grow less tenderly sensitive under the experience. But there is a peculiar pungency in the flavor of our Common Council which must infallibly penetrate their nerves with a new, and perhaps irresistible impulse of disgust; and we should bitterly regret the necessity of sending back the illustrious Kamis of Nipon, not only drawn in the illustrated papers, but quartered by their own princely hands.

abstract: The African Civilization Society met in Convention in Shiloh Church last evening. There was a very fair attendance of colored people, and the proceedings were listened to with interest. After prayer by Rev. Mr. M. WALKER, Rev. Mr. GARNET remarked that, although it was a meeting of the friends of the Civilization movement, still, after the regular proceedings should have been concluded, the floor would be free to those opposed to it. He then read a letter from Rev., Mr. WHIPPLE, favoring the objects of the Society.

abstract: All England is now prostrating itself at the feet of TOM SAYERS in a literally golden silence of admiration, that so small a boxer should have made so great a fight. Dukes and stockjobbers unite in applauding the pluck which has enabled a "light weight" so long to hold the Championship of the Prize Ring. This is all natural enough in a country which worships the flesh, calls itself "John Bull,"
lead_paragraph: All England is now prostrating itself at the feet of TOM SAYERS in a literally golden silence of admiration, that so small a boxer should have made so great a fight. Dukes and stockjobbers unite in applauding the pluck which has enabled a "light weight" so long to hold the Championship of the Prize Ring. This is all natural enough in a country which worships the flesh, calls itself "John Bull," and has been so often snubbed and pooh-poohed of late years, that it may be excused for showing extravagant delight that its hero, having failed to win a victory, should at least have given his conqueror so much trouble in thrashing him. We in New-York, have a more legitimate wonder in the way of "light weights;" not the less wonderful and admirable surely, that, instead of being a hero, she is a heroine. We trust Miss ADELINA PATTI will not consider that we mean to put any slight either upon herself or her sweet gift of song, in thus coupling her name with the phrases of the Ring.

abstract: -- They have a remarkably pleasant way of doing things in some sections of this great and glorious country. An individual by the name of HAR[???], while passing through Kingsville, was so injudicious as to boast that Maryland was an Abolition State within the hearing of Mr. B. FRANKLIN COLK, of the firm of STRAUS, HARTMAN, HOFFLIN & CO., Baltimore. Mr. COLE very gentlemanly gave this assertion the lie, and, as the paper from which we glean these particulars expresses it, "made towards him. Some words ensued, during which the true-hearted Baltimorean manfully stood his ground, and the straggler gave abundant evidence of his being an Abolitionist of the most low and dirty character. Soon it was suspicioned that he was but an impudent free negro from some Northern locality. This he acknowledged, upon being pushed up a little. Mr. COLE then took him aside, into an apartment of the Kingsville Hotel, made him peel off, and gave him the limit of the law, 'well filled, pressed down and shaken together,' upon his bare back." Mr. B. FRANKLIN COLE, of the firm of STRAUS, HARTMAN, HOFFLIN & CO., Baltimore, must be an agreeable man to do business with. After this experience, it is probable that Mr. HARE will no longer labor under the delusion that Maryland is an Abolition State. The proverbial hospitality of the South is daily extending itself; but we doubt if it be susceptible of a more earnest and practical development.

abstract: The attendance at Chicago, not only of delegates but of interested and curious spectators, is large beyond any precedent in the history of National Conventions. No decisive opinion seems to be expressed by a recognized majority as to the candidate, though the friends of Mr. SEWARD are supposed to be the most numerous and most perfectly organized.
lead_paragraph: The attendance at Chicago, not only of delegates but of interested and curious spectators, is large beyond any precedent in the history of National Conventions. No decisive opinion seems to be expressed by a recognized majority as to the candidate, though the friends of Mr. SEWARD are supposed to be the most numerous and most perfectly organized. The supporters of other names are nevertheless urgent in their protests against his nomination, and so certain of his defeat, that it is by no means certain that a majority will be found for him after organization. The Pennsylvania delegation, whose opinions it is of the utmost consequence to consult, represent the chances of securing their State for the New-York Senator as hopeless; while they admit that any other straight Republican would be quite as acceptable. It is thought that Messrs. BATES and MCLEAN are clearly out of the field; and in the event of the non-success of Mr. SEWARD, Mr. WADE is named as next in order of probability.

abstract: Patrick Monckler, the second-mate of the s[???]r D.S. Williams, was examined before the District-Attorney yesterday, on a charge of having stolen a past of the vessel's cargo on the voyage from this port to Moore. Cyrus J. Lawrence, of Jacob-street is said to have been defrauded of $700 worth of property, and several other merchants to the extent of $100 and $200, by the accused, who disposed of his plunder at Mobile... Two carpet-shakers, named Charles Pierson and Wm. Henderson, yesterday stipulated to operate in their dusty way on the three-ply and Brussels of Mr. Thromien, at No. 104 Second-street. They left the premises without their wages, but with a watch and chain belonging to Mr. Thromien and valued at $36. Policeman Gerst subsequently arrested the rogues, and Justice BRENNEN committed them for examination.... Francis Stanley was arrested yesterday, and committed by Justice QUACKENBUSH, on a charge of having broken into the trunk-store of J. Hill, No. 785 Broadway, and carried off $25 worth of property all of which was found in his possession..... A purse containing $27, was snatched from the hand of Louisa Little, of No. 242 Greenwich street, yesterday, as she was passing through Canal-street. The thief -- a lad named Charles Herring -- was pursued, and after a tedious chase, arrested by Officer Steele. Justice OSBORNE held him to answer.... The arrest of a colored man named Wm. Derickson, on Monday night by Officer Welsh, of the Harbor Police, has given a solution to the question which dealers in liquor of late have had much occasion to ask, as to the cause of the short measure in the casks of spirits. The prisoner had invented an ingenious contrivance -- a sort of syphon -- by which he was enabled to transfer the contents of a barrel of brandy into a demijohn with much expedition and small chance of detection. Justice CONNOLLY, before whom the roguish inventor was taken, committed him for trial.

abstract: Hayward vs. The Liverpool and London Insurance Company. -- This was an action on a policy of insurance for $10,000, issued by the defendants to the plaintiff upon his India Rubber Manufactory, at Providence, Rhode Island. The factory was destroyed by fire, occasioned by the explosion of an insured boiler, attached to an insured engine, and an engine, as plaintiff claims, necessary and indispensable to the manufacture of the goods. The policy contains a printed clause that the Company will not be liable for any loss by fire occasioned by explosion, and on that ground the Company resists the plaintiff's claim.

abstract: FIRE DEPARTMENT ELECTION. -- The election for a Chief and Assistant Engineer of the Hoboken Fire Department took place on Monday night, instead of last night, at which time it was reported that it would take place. The vote was as follows: For Chief Engineer, JOHN M. BOARD, 77 votes; JOHN KENNEDY, 65. For Assistant, JOHN LEWIS, 80 votes; JOHN MCALISTER, 61. Messrs. BOARD and LEWIS were accordingly elected.

abstract: The action of the Board of Aldermen on Monday night, in removing A.V. STOUT, Esq., as City Chamberlain, and confirming the nomination of NATHAN C. PLATT, Esq., President of the Artisans' Bank, in his stead, places the financial affairs of the City in a very singular position. The bonds of the newly-appointed Chamberlain must be approved by the Comptroller.
lead_paragraph: The action of the Board of Aldermen on Monday night, in removing A.V. STOUT, Esq., as City Chamberlain, and confirming the nomination of NATHAN C. PLATT, Esq., President of the Artisans' Bank, in his stead, places the financial affairs of the City in a very singular position. The bonds of the newly-appointed Chamberlain must be approved by the Comptroller. That official is at present absent from the City, engaged, in company with many hundred others, in President-making, and of course no official action can be had until his return. Meanwhile the City moneys will be deposited in the Shoe and Leather Bank, as heretofore; but when the main question comes up for adjudication, the aid of the law will, of course, be invoked. Mr. STOUT will undoubtedly claim to hold his office by virtue of Legislative enactment, and also by virtue of appointment and confirmation under that law; while Mr. PLATT will demand the office by virtue of appointment and confirmation -- his predecessor having been removed for cause. In the meantime, warrants drawn for contractors and all officials are likely to remain unrecognized, as the Mayor will probably refuse to sign a warrant drawn on Mr. STOUT, when he does not recognize him as Chamberlain, or his Bank as the custodian of the City funds.

abstract: There are two kinds of creatures of which a faithful proverb assures us that they both invariably "come home to roost." To which class our worthy Mayor belongs we do not pretend to decide, though we hardly think he would claim to be considered a "chicken." Be he what he may, home he invariably comes, no matter how emphatically he may have taken his departure; and just as invariably does he signalize his return by some characteristic proceeding, which convinces the whole City instantly that his "single eye" is once more fixed upon our "public good."
