abstract: At the meeting of the Polytechnic Association last week, Prof. SEELY, Chairman of the Committee to whom was referred for consideration JOHNSON's new patent gas burner, reported in behalf of the majority of the Committee, unfavorably to the invention.
lead_paragraph: At the meeting of the Polytechnic Association last week, Prof. SEELY, Chairman of the Committee to whom was referred for consideration JOHNSON's new patent gas burner, reported in behalf of the majority of the Committee, unfavorably to the invention. The report was of considerable length, and of a scientific character. The points of chief interest to the public are as follows: Gas, in New-York, is not burned economically; and without any material cost to the consumer, the light from gas burned may be increased about twenty per cent. The burners commonly in use have such narrow orifices that the gas issues in a thin sheet, mingles rapidly with the air, and the carbon, to which the light is chiefly due, is consumed too rapidly. The apertures of the burner therefore should be made larger. But the size of the aperture must be carefully limited, or the flame will smoke. The test of the most economical burning is the yellowish hue which a flame has just at the point of beginning to smoke. The objections to such a light are that it is unsteady, and very liable to smoke. These objections may be obviated in a good degree, however, by spreaders and chimnies. The Johnson burner is one of a pretty large class, which has wide orifices, and contrivances within the burner to check the flow of the gas. The Committee believe that no contrivance in these burners is so convenient and effective for checking and adjusting the flow as the ordinary stop-cock.

abstract: At the Academy of Music, last night, Miss PATTI took a benefit, which she has assuredly well earned. It is notoriously indecent to criticize the age of a "gift-horse," and we have no doubt Miss PATTI accepted her benefit with all the sweetness of temper which should belong to so sweet a voice, save only he smiling eyes and the glowing bouquets which welcomed her, and charitably mistook the empty seats for meditative parsons bowed down in delight and admiration. As critics we are bound to no such good-natured blindness; and we cannot therefore refrain from expressing our astonishment that a handsome tribute should not have been paid to this inde[???] and accomplished "pet of the public." The Academy was by no means badly filled, be it understood, and nothing could be more well-intentioned than the applauses of audience. But many hundreds who should have been in Irving-place, if they really care for music and the musicians, were not there. They can hardly have gone to the Winter Garden to hear "Nabuco," for the experience of Tuesday must have warned then that "Nabuco" might not be heard if they should go to hear it.

abstract: We are told that the Court of Oyer and Terminer adjourned on Tuesday without doing any business, owing to the continued absence of Mr. District-Attorney WATERBURY, though several manslaughter cases remain to be disposed of. We commented two days ago upon the delay in bringing MACDONALD to trial, caused by what we must regard as the remissness of this same official. Mr. WATERBURY pleads that...
lead_paragraph: We are told that the Court of Oyer and Terminer adjourned on Tuesday without doing any business, owing to the continued absence of Mr. District-Attorney WATERBURY, though several manslaughter cases remain to be disposed of. We commented two days ago upon the delay in bringing MACDONALD to trial, caused by what we must regard as the remissness of this same official. Mr. WATERBURY pleads that he has not time to take the ordinary measures for bringing even murderers before a jury, and yet he has time to go to Charleston to attend an electioneering Convention, and stays away so long that the Courts have to adjourn over, and lose a term, without doing any business at all. If it be really true that one District-Attorney is not sufficient to bring criminals to justice, all that is to be said is that we must have as many as will be sufficient, because criminals must be brought to justice somehow. The matter is not one upon which we can economize, or which we can afford to postpone. We may remark, however, that we think Mr. WATERBURY's experience would hardly furnish a good reason for making any such change, as he, by his own account, in his letter to the Board of Supervisors two months ago, charges himself, in addition to his duties as public prosecutor, with the task of reforming criminals and pardoning them before trial. He says it is his duty to make such inquiry into each case as will enable him to judge whether the culprit will be improved by having his offence hushed up, or in other words by being "let off," and he mentioned several cases in which the exercise of this discretionary power had been attended with the happiest results.

abstract: The Republicans at Chicago already show, in the tenor of their preliminary proceedings, how much more fortunate they have been in the choice of their place of meeting than were the Democracy at Charleston. The genial influence of a free, active and sympathetic popution is making itself felt upon the delegates. Processions by day, dinners and serenades by night -- the perpetual flutter of banners, and music of military bands -- the glare of torchlights, and the fragrance of flowers -- these are the accompaniments of the Republican councils. They cannot fail to excite the enthusiasm of the delegates, to make them feel that a great population is with them in their work; and by elating them with fresh hopes of victory in the contest upon which they are entering, to make them more forbearing about personal preferences, and less disposed to risk the glittering prize which seems within their grasp by any extravagant devotion to this or that particular leader. There is no danger that the Convention at Chicago will break up like the Convention at Charleston. The strongest candidate of the Democracy at Charleston represented a principle upon which the political existence of his party absolutely depends; and to sacrifice him, therefore, would have been for those who supported him an act of political suicide. The strongest candidate of the Republicans, on the contrary, stands out from his competitors rather on a question of phraseology than on any peculiarity of convictions essential to the success of Republicanism. The individuality of Mr. DOUGLAS was his main strength at Charleston. The individuality of Mr. SEWARD is his main weakness at Chicago. The Democrats could not take Mr. DOUGLAS without his measures. The Republicans are perfectly ready to take Mr. SEWARD's measures without Mr. SEWARD. In this state of things it would be idle to attempt to foresee the result of a contest which turns on no vital point. Mr. SEWARD's friends are urging him with united and determined front. The dissenters from this body -- enemies they can hardly be called -- are casting about in some uncertainty for a man who shall unite all the qualities which they separately admire in the New-York Senator, without the peculiarities of position which to each of them make that Senator seem an unavailable candidate. The heat and burden of the day will consequently fall upon the opposition to Mr. SEWARD, rather than upon his supporters.

abstract: The steamship Karnak arrived at this port yesterday, from Havana and Nassau. We are indebted to Purser ALLEN for late news. The ship Cicero, which left Boston on 23d April, (owned by Messrs. WHITE & CO., of that port.) went ashore at the Great Guano Key, Bahama; all sail being set at the time, such was the force with which she struck, that in half an hour she went to pieces. On board at the time were Capt. SMITH, the master, with Mr. CARNEY and Mrs. SMITH as passengers, and a crew of 20 men, with a cargo of ice in the lower hold, and a general cargo between decks. The Captain, two passengers, the cook and three seaman were drowned. Eight of the seamen are on board the Karnak, and a subscription was raised on board for them. Same of them are in a bruised condition, from being dashed about on the rocks. The names of those known to be drowned are Capt. SMITH, Mr. CARNEY, Mrs. SMITH, and seamen J.P. SHEPHERD.

abstract: The jury, which for three days have had under  consideration the mysterious circumstances in connection with the death of FRANZ GREDEY German, who was instantly killed last Sunday morning, by falling from the fifth-story window of the tenemont house No. 184 Eldridge-street, yesterday returned a verdict in which they implicated ECHA HOLT, alias Miller, the occupant of the apartment from the win-  dow of which the deceased fell, as an accessory to his  death.
lead_paragraph: The jury, which for three days have had under consideration the mysterious circumstances in connection with the death of FRANZ GREDEY German, who was instantly killed last Sunday morning, by falling from the fifth-story window of the tenemont house No. 184 Eldridge-street, yesterday returned a verdict in which they implicated ECHA HOLT, alias Miller, the occupant of the apartment from the win- dow of which the deceased fell, as an accessory to his death. Numerous witness were examined, and their testimony developed the following facts About 12 o'clock on Saturday night, the woman was addressed by a drunken man in the Bowery, near Rivington-street, when GERBER, who was passing by, interfered to protect her from violence, and subsequently he accompanied her home. Soon afterwards the tenants on the same floor heard a violent rapping on the door of the woman's room, but before its cause was ascertained, the attention of some of them was attracted by a crashing of the window-sash, and a man clinging to the sill, struggling to retain his hold, and breaking in his frantic efforts the glass in the window below. Before assistance could be rendered he was either forced from his position by some person inside, or his strength failed, and he fell, meeting an instant death. The accused states that she was in an adjoining apartment procuring a light when the circumstance transpired, and that she can only account for the action of deceased in going to the window by the supposition that he became alarmed at the rapping on the door, and sought to escape or conceal himself in that way. A lad nice years of age, named George Nallinger, residing in the apartment directly over that of the woman, deposed that having been awakened by the noise of the breaking glass, he looked down, and saw the arm of a person who was striking the deceased with a hammer. As all the witnesses were unanimous in giving a very bad character to the woman. Coroner SOU[???]ER decided to commit her for the Grand Jury to act in the [???]a[???]er. Deceased was a married man, 27 years of age, and resided with his wife in Fifth-street.

abstract: In the latter part of last March an Englishman named Richard Vickers arrived in this City, having with him a draft for $484 on the banking-house of Duncan, Sherman & Co., which he at first found difficult to exchange for cash, as he had no person to identify him. For that purpose, however, he obtained the presence of one Henry Butler, a stage-starter at the Fulton ferry, at the banking-house, and upon his assurance that Vickers was Vickers, the latter drew $84, leaving a balance of $400 with the bankers. Vickers alleges that a day or so afterwards Butler prevailed upon him to draw the remaining $400 from Duncan, Sherman & Co., and hand it to him for the purpose of depositing it in a Savings Bank, where it would be at interest, but that instead of fulfilling his promise to place it in a bank, he appropriated it to his own use. Butler was arrested, and Justice OSBORNE committed him for examination on a charge of larceny, while Vickers was detained as a witness.

abstract: The proceedings of the M.E. General Conference to-day were of more general interest than they have heretofore been. The reports of the Slavery Committee, which have been so anxiously looked For, and about which there has been so much speculation, were to-day presented, read, and ordered printed. Both the majority and minority reports were documents of some length, occupying nearly two hours in the reading.

He then nominated as temporary chairman Hon. DAVID WILMOT, of Pennsylvania, ...
lead_paragraph: The Republican Convention at Chicago met yesterday morning, in the Great Wigwam erected by the Republicans of that city. Gov. MORGAN, of New-York, as Chairman of the National Commit- tee, called the Convention to order adding a brief and sensible exhortation to harmony, dignity, and patriotism, and indicating the evils to be avoided by the example of the late Convention at Charleston. He then nominated as temporary chairman Hon. DAVID WILMOT, of Pennsylvania, who before assuming his seat addressed the Convention in remarks eulogistic of Republican doctrines. The remainder of the morning session was consumed in the nomination of Committees, composed of one delegate from each State, upon permanent organization, and upon the order of business. When the Convention met in the afternoon, the Committee of Permanent Organization reported as President Hon. GEORGE ASHMUN, of Massachuserts. Mr. ASHMUN addressed the Convention in eloquent and appropriate remarks, speaking with an ardent hope of the future, and invoking the cooperation and patience of the Convention as aids to the fulfillment of his duties. After the nomination of other Committees -- upon the Platform and upon the appointment of a new National Executive Committee -- the Convention adjourned until this morning at 10 o'clock. Our special reporter apprises us that while the preference of a large majority of the Convention is unmistakably for Mr. SEWARD, his friends hesitate in view of the sturdy opposition of Pennsylvania, Indiana, and Illinois. They confide, however, in the circumstance that no one of these reluctant States has a better candidate to offer, and by maintaining a firm attitude they anticipate ultimate success. Should Mr. SEWARD have to be dropped, Mr. LINCOLN, and after him Mr. WADE, are supposed to be in the more favorable position. A letter from Col. FREMONT, referred to in our dispatch of Tuesday, was made public yesterday. That gentleman declines being considered as a candidate; but is willing, in the event of the Convention failing to unite upon any other, to stand in the gap.

abstract: A MAMMOTH FERRY BOAT. -- The Jersey City Ferry Company have in course of construction at BURTISS' ship yard, Red-Hook Point, L.I., a mammoth ferry-boat to be added to their line. She will be 205 feet in length, 33 1/2 feet beam, and about 850 tons burden. She will be supplied with a beam-engine, the cylinder 45 inches diameter and 11 feet stroke. The boiler and engine are in course of construction at BIRKBECK's foundry, Jersey City. The launch is to take place about the middle of July, and she is to be entirely completed about the 1st of October next. This boat will be 22 feet longer than the ferry-boat John S. Darcy, and by far the largest ferry-boat in the world.

abstract: Yesterday developed no new particulars of interest connected with the defalcation in the NewYork Post-office, and the excitement that attended the first announcement of the news is fast dying away. The friends of Mr. FOWLER, forgetting the crime in their regard for the man, continue to express their sorrow at his downfall, their joy at his escape from the clutches of the law, and their wonder as to what he has done with the money.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday developed no new particulars of interest connected with the defalcation in the NewYork Post-office, and the excitement that attended the first announcement of the news is fast dying away. The friends of Mr. FOWLER, forgetting the crime in their regard for the man, continue to express their sorrow at his downfall, their joy at his escape from the clutches of the law, and their wonder as to what he has done with the money. United States Marshal RYNDERS continues his search for the missing defaulter with unabated vigilance, and has sent out scouts in all directions, whither the fugitive was, or was not, likely to have fled. It is to be hoped that the Captain's extraordinary efforts will be duly appreciated at Washington, for here it is not too much to say that they are the laughing-stock of the whole City. Nobody believes that he would arrest FOWLER if he could, or that he could if he would. The whole thing is a farce, and might as well be dropped first as last. The bondsmen of Mr. FOWLER -- Messrs. LAW and CONOVER -- have signified their willingness to respond immediately to the extent of their bond ($75,000) without a prosecution. As for the remainder, Uncle Sam has only to think of SWARTWOUT, put his hands in his pockets and whistle.

abstract: The various City Departments were yesterday pregnant with official dullness. The only topic of conversation was the quarrel of the Chamberlains' and the officials generally seemed to feel a deep personal interest in the possible or probable result of the contest, for a contest is resolved upon by both sides.
lead_paragraph: The various City Departments were yesterday pregnant with official dullness. The only topic of conversation was the quarrel of the Chamberlains' and the officials generally seemed to feel a deep personal interest in the possible or probable result of the contest, for a contest is resolved upon by both sides. The cashier of the Artisans' Bank, over which the newly-appointed City Chamberlain presides, was present at the Comptroller's Office yesterday, accompanied by his counsel, but, unfortunately, Mr. WARREN, the Deputy Comtroller, was absent, having been taken suddenly ill, and in accordance with the recommendations of his physicians, had left the impure air of the City for the pure and bracing air of the Highlands, where it is quite probable he will remain until the early part of the coining week -- certainly until the Convention at Chicago has adjourned. Of course, in his absence, nothing official could be transacted, and the "end is not yet." It is suggested, and the suggestion is worthy of consideration, that pending the legal proceedings which are to ensue, the Mayor shall sign the warrants for the amount now on deposit with Mr. STOUT, leaving the question of tenure of office to the Courts; and that again gives rise to the suggestion, What is to be done with the deposits daily made to the credit of the City? The Mayor has certainly succeeded in effecting a very pretty snarl, and the cutting of this Gordian knot may not be so prompt or so easy as of old. Meanwhile contractors, inspectors, foremen and laborers, who have amounts due to them, are looking on with great interest.

abstract: The match between Ethan Allen and George M. Patchen, for $2,000, best 3 in 5, in harness, for which sporting men and admirers of fast horses have been so anxiously waiting, transpired yesterday at the Union Course. Early in the day wagons, carriages and vehicles of all kinds began to pass over the Ferry. The special trains were crowded with passengers, and good judges estimated the number inside the inclosure at the time named for the horses to make their appearance at not less than 8,000. The temperature was sufficiently cool to allow the horses to be urged to their greatest speed without distressing them, and the track was in excellent condition.

abstract: -- That Republican dog, of which the Tribune some time since told us a tale, has recently been in high feather, or rather in high hair. We have repeatedly noticed him, of late, standing in the Park, and wagging his tail in indication of eminent satisfaction as he regarded the sable sign which now surmounts the Tribune buildings. There it stands, "grand, gloomy and peculiar," black, unrelievedly black, the very embodiment of the color which he adores. All that is required to make the thing complete is a little wool. We hope that the dogged complacency of the Republican dog will not be subjected to curtailment by any indication of letters; his tail would undoubtedly wag on forever in an ecstasy of joy to know that the artist employed by the Tribune before the completion of his labors "died, and made no sign."

abstract: At the meeting of the Board of Education last evening, Mr. ANDREW H. GREEN in the Chair, a communication was received from the School officers of the First Ward, to the effect that Ward School No. 29, in Greenwich-street, is totally inadequate for school purposes.
lead_paragraph: At the meeting of the Board of Education last evening, Mr. ANDREW H. GREEN in the Chair, a communication was received from the School officers of the First Ward, to the effect that Ward School No. 29, in Greenwich-street, is totally inadequate for school purposes. The rear building, they say, is in a dilapidated condition, and that the children who congregate in the rear of the School are exposed to great danger from the already tottering walls. They asked that an appropriation of $50,000 be made to build a new school-house, upon a site to be obtained by the purchase of the lease of the rear, and of an adjoining building lot. The communication was referred to the Committee on Sites and School-houses and Repairs Committee jointly.

abstract: The present May term of this Court, Judge RUSSELL presiding, hitherto has been a failure. Perhaps the absence from the City of the District-Attorney, Mr. Nelson J. Waterbury, may in part account for it, or the Grand Jury may be lax, or counsel may be unwilling to put money in their purses; but certain it is, very little is doing in the Court of General Sessions, and the City Judge should look to it. It was not so last term, under the Recorder.

abstract: Our English cousins are fearfully exercised about the Benicia Boy and the American eagle. They are spending almost as much time and paper to prove that TOM SAYERS either was not whipped, or ought not to have been whipped, or was whipped with the greatest possible difficulty, by his Yankee antagonist, as they have wasted in keeping up the national courage by showing that the French either never can invade England, or that if they should do so they will infallibly be annihilated among the hedges of Kent before they can so much as get a chance to pick off a minor canon from the towers of Canterbury Cathedral with one of their confounded armes de precision, or to astonish the old walls of Rochester Castle with a shot from one of their Napoleon guns.

abstract: The Richmond Enquirer, edited by Gov. WISE'S son, informs the Democrats of the North that their only possible chance of victory lies in nominating Gov. WISE for the Presidency, and JOSEPH LANE for the Vice-Presidency; that these gentlement will carry "all the Southern States, and Pennsylvania, Indiana, New-York, Oregon and California," and thus secure the  victory, and that nobody else can accomplish as much.
lead_paragraph: The Richmond Enquirer, edited by Gov. WISE'S son, informs the Democrats of the North that their only possible chance of victory lies in nominating Gov. WISE for the Presidency, and JOSEPH LANE for the Vice-Presidency; that these gentlement will carry "all the Southern States, and Pennsylvania, Indiana, New-York, Oregon and California," and thus secure the victory, and that nobody else can accomplish as much. We think that so much as this leaves the Baltimore Convention very little to do. They have but to nominate these gentlemen and adjourn. We hope, however, the Ex-Governor will be able to get along without New-York, as we greatly fear there may be some difficulty in securing this State for him. There is a small knot of miserable fanatics here, who are possessed with the idea that Gov. WISE is wanting in common sense; in fact, some of them go so far as to say that he has, in his public capacity on divers occasions, behaved in a manner strongly indicative of downright lunacy. The influence of these men at a general election is likely to be very great in spite of their individual insignificance, and we candidly confess we believe that their views of the ex-Governor, in spite of the present admiration for him, would prevail in the long run, and lead to his losing the State. As we are loth, however, to have a person of Mr. WISE's tact, taste, judgment, discretion, eloquence, and military genius consigned to the shades of private life without a struggle, we are willing to give the Enquirer a hint, which we trust it will take in good part. We strongly recommend the substitution on the ticket of FERNANDO WOOD for JOSEPH LANE for the Vice-Presidency. Mr. WOOD is the great leader of the New-York Democracy. He has the State under his thumb. Nothing but his love for the office of Mayor has prevented his being Governor half a dozen times. We feel pretty confident the Vice-Presidency would tempt "His Honor" to abandon his beloved municipal duties for a wider sphere of usefulness; and with WOOD as his colleague, Gov. WISE would sweep the State. The rural districts are to a man enthusiastic admirers of the Mayor, and that admiration has, if possible, been increased by his imposing attitude at Charleston, and his commanding eloquence in Connecticut. We of the City should be reluctant enough to have "His Honor" go, but we are geometricians enough to know that the whole is greater than a part, and that when the Union demands him, it is the duty of New-York to deliver him up.
headline: {'main': 'Wise for the Presidency.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Wise for the Presidency.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Mayor says that he "is advised" that in spite of the recent act of the Legislature, he has still the power to remove the City Chamberlain "for cause," and that he has removed Mr. STOUT accordingly, or, at all events, requested him to consider himself removed. If it be really true that Mr. WOOD is acting under advice, and not solely in obedience to his own sweet will, we can assure him he is blessed with the safest counselors that ever whispered wisdom into a Mayoral ear. Whether it be that illustrious jurist who stands by him in his private trials -- "Judge" DEAN -- or his official guide, Judge BRONSON, who has expounded the law to him on this occasion, the conclusion arrived at is unquestionable. The oracle at Delphi never gave a response more thoroughly reliable. That the Mayor may remove the Comptroller "for cause," everybody will admit -- the only difference of opinion that can possibly arise between "His Honor" and the rest of the community being as to what constitutes "cause." If Mr. STOUT were to draw the municipal balance from the bank, and leave with it for parts unknown, or if he were to pass his office hours in a state of insensibility over a whisky bottle, or were to burn down the City Hall, or bite off Alderman BOOLE's nose, or fight TERENCE FARLEY for $100 a side in the Park at noon, or lend the City cash to "Dublin Tricks," we should all of us agree that there was cause for turning him out. But whether his refusing to pay interest on the municipal moneys in his possession, when none of his predecessors have ever done anything of the kind, at the mere orders of "His Honor the Mayor," is "cause" or not, is matter on which both "His Honor" and the community at large need to be still further "advised." The opinions of his private counselors will probably fully satisfy "His Honor's" own mind; but the public is much more obtuse than he, and will certainly need the united force of the Justices of the Supreme Court to batter a clear understanding of the matter into its head. "His Honor" will, no doubt, be patient with the stupid creature, when he remembers that "His Honor" was also "advised" by his private, particular counsel that the Metropolitan Police act was unconstitutional, and that he very foolishly rose in rebellion upon the strength of that very mistaken deliverance of the counsel aforesaid. We had hoped that his experience on that occasion would have inspired in him a little salutary distrust of legal opinions which declare "His Honor" to be competent to do whatever his envy, hatred or malice may suggest. But this is by no means the first time that we have given "His Honor" credit for a more teachable disposition than he really possesses.

abstract: The Commissioners of Emigration held their regular weekly meeting yesterday, Mr. VERPLANCK, the President, in the Chair. The Committee on the claims of the different Counties for the support of aliens made a report by which it appears that the amount due them is $23,746,26. They recommended that the claim be paid.
lead_paragraph: The Commissioners of Emigration held their regular weekly meeting yesterday, Mr. VERPLANCK, the President, in the Chair. The Committee on the claims of the different Counties for the support of aliens made a report by which it appears that the amount due them is $23,746,26. They recommended that the claim be paid. A communication was received from several citizens of Buffalo asking for the removal of the present incumbent from the office of Commissioner in that city, and recommending the appointment of a Mr. THAYER. It was referred. Capt. CRABTREE reported that the charges preferred against Capt. JONES, of the packet ship Constitution, for ill-treating his passengers, had been investigated and found to be unjust.

abstract: A DOUGLAS DEMONSTRATION IN NEW-YORK. -- The New-York Democracy have determined to follow in the wake of their Southern fellow believers, who have been organizing anti-secession demonstrations in all the States from Virginia to Louisiana since the adjournment of the Convention to Baltimore. A grand demonstration in favor of the platform of Senator DOUGLAS will take place at the Cooper Institute on Monday evening next, when the successful onslaught of the "Little Giant" upon his foes will doubtless be handsomely applauded, and the "Union feeling" of the Southern Democratic masses encouraged by a reaffirmation of the principles maintained at Charleston by the New-York Delegation. We are last drifting into the swift whirl of the Presidential contest.
lead_paragraph: A DOUGLAS DEMONSTRATION IN NEW-YORK. -- The New-York Democracy have determined to follow in the wake of their Southern fellow believers, who have been organizing anti-secession demonstrations in all the States from Virginia to Louisiana since the adjournment of the Convention to Baltimore. We are last drifting into the swift whirl of the Presidential contest.

abstract: It strikes us that the system of ruling and guiding a great Community by "Boards" has been tried quite long enough in New-York. What the Board of Aldermen has done for us, the now national reputation of BOOLE AND VAN TINE may testify.
lead_paragraph: It strikes us that the system of ruling and guiding a great Community by "Boards" has been tried quite long enough in New-York. What the Board of Aldermen has done for us, the now national reputation of BOOLE AND VAN TINE may testify. To the Board of Ten Governors we owe the brilliant and Christian idea of thinning out our pauper population by introducing rats to the cradle of the new-born babe, in the place of nurse, physician and priest. To the Board of Education it now appears that we are to be indebted for the complete conversion of our system of common schools into a machine for the dissemination of bigotry and corruption. We have abolished the Ten Governors, and it is high time that we should take the other "Boards" seriously in hand.
headline: {'main': 'The Scandal of our Schools.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Scandal of our Schools.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Board of Police Commissioners met at 1 o'clock yesterday, all the members being present. Sergeant LORD, of the Sanitary squad, presented a report of objectionable and filthy places. Forty-three houses were designated, of which two were reported in a "very dangerous condition." and one having a case of small-pox. The Brooklyn Sanitary report included about the same number, hog yards and slaughter-houses being prominently mentioned among the nuisances which require abatement. Two houses in Navy-street were declared to be extremely unsafe. No other business was made public

abstract: A PLACE FOR THE POPE. -- Minnesota, the "land of cloudy water," is troubled, as Pennsylvania once was, by a whisky agitation. The liquor-dealers burned down a church in St. Anthony, and the roofless members not appreciating this Ephesian demonstration, ordered them to leave town. To this the liquordealers objected, and at last accounts both patties were arming themselves in anticipation of a conflict. They evidently need the Pope in Minnesota. Here is a case in which the spiritual power ought to be controlled by the temporal. Let Pius IX. at once leave St. Peter's for St. Paul's.
lead_paragraph: A PLACE FOR THE POPE. -- Minnesota, the "land of cloudy water," is troubled, as Pennsylvania once was, by a whisky agitation. The liquor-dealers burned down a church in St. Anthony, and the roofless members not appreciating this Ephesian demonstration, ordered them to leave town. To this the liquordealers objected, and at last accounts both patties were arming themselves in anticipation of a conflict. They evidently need the Pope in Minnesota. Here is a case in which the spiritual power ought to be controlled by the temporal. Let Pius IX. at once leave St. Peter's for St. Paul's.

abstract: Mr. JEREMIAH SMITH, a gentleman 60 years of age, who has for some time been in the employ of the New-Haven Railroad Company as chief clerk, died in the New-York Hospital on Wednesday night in consequence of injuries received by being run over on Tuesday evening by a car on the Fourth-avenue road. The Coroner's jury exonerated the driver of the car from all blame.....THOMAS GOFF, a lad, 10 years of age, who has been missing since last Monday from the residence of his parents, No. 310 West-street, was found drowned at the foot of Spring-street, North River. He is supposed to have fallen into the water while playing about the wharves. The Coroners also inquired into the circumstances attending the deaths of three unknown men, one of whom was found in the bay, near Ellis' Island; another at the foot of Pike-street, East River, and the third at Pier No. 2, East River. In each case a verdict of supposed drowning was rendered....MICHAEL ALBUYREN, a butcher, residing at No. 327 West Thirty-sixth-street, was sitting with his family on Wednesday evening, and in the course of conversation expressed his penitence for having allowed himself to indulge in a drunken debauch, from which he was just recovering. Almost immediately afterward he retired to his room and shot himself in the side with a pistol, inflicting a fatal wound. Coroner O'KEEFE held an inquest.

abstract: This match was resumed on Thursday, and terminated in a victory for Newark. This is the second
lead_paragraph: This match was resumed on Thursday, and terminated in a victory for Newark. This is the second of a home-and-home match between these Clubs in which Newark has been victorious; last year they beat the New-York Club in one inning, and they now say that they will play no more matches with any Club in the United States, except they play even -- eleven against eleven. The result of the first innings on each side was: New-York twenty-five; Newark eighty-seven. The result of the second innings is: New-York, one hundred and seven; Newark, forty-six, with the loss of only six wickets of the sixteen. The New-York Club were completely out-played by the Newarkers, although SHARP, BRAY, JOSEPH, SAMS, CROSSLEY and HIGHAX exerted themselves to the utmost, and batted finely, particularly JOSEPH and SAMS. Newark was well represented at the bat by FORD, BAKER, WALTERS and GREACEN, the latter being a very superior batter, and bringing out his bat. HALLIS' bowling was entirely wide of the wicket in the second innings, and HATTERSLEY was not up to his mark in long-stopping as he had been in the first innings -- vide 40 wides and byes.

abstract: THE WINTER GARDEN. -- Astonishing as it may appear, VERDI's opera of "Nabuco" was actually sung as advertised on Wednesday evening, by MAX MARETZEK's company. The performance was rather tentative than tempting; and though much allowance must be made for the jars and jogs incident to a first attempt at putting "Babylon the Great" upon the stage, and to the surprising difference between a Ronconi and an Aidvani in perhaps the most arduous role which VERDI has created, it is only faithful criticism to say that if Nabuco was sung as advertised on Wednesday, it was hardly sung as written. Although this, first, and to our thinking, most durably great success" of the Milanese composer has been essayed before in America, it has never been attacked in so imposing a fashion, and we shall, therefore, defer til, after the performance of to-night the comments which we do not care to make on the attempt of Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: THE WINTER GARDEN. -- Astonishing as it may appear, VERDI's opera of "Nabuco" was actually sung as advertised on Wednesday evening, by MAX MARETZEK's company. abstract: SUICIDE IN HUDSON. -- A man named PETER COMBINE, who for some time past has been employed in Mr. GRUFF's store, in Hudson, Columbia County, entered his boarding-house between 6 and 7 o'clock on Sunday evening, apparently in a great state of excitement, seized a valise, and leaving the house again, started to run up Warren-street. Officer C. CARTER was informed of the occurrence, and immediately went in pursuit of COMBINE, who turned from Warren into Third-street, where he suddenly stopped and drew a razor across, his throat, severing the jugular artery. He expired in a few moments. The occurrence created a great excitement in the town.

abstract: Abigail Dodge Vs. Ezra Flagg et al.--This was an appeal to the General Term of the Supreme Court from a judgment at Special Term, directing an ad-  measurement of the plaintiff's dower in four houses and lots situated in West Eleventh-street, in this City, valued at $40,000.
lead_paragraph: Abigail Dodge Vs. Ezra Flagg et al. -- This was an appeal to the General Term of the Supreme Court from a judgment at Special Term, directing an ad- measurement of the plaintiff's dower in four houses and lots situated in West Eleventh-street, in this City, valued at $40,000. The facts in the case are as follows: The houses in question were owned by Josiah Dodge at his decease, March 20, 1855. By his will he devised to his wife -- the plaintiff -- his homestead in New-Hampshire for life, and in addition, gave her an annuity of $400 for life, which he charged as a lien upon such houses, to be paid in proportion to their assessed value. Subject to this annuity, the testator devised two of the houses to his daughter, and to two sons one house each. The testator directed that the house devised to his eldest son should be held in trust by a trustee to be appointed by the Court, and. further directed that the rents of all the houses be applied to the payment of the annuity and other incumbrances upon the property; and until such incumbrances were thus paid, the devisees were not to enjoy their use. Executors and trustees were appointed by the will. The plaintiff, after receiving her annuity as it accrued, and after the lapse of one year, commenced this action to recover dower on the houses in Eleventh-street. From the Special Term order defendants appealed, and their counsel contended that although the testator did not in express terms give the widow the annuity and other benefits provided by the will, in lieu of dower, nevertheless, as such was his manifest intention, her dower was barred by statute, as she had not, as thereby required, elected within one year from the testator's decree, which she would take; and that the decisions which upheld the arbitrary rule that such intention of the testator would not be adjudged, unless dower would subvert some provision of the will, were unsound, Conceding the rule heretofore applied to be correct, then it was claimed, that a set-off of dower would subvert the annuity, inasmuch as each, house was charged with its share of the $400; and if the widow entered into possession of a third, she must sink so much of her annuity as her third should bear in proportion. Such inconsistency, therefore, demonstrated the testator's intention to bar dower and put the widow to her election. A further reason which was urged in support of the testator's intention to her dower, was the power conferred upon the trustees to lease all of the houses, which power could not be exercised if the widow entered into possession of one-third. It was also claimed that the grant of a valuable homestead and an allowance of annuity were a greater consideration than her dower, and that they would afford her an ample support for life. For such reasons the widow ought not to be allowed, to frustrate the obvious intentions of the testator.

abstract: THE POSTMASTER OF NEW-YORK. -- An explanation of defalcations in the New-York Postoffice may perhaps be found in the miserable meagreness of the salary attached. The "wage" of the Postmaster is but $2,000 a year, and his commission on boxes amounts to about $3,000 more, making a total of $5,000. This is the utmost that can honestly be made from the office. Meanwhile the incumbent is expected to contribute liberally to all political movements, from a bonfire at Tammany to an election in Oregon, and to make himself generally a wheel-horse of the Administration which has honored him with its confidence. In political subscriptions alone, any Postmaster of New-York who "respects his party position" may easily devour his income from his office. In these circumstances, it is to be hoped that Mr. DIX will set his face in favor of an immediate change of tactics on this point. The joke of appointing a man to an office which involves an expenditure of twice the amount of its salary, singularly resembles the pleasantry which Oriental monarchs occasionally permit themselves towards favorites who incur their displeasure. They present the disgraced Vizier with a white elephant. The gift is a mark of distinguished consideration, but the beast soon eats the unfortunate recipient out of house and home. The white elephant of New-York has done more than this He has just eaten his master out of honor as well, and has passed from a joke into a mauvaise plaisanterie."

abstract: ANNIVERSARY OF THE ORPHAN ASYLUM SOCIETY. -- The Twenty-seventh Anniversary of the Brooklyn Ophan Asylum Society, was held last evening, at the Athenaeum, under the direction of A.H. DANA, Esq. The building was crowded. The children in the care of the Society, about one hundred in number, were seated upon the platform. The exercises were opened with prayer by Rev. Dr. CUTLER, who was followed by Rev. Dr. FABLEY, in the reading of a portion of Scripture. The annual reports of the Secretary and Treasurer were read. From these reports it appears that during the year, 174 children received the benefits of the institution, 60 of whom have been received since May last; 64 were discharged -- returned to their friends; 10 furnished with homes; 10 were sent to the Asylum, and there was one death. Total number remaining, 98. There was on hand at the commencement of the year, $743 05, which was increased by contributions, donations, back State money, and from other sources, to $10,268 40. After deducting the expenses of the year, the Treasurer reports a balance on hand of $821 69. The exercises on the part of the children, last evening, consisted of singing and recitations. There were also several addresses made by clergymen, and the proceedings closed with the benediction. The officers elected for the ensuing year are nearly the same with those having the charge of the Institution during the twelvemonth just closed.

abstract: We had heard so much from his own "organ" of the almost superhuman eloquence of "His Honor the Mayor," during the recent canvass in Connecticut, that we have been waiting with some anxiety for the production of a specimen of it a little nearer home.
lead_paragraph: We had heard so much from his own "organ" of the almost superhuman eloquence of "His Honor the Mayor," during the recent canvass in Connecticut, that we have been waiting with some anxiety for the production of a specimen of it a little nearer home. We have now been gratified by "His Honor's" display at the dinner of the Old Dominion Society, on Tuesday evening, of which an authentic report, revised and corrected by himself, appears in the organ aforesaid. As we are firmly persuaded that " His Honor" is the most remarkable man of the present day, and that in elevating him to his present position, New-York has simply shown that she knows what is due to herself, we have perused with great interest what "His Honor" had to say of the great City over which he presides. We should be ashamed of ourselves if we failed to reproduce the following exordium:

abstract: CLUBS. Yesterday being the opening day of the season for the Boat Clubs composing the "Hudson Navy," arrangements were made for a handsome display, in connection with the review and drill. A considerable crowd of spectators assembled at the foot of Christopher-street to see the boats form in line for their departure to the drill ground, opposite the Elysian
lead_paragraph: CLUBS. -- Yesterday being the opening day of the season for the Boat Clubs composing the "Hudson Navy," arrangements were made for a handsome display, in connection with the review and drill. A considerable crowd of spectators assembled at the foot of Christopher-street to see the boats form in line for their departure to the drill ground, opposite the Elysian Fields, Hoboken. The place is hereafter to be designated as "Navy Bay." This miniature navy is composed of young gentlemen who have the leisure and means, as well as the inclination to cultivate the "manly art of" -- rowing. It was organized in October, 1859, at which time the Atlanta, Aurora, Waverley and Atlantic Boat Clubs constitued the infant navy. Several clubs have since been admitted, and they now consist of the following: Atlanta, 8 oars; Our Jessie, 6; Aurora 6; Waverley, 6; Twilight, 6; Eagle, 6; Volante, 4; Washington, 4; Linta, 4; Nassau, 4; and Niantic 6. There are at present 80 members, with a prospect of a steady increase. A large party of ladies yesterday lent the charm of their presence to the occasion, for whose special benefit, including the members of the Press, a steamer was provided to convey them to an advantageous point for observing the evolutions of the little fleet as they went through with their drill, in accordance with the manual adopted for their regulations, under the direction of the Commodore. The elegant boats, each decorated with its proper flag; the neat uniforms of the rowers, and the officer-like bearing of the various commanders, were the theme of much admiration. The heavy east wind, which made it quite rough, and the near prospect of rain, caused an early termination of the review. The scrub-race at the close caused some merriment among the spectators. There were present from the Schuylkill Navy, of Philadelphia, Commodore BROLASKY, Vice-Commodore MITCHELL, ANTHON WELLS, President of the Bachelors' Club, and others. There are to be regular regattas during the Summer, at which handsome prizes will be competed for.

abstract: Joseph P. Lipsker, a Teuton, having a jewelry store in the Bowery, was apprehended yesterday by Officer Miner, of the Tenth Precinct, because he had purchased four gold watches and three silver snuff boxes, worth in the aggregate $240, for one-fourth that sum. The property is ascertained to have been a portion of $3,600 worth, which was stolen on the 7th inst, from Mr. Isadore Samson, of No. 192 Notre Dame street, Montreal, Canada, by one Julius Simpson alias Beers, who brought the property to this City. Justice BRENNAN committed Lipsker on a charge of having received stolen goods.

abstract: The Rebublican National Convention succeeded yesterday in clearing away all the formal and preliminary business before it, leaving nothing to be done but to ballot for a Presidential candidate.
lead_paragraph: The Rebublican National Convention succeeded yesterday in clearing away all the formal and preliminary business before it, leaving nothing to be done but to ballot for a Presidential candidate. The several Committees made their reports, which the Convention acted upon with the utmost promptitude. That on Business reported a number of rules to govern the balloting. Among these were the following: That four votes be cast by delegates at large, and two for each Congressional District; that 304 votes shall be considered a majority of the whole number of votes when all the States in the Union are represented, and that the Convention on this ratio be required to nominate candidates. The first of these, with the amendment that no more votes shall be cast than there are delegates present, was adopted. The second elicited a minority report in favor of a simple majority of the whole number of votes being sufficient to elect; and the minority report was accepted by the Convention. The Committee on Credentials reporting in favor of the admission of Southern States to full votes, a warm debate sprung up, the anti-Seward interest endeavoring to exclude or reduce the influence of these delegations, and the friends of SEWARD advocating its unreserved admission. The point was finally compromised by the apportionment of 23 votes each to Virgian and Kentucky, 11 votes to Maryland, 6 to Texas, and 5 to Oregon. The Platform was then reported from the Committee on Resolutions. It is eminently conservative in tone; declares for the immunity of sovereign States from interference with their domestic institutions; condemns the treason of JOHN BROWN, and advocates au exalted tariff, and a relaxation of the naturalization laws. The tariff clause gave great satisfaction to Pennsylvania, while Massachusetts protested angrily against the concession to the foreign element contained in the naturalization provision. The platform, with a trifling amendment proposed by Mr. CURTIS, of New-York, was adopted. Our Special Correspondent remains of the opinion that the strength of Mr. SEWARD in the Convention is such that he will, in all likelihood, be nominated on the 10th or 11th ballot to-day. The elements of opposition remain incoherent; a last effort to concentrate upon Mr. LINCOLN having failed last evening. Mr. BATES is now abandoned. The Pennsylvania delegation still assert that Mr. SEWARD cannot carry that State; while Massachusetts and Connecticut regard the naturalization clause as fatal to the party in New-England.

abstract: On Wednesday evening, the 2d inst., HEENAN arrived in Liverpool from Chester, and took up his quarters at the Waterloo Hotel. His visit was kept stricily private, so that no manifestation took place on his behalf, and even the persons in the hotel were not aware for some time of the presence of the farfamed Benecia Boy.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday evening, the 2d inst., HEENAN arrived in Liverpool from Chester, and took up his quarters at the Waterloo Hotel. His visit was kept stricily private, so that no manifestation took place on his behalf, and even the persons in the hotel were not aware for some time of the presence of the farfamed Benecia Boy. He was accompanied by two American friends, said to be his backers in the recent contest for the championship. So careful was the American pugilist to avoid recognition, that he moved about under an assumed name. On Wednesday evening and Thursday forenoon he visited several places in the town, and amongst others made a call at the Clayton Hall, where he remained a short time, and [???]ad an interview with some friends he had known in America. Whether he received the subscription said to have been raised for him by a number of American captains belonging to this port, we have not been able to learn. In fact, the inquiries which we have institute incline us to doubt whether any subscription bas been made in this town for the American champion. In the afternoon HEENAN and his two friends proceeded to London by the 3:40 P.M. train. The party occupied a first-class carriage. HEENAN having teen recognised by one or two of the railway officials, the fact of his presence was made known to several persons who happened to be in the station at the time, aid they immediately, sought to gratify their curiosity by attempting to get a sight at the "fighting man." Some were successful, but others were denied the gratification, for the party, on finding themselves recognised, drew up the blinds of the carriage to protect themselves from the public gaze. We understand that two Liverpool gentlemen were, by special desire, allowed to see HEENAN, with whom they exchanged the customary courtesies. One of the spectators, who had previously known HEENAN, describes him as being considerably altered since he passed through Liverpool on his arrival in this country to contest the championship.

abstract: Hon. ABRAM LINCOLN was born in Hardin County, Kentucky, on the 12th of February, 1809. His opportunities for obtaining an education were but limited, but he worked his way to the bar and for some time practiced law. During the Black Hawk war he was Captain of a company of volunteers. Subsequently, and it may have been as a reward for bravery displayed in his campaignings, he was appointed postmaster of a small village in Illinois. From this position he advanced to a seat in the Illinois Legislature, to which he was four times elected. In 1847 he went to Washington as a representative in Congress, and on the 15th of June. 1858, was nominated by the Republican Convention held at Springfield, Illinois, as a candidate for the United States Senatorship, in opposition to Hon. STEPHEN A. DOUGLAS. In his speech accepting the nomination, he emphatically indorsed the "irrepressible conflict" doctrine as enunciated by Mr. SEWARD. The contest which succeeded Mr. LINCOLN's nomination was carried on by the opposing candidates with great earnestness, each stumping the State in his own behalf. The canvass terminated in the triumph of Mr. DOUGLAS. He secured the election of a majority of his friends to the State Legislature, and was returned to the seat in the Senate which he now occupies.

The contest which succeeded Mr. LINCOLN's nomination was carried on by the opposing candidates with great earnestness, each stumping the State in his own behalf. The canvass terminated in the triumph of Mr. DOUGLAS. He secured the election of a majority of his friends to the State Legislature, and was returned to the seat in the Senate which he now occupies.

abstract: On Sunday, April 22, at twelve minutes before 2 o'clock P.M., a prolonged shock of an earthquake, lasting eighty seconds, was experienced in Lima, Callao, Chorrillos, Canete, and in other places in the vicinity of Lima, which caused immense damage. The shocks continued at short intervals, so that fifty of them were experienced within the space of seventy-two hours. In Lima the greater portion of the buildings have received more or less damage by falling of walls, roofs, cracks, &c., and many buildings and outhouses have been totally destroyed. Most of the public buildings, the palaces, churches, convents, carcels, colleges, &c., have suffered by the falling or inclination of their towers. In Callao, the damage has been comparatively slight. In Chorrillos, the watering place of the Limenos, several fine buildings have been destroyed, all or nearly all are badly injured, and several persons were killed. Canete has suffered severely, nearly the whole town having been thrown down. The shocks continued, but were slighter and of less frequent occurrence, no to the time of the sailing of the steamer on the 27th. The people of Callao, fearing that the sea might recede, and returning, drown the whole population, as it did in 1749, fled by thousands to Lima, which is situated six miles from Callao and is 309 feet higher than the latter place. The people and visitors of Chorrillos also flocked to Lima. In Lima thousands of persons were encamped in the Plazas and on the Alameda, fearing to occupy the houses. The losses in Lima are estimated at $1,000,000, and it is computed that $200,000 will cover the losses, so far as heard from, in the neighboring towns. Callao is only, damaged about $30,000 and Chorrillos loses $40,000. The dead do not probably comprise over a dozen persons, but a great number have been wounded. In Manta trees were rooted out of the ground, and one of the hills in the vicinity was split in twain, hot foetid water issuing from the fissure. The panic among the people still continued when the steamer left. The priests were carrying images of the Virgin and the Saints through the streets, followed by long processions of the frightened people. Some of the most frightened and bigoted at Callao took from the church of Bella Vista an image of our Lord of the Sea, and, accompanied by a band of music and a guard of honor on each side of the image, marched in procession to the seaside and set it up to stay the waves that they feared would overwhelm them. The steamer brings no accounts of serious shocks from more northerly ports.

abstract: The Washington Constitution, referring to the charges made against the Administration relative to its previous knowledge of the deficit in Mr. FOWLER's accounts, says: "There is only one assertion in the articles to which we refer which we would condescend to notice. It is that which states that Mr. FOWLER acted in opposition to the views of the president at Charleston. In the first place, the President never intimated to Mr. FOWLER, or to anybody else, what course he should pursue at Charleston. Mr. FOWLER knew that Mr. BUCHANAN had no desire with regard to the action of that Convention but that it might secure the best interests of the Democratic Party, and, consequently, secure the welfare of the country: and we can testify, of our own personal knowledge and observation, that Mr. FOWLER used every exertion of which he was capable, both as a delegate and a private citizen, that that laudable and patriotic desire should be realized. Deeply as we deplore that gentleman's dereliction of official duty and deviation from the path of rectitude, we cannot permit his fidelity to his party to be questioned by men who only dare to assail him because he is unable to defend himself, and in order to provide a basis for their ribald assaults on private character. The instant that Mr. FOWLER's defalcation was made known to the Administration he was removed from office, and orders placed in the hands of proper officers to proceed to New-York, to take possession of the Post-office, and Commence, the necessary proceedings for Mr. FOWLER's arrest, and the recovery, by the sale of Mr. F.'s property, and the enforcement of the bend given by his sureties, of the whole, or as much as possible, of the sum due to the Government."

abstract: This Republic seems to be in a highly prosperous condition. New mines of copper and silver are being discovered in all the mineral districts, of exceeding richness. Commerce is greatly increasing. Agriculture is prospering, and great public improvements are progressing and in contemplation. In the Province of Coquimbo, where ten gold mines, twenty silver, and three hundred copper ones, are already worked, a rich copper mine has been discovered, yielding 40 per cent. A great discovery of silver and copper mines in the Province of Aconcagua is also spoken of.

abstract: W. Hislop, F.R.A.S., in view of the near approach of the great solar eclipse of July, suggests the construction of a heliograph, as follows. He says: "I propose to take a view lens of about 26 inches focus, and of a diameter sufficient to insure accuracy in the figure. This should be furnished, at the proper distance in front, with a series of stops, say from 116th of an inch to the larger size, at which the lens will work without sensible spherical aberration. These apertures should be so arranged as to be readily changed, and may be either holes pierced in a plate of brass sliding in front of the lens, or be arranged in a circular disc, turning on a centre, similar to the diaphragm of a microscope. The lens so fitted should be fixed at the end of a telescope tube of the proper length, and the image of the object, instead of being received upon a screen, or impressed upon a sensitized plate, should be received by another photographic lens, adjustable at the proper distance to magnify the image. The best lens for the latter object would probably be one on the orthographic principle, which construction would also increase the means of correction in combination with the front lens, so as to obtain the utmost amount of accuracy of picture. By the arrangement I have thus described, instead of retarding the sensitiveness of the plate by chemical means as is now done, we have the power mechanically of diminishing the light, and at the same time arriving at our results by a shorter path.
lead_paragraph: W. Hislop, F.R.A.S., in view of the near approach of the great solar eclipse of July, suggests the construction of a heliograph, as follows. He says: "I propose to take a view lens of about 26 inches focus, and of a diameter sufficient to insure accuracy in the figure. This should be furnished, at the proper distance in front, with a series of stops, say from 116th of an inch to the larger size, at which the lens will work without sensible spherical aberration. These apertures should be so arranged as to be readily changed, and may be either holes pierced in a plate of brass sliding in front of the lens, or be arranged in a circular disc, turning on a centre, similar to the diaphragm of a microscope. The lens so fitted should be fixed at the end of a telescope tube of the proper length, and the image of the object, instead of being received upon a screen, or impressed upon a sensitized plate, should be received by another photographic lens, adjustable at the proper distance to magnify the image. The best lens for the latter object would probably be one on the orthographic principle, which construction would also increase the means of correction in combination with the front lens, so as to obtain the utmost amount of accuracy of picture. By the arrangement I have thus described, instead of retarding the sensitiveness of the plate by chemical means as is now done, we have the power mechanically of diminishing the light, and at the same time arriving at our results by a shorter path.

abstract: Two atleast of the three candidates whose claims are to plead for the suffrages of the American people, in the canvass of 1860, now stand before the country. lead_paragraph: Two atleast of the three candidates whose claims are to plead for the suffrages of the American people, in the canvass of 1860, now stand before the country. The Union Conservatives, as they style themselves, having nominated Mr. BELL, of Tennessee, on the ground of his integrity, the Republicans have now put forward Mr. LINCOLN, of Illinois, on the ground of his availability. The proceedings of the Democracy at Charleston, and their subsequent movements in the most important sections of the South, indicate with tolerable clearness that Mr. DOUGLAS will be selected by this party at Baltimore, on the 18th of June, as its standard-bearer.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC -- That most dramatic singer, Mme. GAZZANIGA took her benefit at the Opera House, last night, in that role of Lucrezia Borgia, which first introduced her to the acquaintance and admiration of the New-York public. Mme. GAZZANIGA is preeminently an artist of feeling, a born interpreter, to use the jargon of the old Weiamr criticism, rather of BELLINI's Parma violets and DONIZETTI's passion flowers, than of AUBER's camellias and WEBER's magnolias. She has neither classic delicacy of execution, nor intense intellectual depth of expression, but she sings with all the emphasis of emotion; and therefore above almost any prima dona whom we have had among us, requires the support of a well-combined, well-administered and scientifically accurate orchestra and company. Need we say, therefore, that she might be heard to better advantage than she just now can be, in Irving-place? Today Mme. GAZZANIGA, PATTI, BRIGNOLI, and the rest, close the season with "Don Giovanni."
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC -- That most dramatic singer, Mme. GAZZANIGA took her benefit at the Opera House, last night, in that role of Lucrezia Borgia, which first introduced her to the acquaintance and admiration of the New-York public. Mme. She has neither classic delicacy of execution, nor intense intellectual depth of expression, but she sings with all the emphasis of emotion; and therefore above almost any prima dona whom we have had among us, requires the support of a well-combined, well-administered and scientifically accurate orchestra and company. abstract: The Finance Committee of the Heenan Testimonial Fund met last evening, at the Malta Saloon to report, Mr. MICHAEL PHELAN in the Chair, Mr. MCGOWAN Secretary. On motion of Capt. TURNER, the reading of minutes of the last meeting were dispensed with. A letter was read from Mr. BURNS, begging to be excused from acting on the Committee, on account of indisposition; his resignation was accepted, and Mr. M.D. GOODERSON was appointed in his stead. On report from the Treasurer being called for, Mr. JOHN HOUGHTLIN arose and stated that very little cash had yet been paid in. Mr. CAMPBELL had in hand about $200, Mr. CONWAY nearly $90. Mr. CONWAY stated that he had called on Mr. BARNUM, of the Museum for a contribution, and that Mr. BARNUM had promised to contribute $100 conditionally. The conditions were that Mr. HEENAN should show himself in the Museum fifteen minutes after his arrival, and enter into a permanent arrangement to remain on exhibition as a curiosity. On learning that their friend was expected to walk, on a platform in company with the WHAT IS IT, the soliciting gentlemen indignantly declined taking Mr. BARNUM's subscription on such terms. Mr. CONWAY also stated that he had called on JAMES GORDON BENNETT, of the Herald. Mr. BENNETT was in his private room, but Mr. HUDSON sent in the subscription-book for his attention; it came back with the reply that the thing was not quite in his line. Mr. CONWAY proposed to call upon him again. It was moved that the names of all subscribers to the testimonial be gathered in a book and bound in gold, the motion, after some discussion, was adopted by the meeting. Mr. CAMPBELL had seen a letter from JAMEL MULLIGAN, stating that in one night, in New-Orleans, $1,600 had been subscribed to the fund. Mr. NEIL BRYANT reported collections of about $300; Mr. IRVING was not present, but it was stated that his book bore subscriptions to the amount of $1,100.

abstract: Our files of Buenos Ayrean journals furnish intel ligence from River Plate to the 30th of March.  The political news is of interest. The Government, or at least the Commission, named to arrange the details of a return of the State to the Argentine Union, had been raising difficulties in the way of the incor- poration, and by various overt acts had indicated an...
lead_paragraph: Our files of Buenos Ayrean journals furnish intel ligence from River Plate to the 30th of March. The political news is of interest. The Government, or at least the Commission, named to arrange the details of a return of the State to the Argentine Union, had been raising difficulties in the way of the incor- poration, and by various overt acts had indicated an intention to disregard the treaty signed in December last, and remain independent. The prevalent impression of the foreign residents was that a public declaration of a design to regard that treaty as null would soon appear, and that the Argentine Government would at once resume hostilities.

abstract: The work of the Convention is ended. The youngster who, with ragged trousers, used barefoot to drive his father's oxen and spend his days in splitting rails, has risen to high eminence, and ABRAM LINCOLN, of Illinois, is declared its candidate for President by the National Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: Special Dispatch to the New-York Times.

abstract: The Convention at Chicago yesterday completed its labors by nominating for President ABRAM LINCOLN; for Vice-President, HANNIBAL HAMLIN. The result was so little the result of preconcert, and so little anticipated by the Convention, as to have excited there as much surprise as it has unquestionably excited in the public mind here. Upon the first ballot, Mr. SEWARD received 173 1/2, Mr. LINCOLN, 102, Mr. CAMERON, 59 1/2, Mr. BATES, 48, Mr. CHASE, 40, scattering 42. The second ballot gave Mr. SEWARD 184 1/2, Mr. LINCOLN, 181, Judge MCLEAN, 50 1/2, Mr. CHASE, 42 1/2, Mr. BATES, 35, scattering 14. The third ballot resulted in the choice of Mr. LINCOLN, which, on the motion of a New-York delegate, was made unanimous. The nomination was received with wild demonstrations of delight and enthusiasm on the part of the original supporters of the Illinois candidate, and with no marked evidences of dissatisfaction among the friends of the disappointed contestants. The first impression generally in this City, and, as far as the telegraph informs us, throughout the Eastern and Middle States, is not unreservedly favorable to the ticket. The party organizations here held their meetings last evening, and discussed the subject without any demonstrations of warm approval, or contented acquiescence; the expression of a belief that the chances of the candidate to be nominated at Baltimore are greatly improved by the action at Chicago being quite general. At Albany the same feeling of disappointment obtained at first; but a reaction took place before evening, when the jubilation became universal. The nomination of Mr. HAMLIN as Vice President was a concession, it was understood, to the disappointed feeling of the New York delegation.

abstract: Zimmer vs. Eidlits. This was an action to recover of the defendant damages for injuries alleged to have been sustained while in his employ and through his negligence. The defendant was contractor for the erection of Tabernacle Church, corner of Sixth-avenue and Thirty-fourth-street, and the plaintiff was a laborer thereon. The accident
lead_paragraph: Zimmer vs. Eidlits. -- This was an action to recover of the defendant damages for injuries alleged to have been sustained while in his employ and through his negligence. The defendant was contractor for the erection of Tabernacle Church, corner of Sixth-avenue and Thirty-fourth-street, and the plaintiff was a laborer thereon. The accident occurred on the 22d of August, 1858, while the plaintiff was standing near the church, a mason's tool, weighting about two pounds, falling upon his head, fracturing his skull and otherwise injuring him. The work men were engaged on the tower of the church, and it was sought to make the contactor liable, because he did not cause to be erected a scaffold to protect those below from falling implements or materials

abstract: From some unascertained cause a fire broke out between 7 and 8 o'clock last evening in Mr. ROBERT E. BURNS' daguerrian saloon, on the third floor of the building No. 365 Broadway, causing the entire destruction of the contents, and involving a lose of between $3,000 and $4,000, which is nearly covered by an insurance of $2,000 in the Firemen's Fund and a similar amount in the People's Company. The stock in the clothing store of WOLF SCHO[???]CK, on the second floor, was also injured to the extent of $500 by water. Insured for $4,000 in the Washington, Brooklyn, Rutgers and Pacific Compadies. R. O'NEAL, a carpet weaver, who occupied the basement, suffered a loss of $100, also by water. He is insured in the Market Co., for $500. The building is owned by Mrs. JANE DUNCAN, and the damage it sustained, about $500, is met by a full insurance. The adjoining premises, No. 363, owned by Mr. A. WOOD, were slightly injured; they are insured in the Manhattan Co. Mrs. DICKIE, a milliner, who occupied a part of the store, and the tenants in the upper part of the building, suffered an inconsiderable loss by water.

abstract: The reception of the news of LINCOLN'S nomination, at Chicago, threw the House of Representatives into such excitement as to suspend business for some minutes. Everybody was delighted. Even Mr. SEWARD'S warmest admirers pronounced the nomination most able and judicious. Judge DOUGLAS and his friends think it the heaviest blow the Democracy has yet received, and say that by to-morrow night there will not be a tar barrel or a pound of powder in Illinois.

abstract: -- Popular Astronomy is the title of a concise elementary treatise, just issued by PHINNEY, BLAKEMAN & MASON, from the pen of Prof. O.M. MITCHEL. The bare announcement that Prof MITCHEL has written a book devoted to the exposition of that science in which he is an acknowledged master, is sufficient to commend it to the reading public. The Professor is one of the earnest, hard-working, untiring and faithful laborers in the field of Science, whose utterances become law, and to whom a confiding community awards its unanimous verdict of approval. He is a simple man, lucid and logical in his style, poetical when he pleases to be, but usually hard and solid as the facts he sets forth; deeply imbued with enthusiasm, but able to check the exuberance of fancy; fond of elucidating great principles in nature, but cautious in adapting theories until he has subjected them to the test of actual experiment. In this volume he has followed, as he very justly observes in some modest prefatory remarks, "the path of real discovery." An exceedingly valuable part of the work is the history of his own observations, including sketches of new methods and new instruments which he has introduced into the Observatories at Cincinnati and Albany. With the exception of certain general descriptions, given some years since at the meetings of the Scientific Convention, Prof. MITCHEL has never before defined the full uses or illustrated the practical utility of his inventions for the measurement of North polar distances and right ascensions. The simplicity, beauty, and value of these applications are developed in the present volume, imparting an additional value to a work which will justify its claim to the title of a "popular" Astronomy.

abstract: The religious Press, chiefly filled with reports of the Anniversaries, still find room for editorial comment upon the character of the Society meetings. The Evangelist remarks a decided change In the general aspect of Anniversary week in this City; laments the decline of interest in the religious exercises, and draws a striking contrast between former times and times present. "The time was," says the Evangalist, "when the return of May was an event; when it was an annual feast; when pastors, with joyful hearts, came from far and near: but the glory of those days is departed." It finds the reason of this change, primarily, in the obvious fact that the special need of such occasions as a means of at once gathering and diffusing religious intelligence, is done away, for all the information given is anticipated by more rapid and universal modes of communication. The Observer devotes itself to a review of the action of the American Tract Society, rejoicing that its recent anniversary was free from the annoyances of past years. The Observer says: "Conservative men of the East and the West, of the South and the North, who now contribute to its support every year, are satisfied that the discussion has gone far enough, and it is now time to go on with the single work for which the society was established. This conviction was clearly announced by the vote to adjourn at the late meeting." The same paper publishes the following explanatory note from Hon. GREENE C. BRONSON:

abstract: The announcement that the National Republican Convention at Chicago had nominated ABRAM LINCOLN for President, on the third ballot, was published in the City at 1 o'clock, and, as it spread, was received by the friends of Senator SEWARD with some show of disappointment.
lead_paragraph: The announcement that the National Republican Convention at Chicago had nominated ABRAM LINCOLN for President, on the third ballot, was published in the City at 1 o'clock, and, as it spread, was received by the friends of Senator SEWARD with some show of disappointment. They had been informed by the Republican organ, in the morning, that the opposition to Mr. SEWARD could not be united, and that therefore his prospect of receiving the nomination was very good. Therefore, many of them were unprepared to hear of his defeat soon, if at all, they had not anticipated such a result until after a protracted struggle. The result was that the nomination was not received with enthusiasm. During the morning, the only Republicans who seemed pleased with the result, who were inclined to talk, were those of the old friends of HENRY CLAY, who had joined the Republican Party. Some of them showed great delight, not so much because Mr. LINCOLN had received the nomination, as that Mr. SEWARD had been defeated. They claimed that in his defeat he had received full pay for having defeated HENRY CLAY in the very same manner and under similar circumstances. The Democracy appeared jubilant. They said they saw in the action of the Republican Convention the same unfortunate element that destroyed the old Whig Party. The old doctrine of availability had ruled, they said, and it would ruin, as it had dove before. They pretended great indignation that the Republicans should have sacrificed their representative man in the present campaign, as the Whigs did in the case of HENRY CLAY and of DANIEL WEBSTER, and resolved to punish them by electing a Democratic Present in November next. Later in the day many of the Republicans came to speak of the nomination as a very good one, although they coupled with the remark an expression of regret that Mr. SEWARD had not been made their candidate. At about 4 o'clock one hundred guns were fired in the City Hall Park, and some of the several hundred present spoke cheeringly of the nomination of Mr. LINCOLN. In the evening several meetings were held, which are reported below.

abstract: -- The Paris correspondent of a New-York journal tells us of a celebrated painter, who was much annoyed in his morning walks by a Biblical painting, miserable in taste and execution, representing a hideous "Joseph" struggling to escape from the embraces of an abominably ugly "Potiphar's wife." So much annoyed was he by this libel in oil that he finally concluded to purchase the picture and reduce it to ashes. Stepping into the shop he demanded of the proprietor the price.
