abstract: The latest advices from Europe inform us that the Pope has no intention of recovering the Romagna by force of arms, from which he no doubt desires us to draw the inference that he is averse to shedding blood, even to preserve the patrimony of St. Peter. As, however, his army does not yet amount to 20,000
lead_paragraph: The latest advices from Europe inform us that the Pope has no intention of recovering the Romagna by force of arms, from which he no doubt desires us to draw the inference that he is averse to shedding blood, even to preserve the patrimony of St. Peter. As, however, his army does not yet amount to 20,000 men in all, and as it is extremely doubtful whether it will ever be any larger, and as it is in the main composed of mercenaries, adventurers, and chevaliers d'industrie from every country in Europe, while the army of Sardinia musters 200,000 men in arms, with the entire population of Central Italy behind them, the world will be somewhat slow in appreciating His Holiness' magnanimity in not laying violent hands on the Romagnoles. In fact, we fear most people will come to the conclusion that the want of a will is simply due to the want of a way, and that if the Prince of Peace could muster 300,000 men of war he would treat most of the cities of AEmilia to a dose of that "grace, mercy and peace" which he showered, by the aid of Swiss bayonets, upon the obstinate sinners of Perugia. His forbearance is somewhat similar to that of the brigands, who permitted the regiment of Zouaves to circulate along the loneliest roads in Italy without once molesting them. If there is one thing more than another which the enemies of the Papacy sincerely desire, it is an onslaught of the faithful few who have congregated under the Papal banners upon the Sardinian army. The worst service the "young men of good family," who are said to be flocking to his Holiness' banners, could possibly render him, would be to win their spurs in conflict with his revolted subjects. In a military point of view, the attempt would be all but ridiculous. Its political results would pretty certainly be a revolt at Rome, another in Naples, and the departure of his Holiness and the "young men" in question for parts beyond the Tyrrhene or the Adrian Sea. In a moral point of view, it would be more disastrous still. His Holiness' best friends concede to his spiritual sovereignty a far greater importance than that of his temporal dominion; and a civil war with carnal weapons -- a war accompanied by horrible bloodshed and disorder, such as a war between the Italian Pope and the Italian people would be sure to be -- is something which, if undertaken by Christ's Vicar on Earth, would administer a greater shock to the moral sense of mankind than anything which has occurred since the massacre of St. Bartholomew. The civilized public of modern times can stand a great deal, but the spectacle of a hired Swiss sticking a bayonet into the heart of an Italian citizen for demanding his civic rights, at the command of a minister of religion who claims to represent the Apostle rebuked by his Master for drawing his sword upon the high-priest's servant, is something which the nineteenth century will not endure. A few fanatics may aver and believe that God would look down approvingly upon the whole matter -- and that the angels in Heaven would rejoice over the dead carcases of the slain upon the storming and sacking of Bologna and Ferrara; and that the blood on the Pontifical robes would smell sweetly at the judgment bar, when PIUS the Ninth presents himself for approval, -- but these are things the civilized world, even the Catholic civilized world, will not believe. Ninety per cent. of all Christian men and women baptised in the Roman communion would shudder over the bloody tale, and whatever their lips might say, their hearts at least would wander from their allegiance to the author of so hideous a crime. It is useless for bishops to bewail this state of the case, for all their wailing will not alter it. There was a time when the Pope was above the moral law, but in this century he lies under it, and there is no safety for him or for his authority in trifling with its majesty. One of the disadvantages of his Holiness' position is that it is a little more unseemly for him to order women to be massacred than for a lay prince to do so. If his advisers are at all rational, they will, however, remind him that this little inconvenience of the Papacy is counterbalanced by advantages which had better not be sacrificed to remedy it.

abstract: The old and well-known site of Athens continues to offer as rich a field for exploration as the buried cities of Pompeii and Herculaneum. You cannot dig a trench anywhere within a mile of the citadel without coming upon some fragment of an ancient edifice, and every spadefull of earth is sure to contain a dozen bits of old pottery, often with a name or a design of some kind upon their sides. Some localities are particularly rich. Such was a spot on which the Athenian Archeological Society chanced to light a few years ago; where was found a collection of inscriptions all more or less mutilated, but some of them of remarkable interest. Within a comparatively short time the Government has begun a thorough search for the relics of antiquity which might yet be discovered on the platform of the Acropolis, in the vicinity of the Parthenon and Erechtheum. Some extracts from the last report of the General Superintendent of Antiquities, Mr. PITTAKES, contained in the Journal of the Studious published at Athens, may be read with pleasure by the readers of the TIMES: "During the months of October, November and December, the archaeological excavations in the Acropolis were prosecuted on the southern side of the inclosure. This entire side was uncovered, and everywhere appeared the upper courses of the Cimonian Wall. This wall is built of stones of tufa laid in six rows, so as to form a wall five French metres in breadth. The empty space within the wall, and between it and the descending rock, the ancients filled with chips of scene and ruins of various old edifices. Having made a very slight excavation here, I found a fragment of a bas-relief of ancient AEginetan workmanship, representing horses drawing a chariot. Its execution, like that of all works of Archaic sculpture, is stiff, sinewy and harsh. It resembles closely the pas-relief of Ceres placed at the entrance of the Acropolis, and seems, indeed, to have formed a part of it. After the conclusion of the examination of the vicinity of the Erechtheure, I design making a more thorough search in the spot I have just mentioned, where I anticipate rich and curious discoveries. For, as I have said, it was filled with relies of the time before the Persian wars, with remains of ancient temples, altars, and other works of sculpture and the plastic art, and architecture, -- works which they deemed useless, but which we, in our lack of the wealth of ancient art, in which they abounded, consider extremely valuable." Next, Mr. PITTAKES tells us, workmen were employed on the northern side of the citadel, beginning with the temenus of the Ereentheum. On the very second day, some votive tablets and three decrees of the people rewarded their tolls. These were followed by the disclosure of the pedestal of a statue of CAIUS JULIUS, son of NICLAS LAMPRRUS. But the most valuable result attained was the discovery of a colossal female statue, clad in a long tunic, and seated upon a rock, which it is easy to see was intended to be a miniature representation of the Acropolis itself in its original state. It is therefore conjectured to have been a Minerva Poleouchus, or "Guardian of the City," and to have served as a sort of guide to the devotee who approached the revered shrine of the goddess. The upper part of the figure is, as in so many other cases, sadly mutilated.

abstract: The controversy regarding the City Chamberlainship remains in statu quo. As might be expected, Col. BURNHAM, the Mayor's Marshal, deposits his receipts at the Artisans' Bank, bat does so in his own name. The Street Commissioner will deposit in some bank in the name of his Department. Col. DELAVAN, the City Inspector, has no money at his disposition at present -- that is, in his official capacity -- but says that he shall recognize Mr. PLATT; while the Clerk of the Common Council, Mr. MCCLENACHEN, and the Collector of Assessments will hand over the money which may come into their hands to Mr. STOUT.

abstract: The season is fast approaching when our wealthy and fashionable citizens will, according to their annual custom, leave the City, and seek a more comfortable and healthy retreat in the country. And what, then, of the poor, whom poverty and the necessity of labor hold prisoners in the City through the hot and sickly season, to whom the spacious and airy houses that the rich forsake, on the comparatively clean streets, would be like so many palaces in Eden compared with their own miserable, crowded and stifling homes, on filthy streets and alleys?
lead_paragraph: The season is fast approaching when our wealthy and fashionable citizens will, according to their annual custom, leave the City, and seek a more comfortable and healthy retreat in the country. abstract: An application was made some days since to the General Term of the Supreme Court to admit to practice as attorneys and counselors twenty-two young gentlemen, graduates of the law department of the New-York University. This application was based on the act of the Legislature providing that graduates of the school, having received diplomas, should be entitled to admission to the bar upon such diplomas, and without further examination.

abstract: Before steam fire-engines are fairly started, as an institution of this City, the whole enterprise is already committed to corruption and jobbery. The laws of New-York require that all contracts for work over $250 in value shall be awarded to the lowest responsible bidders. In the contracts for steam fire-engines Nos. 38 and 29, now building for the City, this law has been evaded by specifying -- not that the engines shall do certain duty at certain cost, that they shall do the most service at the least expense of construction and repairs -- but that (we quote from the official specification furnished to hidders.)

lead_paragraph: As this trial approaches its termination, the interest of the public therein seems to increase. There were not more people inside the Court-room yesterday than on the day previous, for that would have been impossible, but a great many more tried to get in than on any former occasion, and went away disappointed. Capt. Nickerson, the witness expected from Boston, who commanded the schooner R.L. Martha, when she was run into by the E.A. Johnson in the Lower Bay, not having been heard from, Mr. Dwight, the prosecuting officer for the Government, Stated to the Court that he would not further delay the proceedings of the trial, but would rest his case as it stood. The District-Attorney, Ex-Judge Roosevelt, made a few remarks to the same purport. The Cour[???] asked counsel for the defence if they were ready to proceed. Mr. Sayles, junior counsel for Hicks, replied that his colleague, Mr. Graves, was unavoidably detained, whereupon the Court took a recess till 12 o'clock.

abstract: We are glad to see that Capt. DUPONT has given our Municipal "Reception Committee," who are lying in wait for the Japanese at Washington, a few hints on manners, which we trust may save the Ambassadors from a good deal of annoyance. He has informed...
lead_paragraph: We are glad to see that Capt. DUPONT has given our Municipal "Reception Committee," who are lying in wait for the Japanese at Washington, a few hints on manners, which we trust may save the Ambassadors from a good deal of annoyance. He has informed them, in the first place, that he will keep the Embassy under his own charge while in this City, as the representative of the President, whose guests they are; in the next place, that the Committee must not worry the foreigners by "assiduous attention," -- that they are "Princes," and unused to great physical fatigue, or, in other words, that they will not enjoy continual jolting over our well-paved streets in a hack with our well-conducted Common Councilmen during their stay, but must be left to follow their inclination as to what they will see, and when and how they will see it; in the third place, that a great "feed" at a hotel -- strange as it may seem to a Common-councilman -- is not a Japanese gentleman's ideal of bliss; and lastly, that they had better not be taken round to the "Institutions," or treated to a private view of the jails and hospitals, the lunatic asylums and the dog pound.

abstract: When Senator IVERSON, of Georgia, last week opposed the resolution authorizing the employment of a vessel to transport five astronomers to some point where the solar eclipse of next July might be best observed, on the ground that he "could not see that the observation of the eclipse of the sun would enable ships to get into port any sooner," he gave utterance to a vulgar error unhappily not confined to the Senate of the United States. A very little astronomy would have taught the doubting Democrat that observations on the phenomena presented during total eclipses do subserve most important uses to navigation, through their determination of terrestrial longitudes; not to mention their value as furnishing opportunity for the more exact measurement of the sun's distance from the earth, and the determination of the velocity of light. Besides, if there is any one thing which the history of mechanical inventions shows, it is the marvelous manner in which the most purely abstract speculations push to prolific practical applications. There is not a mechanical result but goes back through a chain of antecedents to a theoretical conception, first thrown out, it may be, as a daring idealism. For instance, the ancient Greek geometers delighted themselves with beautiful speculations on Conic Sections: those speculations wrought, after a long series of generations, the renovation of astronomy; and out of this has the art of navigation attained a perfection which it never could have reached otherwise than through the speculative labors of ARCHIMEDES and APOLLONIUS: so that, to use CONDORCET's illustration, "the sailor who is preserved from shipwreck by the exact observation of the longitude, owes his life to a theory conceived two thousand years before, by men of genius who had in view simply geometrical speculations."
lead_paragraph: When Senator IVERSON, of Georgia, last week opposed the resolution authorizing the employment of a vessel to transport five astronomers to some point where the solar eclipse of next July might be best observed, on the ground that he "could not see that the observation of the eclipse of the sun would enable ships to get into port any sooner," he gave utterance to a vulgar error unhappily not confined to the Senate of the United States. A very little astronomy would have taught the doubting Democrat that observations on the phenomena presented during total eclipses do subserve most important uses to navigation, through their determination of terrestrial longitudes; not to mention their value as furnishing opportunity for the more exact measurement of the sun's distance from the earth, and the determination of the velocity of light. Besides, if there is any one thing which the history of mechanical inventions shows, it is the marvelous manner in which the most purely abstract speculations push to prolific practical applications. There is not a mechanical result but goes back through a chain of antecedents to a theoretical conception, first thrown out, it may be, as a daring idealism. For instance, the ancient Greek geometers delighted themselves with beautiful speculations on Conic Sections: those speculations wrought, after a long series of generations, the renovation of astronomy; and out of this has the art of navigation attained a perfection which it never could have reached otherwise than through the speculative labors of ARCHIMEDES and APOLLONIUS: so that, to use CONDORCET's illustration, "the sailor who is preserved from shipwreck by the exact observation of the longitude, owes his life to a theory conceived two thousand years before, by men of genius who had in view simply geometrical speculations."

abstract: The Valparaiso did not touch at Guayaquil. By way of Paita I learn that Ex-President Gen. FLORES who was expelled from Peru, (as I wrote you in my last,) has arrived at Manta, in Ecuador. It is now said he was invited to Ecuador by Dr. GARCIA MORENO, the chief of the Quito Junta, and that he wil probably lead the Morena party in the approaching wrestle with FRANCO, the Presidential puppet set up by President CASTILLA. After a good deal of opposition from his Ministry, CASTILLA at last has sent FRANCO $200,000 and 1,000 muskets, with which to maintain himself at Guayaquil. As the dry season is now near at hand, it will soon be seen whether CASTILLA will expend other millions to maintain FRANCO in power and to enforce the treaty made with Ecuador.

abstract: Crimes, like sorrows, rarely come "single spies," but rather whole battalions. The present year, both in Europe and America, has been already signalized by a most remarkable series of defalcations and breaches of faith. They have occurred alike in public and in private life. The highest official rank has proved no guarantee against the same temptations to which obscure responsibility has suc- cumbed.
lead_paragraph: Crimes, like sorrows, rarely come "single spies," but rather whole battalions. The present year, both in Europe and America, has been already signalized by a most remarkable series of defalcations and breaches of faith. They have occurred alike in public and in private life. The highest official rank has proved no guarantee against the same temptations to which obscure responsibility has suc- cumbed. The proudest ministers of absolute sovereigns have fallen into one gulf of felony with the servants of a free people. The honor of the soldier and the probity of the banker have disappeared in one crucible. The Catholic General, Baron VON EYNATTEN, and the Protestant cashier PULLINGER, have stricken hands over one common compact with shame. The finances of an Empire have been shaken by the dishonorable suicide of a world-renowned statesman in Vienna; and the credit of a great commercial company reels in New-York at the disappearance of a common-place accountant. So frequent have acts of administrative dishonesty become of late years, that the first explanation which occurs to the public mind, of any irregularity or interruption in the financial processes of a public or private corporation, is now at once attributed to fraud, and the values vested by governments or by commercial companies are consequently held constantly liable to the most sudden and alarming depreciations, at the mercy of a hundred accidents. The case of the Pacific Mail Company's stock on the New York market, at the end of last week, is the latest and not the least striking illustration of this state of things. It has already begun to appear that the sudden evasion of one of the officers of that Company is attributable rather to despair at his incapacity of correcting accounts, which he had kept without sufficient order or method, than to any malversation or dishonesty on his part. It is more than probable, even, that no damage to the property of any holder of the Pacific Mail Stock will accrue from this evasion. Yet how instantaneous and how severe was the depression produced by the first appearance of any disorder in the Company's affairs! Men's minds, not yet recovered from the shock of recent disclosures at the National Post-office, ran back at once to the calamities which ushered in the crash of 1857, and to the guilty machinations of ROBERT SCHUYLER. The hypothesis of crime comes most quickly into every mind, when trouble overtakes any institution dependent on the integrity of individuals for its credit and its currency. This is certainly sad enough; and as certainly it marks our own age with a peculiar emphasis. There have been frauds always, and malversations in office, and abuses of confidence. Possibly it might be shown by a competent statistician to be true that in proportion to the enormous extent of modern financial transactions, modern financial probity need really fear no comparison with the probity of bygone times. But the special feature of our current crimes of this kind is to be found in the facility with which everybody admits their existence, as a sufficient explanation of all sorts of financial disasters; and this feature deserves the most thoughtful attention. A thousand subtle philosophical reasons might easily be given, we dare say, for this prevalent temper of the day, and as many moral remedies for it suggested as there are preachers in the land. But without entering upon the profounder metaphysics of the matter, it is tolerably plain that the intense competition and the vast personal opportunities of modern society have sorely disturbed the ancient limits of meum and tuum in the current conscience of mankind. Turn where we may, we can light upon no case of national or commercial malfeasance which cannot be radically accounted for, at the root, by the weakening in men's minds of the barriers which divide "mine" from "thine " -- the barriers so happily described by SCHILLER as "the holy bounds of property." Devotion to ends begetting indifference to means, runs throughout the enterprise of the world. It is constantly veiled under fine names and sounding forms of words, but it amounts in substance to a very vulgar offence, as old as the Decalogue, and common alike to the Tahitian savage, who covets the brass buttons of the European middy, and to the American million-aire, who risks other people's investments to assure his own objects. "Scratch a Russian," said M. DE CUSTINE, "and you will find a Tartar." "Scratch a defalcation," we say, "and you will find a theft." Of course, in nine cases out of ten, the civilized defaulter does not recognize this true nature of the deed that he is doing. But it is precisely because they do not or will not thus look it in the face, that the nine do the deed. The Government officer who lends the nation's money intrusted to himself to his friends, would no doubt shrink from taking his neighbor's watch to give it to his wife; and tie consents to the first act because it never so much as occurs to him to see in it precisely the same qualities which would make the second loathsome in his eyes. The tolerance, the indifference, the condonation, silent or expressed, of half the busy world, confirms him in this blindness; and so from step to step he hurries down the abyss. The railway functionary who takes the names of stockholders to bribe legislators into passing acts which he thinks advisable to be passed, never dreams that he is committing a positive breach of trust; the Board of Directors who declare dividends that have never been earned, out of money borrowed on the strength of dividends previously declared, would shrink with horror from the flat truth which brands them as practical swindlers. The names of things have taken the place of things themselves, and men having fixed the names of certain crimes upon certain varieties of those crimes, gradually lose the power of perceiving the real and unvarying nature which underlies all varieties of crime alike -- identical in intrinsic baseness and in the mischief it is sure to work, however covered up and concealed it may he under the specious forms and habits of men's minds.

abstract: The steamship Adriatic, from Southampton on the 9th May, arrived here on Saturday morning with three days' later news from Europe. She left Havre on the 8th inst., and arrived off Cowes the same evening. Having embarked the mails and passengers she sailed again on the evening of the 9th, passing the Needles at 6:20 P.M., from whence to Cape Race she encountered a constant succession of strong westerly winds, with head sea.

abstract: There is no surer sign of an imperfect civilization than a passion for noise. The Fejee Islanders, whenever they had secured a particularly fat family of foreigners for one of their national feasts, used to give vent to their delight by blowing through horrible tubes the most dissonant and far-resounding notes.
lead_paragraph: There is no surer sign of an imperfect civilization than a passion for noise. The Fejee Islanders, whenever they had secured a particularly fat family of foreigners for one of their national feasts, used to give vent to their delight by blowing through horrible tubes the most dissonant and far-resounding notes. The Chinese invented the gong, and forthwith petrified into eternal immobility. We hope there may be a few years of progress still in store for the United States, but really we begin to entertain grave doubts on the subject. The unbridled indulgence of our people in political gunpowder is entirely inconsistent with anything like a rational advance in the arts of life. On Friday, for instance, the Republicans of this City, having received the news of Mr. LINCOLN's nomination at Chicago, instantly found a small field-piece, dragged it into the Park, and began firing blank cartridges, not by the dozen but by the hundred! Now what did they mean by this demonstration, and what did they effect by it? Did they mean to impress the people of New-York with a sense of Mr. LINCOLN's popularity?

abstract: Advices from Melbourne are to March 17, Adelaide March 19, and Sydney, by telegraph, to March 16. At Melbourne, the Land bill was still under discussion. Respecting the gold fields, the Melbourne Herald says: "Accounts from the gold fields are not so encouraging as formerly; water is very scarce. There was a decline for the past month in the gold received by escort of 30,413 ounces, as compared with the corresponding month of 1859. The shipments of last month show a falling off of 32,518 ounces, as compared with the corresponding month in 1859, and of 113,617 ounces, as compared with the corresponding of 1858."

abstract: The late performance of the steamship Fulton, of the New-York and Havre line, deserves special no- tice, on the ground that it is one of the shortest westward passages ever accomplished between the port of Havre (by way of Southampton) and New-York.
lead_paragraph: The late performance of the steamship Fulton, of the New-York and Havre line, deserves special no- tice, on the ground that it is one of the shortest westward passages ever accomplished between the port of Havre (by way of Southampton) and New-York. We accordingly insert in our columns to day an abstract of the ship's [???] og, which ranks the Fulton at once among the fleetest of the steamers which have yet crossed the Atlantic. This result has been achieved by effective new boilers, made at the Morgan works, and differing in their construction on combined principles from any others used in ocean steamers.

abstract: The first surprise at the nomination effected by the Convention at Chicago, appears to have given way in the Repnblican party to a feeling of satisfaction more or less decided. In this City the tone of sentiment was on Saturday much more favorable to the ticket than on Friday evening, while from other points in the Northern States we hear a promising tale of gratification and rejoicing.
lead_paragraph: The first surprise at the nomination effected by the Convention at Chicago, appears to have given way in the Repnblican party to a feeling of satisfaction more or less decided. In this City the tone of sentiment was on Saturday much more favorable to the ticket than on Friday evening, while from other points in the Northern States we hear a promising tale of gratification and rejoicing. The press, too, responds to the nominations with, unexpected readiness and favor. At Washington, on Saturday, the Republican Association, having formed a procession, and procured the assistance of a band, visited the residence of Hon. HANNIBAL HAMLIN, the candidate for Vice-President, and in acknowledgment of their homage received from Mr. HAMLIN a few modest and appropriate remarks. They subsequently waited upon Messrs. CAMPBELL of Pennsylvania, and TRUMBULL and WASHBURNE of Illinois, who also indulged in a few congratulatory addresses. While the latter was speaking an attempt was made by Washington rowdies to disperse the audience, but the promptitude of the police defeated the attempt.

abstract: ITEMS. The house occupied by Mr. CANE, at No. 221 Court-street, was entered by thieves Saturday, who carried away two watches, chains, , valued in all at $125.... The thirty-first anniversary of the Brooklyn Sociable School Union will be cele- brated to-morrow, weather permitting.
lead_paragraph: ITEMS. The house occupied by Mr. CANE, at No. 221 Court-street, was entered by thieves Saturday, who carried away two watches, chains, , valued in all at $125.... The thirty-first anniversary of the Brooklyn Sociable School Union will be cele- brated to-morrow, weather permitting. In case of a storm, the celebration will be postponed until the first fair day. The schools will be divided into two divisions -- Eastern and Western. The former will march in procession through Clinton-avenue, between Gates and Myrtle avenues. The latter will march on Remsen, Clinton, Pierrepont and Hicks streets. The annual meeting of the Union will be held in Plymouth Church Tuesday evening, when there will be singig by a choir of Sabbath-school scholars, and addresses by different clergymen..... The Sunday Liquor-law was generally observed in this city yesterday.... Two men were arrested in this city on Saturday for passing counterfeit $5 bills on the Mercantile Bank of Hartford, Conn. They were committed for trial.... MARY J. COLLINS, (colored,) residing in Seventh-street. E.D., on Friday night last attempt to split hr husband's head open with an axe. She was arrested and committed to await the result of the injuries..... A meeting of tax-payers is called for this evening, at the City Hall, to adopt such measures as may be deemed necessary to say proceedings for the enforcement of the laws recently passed by the Legislature, laying out a park and several avenues, to be paid for by tax on property within the Western Fire District.... Two hundred and seventy six children have been vaccinated in the Williamsburgh Dispensary since the 1st inst.

abstract: The Legislature passed an act last session declaring graduates of the Law School of Columbia College to be entitled to admission to practice as attorneys and counsellors of the Supreme Court, without further examination.
lead_paragraph: The Legislature passed an act last session declaring graduates of the Law School of Columbia College to be entitled to admission to practice as attorneys and counsellors of the Supreme Court, without further examination. By what influence or by whose solicitation this act was passed, we do not know. Its object was apparently to draw students to the Law School, by holding out the prospect of a substantial advantage at the close of the curriculum; and if so, we may add that we could wish all the acts of the session had been half as praiseworthy. Under it, twenty-two graduates applied to the Supreme Court for admission to the Bar a few days ago. On Friday Judge SUTHERLAND delivered the judgment of the General Term refusing it, Judges MULLEN and LEONARD concurring. He holds that the Legislature cannot, under the Constitution, deprive the Judges of the power of passing on the qualifications of applicants for admission to practice; -- that the Supreme Court possesses an absolute discretion in the matter, with which no other body in the State can interfere.

abstract: The St. Louis Democrat says:  It is understood that when the wires are completed to Fort Smith and Los Angeles, the Overland Mail Company, operating under the Butterfield contract, will establish a horse express, in opposition to...
lead_paragraph: The St. Louis Democrat says: It is understood that when the wires are completed to Fort Smith and Los Angeles, the Overland Mail Company, operating under the Butterfield contract, will establish a horse express, in opposition to that owned by RUSSELL & Co., upon the Central route. The facilities on the El Paso line for an enterprise of that character are very superior; their stations and employes at regular intervals along the roads, already afford means of running an express at a trifling cost, compared to the expense that any other Company would be subjected to. The calculation is to go from Fort Smith to Los Angeles in five days; and starting as it appears, there is nothing in the undertaking to stagger a Company that has put through a stage coach from Syracuse, in this State, to San Francisco in sixteen days -- a distance of twenty-seven hundred miles. The space between Fort Smith and Los Angeles is about fifteen hundred miles, and three hundred miles per day would be the maximum speed required to overcome it in fire days. This is at the rate of 12 1/2 miles per hour, and as their stages frequently go 13 miles in a single hour, it is supposed that over these favorable places, horses, with relays every ten miles, could be put through at the extraordinary speed of twenty miles per hour, which would leave ample margin for the rough places in the mountains, and for stops along the route. Even admitting that the trip is capable of being made in six days, it at once takes the lead in the annals of fast traveling. Nothing short of a race-course could surpass the speed shown in the grand race between the two oceans. The Pony Express, by the central route, would, undoubtedly, contest the palm nobly, and between the two, the speed, would become positively terrific.

abstract: We have very little original matter to add to this affair. Notwithstanding what has been stated as to the intention of the authorities to interfere, and notwithstanding the recommendations of various lovers of the art, both men but more especially HEENAN appear bent of fighting again.
lead_paragraph: We have very little original matter to add to this affair. Notwithstanding what has been stated as to the intention of the authorities to interfere, and notwithstanding the recommendations of various lovers of the art, both men but more especially HEENAN appear bent of fighting again. That this will not be permitted anywhere in the United Kingdom is now evident, for on Thursday last we had a visit from Superintendents DURKIN, of the F division, and HANNANT, of the A division, who informed us they were instructed by the Commissioners, who were acting under the direction of the Home Secrete give us official notice that if either TOM SAYERS or HEENAN attempted to renew hostilities in any place which could be reached by a Secretary of State's warrant they would be arrested, and their designs frustrated; and not only this, but directions would be given to the proper persons to indict them and all persons concerned for the breach of the peace already committed, at the ensuing assizes. This warning has been communicated to the referee, who has determined, beyond the naming of a future day, to wash his hands of the business. On Friday we had a visit from HEENAN, who, in company with Mr. WILKES, came to demand that a day should be fixed for the battle to be resumed. Both were aware of the notice alluded to in our last, and both suggested that the fight should take place outside of England; but whether SAYERS will agree to this remains to be proved. A day has been named, but, as by the articles, the men are bound to fight in England; and as the authorities are determined, we cannot see a way out of the difficulty unless SAYERS waives the articles entirely and goes abroad to continue the contest. We had not seen HEENAN since the fight until Friday, and were glad to perceive that, beyond a scar and a few discolorations, he had entirely recovered from the punishment he had received. He, of course, expressed his anxiety to have the matter settled in one way or the other, and made no objection to give the proper time for SAYERS to be placed on an equal footing with himself. He announced that he will shortly take a benefit, but that there had been some difficulty as to a place, which prevented him at present fixing a day. All we can say is, let him lose no time, but "strike the iron while it is hot." The excitement at present is very great, and if he fixes upon a spot within a few days he must realize a large sum. If he tarry too long, public interest will be on the wane, and his receipts will be diminished by one half. Of TOM SAYERS we have heard but little during the week. He has been at Chester and Liverpool, at each of which places he has had most rapturous receptions, and received large subscriptions. His arm is progressing favorably, although, of course, the cure must be very slow. We have received a message from Mr. HOGG, of the Angel, Stratford, (the Mr. H. alluded to in our last,) stating that he was not a friend of HEENAN's, and knew nothing of him beyond seeing him with MACDONALD, and that he was sent to the referee by the latter to request him to return to the ring and allow the battle to go on, and not for the purpose of putting an end to it. If Mr. HOGG sends us a letter to this effect we will insert it; but we may inform him at once that his memory must be some what at fault if he imagines he put his request to the referee in the way stated. Before concluding these remarks, we have only to repeat the recommendation that the men should shake hands and settle the matter in an amicable manner. The feeling throughout the country, it we except certain of the betting fraternity, is so decidedly in favor of a draw, and the opinion so universal that both men have done enough, that we do not hesitate to adopt this course. We have no doubt many will be found ready to throw suspicion upon such a recommendation, as tending to imply a doubt in our minds as to the capabilities of the Champion, out they will not be found among a class to whom it is of any importance to us to explain our motives. We feel quite confident that those whose good opinion alone we care for will all be ready to justify what we have said and done. Our correspondent is wrong in supposing TOM SAYERS can claim the belt without fighting out the present match with HEENAN, supposing it does not take place previous to the 16th of June. The match once made must be decided one way or the other, unless the men agree to a draw.

abstract: About 3 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning, the three-story frame building in the rear of No. 258 West Thirty-third-street, owned by JOHN OGDEN, and occupied as a carpenter's shop by SAMUEL MANDEVILLE, was discovered on fire, and before the flames could be extinguished about $500 damage was done to the house and $1,000 to the stock and tools, upon neither of which was any insurance. Two horses, valued at $200 each, were burned to death -- one of the animals having been owned by Mr. MANDEVILLE and the other by Mr. VAN NOSTHRICK. The fire communicated to two frame buildings in the rear of Nos. 251 and 253 West Thirty second street, belonging to Mr. OHL, and occupied as tenement houses, the families in which lost all their furniture by fire and water. The damage to the buildings will reach about $800, but it is fully covered by insurance.

abstract: Last evening Dr. CHEEVER delivered a discourse to a large congregation in his own church, on the "Rights of conscience towards God in the people of the United States, and the violation of that right in the illegal imprisonment of Mr. HYATT by the United States Senate."
lead_paragraph: Last evening Dr. CHEEVER delivered a discourse to a large congregation in his own church, on the "Rights of conscience towards God in the people of the United States, and the violation of that right in the illegal imprisonment of Mr. HYATT by the United States Senate." Before commencing his discourse he announced that on next Sunday evening he would speak of the relation of the Church to the Society, and assert the entire independence of the Church of the Society. He took for his text the 12th verse of the 16th chapter of Luke -- "And if ye have not been faithful in that which is another man's, who shall give you that which is your own?" Speaking of the importance of faith in God, he said it was as necessary to a nation as to an individual, to save from wrong and oppression. And, when a Government persisted in doing wrong, he held that it should be overturned -- the rule of action in all such cases should be revolution. The law of God was the foundation of all just law, and a violation of His law by a nation, was just as sure to bring punishment as when the violation was by an individual. Thereupon the nation that looked upon man-stealing as law and rightousness, would surely come to punishment. The piety of a nation that judged of manhood by the color of the skin, was not even skin deep, while its wickedness reached to the bone. Against such a nation, and against bad laws, he considered it to be the duty of the minister to preach. It was his duty to preach God's law against bad laws. Coming to speak more directly to the case of THADDEUS HYATT, he said Mr. HYATT's conscience would not let him answer such questions as a Committee of the United States Senate chose to ask him; and that his declaration of a conscience towards God caused contempt and rage. He was declared in contempt and thrown into prison, because he dared to place conscience before God higher than a Senatorial Committee with power. The speaker, in continuation, over and over again, said that it was nothing but the association of a conscience toward God that caused Mr. HYATT to be imprisoned; that there was no other charge brought against him and that for that, and that alone, he was cast into a filthy dungeon -- simply because he spoke of a conscience toward GOD, and [???]enied that the Senate had any of the attributes of GOD. Thus was Mr. HYATT imprisoned without law; and he, repeating what he remarked at the Cooper Institute meeting, held that the people were bound to go to Washington and, in the name of GOD, take Mr. HYATT out of prison.

abstract: In reply to the proposals of France, England con- cents to adopt as the basis of the Conference Article 92 of the final Act of Vienna, which refers to the neutralization of the districts of Chablais and Fauoigny. England reserves, however, the right of making at the said Conference proposals relative to the mode of this neutralization. This declaration of England is likely to increase the probabilities of the assembling of the proposed Conference.

abstract: The accounts from Aberdeen, to-day, (Monday,) state that the defalcations of JOHN BLAIKIE, the advocate who has lately absconded, will be about $200,000. At first it was feared they might be double that amount. He is stated to have obtained advances from the Union Bank of Scotland, to the extent of about £80,000, but they have numerous securities, and are not likely to lose more than £10,000 or £15,000. BLAIKIE is understood to be in Sweden.
lead_paragraph: The accounts from Aberdeen, to-day, (Monday,) state that the defalcations of JOHN BLAIKIE, the advocate who has lately absconded, will be about $200,000. abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. Though the "season" at this Opera-house came to an end on Saturday, a special performance will be given to-morrow evening for the benefit of Mlle. SPERANZA.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- Though the "season" at this Opera-house came to an end on Saturday, a special performance will be given to-morrow evening for the benefit of Mlle. SPERANZA. This most unfortunate young lady, whose failure at her debut in New-York clouded so sadly the opening of the Winter's amusements, has been detained in this City until the present time by the illness which overtook her on her voyage from Italy, and deprived her, in depriving her of the use of her voice, at once of a thousand brilliant hopes and of the means of supporting herself and her parents. A more distressing story no page of fiction records; and it will be terribly to the discredit of the musical public if the unreserved benefit which the managers of the Academy offer Mlle. SPERANZA to-morrow evening, shall fail to relieve this young, lovely, and accomplished lady, from the sufferings which she has uncomplainingly borne while the Opera has been running its gay career; and to furnish her with the means of seeking health and new life in her native land. Both Companies contribute to the occasion; Mad. GAZZANIGA, Miss WISSLER, Signor TAMARO, and signor AMODIO, having volunteered their services in the opera of "II Trovatore."

abstract: Detectives Slowey and King yesterday arrested Capt. D. S. Williams, owner of a schooner of the same name, and David F. Williams, his brother and mate of the vessel, on charges of having been engaged in extensive larcenies of merchandise committed to their care.
lead_paragraph: Detective Slowey and King yesterday arrested Capt. D.S. Williams, owner of a schooner of the same name, and David F. Williams, his brother and mate of the vessel, on charges of having been engaged in extensive larcenies of merchandise committed to their care. The accused have for some years been engaged in carrying assorted cargoes from this port to Mobile, Ala; but for months past the New-York shippers have received complaints from their Southern customers that the consignments invariably fell short of the quantity named in the invoice. It was at first suspected that Patrick Mockler, the steward of the vessel, was the thief, and he was arrested, but an investigation resulted in causing suspicion to rest upon the accused, who arrived from Mobile last Saturday. In searching the Captain's premises at Forked River, Monmouth County N.J., the officers discovered a large trunk, filled with various packages of merchandise, buried in the garden, and yesterday afternoon another trunk, containing dry goods, was dug out of a sand-bank at Staten Island. In each instance the trade-marks had been left upon the property, so that little difficulty will be experienced in identifying it. The detectives have also traced a portion of the stolen goods to Providence, R.I., and the supposition is that the cases were broken and the contents abstracted before the vessel left port. The prisoners will be examined to-day by a United States Commissioner.

abstract: from himself and Mr. LESLIE completely exonerate him from this imputation. But it does seem to be true that some American devotee of the Fine Arts, probably no more familiar with the Japanese language than with the laws of property, did "borrow" a sketch-book from one of our Oriental visitors, and to the utter consternation and possible damage of the owner, quietly put it into his pocket, and walk away with his prize to show it to his wife, his family and his friends. This act may very well have been committed with no sort of intention on the part of the perpetrator of keeping what he had thus obtained; and it is no doubt to be stigmatized as a piece of bad manners and indecently selfish curiosity rather than as a deliberate larceny. We trust that some of the respectable Americans who seem to have some access to the Japanese Ambassadors will take pains to explain this to our benighted visitors from the Pacific; and that they will intercede to save the unfortunate Niphonese knight of the pencil from the punishment with which it appears he is threatened for his blind confidence in the breeding of Great Republicans. Possibly it might be a good thing to translate for the Kamis and other functionaries those passages in the works of Dr. KANE, Capt. COOK, LA PEROUSE, and other famous navigators, in which those enterprising explorers recount the great trouble they were at in preventing the people of the Sandwich Islands or the Esquimaux from carrying off light articles from the decks of their ships, and from about their own persons. This would at least have the good effect of satisfying the envoys of the Tycoon that vulgar and inconsiderate curiosity is not absolutely peculiar to Christian nations.

abstract: Mr. CAMERON presented to the Senate a petition from citizens of Pennsylvania in regard to the Revenue laws, stating that he should seize an early occasion to press the subject. The hour of meeting for the Senate was altered to 11 o'clock. The bill for the more effectual suppression of the slave trade having been called up, Mr. WILSON explained its provisions at length and urged the passage of the measure, so pressingly called for by recent developments on the coasts of Africa and Cuba. The Davis resolutions were then considered, and spoken upon by Mr. TOOMBS, of Georgia, who took the extreme Southern view in support of the principles embodied by the resolutions. Mr. TOOMBS referred to the understanding existing among Democratic leaders, prior to the decision of the Supreme Court in the Dred Scott case, that such decision should be final as to the constitutionality of Squatter Sovereignty; and pronounced Mr. DOUGLAS untrue to his engagements in still persisting in the advocacy of that obnoxious and illegal doctrine. He desired to see the Southern delegates participate in the deliberations at Baltimore, in the hope that Northern members might yet be brought to see the necessity of concession, as the only means of defeating the Republicans; but was unwilling to abandon one outpost of the Southern position. The remarks of Mr. TOOMBS were listened to with profound attention. In the House, the message of the President relative to the slaver Wildfire was received. Mr. MONTGOMERY moved a resolution that the House adjourn sine die on the 10th prox. Mr. SHERMAN moved as an amendment the substitution of June 18, which prevailing, the resolution was adopted. The Pacific Railroad bill, on motion of Mr. CURTIS, was made the special order for Thursday and the following days. The Senate Homestead bill was then taken up, and the substitution of the original bill of the House was carried by a vote of 104 to 39, and the bill returned to the Senate. The bill raising the pay of officers of the Navy was passed. The entire prooceedings of the day are reported as having been characterized by great turbulence and clamor; insomuch, that the Republican leaders, though, anxious to press measures of great importance, declared they preferred an adjournment to a continuation of scenes so disorderly.

abstract: Mdlle. Titiens is at present in Paris on her way to Loudon, having been engaged at Her Majesty's Theatre. Mdlle. Titiens has been singing at the Opera House in Barcelona, where, on her closing night, the subscribers presented her with a laurel crown in silver, with berries in gold. It was her benefit night, and the house was crowded to excess; the fair artiste receiving the crown on the stage, with every manifestation of favor Spanish enthusiasm could show.

abstract: CABS AND THE CENTRAL PARK. -- There is a snarl twisting up between the Central Park Commissioners and the proprietors of business wagons as to the right of entry into the Park, which some good citizen might unravel, and at the same time do the public a great service, by establishing near the Park a stand of light one-horse carriages, to be let out at a cheap rate, by the hour or otherwise, to persons desiring a drive in the grounds. At present everybody who does not possess either a private carriage or a grocer's wagon must charter one of the antediluvian coaches, with two horses, known to Aldermen and livery stable keepers as the common domestic "hack," at a cost of from five to ten dollars, if he wishes an hour's ride in the Park. Why, in the name of cheapness, common sense and comfort, cannot the mass of decent citizens be enabled, after riding to the Park in the cars, to find there a passable vehicle, with a single horse, in which they may make the circuit of the grounds for a quarter, or a half, or even a whole dollar? What has become of that mysterious Corporation which regularly every session takes out a charter authorizing it to furnish New-York with cheap cabs, and yet never starts them? What is the reason that in the most enterprising City in the world we find it so hard to get rid of the old "glass coach" of Queen ANNE's time, which has not been seen in any other capital for fifty years? Will not some energetic and intelligent stable keeper answer these questions in a practical way?

At present everybody who does not possess either a private carriage or a grocer's wagon must charter one of the antediluvian coaches, with two horses, known to Aldermen and livery stable keepers as the common domestic "hack," at a cost of from five to ten dollars, if he wishes an hour's ride in the Park. Why, in the name of cheapness, common sense and comfort, cannot the mass of decent citizens be enabled, after riding to the Park in the cars, to find there a passable vehicle, with a single horse, in which they may make the circuit of the grounds for a quarter, or a half, or even a whole dollar? What has become of that mysterious Corporation which regularly every session takes out a charter authorizing it to furnish New-York with cheap cabs, and yet never starts them? What is the reason that in the most enterprising City in the world we find it so hard to get rid of the old "glass coach" of Queen ANNE's time, which has not been seen in any other capital for fifty years? Will not some energetic and intelligent stable keeper answer these questions in a practical way?

abstract: BROADWAY IN DISORDER.-- The prudent gardeners who supply our hungry City, take pains to sow different plats successively, in order that a succession of crops may furnish a constant supply. And to the end of the season their gardens present every stage of vegetable growth, from the blade just breaking the ground to the faded and withered seed-stock. The builders in Broadway seem generally to adopt a similar plan, and manage somehow to keep that street [???]umbered with rubbish in one or two places at a time the year round. They very seldom begin operations in more than two peaces at once, and in these the new building goes up while the old one is coming down, and the sidewalk in front is thus obstructed simultaneously with old ruins and new materials. The genius of destruction, however, has during the past week devoted itself with unparalleled activity to the demolition of old buildings, in apparent disregard whether newer fabrics shall rise from the ruins or the sites be left blank. Between the City Hall and Grace Church there are no fewer than a dozen houses undergoing the process of entire demolition. The safety of the thousands of pedestrians crowding the side-walk renders, equal care, necessary in taking down old materials as in carrying up new. And hence though gravitation offers its cheap services to the tearers down, those worthies refuse to contract with it, and employ a hod and Celtic muscle instead for taking down the street walls. The timbers within, however, are pried from their sockets, and fall with a crash, filling the street with a cloud of brick and lime dust, which excites refreshing recollections of the reign of street dust that prevailed in the earlier and windier months of Spring. Black coats and silk dresses are whitened, to the infini[???]e disgust of their half-stifled wearers, though the ladies refuse to hurry past these threatening ruins, but persist, with sweet complacency, in stopping to chat on the very spot where the next timber is likely to fall. Past experience furnishes no ground for hope that Broad way will ever hear the last of the builders' hammer. But it is at least a consolation to observe so many houses rebuilding at the same time, as to warrant the expectation that when these are completed we may enjoy a temporary lull of the dust and rubbish which at this moment barricade the street at almost every block, and that the variformed fronts on either side may remain without change while Mr. ANTHONY has time to take an instantaneous view for the historical edification of the next generation.

abstract: THE COURTS AND COLUMBIA COLLEGE. -- We understand that the late decision of the General Term of the Supreme Court on the subject of admissions to the bar, on which we commented yesterday, referred exclusively to applications made by students of the University of New-York, and not of Columbia College; though the rule laid down by the Court will, of course, apply to both. The graduates of the Columbia College Law School will, however, make their application to-day, and this will bring the matter up for reargument. The case of the College will be presented by Prof. DWIGHT. It is highly desirable that the question should be finally settled whether the Supreme Court has power to keep the Bar in its present depressed condition, by driving everybody else who attempts to better it from the field. We repeat once more that we believe the Court, in charging itself with the duty of examining candidates for admission, attempts something which it cannot well perform, for which it has no time, and no adequate machinery, and which it would therefore, do well to hand over to more careful and competent hands.

abstract: Mrs. CAROLINE G. MITCHELL, a lady 59 years of age, the wife of Judge MITCHELL, residing at No. 1 Irving-place, died on Sunday morning, in consequence of injuries received by being knocked down and run over on the previous evening at the corner of Fifthavenue and Fourteenth-street, by a horse and light wagon driven at a furious rate.
lead_paragraph: The driver of the vehicle stopped for a few moments, not long enough to ascertain the result of the injuries which the unfortunate lady had sustained, and then drove off. The answers which he gave to questions asked by the passers-by, were not sufficiently definite to secure his attendance at the inquest. The jury rendered a verdict that Mrs. MITCHELL's death had resulted from compression of the brain, in consequence of a fractured skull; and though relieving the driver of any intention to do the injury, they reprehended him for his inhuman conduct after the accident. Some hours after the verdict had been rendered, Mr. PENNIMAN, residing at the St. Germain Hotel, called upon Coroner SCHIEMER, and informed him that the young man who drove the vehicle was his groom, that he had given his right name, but he had become so alarmed at the result of the accident that he had fled from the City.

abstract: There are one or two features of our Western civilization which we venture to think that "His Majesty, the President," and the Republican Court at Washington, are not taking precisely the proper steps to recommend to the favor of their Japanese guests.
lead_paragraph: The envoys of the Tycoon are supposed to be sitting now for the first time in the broad light of social and political wisdom; and as they are evidently sufficiently sharp and teachable persons, it is no doubt the hope of many friends of humanity that they will go back to the "England of the Pacific" prepared to set on foot a tremendous movement of progress in that powerful and prosperous realm. We trust that this hope may not be disappointed; but we cannot repress some anxiety and concern on the subject when we see the little pains which have been taken to put our best traits forward in a fashion to do justice to their merits. If there are two points on which we value ourselves as in contrast with the Asiatic nations generally, they are our enjoyment of religious truth in religious freedom and the lofty position which we have accorded to women. The Japanese have astonished us by the perfection to which they have brought their culture of many of the useful arts and sciences. Their chemistry stares ours out of countenance by the superior splendor of its chromatic results. As workers in metal they need not shrink from competition with the Birminghams and Sheffields of the West. Their personal neatness has confounded the Washington hotel-keepers, accustomed mainly to the habits of members of Congress and lobbyers. Their exquisite politeness has shamed even our New-York Common Councilmen into agreeing to treat them decently.

abstract: Quite an exciting affair transpired at Spingler Institute, corner of Fifth-avenue and Thirty-fourthstreet, on Saturday evening. Miss PHIPPS, from Tennessee who has been an inmate of the institution for some time, had requested of Mr. ABROT, the Principal of the Institute, that Gen. BYNUM, who, she affirmed, was from the same State as herself, might be allowed to visit her as a relative.
lead_paragraph: Quite an exciting affair transpired at Spingler Institute, corner of Fifth-avenue and Thirty-fourth-street, on Saturday evening. Miss PHIPPS, from Tennessee, who has been an inmate of the institution for some time, had requested of Mr. ABBOT, the Principal of the Institute, that Gen. BYNUM, who, she affirmed, was from the same State as herself, might be allowed to visit her as a relative. Her request was granted, and Gen. BYNUM had seen her once in public, and once in private, when suspicions were aroused that his visits were of a different character from those which a relative would pay. Inquiries at the St. Nicholas, where he was stopping, confirmed these suspicions, and Gen. BYNUM was requested to discontinue his visits. This he not only promised to do, but volunteered a written pledge to that effect, and gave his word that he intended to leave the City immediately. On Saturday afternoon, notwithstanding these assurances, he called again at the Institute, and sent up his card to Mrs. ABBOT. This visit was made, as is alleged, at a time when it was known Mr. ABBOT was habitually absent. Mrs. ABBOTT responded promptly, however, and almost at the same moment that she made her appearance Miss PHIPPS entered the room. Mrs. ABBOT requested the young lady to withdraw, as she desired to see the General alone, but this he protested against, affirming that he had no secrets from Miss PHIPPS. Mrs. ABBOTT replied that all conversation between them must be in her presence. Gen. BYNUM immediately stepped up to Miss PHIPPS and addressed her a few words in a whisper. Miss PHIPPS then turned to Mrs. ABBOT and said, "I must bid you good bye." To such summary proceedings as these Mrs ABBOT objected, and attempted to take out a writ of habeas corpus by throwing her arms around her pupil and holding her. Gen. BYNUM finally succeeded in releasing Miss PHIPPS from Mrs. ABBOT's e'mbrace. Mrs. ABBOT instinctively turned and seized the General, but he threw her from him in a violent, and as is charged, almost in an insulting manner, and started for the door in company with Miss PHIPPS. Mrs. ABBOT reiterated her entreaties to the young lady to abandon her design of eloping. The teachers and young ladies of the family added their remonstrances, and for a moment Miss PHIPPS seemed to hesitate; then Gen. BYNUM put his arms around her apparently urging her to get in the carriage; she yielded, and the couple drove off. All this time Mrs. ABBOT was calling on the bystanders to interfere, but no one responded to her calls for hel[???], and Miss PHIPPS is now at the St. Nicholas Hotel, having become Mrs. Gen. BYNUM. This is the story, as it comes to us from reliable sources.
headline: {'main': 'CITY INTELLIGENCE.; Elopement from Spingler Institute. A FOOLISH YOUNG LADY AND A VALIANT GENERAL CARD FROM MR. ABBOT.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'CITY INTELLIGENCE.; Elopement from Spingler Institute. A FOOLISH YOUNG LADY AND A VALIANT GENERAL CARD FROM MR. abstract: We are sure that no New-Yorker of even ten years standing can read with absolute indifference the advertisement which offers for sale, at public auction, "the entire gallery of the late WM. E. BURTON, Esq."
lead_paragraph: In a few years the tide of metropolitan life, fed continually from a thousand new springs will, doubtless, sweep over the memory of all the popular favorites of the passing day; and the time may not be far distant when people will ask, as they turn over the record of New-York doings and sayings, who WM.E. BURTON was, and what he did. But it has not yet come. Swiftly as we move from one to another excitement in this mercurial and kaleidoscopic City of ours, the echo of the great comedian's voice still lingers, as from yesterday, in the ears of the theatre-going world of New-York. But a little while ago, and we were shaking our sides with him over the humors of Mr. Toodle; reading new meanings by the light of his genius in SHAKESPEARE's Antolycus and Falstaff -- and now we are asked to help disperse his household gods; and efface the last vestiges of the home he had built up for himself out of a long, and busy, and checkered life.

abstract: To the Senate and House of Representatives:  On the 26th day of April last, Lieut. CRAVEN, of the United States steamer Mohawk, captured the slaver Wildfire, on the coast of Cuba, with five hundren and seven African negroes on board. The prize was brought into Key West on the 30th April, and the negroes were delivered into the custody of FERNANDO J. MORENO, Marshal of the Southern District of Florida.

abstract: THE UP-TOWN MOVEMENT. -- Somebody relates of the grampus a remarkable mode of fighting, the result whereof is bloodless alike to victor and vanquished. Two of these animals no sooner meet, than, like two irate Congressmen, they retire from the gaze of the world to some sheltered spot, and there engage in quite as harmless strife as a Congressional duel generally proves to be. Grampus number one opens the contest by stretching out his neck to an unusual length. His opponent endeavors to raise his own head higher still, and succeeding, is in turn outdone by his ambitious rival. The strife continues till one of the creatures breaks his neck, when the victor returns to his accustomed haunts. To this eccentric type of rivalry we think a parallel is furnished by the eagerness which some of our business men display to outstrip each other in the up-town race. No sooner does Smith forsake his long-occupied stand for one above Brown's, and fairly ensconce himself therein, than Brown strikes his tent and pitches it further up than Smith. Each becomes imbued with the insane, but quite popular idea, that the North pole of commercial magnetism is somewhere among the bushes and rocks of Harlem, where also a City Hall will shortly be built, to be occupied at first by the Albany Legislature, and subsequently by Congress itself. It is a great mistake to suppose that any possible or conceivable increase of population can change the physical conformation of the island, so as to bring the Battery and the adjacent ferries and wharves to the immediate neighborhood of Central Park or Madison-square. The position of those, -- "the lay of the land" -- determines the tendency of business. The business centre of the City is not likely, for many years to come to be further up town than it is at present; and we greatly mistake if some of those, whose eager zeal to be in the van of the commercial anabasis induces them to rent or buy expensive stores in the aristocratic dwelling quarters of the town, do not, sooner than they expect, find like the defeated grampus, that their ambitious zeal has been their ruin.

abstract: Another scene of the Presidential drama is to be enacted to-night in New-York. The Democracy of the Metropolis propose to define their position, and the position of the New-York delegation at Charleston, and the position of the champion candidate of the Democratic Party, in a meeting at the Cooper Institute.
lead_paragraph: The interest which would naturally be excited by this demonstration of New-York in defence of the doctrine of Popular Sovereignty, and of Senator DOUGLAS, will not be diminished by the circumstance that it follows so immediately upon the nomination of Mr. LINCOLN, at Chicago. As the whole country is fast making up its mind that the National battle of 1860 is really to be fought out between Mr. DOUGLAS and his ancient antagonist in a hardly less conspicuous contest, it will be highly interesting to hear what the orators of the Democracy have to say of their foeman, and of the chances of the impending strife. There will be orators enough to enlighten us on these points, too, for all sections of the Union are to be represented on the platform. CLINGMAN, of North Carolina; MILES TAYLO [???], of Louisiana; RUST, of Arkansas, memorable for his fray with the Editor of the Tribune; HAMILTON, of Texas, at one time the "coming man" in the contest of last Winter for the Speakership at Washington; RICHARDSON and LOGAN, of Illinois; WATERSON, of Tennessee; MARSHALL, of Kentucky, and ROBERT J. WALKER, of Mississippi, Kansas and New-York, are announced in the programme of the evening. The recent letter of STEPHENS, of Georgia, approving the attitude assumed by the Senator from Illinois, and the growing weakness which appears in all the demonstrations of the Charleston "seceders" at the South, will concentrate particular attention upon the utterances of the Southern statesmen in this formidable list; and those who delight in studying the signs in the heaven of politics, will, doubtless, see portents enough to-night, raining prophetic influence upon their intellects, and "adjudging the prize" of the approaching joust at Baltimore.

abstract: The will of the late eminent lawyer, George Wood, Esq., was to-day admitted to probate before the Surrogate, Hon. EDWARD C. WEST. The test[???]tor leaves to his wife his plate and household furniture, the house and lot corner of Fifth-avenue and Eleventh-street, a house and lot in Baltic-street, Brooklyn, and five vacant lots corner of Hicks and Baltic-streets. He leaves to his son, Dr. George K. Wood a lot of land in the town of Walde, Texas, and to his son Frederick Wood, his law library, two houses in Brooklyn, and the right to half of the dock fronting Baltic-street, with the vacant lots attached to it. The residue of his real estate is then divided into seven parts, the first of which, consisting of eight houses in Brooklyn, he gives to his son Dr. George K. Wood; the second part, consisting of 340 acres in the Valley of Lake Pepin, Minnesota, and six houses in Brooklyn, to his daughter Catharine; the third part, consisting of a dwelling and farm of thirty acres in Rye, Westchester County, and four houses in Brooklyn, to his daughter Anna; the fourth, consisting of six houses in Brooklyn, to his daughter Mary; the fifth, consisting of six houses in Brooklyn, to his daughter Julia; the sixth, consisting of six houses in Brooklyn, to his daughter Louisa; the seventh, consisting of real estate held by his son Frederick, he devises to him in fee absolute. The devises to his daughters are to be free from the control of their husbands. George and Frederick are constituted residuary legatees. Out of the personal estate, $1,000 is to be applied to the use of the testator's daughter Anna. Most of the houses in Brooklyn are situated in Sidney place, State and Joralemon streets. The widow and son, Frederick Wood, are appointed executors.

abstract: CRITICAL CONDITION OF REV. THEODORE PARKER. -- Letters from Florence, received in this city, co[???]m the statements in regard to the dangerous illness of Rev. THEODORE PARKER. For several weeks previous to the date of the letter, (the latter part of April) he had been falling sensibly, while a serious depression of spirits reacted upon his bodily condition. Feeling that something must be speedily done, a consultation of Dr. APPLETON, Mr. APTHORP, of Boston, and others of his friends was called, and it was decided to obtain a vetturine with a view of transporting him by easy journeys to Florence, in the hope that new sights and scenes might improve his mental condition. For two days the journey was prosecuted, but then the patient became so weak that the vetturino was abandoned. After a period of rest he was taken to Florence by rail, and at last accounts, was surrounded by his friends, growing daily weaker and weaker and with but faint hopes of another rally. The [???]enor of the letter, which was written by one often at his bedside, bids his friends here to prepare for early intelligence of an afflictive character. -- Boston Traveller, 19th.

abstract: Henry A. Hartt et. al. vs. George H. White et. al. -- The litigation in this matter now assumes a new form The opinion of Justice MULLEN in a former proceeding having left the parties in precisely the same position as before the litigation commenced, the Cheever party, or the plaintiffs in that action, have new obtained an alternative mandamus against the inspectors of election, requiring them to give the plaintiffs herein certificates entitling them to the office of Trustees, to which they claim to have been elected, or to show cause on Wednesday why they refuse to so. This writ, together with the order to show cause, was granted by Justice BONNEY, of Chambers, and is thence returnable on the 23d, when it is quite likely the same old story will be repeated. Edward Gilbert for plaintiffs.

abstract: Steinman vs. Clarke. -- This was an action of slander, both parties being females. The complaint alleged that defendant charged plaintiff with being a prostitute, and having stolen articles of property specified. The answer, besides a general denial, set up that the articles named in the complaint had been takes from the defendant, and she was informed and believed that plaintiff was guilty of the charges alleged to have made against her by defendant.

abstract: The letter of Hon. HOWELL COBB, already referred to in our telegraphic dispatches, discusses at length the difficulties in the Charleston Convention, and the causes which produced them. Mr. COBB expresses deep regret at the disruption of the Convention, but praises the action of the Georgia delegation in withdrawing, and declares that, had they returned from Charleston "bearing to the people of Georgia the humiliating terms of surrender which, the majority of the Convention sought to put upon them in the platform and candidate proposed, the people would have received their report in sorrow, and spurned the candidate with indignation."

abstract: AN IMPORTANT QUESTION -- THE LAW SCHOOLS. -- Twenty-eight young gentlemen connected with the Law School of Columbia College were presented to the Supreme Court, yesterday morning, for admission to the Bar. The motion was made in their behalf by THEODORE W.DWIGHT, Professor of Municipal Law in the College, under the clause in the recent statute entitling the students to admission to all the courts of the State after due examination by the law professors of the College and a committee of six of the Trustees, selected from the members of the legal profession. By former statuses similar privilege[???] had been granted to the law schools at Albany, at Poughkeepsie, and at the University of New-York.

abstract: Misrepresentation has achieved its work. The tanid and credulous have sucoumbed to threats and perver-  sions. To please a few thousand men of equivocal principle and faltering frith, millions of loyal hearts have been saddened. The recognized standard bearer of the Republican Party has been sacrificed upon the altar of fancied availability.
lead_paragraph: This sacrifice was alike cruel and unnecessary No man in the Republican Party has greater strength than WM H. SEWARD. No man deserves more at the hands of that party, or possesses greater fitness for the high office for which its national tribunal has declared him unworthy. His platform is that of the Republican Party, and was before it. He, more than any other man, initiated the principles which called it into being, and which gave and which still gives it all its vitality. No other man's history so distinctly embodies the grand idea which brought together these who originally entered into the Republican organization; and the world's verdict was, that good faith, common honesty, and the future history and well-being of the Republican Party demanded his nomination as its standard-bearer in the pending canvass.

abstract: Garrett S. Mott vs. The Hudson River Railroad Company. -- This was an action against the defendants to recover damages for the destruction of a house of plaintiff, by fire, under the following circumstances: On the 15th of July, 1857, the plaintiff's house took fire about half-past 12 o'clock, and while Engine No. 32 was playing upon the fire a train of defendants' cars came along, cutting off the hose, by reason of which, it is claimed, the property was destroyed. A number of the members of the Fire Department testified that they ran up the track and attempted to stop the locomotive. They thought the engineer could have well observed the fire and the signals given for him to stop, had he not been negligent.
