abstract: case are, that THADDEUS HYATT was subpoenaed before a Committee of the United States Senate, to be examined touching the Harper's Ferry insurrection. He obeyed the subpoena by appearing, and announced that he was ready to tell all he knew if the Senate would acknowledge beforehand that it had no power to compel him to testify. This the Senate very properly, or at all events very naturally, declined to do, and, as we believe with equal propriety, committed THADDEUS to close custody for a gross contempt in refusing to answer unconditionally. In order to test the legality of this imprisonment, THADDEUS has only to apply to any of the Courts for a writ of habeas corpus. None of them dare refuse it, and if the Senate has exceeded its powers under the Constitution, his discharge is certain, upon the return of the writ and the production of his body. This is what the law prescribes in every case of illegal imprisonment, -- this the precise course which all good citizens are bound to follow. It is, moreover, the course pursued by Mr. SANBORN in Concord, under similar circumstances. But it is much too sensible a course for HYATT. Saint THADDEUS repudiates the habeas corpus -- will not apply for it; will not bring his case before the Courts of law; will do nothing, in short, but lie helplessly in jail. Unless the Senate of the United States chooses to adopt his views on parliamentary privilege, without the smallest doubt or question, he will not leave his cell, nor make any effort to leave it
lead_paragraph: case are, that THADDEUS HYATT was subpoenaed before a Committee of the United States Senate, to be examined touching the Harper's Ferry insurrection. He obeyed the subpoena by appearing, and announced that he was ready to tell all he knew if the Senate would acknowledge beforehand that it had no power to compel him to testify. This the Senate very properly, or at all events very naturally, declined to do, and, as we believe with equal propriety, committed THADDEUS to close custody for a gross contempt in refusing to answer unconditionally. In order to test the legality of this imprisonment, THADDEUS has only to apply to any of the Courts for a writ of habeas corpus. None of them dare refuse it, and if the Senate has exceeded its powers under the Constitution, his discharge is certain, upon the return of the writ and the production of his body. This is what the law prescribes in every case of illegal imprisonment, -- this the precise course which all good citizens are bound to follow. It is, moreover, the course pursued by Mr. SANBORN in Concord, under similar circumstances. But it is much too sensible a course for HYATT. Saint THADDEUS repudiates the habeas corpus -- will not apply for it; will not bring his case before the Courts of law; will do nothing, in short, but lie helplessly in jail. Unless the Senate of the United States chooses to adopt his views on parliamentary privilege, without the smallest doubt or question, he will not leave his cell, nor make any effort to leave it

abstract: A regular meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held last evening. A communication was received from Mayor POWELL, calling attention to the necessity of making some preparation for a YellowFever Hospital. The subject was referred to the Health Committee.
lead_paragraph: A regular meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held last evening. A communication was received from Mayor POWELL, calling attention to the necessity of making some preparation for a Yellow-Fever Hospital. The subject was referred to the Health Committee. A petition was received from the Trustees of the Church owning the Lorimer-street (E.D.) burying-ground asking permission to remove the bodies from that ground to a cemetery in the country. The subject was referred to the Alderman of the Eighteenth Ward, with power. This is the same complained of as a nuisance a few weeks ago, made so by removal of bodies from one part of the ground to another. The Methodist Episcopal Church, corner of York and Gold streets, asked to be excused from paying taxes upon their building adjoining the Church used as a parsonage. Alderman SCHOLES said the Assessment Committee had once reported against this exemption, on the ground that the property was not exempt under the law, which exempts only places used for public worship and not church property. The subject was referred to the Law Committee. The City Railroad Company petitioned for permission to run their cars on the Greenpoint route through Front instead of Sands-street, and to change that of the propose. Powers-street route so as to pass through Bridge-street instead of Fulton avenue and street to Fulton Ferry. Referred to the Railroad Committee. A Special Committee, appointed to investigate the condition in which the late Commissioner of Repairs and Supplies left that department, made a lengthy report, showing that during the last four months of his term he expended nearly every appropriation made for different purposes for the whole year, and that the record of these expenditures cannot be found; that a large amount of work was ordered, paid for and never done; in other cases much more was paid than the work was worth; in some cases certificates for work were issued several weeks before the work was done; that he gave contracts for work to the quartermen in his employ, and paid by the City; that he gave out the contract for the Sixth Precinct Station-house so as to be exclusively under the control of an architect without recourse, and that in various other ways the Committee think he "conducted the business of the Department with a total disregard of the interests of the city." The Committee recommend that the Counselor be directed to compel the late Commissioner to return the missing records of the Department; that the Finance Committee be directed to report some way in which to provide for meeting the expenses of the Department for the balance of the year, where the appropriation has been exhausted, and that a Special Committee be appointed to draft an ordinance regulating this Department so as to prevent any future squandering of the City money by the holder of this office. The report was laid on the table for two weeks, and was ordered printed. WM.B. BOMEN was confirmed as Deputy City Clerk, and after the transaction of considerable other business, the Board adjourned for one week.

abstract: At the annual dinner of the Royal Academy, on the 6th inst., a fair representation of the better classes of English society was present, including Cabinet ministers, peers, members of Parliament, authors, artists,  Among other names honored by the President, Sir CHARLES L. EASTLAKE, was that of Mr. J. LOTHROP MOTLEY, the American historian, now prosecuting historical researches in Europe. Sir CHARLES said:
lead_paragraph: The next toast is "the interests of literature," a subject connected with no country; and in reference to which I have great pleasure in paying a just tribute to a distinguished American writer, Mr. MOTLEY, who this day honors us with his presence. Mr. MOTLEY's well-known work, The Rise of the Dutch Republic, has earned for its accomplished author the reputation of historical accuracy, philosophical largeness of treatment, and clearness and vigor of style, while to the lovers of an enlightened freedom it offers the charm of a heartfelt sympathy in its subject. [Cheers.]

abstract: An application has been made to the Supreme Court at General Term to admit to the bar the graduates (28 in number) of Columbia College Law School. The application is made under a similar statute to that enacted with reference to the Law Department of the New-York University, which the General Term have lately held unconstitutional. Prof. Dwight, of the Columbia school, will argue the application of his class this morning before the General Term.

abstract: There was not a quorum of Aldermen present, last evening, at the time for meeting, and, therefore, the Board did not organize. A veto was sent in by the Mayor, on the supposition that the Board would meet, to the effect that he returned without approval the resolution authorizing Mr. Charles Cheesborough to use the pier or bulkhead at the termination of the Third-avenue as a landing place for steamboats, for the reason that the point designated has already been leased by the Corporation to the Harlem Navigation Company, and that, therefore, it is not now the property of the City. As the Board, did not organize, there was, of course, no action taken on the message.

abstract: The continued absence of the Comptroller has tended to produce a most unwonted complication in municipal affairs. Some of the Department, (as heretofore noticed,) continue to recognize Mr. STOUT as City Chamberlain, and pay orer to him all moneys officially received, while others, in obedience to the dictum of the Mayor, acknowledge obedience only to Mr. PLATT. The presence of the Comptroller (expected to-day) may tend to solve this quibble, but the inevitability of a prolonged law-suit becomes daily more and more apparent, and the principal sufferers may be counted the creditors of the City, foremost among whom are the office holders, whose pay for the present month depends upon the arrangements made between the Mayor and Comptroller. Mr. STOUT has the great legal advantage of possession, which is acknowledged to be nine points of the law, but his past justifies the conviction that when legally ousted, he will surrender without asking for quarter, and which, under present circumstances, would scarcely be granted.

abstract: The Boston Courier tells the following story of the robberies lately perpetrated in that city by policemen and the manner of their detection:
lead_paragraph: On Thursday night the store of S.H. NEWMAN, NO. 41 Court-street, was entered, and a coat and a pair of pantaloons were stolen. On Friday the stolen articles were found at the house of JAMES MCCRILLIS, No. 377 Harrison-avenue, who was discharged from the police force about two years ago, on a suspicion of his having been connected with the robbery of a store. Since his discharge from the police he has been keeping a disreputable house on Harrison-avenue. It is said that the police were informed that the stolen property was in the possession of MCCRILLIS by his wife. He was arrested on Friday evening by Deputy Chief HAM and detective officer WRIGHT, and lodged in the Tombs. Mr. HAM had an interview with him, and questioned him about the robbery. MCCRILLIS owned that it was committed by members of the police department. Mr. HAM had suspected this, as he had been cautioned by some person to be on his guard. MCCRILLIS would not make any statement in regard to the matter, and Mr. HAM arrested ISAAC B. HUTCHINS and JETHRO H. GOODWIN of the second station, when they came in from their beats that night at 1 o'clock' on suspicion, and kept them in custody until morning. They were then taken to the Chief's office, and searched in separate rooms. They found on HUTCHINS a bunch of skeleton keys and a loaded pistol, with which he threatened to take his own life. The Chief of Police told him that his case was bad, and HUTCHINS pretended to make a clean breast of it, implicating many other officers, who, he stated, had been for several years in the habit of entering stores with false keys and in other ways, and stealing all kinds of merchandise in small quantities. Nothing was found on GOODWIN, and he refused to make any statement. An investigation before the Mayor and Committee on Police -- Aldermen ATKINS, AMORY, and C[???]ANE -- was had on Saturday, and all the officers implicated by HUTCHINS (twelve at the second station, and one at the first and eighth) were ordered to appear at the City Hall. The investigation was commenced in the morning at the Mayor's office, and lasted until about 11 o'clock on Saturday night.

lead_paragraph: of tenement houses, and the facility with which, under a proper system of regulations, they may be removed, it is sufficient to state that in most of the cities of Europe a large proportion of dwellings let to lodgers consist of houses of this description, while they are entirely free from the objections urged against such buildings in this City. In those buildings in the large European cities, the same good order and cleanliness prevail as in houses occupied by single families. They are inhabited, in most instances, by classes accustomed to the comforts and luxuries of life, and neatness and good order prevail throughout. If the landlords of tenement houses were held responsible for the violation of the sanitary ordinances of the City by their tenant it is believed that it would result, in the end, to their own advantage, as well as the public good, and the unpleasant and unhealthful associations connoted with the name of tenement houses would cease to exist.

abstract: Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, has at length introduced his bill in the Senate for the better suppression of the Slave-trade; and it certain- ly promises, if passed, to leave nothing undone that a mere act of Congress can do, to put an end to American participation in the traffic.
lead_paragraph: Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, has at length introduced his bill in the Senate for the better suppression of the Slave-trade; and it certain- ly promises, if passed, to leave nothing undone that a mere act of Congress can do, to put an end to American participation in the traffic. It authorizes the preparation of five sloops for service on the coast of Africa, and imposes on the District-Attorney the duty of searching carefully all vessels bound for the slave-coast. It moreover releases naval officers from-their present liability in an action for damages, in case they make a mistake in overhauling a vessel suspected of being a slaver; substitutes imprisonment for life for the death penalty, and raises the prize-money on every captured negro from twenty-five to one hundred dollars. These are the principal provisions of Mr. WILSON's bill, and they are supported by a large number of minor clauses which will give the act, if faithfully carried through, a fair prospect of real efficacy. Mr. WILSON ought, however, to add still another clause, adopting Mr. BUCHANAN's recommendation in his late message on this subject, and establishing depots for the negroes captured by cruisers, in which these unfortunate people can remain until returned to their own country. At present they are brought into the port nearest the point at which a slaver is taken, and enormous expense is incurred in providing them with food and shelter.

abstract: There was a very large gathering of those who desire the nomination of Senator DOUGLAS by the Democratic Convention about to meet at Baltimore, at Cooper Institute, last evening. The large Hall was crowded to excess, and several meetings were organized outside.
lead_paragraph: There was a very large gathering of those who desire the nomination of Senator DOUGLAS by the Democratic Convention about to meet at Baltimore, at Cooper Institute, last evening. The large Hall was crowded to excess, and several meetings were organized outside. Hon. F.B. CUTTING presided, and speeches were made by Hon. Messrs. RICHARDSON and LOGAN, of Illinois; WATTERSON and FOOTE, of Tennessee; E.C. MARSHALL, of Kentucky; Judge LARRABEE, of Wisconsin; THOS. C. FIELDS and others, -- all favoring the nomination of Mr. DOUGLAS, and considering him the only man who could save the Democratic Party, and through it, the Union, from impending dissolution. The meetings did not break up until near 12 o'clock, and after that a very large number proceeded to the Fifth-avenue Hotel, where Dodworth's full band serenaded the speakers and invited guests.

abstract: At a recent sale of drawings at the Hotel des V[???]ntes, among other lots was a small sepia, not three inches square, signed "Louis Napoleon Bonaparte." It represents a mounted grenadier of the Old Guard charging with such impetuosity that his bear-skin cap has fallen off. The play of the muscles and the shortening of the hind quarters of the horse, which is going at full speed, are rendered with great boldness. After a spirited competition it was knocked down for 390f.

abstract: At the meeting of this Board yesterday the report of the Sanitary Squad was received, designating the usual number of places in this City and Brooklyn requiring immediate attention. Sergeant LORD also presented a special report in relation to bone-boiling establishments, slaughter-houses and other nuisances of like character in the upper part of the City. The report was referred to the Sanitary Committee for such action as may be deemed best for the public health.

abstract: DEDICATION OF A REPUBLICAN WIGWAM. The Wigwam recently erected on Fulton-street, opposite the City Hall, by the Ashland and Rocky Mountain Clubs, was formally dedicated last evening. WM. H.
lead_paragraph: DEDICATION OF A REPUBLICAN WIGWAM. The Wigwam recently erected on Fulton-street, opposite the City Hall, by the Ashland and Rocky Mountain Clubs, was formally dedicated last evening. WM. H. PEET and JOSEPH REEVES presided, and speeches were made by Messrs. FRY, SPENCER, R.S. ANDREWS, BURLEIGH, and others. The Wigwam, which is capable of holding about 3,000 persons, was full during the whole evening, and much enthusiasm prevailed.

abstract: COLUMBIA COLLEGE LAW-SCHOOL?SERMON BEFORE THE GRADUATING CLASS.?Trinity Chapel, in Twenty-fifth-street, was last evening filled with a select and deeply-interested audience of ladies and gentlemen,to hear the Baccalaureate Sermon by Rev. Dr. FRANCIS VINTON, before the graduating law class of Columbia College.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA COLLEGE LAW-SCHOOL -- SERMON BEFORE THE GRADUATING CLASS. -- Trinity Chapel, in Twenty-fifth-street, was last evening filled with a select and deeply-interested audience of ladies and gentlemen,to hear the Baccalaureate Sermon by Rev. Dr. FRANCIS VINTON, before the graduating law class of Columbia College. President KING and Profs. MCVICAR, NAIENE and DWIGHT occupied seats in the chancel. The lesson of the evening, in part, was the reading of the Decalogue. The introductory services being concluded, Dr. VINTON ascended the desk on the left of the altar, and announced as the text of his sermon the 52d verse of the 11th chapter of Luke: "Woe unto you lawyers, for ye have taken away the key of knowledge." After expounding the context, and the circumstances under which this language was addressed, by Christ, to the scribes of his day, because they had perverted the law, instead of teaching it in its purity, he gave, as the leading doctrines deduced from the text first, the majesty of the law; second, the dignity of the legal profession; third, the liability of lawyers, from misinterpretation of the law, to mislead and hinder both themselves and others from duty; and, fourth, the penalty denounced against the perversions of the law. The concluding portion of the discourse was a review of the safeguards thrown around the purity and impartiality of the Judges, in both the English and American Constitutions, and a strong denunciation of the dangerous lapse of this state by the adoption of an elective Judiciary. The sermon was one of great eloquence and power, and produced a profound impression upon the audience.

abstract: All authentic intelligence up to the present moment goes to prove that the European Powers holding relations with Mexico have actively and strenuously opposed American diplomacy and influence in that country. The
lead_paragraph: All authentic intelligence up to the present moment goes to prove that the European Powers holding relations with Mexico have actively and strenuously opposed American diplomacy and influence in that country. The recognition of the Liberal or Constitutional Government of the Mexican Republic by Mr. MCLANE, the American Minister, has recently developed this opposition in the most marked and emphatic manner. No means within the reach of the European representatives have been neglected by them in their efforts to sustain the bloody and bigoted despotism of the Church faction to crush the Liberals, and thus effectually to prostrate American interests and destroy American influence throughout the Mexican territory. Singular as it may appear, this thoroughly sordid and selfish policy of the European Powers, so entirely opposed to the dictates of Christianity and humanity, and so completely at variance with the spirit of the age that it might be supposed to be a legacy from the sixteenth century and PHILIP II. of Spain, has secured a practical alliance within the limits of the United States themselves, and has found its chief foreign support in the Republican Party of the North.

abstract: The New-York and New-Haven Railroad Company vs. Robert Schuyler et al. -- The trial of this suit was proceeded with this morning. By previous understanding the issues joined by the defendants presented by Mr. Daniel Lord were first tried. Following these the counsel engaged were called on in alphabetical order, each being expected to try the cases of all the defendants represented by him. Messrs Benjamin V. Abbott, L.S. Ashley, S. Blatchford, Codert Brothers, Francis B. Cutting, Mr. De Witt, John Foot, Foster & Thompson and Ashbel Green were ready, and their cases were disposed of. Mr. Bliss was in attendance and asked a postponement on the ground of sickness of a witness; but as Mr. Noyes expressed himself willing to admit the fact to be proved by this witness. Judge INGRAHAM held the reason insufficient. The cases of many other defendants represented by counsel whose names were intermediate between those above mentioned on the alphabetical list, were run down, owing to their counsel being absent or unprepared.

abstract: ANNUAL SABBATH SCHOOL PARADE. The annual parade of the Brooklyn Sabbath schools, postponed from Tuesday, on account of the rain storm, came off yesterday.
lead_paragraph: ANNUAL SABBATH SCHOOL PARADE. -- The annual parade of the Brooklyn Sabbath schools, postponed from Tuesday, on account of the rain storm, came off yesterday. Nearly every school in the city turned out with full ranks, under the immediate care of their teachers -- the whole comprising a force of nearly twenty thousand. More than one-half of this number marched on Remsen-street and streets in the vicinity; between four and five thousand paraded on Clinton-avenue, and the remainder of the schools formed in the Eastern District. Each division had music, and, after counter-marching, the schools filed off to the different churches, as indicated in the programme, in each of which short addresses were made, followed by refreshments. The day was pleasant, the children were all neatly dressed and each school carried one or more appropriate banners, and nothing occurred to mar the pleasures of the occasion. From the annual report of the "Union," which includes only the schools connected with churches in the Western District, we obtain the following particulars: During the last year, two additional church schools have been organized, and six new mission schools, while one, hitherto a mission school, has matured into an organized church, with its dependent S. school. The increase of scholars over the past year is 1,913, and of teachers 80. Of these scholars, 710 are in the mission schools. The reported number of conversions is 394, of which 324 are pupils, and 70 are teachers. The total number of schools (only including the western division of the city) is 109, of which 76 are church, and 33 mission schools. The total number of scholars is 22,982, (average atteadance 13,603) of teachers 2,611. The mission schools have 2,964 scholars.

abstract: SYHOD'S SABBATH-SCHOOL UNION. The anniversary exercises of the Sabbath-school Union, connected with the Reformed Protestant Dutch Church, were held yesterday, in Dr. GANSE'S church, Twenty-thirdstreet, Rev. BENJAMIN C. TAYLOR, D.D., presiding;...
lead_paragraph: SYHOD'S SABBATH-SCHOOL UNION. -- The anniversary exercises of the Sabbath-school Union, connected with the Reformed Protestant Dutch Church, were held yesterday, in Dr. GANSE'S church, Twenty-thirdstreet, Rev. BENJAMIN C. TAYLOR, D.D., presiding; in the church earner of Twenty-ninth-street and Fifth-avenue, JAMES ANDERSON, M.D., presiding; in Rev. A.R. VAN NEST's church, Twenty-first-street, Rev. MARCUS S. HUTTON, D.D., presiding; and in the church corner of Fifth-avenue and Twenty-first-street, Rev. GEORGE W. BETHUNF, D.D., presiding. At 2 o'clock the schools formed into line of procession, Mr. JAMES HARRISON acting as Marshal of the day. A band of music headed the procession. The first division was composed of the following schools: Washington Heights, Harlem Mission do., Twenty-third-street Mission do., Knox Memorial, Prospect Hill, Broome-street Chapel, Mount Pleasant. The second Division, Mr. GARRETSON, Marshal, contained the following schools: Houston-street German Department, Twenty-ninth-street; First Mission, Second Mission, Green Point. In the Third Division, Mr. JAMES KING, Marshal, were the German School, Franklin-square School, East River, Greenwich-street Mission, and Manhattan Schools. The Fourth Division, THOS. SPROULL, Esq., Marshal, comprised the Greenwich School, Twenty-first street School, Middle Church Bowery Mission, and Madison-street Mission School. The procession marched up Fifth-avenue to Twenty-ninth-street, down Twenty-ninth street to Sixth-avenue, and down Sixth-avenue to Twenty-third-street, where the Second Division filed off. The main line then continued down Sixth-avenue to Twenty-first-street, where they entered their respective Churches. The school connected with the North Reformed Protestant Dutch Church, corner Fulton and William streets, met in their own Church, together with the schools connected with the Forsyth-street and Duane-street German Schools. Addresses were made by Rev. Mr. LEE, of Buffalo; Mr. BARLOW, of the House of Industry, and others. At the conclusion of the exercises in the Church, these schools formed into a procession, marched up Fulton-street to Broadway, up Broadway to the Park, entering by the south gate. After marching and counter-marching, they dispersed to their respective Churches, where refreshments were provided for the children.

abstract: The revolution which has been firing minuteguns from one and another height of the Sicilian coasts for the last two months, has been heard and answered. There can be no doubt now that GARIBALDI, after maturely weighing the actual chances of the rising in Sicily, has once more drawn his sword in the cause to which his whole life has been given.
lead_paragraph: The revolution which has been firing minuteguns from one and another height of the Sicilian coasts for the last two months, has been heard and answered. There can be no doubt now that GARIBALDI, after maturely weighing the actual chances of the rising in Sicily, has once more drawn his sword in the cause to which his whole life has been given. With a well-organized force-of two thousand volunteers, partners of his splendid campaign in the Lombard Alps, and devoted, like himself, to the standard of Italian unity and Italian independence, the defender of Rome and the hero of Varese has sailed from Sardinia, to kindle into a wide and devouring flame the scattered fires which threaten the throne of the dull tyrant of Naples. As to the gallantry and generosity of this act of the great Italian guerilla, there can be hardly two opinions among men worthy of the name, be their political opinions what they may. The Press of England and France, of course, pay public law the easy tribute of pointing out that GARIBALDI, arming troops in Sardinia for-the invasion of Sicily, is really a fillibuster; but this recognition of the legal nature of his expedition is accompanied by none of those denunciations which our foreign contemporaries can always pour forth in such overwhelming profusion whenever our American "sympathizers" go crusading across the frontiers of Canada and Mexico, or hover, magnanimous eagles of liberty, over the tempting shores of Cuba. They all admit that GARIBALDI has done a very incorrect thing; they all take the Government of VICTOR EMANUEL more or less gently to task for its failure to find out what the General was at, and to do their duty by young King BOMBA, with whom the Sardinian Sovereign maintains the usual diplomatic relations.

abstract: A fearful conflict occurred yesterday afternoon on board the packet-ship Wm. F. Storer, Capt. TRASK, between the officers and the seamen.
lead_paragraph: A fearful conflict occurred yesterday afternoon on board the packet-ship Wm. F. Storer, Capt. TRASK, between the officers and the seamen. Early in the morning the vessel's crew were shipped and she was hauled into the stream near Bedloe's Island, preparatory to her departure for Liverpool. The seamen, as is invariably the case, were partially intoxicated at the time they embarked and their frequent potations in the interval before the vessel was ready to go, rendered them very disorderly. In order to secure their services, the officers nailed up the forecastle where the sailors had secreted their liquor, and at 3 o'clock the anchor having been raised, a steam-tug started down the Bay with the ship in tow. Soon afterwards some of the crew came aft and demanded of Capt. TRASK that the forecastle should be opened, but on his refusal to comply with the request, the men declared that they would not work, and immediately inaugurated a disturbance. Marlin-spikes, belaying-pins, and other missiles, were thrown at the officers upon the poop deck, until finally the captain had to fire several times upon the mutineers, who returned the shots without doing any damage. Meantime, the captain gave orders to have the vessel towed back again, and anchored. This was done, and a signal of distress was displayed, but the battle was kept up without intermission, and the steward of the ship, who had been assisting the officers to keep the rebels from the poop, received a shot in the head which laid him insensible on the deck, and which is believed will speedily result in his death. B.W. CARE, the second-mate, was also felled with a handspike, and received a terrible scalp-wound.
headline: {'main': 'A Mutinous Crew.; ONE MAN FATALLY INJURED AND SEVERAL BADLY WOUNDED.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Mutinous Crew.; ONE MAN FATALLY INJURED AND SEVERAL BADLY WOUNDED.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: VICTOR EMANUEL left Florence at the beginning of the present week, and the town has returned to its usual quiet. abstract: When KAMI BUGEN and KAMI AWADJI, and their illustrious suite, left the pearl of the Pacific for these remote and melancholy coasts, they probably never expected to find themselves used as bait.
lead_paragraph: When KAMI BUGEN and KAMI AWADJI, and their illustrious suite, left the pearl of the Pacific for these remote and melancholy coasts, they probably never expected to find themselves used as bait. But they have seen and suffered, already, so many other things which they can never have expected, that they ought to be prepared for this also. After shaking hands with ragged little negroes and "greasy citizens;" and standing bare-headed in the sun to be sketched by special artists; and being inspected by young ladies perched on pier-tables, it ought not to surprise them to learn that all the theatrical world of New-York proposes to angle with them for audiences. It has unhappily leaked out that they are fond of spectacles and shows; and it will not be the fault of our New-York managers if they are not "fooled to the top of their bent," this way. From the New Bowery to Barnum's Museum, and from Wallack's to the Academy of Music rings the dreadful note of preparation. The illustrious strangers will be solicited to study the American stage in all its developments. They will hear opera in the critical company of BOOLE, and be introduced to the debate between the lovers of ROSSINI and the worshippers of WAGNER, by that aesthetic authority VAN TINE. The "What is it?" will stimulate their zoological zeal by his amiable and expressive gambols, and the California bears bewitch them by their intelligence and beauty. They will, no doubt, be invited to compare JACOBS and his saloon of magic with the black art as practiced in their own highly polished land. We should not be astonished if they were finally to decide for us the important question of the sex of ZOYARA.

abstract: Justice OSBORN yesterday granted a hearing in the cases of Charles Gilmore and William Eoright, who keep an office at No. 109 West-street, and who were recently arrested for alleged swindling transactions in the sale of tickets.
lead_paragraph: Justice OSBORN yesterday granted a hearing in the cases of Charles Gilmore and William Eoright, who keep an office at No. 109 West-street, and who were recently arrested for alleged swindling transactions in the sale of tickets. The arrests were made under the new act. The accused were discharged on the ground that they were not identified as the persons who negotiated the sale of the tickets. Officers Lawson and Mason arrested James McCurran and John Brophy, of No. 146 Liberty-street; the notorious Isaiah Selover, of No. 121 Cedar-street, and Geo. Ward, whose office is at the corner of Liberty and Greenwich-streets. They were taken before Justice OSBORN and discharged on their own recognizances. James Levy and John Hughes, who were found in possession of ticket office No. 157 Cedar-street, were arrested, and on motion of counsel were remanded to enable them to prepare a case on which the new law can be fully tested. This ticket-swindling-fraternity declare that they care nothing for the new Jaw, and expect to prosecute their trade without successful opposition from the Courts.

abstract: GARIBALDI's expedition to Sicily engrossed a large share of public attention. A correspondent of the Daily News describes the departure of the expedition from Gene[???] on the 5th of May, at midnight. [???] was composed of 2,200 volunteers. Three steamers were lying in the offing, to which they were conveyed in detatchments from various points along a range of four or five, miles of coast. The concentration of any large body on a given spot was avoided, in order not to bring additional perplexity on the Government. Nearly 5,000 people of all ranks flocked to the beach to bid the gallant adventurer "Good speed." As usual with Garibaldi volunteers, they were of every grade, and calling -- nobles, soldiers, artists, physicians, down to peasants and workmen. The enthusiasm of the troops in garrison at Genoa has been so roused that it was necessary to confine them to their barracks to prevent their deserting in order to enroll themselves. GARIBALDI had sanguine hopes of cutting out someone or other of the Neapolitan frigates, which were on the watch for his appearance. MEDICI, GARIBALDI's able lieutenant, was to start in four or five days with 2,000 more volunteers.

abstract: BALTIMORE, May 22. -- The schr. abstract: In the House of Lords, on the 10th inst., the Earl of MALMESBURY inquired whether the Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs would have any objections to inform the House in what state of progress the important negotiations connected with the Central States of America were at present?
lead_paragraph: In the House of Lords, on the 10th inst., the Earl of MALMESBURY inquired whether the Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs would have any objections to inform the House in what state of progress the important negotiations connected with the Central States of America were at present? This was an important matter, not so much as relates to the relations of those States themselves with Great Britain, but as to the settlement of the long-vexed question of the Clayton-Bulwer Treaty. When the late Government went out of office there were three questions under consideration -- namely, the settlement of the boundary line, the cession of the Mosquito protectorate to the Nicaraguan Government, and the cession of the Bay Islands to Honduras, on conditions insuring the safety of Her Majesty's subjects in those islands. The discussion of these three subjects had been commenced by the late Government and he should like to know the progress made in the negotiations. He had read in the newspapers the other day that the Bay Islands had bean ceded to Honduras. If that were so, and if it were done on the condition laid down first by Lord CLARENDON and afterwards by himself, he thought it would be a subject of great congratulation, that condition being the complete and entire recognition of the Clayton-Bulwer Treaty by the United States, and the entire security of Her Majesty's subjects in the Bay Islands against any interference from the United States or any other State whatever. He should like to know whether those negotiations were in such a position as would enable the Government to present the correspondence on the subject.

abstract: The Persia, bringing Liverpool advices to the 12th, and Queenstown telegrams to the 13th inst. arrived here yesterday. The news is of interest. The departure of Gen., GARIBALDI for Sicily with three vessels and some 2,200 men, is confirmed.
lead_paragraph: The Persia, bringing Liverpool advices to the 12th, and Queenstown telegrams to the 13th inst. arrived here yesterday. The news is of interest. The departure of Gen., GARIBALDI for Sicily with three vessels and some 2,200 men, is confirmed. Every precaution had been taken by the Sardinian Government to defeat the attempt, but so skillfully had the plans of the troops been laid, that they escaped without molestation. The vessels had subsequently touched at a Tuscan port for additional stores, and then put to sea, for what immediate destination was not known. It was rumored that a landing in Calabria, by way of a diversion in favor of the Sicilians, was contemplated by GARIBALDI. Much apprehension was felt lest the gallant leader and his chivalrous band should fall into the hands of the Neapolitan steam-cruisers. VICTOR EMANUEL had returned to Turin amid the liveliest demonstrations of popular joy. The Papal troops were rapidly organizing, with a view to opening the campaign on the Romagna. The intelligence from the rest of the Continent, beyond an improbable rumor that the French Government had inquired at Berlin the reason of the extraordinary armament of Prussia, is without importance. In the British Parliament, Lord MALMESBURY had obtained from the Ministry an explanation of the state of Central American diplomacy. The information elicited was already current here. Mr. HALIBURTON had called attention to French aggressions in Newfound land, declaring that the recent fortifications and naval stations of that Power controlled the entrance to the St. Lawrence. Lord JOHN RUSSELL said the subject had been examined by the law officers of the Crown, who discovered no infraction of right on the part of the French. Spirited correspondence had passed between Earl GREY and Lord JOHN RUSSELL relative to the course of these statesmen upon the reform question. It is one of many evidences of misunderstanding existing in the Cabinet. From China we learn that the European ultimatum was presented to the Court of Peking on the 8th of March, and that it was still unanswered.

abstract: Agreeably to the terms of the new act, and in pursuance, it is believed, of a previous private understanding in the Board of Police Commissioners, JOHN A. KENNEDY, the present Superintendent of the Emigrant Establishment at Castle Garden, was appointed General Superintendent of the whole Police forceCapt. DOWLING, of the Sixth Ward, and Capt DILKS'...
lead_paragraph: Agreeably to the terms of the new act, and in pursuance, it is believed, of a previous private understanding in the Board of Police Commissioners, JOHN A. KENNEDY, the present Superintendent of the Emigrant Establishment at Castle Garden, was appointed General Superintendent of the whole Police forceCapt. DOWLING, of the Sixth Ward, and Capt DILKS' of the Fifteenth, were appointed Inspectors; the one to take supervision of Police affairs in the lower part of the City, and of the more adjacent localities in Brooklyn; the other to take charge in the up-town Wards. Sergeant CAFFREY, now commanding the Broadway Squad, was promoted to the rank of captain, and Sergeant HELME was detailed to take his place. Sergeant PALMER, of the steamboat squad, and Sergeant SLOAT, of the Twenty-Second Ward, were also advanced to the captaincy of districts, which as yet have not been made known. Sergeant PALMES's position on the steamboat squad was assigned to Sergeant CROPSEY. It is said that Inspector CARPENTER, who still retains his rank as such, will be permitted to remain at the head-quarters in Broome-street. There was much anxiety exhibited as to the several appointments, and when the names of the fortunate applicants had at last oozed out, appointments and disappointments were synonymous with many.

abstract: In the General Term of the Supreme Court the Justices have announced their decision, denying the application of the Columbia College law students to be admitted to the Bar upon their diplomas. The Court hold that there is no substantial difference between the act of the Legislature relative to Columbia College, and that relative to the University; which latter act they decided a few days since to be unconstitutional. The opinion of the Court on the Columbia application is in preparation by Mr. Justice BONNEY.

abstract: The bill providing for the return to Africa of the negroes rescued from the slavers William and Wildfire was, after an animated discussion, in which the Southern extremists exhibited great reluctance to part with the sable strangers, passed by a decided majority. Mr. DAVIS' resolutions...
lead_paragraph: The bill providing for the return to Africa of the negroes rescued from the slavers William and Wildfire was, after an animated discussion, in which the Southern extremists exhibited great reluctance to part with the sable strangers, passed by a decided majority. Mr. DAVIS' resolutions having been called up, Mr. BIGLER, of Pennsylvania, expressed his views upon the general subject. The Senate proceeded to vote upon them, pa[???]sing the first and second by a vote of 36 to 20. Mr. CLINGMAN desired to amend the third by a declaration that nothing in the actual condition of the Territories calls for Congressional intervention. Mr. BROWN desired to amend the amendment, by asserting that such intervention is imperatively needed. Neither motion prevailed, and the resolution was adopted: Pending the voting the Senate adjourned. The House passed the Pacific Telegraph bill, with an amendment throwing the contract open to competition. The Pacific Railroad bill, as the order of the day, was discussed by Mr. CURTIS, who explained and advocated its provisions, and it was finally made the order for Monday and Tuesday.

abstract: DEATH OF PROF. WILSON, THE ORIENTALIST. The death of HORACE HAYMAN WILSON, M.A.,  F.R.S., Professor of Sanscrit in the University of Oxford, is just announced. He was born in London,...
lead_paragraph: DEATH OF PROF. WILSON, THE ORIENTALIST. The death of HORACE HAYMAN WILSON, M.A., F.R.S., Professor of Sanscrit in the University of Oxford, is just announced. He was born in London, in September, 1796. At the age of fifteen he was taken from the Soho-square school, where he had received an excellent education, to be initiated into the mysteries of the counting-room. It took but a few months to prove to young WILSON that the desk could not develop those powers which he felt conscious that he possessed, and he left it to devote himself to the study of medicine. In 1805 he passed as a member of the College of Surgeons, and soon afterwards received an appointment to an office in the Calcutta Mint. While on his voyage to India he commenced the study of the Oriental languages. The works of Sir W. JONES, which fell under Mr. WILSON's eye soon after his arrival at the scene of his labors, induced him to commence the study of the Sanscrit. At every turn he found himself crippled by the want of a good Sanscrit-English Dictionary; and as the most satisfactory and speedy way of supplying his necessity, he turned his attention to the preparation of such a work. It appeared in 1819, and met with a hearty reception from scholars. After having accomplished this task, Mr. WILSON devoted himself to reorganizing the Benares Sanscrit College, which had fallen into decay. In 1821 he returned to Calcutta. Contributions from his pen, which appeared in the Arabic Researches and the Oriental Quarterly Magazine, testified to his continued industry. The Sanscrit College, at Calcutta, was a[???]o greatly indebted to his efforts for a revival of its efficiency. The appointment to the Boden Professorship of Sanscrit in the University of Oxford, which was offered Mr. WILSON in 1833, induced him to return to England. All the learned societies with which he had been connected expressed their regret at his departure in complimentary addresses. Prof. WILSON landed in England after an absence of a quarter of a century, and immediately entered himself as a member of Exeter College, where be was admitted to the degree of A.M. He was, about this period, elected a Fellow of the Royal Society, and became a member of the Numismatic and Philological societies soon after their formation. He was L[???]orarian to the East India Company, Visitor to the East India College of Addiscombe, and President of the Royal Arabic Society. The scholars on the continent displayed their appreciation of his eminent services by electing him a member or the Imperial Institute of France, and of the Imperial and Royal Academies of St. Petersburgh, Vienna, Munich and Berlin. He had a membership in numerous other societies besides these. Besides writing miscellaneous works, illustrating the mythology, history and traditions of the East, he supervised and corrected an edition of Mills' History of India. Prof. WILSON's wife was a daughter of GEORGE SIDDONS, Esq., of the Bengal Civil Service, youngest son of the celebrated SARAH SIDDONS.

abstract: By force of a transposition, eminently allowable and judicious in this climate, of May-Day from the beginning to the end of the "merry month," the NewYork Harmonic Society will give us on Monday even...
lead_paragraph: By force of a transposition, eminently allowable and judicious in this climate, of May-Day from the beginning to the end of the "merry month," the NewYork Harmonic Society will give us on Monday evening next, as Dodworth's Saloon, an appropriate musical festival in STERNDALE BENNETT's cantata of "The May Queen." STERNDALE BENNETT is hardly so well known in America as his merits ought to have made him. He bears, as a composer, a very close relation to the school of MENDELSSOHN, under whose supervision he made his debut in Germany in 1836; bat he does not belong to the Germans in the same sense, for instance, in which his countryman ONSLOW must be called a French composer. More than any living Englishman BENNETT deserves the praise of a specially English and original quality of mind. His "Wood Nymphs," and his "Merry Wives of Windsor," laid the foundations of an English popularity of the highest order, which has been enhanced by the brilliant success of the "May Queen," a cantata essentially national alike in theme and in treatment. Mr. BENNETT is a thorough master of harmony, but the lyric traits of-his genius make their way constantly in bursts of light and melody; and as the "May Queen" is to be performed under the direction of that accomplished virtuose Mr. G.F. BRISTOW, the musical public will expect to hear full justice done to the English composer's masterpiece.

abstract: The Board met at 10 o'clock yesterday morning, and granted five licenses. The following rates were fixed upon for the licenses heretofore granted to the hotels: Metropolitan Hotel, $50; St, Nicholas Hotel, $50; Fifth-avenue Hotel, $50; Lafarge House, $40. All the other licenses already granted were fixed at $30. The Board will sit daily until the fifty days allowed it by law have expired. After that time no licenses can be granted.

abstract: It yesterday became the duty of Justice-KELLY to commit for examination on charges of grand larceny two men, known as John Hurley and J.T. Brown, whose pleading accents have almost daily fallen upon his judicial cars as practitioners at the bar of his Court. Mr. Harvey B. Dodworth, the music...
lead_paragraph: It yesterday became the duty of Justice-KELLY to commit for examination on charges of grand larceny two men, known as John Hurley and J.T. Brown, whose pleading accents have almost daily fallen upon his judicial cars as practitioners at the bar of his Court. Mr. Harvey B. Dodworth, the music publisher, of No. [???] As[???]-place, is one of the complainants, and Mrs. Delia, A. Corbiene, keeper of a boarding-house at No. 316 Lexington-avenue, is the other. Mr. Dodworth alleged that he had stored at the printing-office of George W. Ackerman, No. 53 Mercer-street, a quantity of stereotype music plates, and that, as he had been informed, on the morning of Saturday last the accused called at Ackerman's place, having a pretended execution against him for debt, and levied not only on the property of the printer, but also upon that of the, complainant. The plates however, at that time, were restored, when the accused learned from a journeyman in the office that Mr. Ackerman did not own them, but on Monday morning the prisoners reappeared at the printing-office, and after breaking open the door, carried away all the property, including $3,000 worth of Mr. Dodworth's plates, which they secreted. Hurley subsequently called upon Mr. D., and stated that he was a constable, but offered to restore the property. His proposal did not meet with an acceptance, and a complaint was lodged against both Brown and himself. The claim of Hurley to being a constable is not admitted, not withstanding the fact that he was elected to the office at the last election, as he failed to comply with the law in filing his securities within the specified time. Upon this ground the complaint of Mrs. Coro[???]ne is made against him, she having alleged that he broke into her house without authority, and carried away $500 worth of her household furniture.

abstract: Nathan Hayward vs. The Liverpool and London Insurance Company. -- This was an action on a policy of insurance for $10 000, issued by the defendants to the plaintiff upon his India-rubber manufactory, at Providence, Rhode Island. The factory was destroyed by fire, occasioned by the explosion of an insured boiler, attached to an insured engine, and an engine, as plaintiff claims, necessary arid indispensable to the manufacture of the goods. The policy contained a printed clause that the Company will not be liable for any less by fire occasioned by explosion, and on that ground the Company resisted the plaintiff's claim.
lead_paragraph: Nathan Hayward vs. The Liverpool and London Insurance Company. -- This was an action on a policy of insurance for $10 000, issued by the defendants to the plaintiff upon his India-rubber manufactory, at Providence, Rhode Island. abstract: THE K.G.C.'s IN TEXAS. -- A Brownsville correspondent of the New-Orleans True Delta says: "There have been encamped above here for some time about 200 K.G.C.'s, as they are called, but they are about to be dismissed on furlough, as it is said, Gen. REREAU, from Tennessee, is here -- came on the last boat from New-Orleans and brought the orders. This is probably the end of this Utopian scheme. If men knew Mexico, they would not risk their means to gain a country, which, when possessed, will be nearly valueless to such as go in there. All that is valuable is now in private hands, and no good man would be concerned in taking it from them by force. In war civilized nations respect private rights. I would add, that it is universally conceded that these men, K.G.C.'s, have been irreproachable in their conduct while out here, and retire leaving behind them the very best reputation."

abstract: A terrible tragedy occurred lately in De Soto County, Mississippi. One Nesbitt became so enraged at his son, with whom he had a dispute, that he seized a billet of wood and felled him to the earth. While the young man was lying helpless he repeated the blows, fracturing his skull, and inflicting injuries which soon terminated in his death. The unnatural father was committed to jail.

abstract: There was a disastrous conflagration at Nebraska City on the 12th. It broke out in a butcher-shop in consequence of some tallow catching fire, and destroyed property valued at $100,000. The following are the insurance offices interested: Merchants', St. Louis, $5,000; Great Republic Company, $3,000; Augusta Company, $6,000; Fulton, N.Y., $5,000; City of Hartford, $3,000; America, N.Y., $2,000; Hartford Fire Insurance Company, $4,000; Iowa Insurance Company, $4,000; Hartford Fire Insurance Company, $4,500; Quaker City, $5,000; AEtna's office, $30,000; other offices not known, $30,000.

abstract: We have at last an organized Police Department. The Commission has been filled up to its legal number, and the Commissioners have appointed a Superintendent, instead of allowing that most important office to devolve upon Mr. President BOWEN.
lead_paragraph: We have at last an organized Police Department. The Commission has been filled up to its legal number, and the Commissioners have appointed a Superintendent, instead of allowing that most important office to devolve upon Mr. President BOWEN. The $5,000 salary, which the latter so magnanimously relinquished and devoted to libraries for the policemen, must now be diverted from that use, and applied to the payment of the Superintendent.

abstract: Amelia Trow vs. Francis Becker. -- This was an action to recover damages for an alleged indecent assault, by reason of which the plaintiff claims to have become a mother, in April, 1858. The plaintiff testified that the defendant came to her house, in the upper part of the City, on the 23d of July, 1857, and finally remained to dinner. She also avers that while at dinger her coffee was drugged by him, so as to stupefy her, during which state of insensibility she was dishonored.

abstract: TWENTIETH ANNIVERSARY OF THE COLORED HOME. -- The Twentieth Anniversary of the Colored Home, in Sixty-fifth-street, was held yesterday afternoon. The Institution provides a home for about five hundred persons, a majority of whom are aged and infirm men and women. There are also a number of young persons of both sexes, and children from infancy upwards. It is sustained by donations, collections, and bequests of philanthropic persons. The treasurer's report set forth that there had been received upwards of $14,000, leaving a balance of upwards of $1,200, which, with various grants, amounts to about $2,000, which go towards liquidating the building fund debt. The exercises were conducted by Rev. Mr. MCDONALD. Rev. Mr. HENDERSON, colored, of British Guiana, read the 34th Psalm; Mr. R.G. PARDEE, of the Sunday School Union, offered prayer, after which brief addresses were made by Rev. H.H. GARNET, Rev. J. THOMPSON, of the Scotch Presbyterian Church in Grand-street; Rev. Mr. WELLS, of Williamsburgh; Rev. J.B. WAKELY, Methodist, Rev. C.B. RAY, Rev Mr. HENDERSON, and others. The addresses were interspersed with the singing of hymns, in which the congregation united. A collection was taken, after which the doxology was sung, and the exercises were closed by the Benediction. Afterwards the people, including the beneficiaries, old and young, took their way about the grounds, and enjoyed themselves in various sports.

abstract: The missing sketch-book has been discovered. Our readers will be gratified to learn that it was not stolen by any "special artist."
lead_paragraph: The missing sketch-book has been discovered. Our readers will be gratified to learn that it was not stolen by any "special artist." The official that had the book in charge, in endeavoring to slip it in the loose folds of his trousers, by a very natural mistake slipped it into one of the carriage pockets instead, where it was subsequently found by the driver. The driver, not comprehending the Japanese characters, thought at first that he had discovered a new Mormon revelation. Happening to exhibit his acquisition to an officer who had accompanied Com. PERRY in his visit to Japan, the true character of the book was recognized, and it was forthwith restored to the owner, who expressed his delight at its recover with many profound bows, and the presentation of a fan and paper smelling-bottle to the driver. The sketch-book contained a letter which Lieut. TYSASH took the liberty of translating, feeling that in so doing he was not violating the sanctity of private correspondence more than is customary with American people. After translating the letter he sent a note to MOORAGAKE, asking his permission, to which that Prince returned answer somewhat as follows: "Do as thou wilt! oh, TYSASH-KAMI, Namoo Amadi." The latter phrase is frequently used by the Japanese, and is somewhat analogous to our Hallelujah. We publish the letter as translated.

abstract: AMERICANS IN JAPAN -- AN UNFORTUNATE INCIDENT. -- An incident has occurred in Japan, which, though trivial in itself, may be productive of serious consequences. It seems that a merchant by the name of SMITH, doing business in Hakodadi, detected a party of natives in the act of robbing his house. Mr. SMITH was armed with a revolver of the most improved pattern, and instantly opened a fire upon the party, wounding one of them mortally. Mr. SMITH was arrested and tried before the American Consul, the trial resulting in his acquittal and a verdict of justifiable homicide. But it is said that the natives are not at all pleased with the result of the proceedings. In the first place, this summary method of punishing theft does not at all coincide with the Oriental notions of justice. To their crude thinking, a human life is of more value than a few yards of tape and calico. Nor do they think that the Consul was justified in disposing of the case quite so off-handedly; they seem inclined to claim a representation of the native judiciaries in an affair of this kind.

abstract: NOT IDENTIFIED. The body of a man found at the foot of J-street, Greenpoint, Wednesday, and at first supposed to have been the remains of Capt. BUER, of the sloop E.A. Johnson, has not yet been identified. A post-mortem examination was made...
lead_paragraph: NOT IDENTIFIED. The body of a man found at the foot of J-street, Greenpoint, Wednesday, and at first supposed to have been the remains of Capt. BUER, of the sloop E.A. Johnson, has not yet been identified. A post-mortem examination was made yesterday by Dr. BAUER, assisted by Dr. WHALEY. There were evident marks of violence on the body, but none of the wounds were sufficient to have caused death, though evidently made just before death. An inquest will be held on the body to-day. On some part of the clothing was found in writing "Dr. Breat[???]an." which fact may lead to the identification of the body.

abstract: THE CARSTANG-SHAW BREACH OF PROMISE CASE. -- The motion for a new trial in the celebrated case of CARSTANG vs. SHAW came up for argument before Judge REBER in the Court of Common Pleas this morning. Major WRIGHT desired to introduce the oral testimony of two or three witnesses in support of the motion, and in order to show that the jurors impaneled at the recent trial prejudged the case previous to their being impaneled. The counsel for defendant objected to the course of procedure proposed by Major WRIGHT, on the ground that the proper method was to introduce affidavits in support of the motion. After considerable argument on the part of counsel in the case, the Court finally sustained the objections of defendant's counsel, and postponed the further consideration of the matter until next law day, in order to give Major WRIGHT an opportunity to take the affidavits. -- St. Louis Evening News, 19th

abstract: IMPORTANT DECISIONS OF THE COURT OF APPEALS. -- Two questions of practical moment, as affecting a large interest among us, have been passed upon by the Court of Appeals -- one at the last Albany Term, and the other at a previous term. They relate to the scope and meaning of the Excise act of 1857. An appeal was taken in Onondaga County against the decision of the General Sessions, in a case of indictment and conviction for the sale of liquors without license. The Supreme Court affirmed the judgment. The Court of Appeals pronounced its opinion by PRATT, Justice, to the effect that, beside the civil penalty for violation of the act, the sale of strong or spirtous liquors or wines, without license therefor, is a misdemeanor, to be proceeded against criminally, either by complaint before a magistrate, or by indictment. Under the provisions of that act, and more specifically by the terms of the amended Police law, it is the duty of Policemen to make arrests for this offence, without warrant; and it is also the duty of magistrates to punish upon adequate proof of wrong-doing. This matter being settled, dealers can have no alternative but to procure licenses or shut up shop.
lead_paragraph: IMPORTANT DECISIONS OF THE COURT OF APPEALS. -- Two questions of practical moment, as affecting a large interest among us, have been passed upon by the Court of Appeals -- one at the last Albany Term, and the other at a previous term. They relate to the scope and meaning of the Excise act of 1857. An appeal was taken in Onondaga County against the decision of the General Sessions, in a case of indictment and conviction for the sale of liquors without license. The Supreme Court affirmed the judgment. The Court of Appeals pronounced its opinion by PRATT, Justice, to the effect that, beside the civil penalty for violation of the act, the sale of strong or spirtous liquors or wines, without license therefor, is a misdemeanor, to be proceeded against criminally, either by complaint before a magistrate, or by indictment. Under the provisions of that act, and more specifically by the terms of the amended Police law, it is the duty of Policemen to make arrests for this offence, without warrant; and it is also the duty of magistrates to punish upon adequate proof of wrong-doing. This matter being settled, dealers can have no alternative but to procure licenses or shut up shop.

abstract: The Evening Post is undoubtedly right in ascribing to the Albany legislation of last Winter something of the responsibility for the defeat of GOV. SEWARD at Chicago.
lead_paragraph: The Evening Post is undoubtedly right in ascribing to the Albany legislation of last Winter something of the responsibility for the defeat of GOV. SEWARD at Chicago. We need not repeat the opinion we expressed of the character of that legislation while it was pending. The TIMES never failed to denounce it as a disgrace to the State, and as certain to brand with lasting obloquy every one connected with it. It was easy to see that such wholesale corruption as was there practiced could not fail to recoil with fearful effect, not only upon the persons directly guilty, but upon the Party upon which the responsibility for it should be in any degree devolved. The Press did its duty to the public in exposing its character, and in branding it as it deserved.

abstract: PREPARING FOR THE CAMPAIGN. -- A meeting was held last night at Scott's Exchange in Montgomery-street, Jersey City, for the purpose of organizing a Lincoln Club. A. GRIERE was appointed Chairman, and WM.B. DUNNING Secretary. Ex-Mayor GREGORY, one of the delegates to the Chicago Convention, was present and made an interesting report of the proceedings during the several days that the Convention was in session. From conversation with gentlemen from various sections of the country, and the enthusiasm manifested on the nomination of Mr. LINCOLN, Mr. GREGORY believed that the opposition would be triumphantly elected. A Committee, consisting of two from each Ward, was appointed to present a plan of organization. They subsequently reported in favor of calling the organization "The Lincoln Campaign Club, of Jersey City." A Committee was appointed to ascertain the probable cost of erecting a wigwam, and find a location upon which to construct it. Directions were also given to procure a hall temporarily for the use of the Club. Quite a number of names were enrolled for membership....... Preliminary steps have been taken for the purpose of forming an organization, to be called the "Hudson County Lincoln Brigade."

abstract: The persistent efforts of English alarmists to frighten the good people of Prussia into expecting a French army on the Rhine, have not thus far been very successful; for it...
lead_paragraph: The persistent efforts of English alarmists to frighten the good people of Prussia into expecting a French army on the Rhine, have not thus far been very successful; for it seems to be gradually dawning upon the German, and particularly upon the Prussian mind, that the domestic relations of the German States are matters almost as important to German statesmen and the German people, as the foreign policy of Great Britain. England has always found it very convenient to use Germany as her army. Strong by sea and weak by land, English Governments, planning Continental wars, cannot dispense with a Continental ally, powerful enough to supply the bayonets which England lacks, and just not independent enough to pursue a policy of her own. No such ally now remains to England, unless Prussia will accept the duty; and it is quite touching to see with how much pathos and eloquence English orators and journalists have of late been urging Prussia to beware in time of the stealthy advances of the Napoleonic power. This pathos and this eloquence, we will not say, have been utterly wasted upon their object; but they have certainly failed to elicit the grateful and immediate response which such disinterested devotion perhaps deserved. Prussia is indeed, agitated, as she has not been since 1848; but neither her anxieties nor her hopes are of a kind to satisfy her British advisers. It is not by the fear of France, but by the determination of ruling a united Germany, that the actual Government of Prussia seems now to be controlled. Prussia, under M. DE SCHLEINIT[???] and the Prince-Regent, is less concerned to protect the Rhenish frontier against a problematical French invasion, than to annihilate the influence of Austria in the Federal relations of the German Powers, and to make herself the representative and head of all truly German interests In the pursuit of this double aim, it is not impossible that Prussia may suddenly come into collision with France; but there is as yet no sort of valid reason for anticipating such a catastrophe. A very few words will suffice to explain to our readers the elements of a political situation which is now dividing the attention of diplomatic Europe with the position of FRANCIS II. in Naples.

abstract: Mary Dutrig vs. The Mayor, &c. -- This was an action of the plaintiff, as janitress of the Marine Court-rooms, to recover of the City the sum of $317, with interest from May, 1858, for alleged extra services. The plaintiff claimed that she had built fires and carried water in addition to her regular duties, for which she had not been paid. On the trial she produced the certificate of the judges of the Marine Court, to the effect that she had performed the services for which she claimed. Plaintiff testified that Comptroller FLAGG refused her the extra claim. The defence of the Corporation is pavement; and David Gr[???]esbeck, of the Comptroller's Office, testified that the pay-rolls of that office showed that the plaintiff had been paid $1 a day for the period claimed -- October, 1856, to May, 1858.

abstract: The recruiting of Irishmen for the service of the Pope, which is said to be now progressing very steadily, is a curious illustration of that...
lead_paragraph: The recruiting of Irishmen for the service of the Pope, which is said to be now progressing very steadily, is a curious illustration of that strange political perversity which seems to be one of the hardiest products of the long course of oppression which Ireland has undergone. The earlier struggles of the native population with their conquerors, were simply the struggles of two hostile races. It was not till the English had embraced Protestantism that their animosities became religious. The hatred of the Irish was no longer lavished on the Saxon but on the Protestant, and the Saxon in his turn transferred his loathing from the "wild Irishman" to the "Papist." It was the Catholics, and not the Irish, who were routed at the Boyne, and foiled before Londonderry, and it was against heretics, and not English, that SARSFIELD made his last stand at Limerick. In 1700 the distinction of race was no longer heard of, but the distinction of creed was a flaming sword. The more intensely Protestant England became, the more intensely Catholic Ireland became. The more English Liberals shrank from contact with foreign Ecclesiastics, the more fondly the Irish turned towards Rome. Whatever the one hated, the other with unconquerable pugnacity began instantly to adore. Hardly one of the great political principles for which the Whigs of 1688 contended, ever took the least root on the Irish side of the Channel. The more the British clung to representative institutions, the more the Irish bowed to priests and kings. While SOMERS was busy over the Bill of Rights, the ideal Government of the Irish people was the despotism of a gentlemanly Catholic, regular at mass and confession, and in good standing at the Vatican.

abstract: Comptroller HAWS, in order to save tedious litigation and the credit of the City, has proposed to the counsel of Mr. PLATT that a case should be made up in which the points at issue shall be distinctly placed before the Supreme Court. lead_paragraph: THE NEW COUNTRY MARKET IN CANAL-STRFTT. In December of the past year, the following resolution was passed by the Common Council and approved by the Mayor, and by virtue of the authority thus conferred, the Street Commissioner is at present engaged in removing the unseemly mass of brick and mortar misnamed a depot, and occupied by Hudson River Railroad Company, the intention of the authorities being to open the space thus vacated for a country market, which is much needed in that neighborhood. This is one step towards breaking up the monopoly of the Washington Market, and while it will afford much-needed accommodations to residents in that vicinity, may prove to be the entering-wedge of the contemplated new market in the upper portion of the City:

lead_paragraph: Mr. Fry, of Bristol, is engaged, we understand, in preparing an edition of Tyndale's New Testament, printed at Worms in the year 1525, from the copy preserved in the Baptist Museum at Bristol. It is to be an exact transcript of the original, which will be first traced page by page, and then lithographed in facsimile. Of this publication, only a limited number of copies will be issued, some few of which will be printed on large paper, and three or four on vellum.

abstract: During the past two days the Street Commissioner has been the recipient of more "calls" than ever fell to the lot of any oificial with the exception of the Mayor on New-Year's day. The occasion which has caused this sudden influx of visitors, is the recent action of the Police Commissioners, in directing the removal of all obstructions in the streets and  from the sidewalks, including awning-posts which did not conform to the prescribed pattern.
lead_paragraph: During the past two days the Street Commissioner has been the recipient of more "calls" than ever fell to the lot of any oificial with the exception of the Mayor on New-Year's day. The occasion which has caused this sudden influx of visitors, is the recent action of the Police Commissioners, in directing the removal of all obstructions in the streets and from the sidewalks, including awning-posts which did not conform to the prescribed pattern. This new movement, which was, however, once before attempted, has kept the policemen busy, and has proved a terrible tax upon the patience and temper of the street Commissioner and his aids. A little retrospection may not be uninteresting, as affording some insight into the promptings of the present movement.

abstract: Hon. A. RUST, member of the House of Representatives from Arkansas, has addressed a circular to his constituents, in which he discusses the prominent political questions of the day. The greater part of the circular is devoted to questions of State policy. In that portion of it which relates to national policies. Mr. RUST contends that there is a party in the South whose leaders at heart are disunionists, and who now seem careless about concealing the aim of their policy, and in order to carry out their schemes, have availed themselves of the just resentment excited in the popular mind of the South, caused by the recent outrages perpetrated upon the citizens and soil of Virginia, by the fanatic BROWN and his followers. These violators of law, having paid the last earthly penalty of their crimes by an ignominious death, Mr. RUST thinks the fact should be accepted by the Southern people as the most ample expiation that could be rendered, instead of producing such a degree of sectional bitterness and exasperation as (to use the language employed by Mr. YANCEY in his letter to Mr. SLAUGHTER of June 15, 1808,) "to fire the Southern heart," and enable them, (the Democrats) by "one organized, concerted action, to precipitate the Cotton States into a revolution."
lead_paragraph: Hon. A. RUST, member of the House of Representatives from Arkansas, has addressed a circular to his constituents, in which he discusses the prominent political questions of the day. The greater part of the circular is devoted to questions of State policy. In that portion of it which relates to national policies. Mr. RUST contends that there is a party in the South whose leaders at heart are disunionists, and who now seem careless about concealing the aim of their policy, and in order to carry out their schemes, have availed themselves of the just resentment excited in the popular mind of the South, caused by the recent outrages perpetrated upon the citizens and soil of Virginia, by the fanatic BROWN and his followers. These violators of law, having paid the last earthly penalty of their crimes by an ignominious death, Mr. RUST thinks the fact should be accepted by the Southern people as the most ample expiation that could be rendered, instead of producing such a degree of sectional bitterness and exasperation as (to use the language employed by Mr. YANCEY in his letter to Mr. SLAUGHTER of June 15, 1808,) "to fire the Southern heart," and enable them, (the Democrats) by "one organized, concerted action, to precipitate the Cotton States into a revolution."

abstract: No event has recently occurred which furnishes so good an illustration of the progress made in the printing and photographic arts, and the facility with which the Press, as now conducted, carries intelligence of every description to the million, than the arrival of the Japanese in this country. Fifty years ago the news that such an Embassy had arrived at Washington would hardly have reached New-York in less than a fortnight, and then the accounts would have been so meagre that the subsequent arrival of the strangers here would have found the public curiosity wholly fresh. At the present time, however, let one of the illustrious Pagans but light his diminutive pipe at WILLARD's, and before half the contents is burned, every boot-black in the Park can tell how many puffs he takes in a minute; and an hour later the illustrated papers will inform the public eye of exactly the shape which the smoke-cloud took as it curled away. The public is familiarized not only with the meaning of everything said by the strangers, but even with its sound, by means of reports containing each word doubly orthographed in Niphonese and English, and syllabled to suit the reading capacity of infants in the primer.

abstract: A regular meeting of the First Assembly District Republican Campaign Club was held last evening, O.H. KOPP presiding. A number of new members was added to the roll, increasing the list to over two ...
lead_paragraph: A regular meeting of the First Assembly District Republican Campaign Club was held last evening, O.H. KOPP presiding. A number of new members was added to the roll, increasing the list to over two hundred. An Executive Committee of one from each Ward was appointed as follows: First Ward, James Marshall; Second, John Shipton; Third, John M. Costa; Fourth, Louis Nauman; Sixth, John Letson. It was decided to meet two weeks [???]ence, for the purpose of ratifying the national nominations. Mr. COSTA announced that tar barrels and fireworks, as well as eminent speakers would be provided on the occasion, in order to show that the down-town Republicans were alive.

abstract: Mr. SCOTT RUSSELL recently read a very interesting paper on the shape of vessels, before the Institute of Naval Architects. His experiments as to the shape of sterns of vessels showed that they should have a cycloidal curve, in order to prevent the adverse action of the "replacing" or following waves. As to the wave at the bow, supposing the vessel to have power enough to go faster than the water could spread itself, he said that the water would rise up and stand at both sides of the boat until the load had passed, and then fall down into the hole left behind it. He narrated the following singular and important fact: "In a shallow canal in Scotland, where the carrier wave traveled only seven miles an hour, he had compelled a boat to go ten miles, and he found that the water not only rose up, but lifted the boat with it, so that she drew less water than before, and actually wont easier at ten miles an hour than at five. Had not railways come into fashion just at the time, the country would have been covered with little troughs, and people would have been riding on the tops of these waves in an easier and cheaper mode than by any other means then known."
lead_paragraph: Mr. SCOTT RUSSELL recently read a very interesting paper on the shape of vessels, before the Institute of Naval Architects.
