abstract: I compassionate the gentleman, and even the lady, who has never ridden in or upon an omnibus. A man who has never sat upon the knifeboard, has not completed his education; he has left a very great deal unseen, unheard and unfelt; he has missed the sensations of looking involuntarily into first-floor windows, of picking up information of a more startling than reliable nature and of testing the ability of the small of his back to resist the incessant attacks of a sharp-edged instrument. You are recommended always to live up to your privileges, and surely a bus is a privilege. The hypochondriacal author of the Anatomy of Melancholy, who was wont to cheer his drooping spirits by furtively listening to the "chaff" of "bargees" upon the banks of classic Isis, would have reveled in the amenities of a London 'bus. It is essentially the people's conveyance, and therein you encounter the many-headed monster in all its multiform variety, from the dirty little boy who "sniffs" unpleasantly, to the moustached don who stares unpleasantly. Nor is the spice of danger wanting. You are taking money to your banker's -- you know you are, or you would never look so conscious, and that over-dressed man upon your left knows it too, and will consider it a reflection upon his character as a man of talent if it arrive at its destination. Mark that amiable-looking youth upon your right, with loose coat-sleeves and hands neatly folded upon his knees -- his digits are even now making researches into your pockets; and that pretty young lady seated opposite you, who timidly inquires at the very nick of time if she is 'near the Old Bailey,' is neither more nor less than an accomplice. Everybody is entitled to his opinion upon tragedy and comedy, and to me there is something irresistibly comic in an omnibus full of utter strangers. Face to face they sit, and their muscles are perfectly rigid; they nod forward, like an old dame dozing, at every jolt of the omnibus, and threaten each other with their noses; they stare vacantly at the brims of each other's hats or bonnets; their hands are crossed upon the handles of their sticks or umbrellas; and they speak never a word unless the gentleman at the top should still have sufficient confidence in the kindliness of human nature left to ask the gentleman near the door to tell the conductor "Fleet-street." This simple request does not at first sight appear likely to call for any vast supply of the milk of human kindness; it is, however, not unfrequently the precursor of altercations, contumely, and heart-burnings, for the conductor, you will observe, is upon the topmost step, conversing with "Old Gutta Percha," as he politely calls the driver, in playful allusion to his water-proof overcoat. So the gentleman near the door, after a careful reconnaissance, takes good aim, and lunges at him with his umbrella: the sharp point hits him full and true, and down hops the discom[???]ited "cad" like a spiteful parrot from his perch. "Hulloa! I say, sir, 'ductors 'as feelin's as well as other people. I ain't paid for to be knocked about."

abstract: --The brutality of American masters at sea has furnished English journalists with a prolific theme for at least a dozen years. That occasional instances of maltreatment may be met with on American vessels we admit, but that such an unmitigated piece of brutality as the Aylesbury News chronicles as having just been displayed in England, would have been tolerated anywhere upon American soil, we doubt.
lead_paragraph: -- The brutality of American masters at sea has furnished English journalists with a prolific theme for at least a dozen years. That occasional instances of maltreatment may be met with on American vessels we admit, but that such an unmitigated piece of brutality as the Aylesbury News chronicles as having just been displayed in England, would have been tolerated anywhere upon American soil, we doubt. An offending member of an Artillery company which was ordered from Northampton to Aldershot, by way of punishment was tied to a gun-carriage, and as he was either unable or too obstinate to walk, he was dragged out of town as far as Tingewick-road Bridge, and only released from the wheels of the gun-carriage when it was found that he was on the verge of strangulation, black in the face, and blood gushing in torrents from his nose and mouth. Without claiming for our people any superfluse tenderness of feeling, we will yet venture to assert that no Artillery company would dare, if disposed, to drag a man at the [???]all of a gun through the streets of a town in the heart of a thickly settled country.

abstract: At the meeting of the Association on Thursday evening, the subject of gas-burning having been set apart for special discussion, was considered. This subject arose from a disagreement of the Committee, to whom was referred the consideration of Johnson's patent gas burner, for which is claimed by the inventor a great saving in amount of gas consumed as well as an increased percentage of light.
lead_paragraph: At the meeting of the Association on Thursday evening, the subject of gas-burning having been set apart for special discussion, was considered. This subject arose from a disagreement of the Committee, to whom was referred the consideration of Johnson's patent gas burner, for which is claimed by the inventor a great saving in amount of gas consumed as well as an increased percentage of light. A majority of the Committee, represented by Messrs. HEDRICKS and SEELY, reported adversely to the burner, but a contrary opinion was held by Prof. GAROY, who represented the minority.

abstract: Beaten as we have been upon our own waters by the enterprise of foreign shippers and the apathy of our own legislators, it is satisfactory to see that the few American steamships which are still in a condition to breast the Atlantic are not absolutely rotting at our wharves. The present season has been honorably distinguished by something like a renewal of that conflict with Great Britain and Germany for supremacy on the high seas from which we seemed to have definitely retired two years ago. The screw-traffic of commerce remains, indeed, with our European rivals, Liverpool, Hamburg and Bremen, leaving us no room in that direction. But the swift passenger traffic, which had been pretty thoroughly conquered by the Cunarders, is now boldly grasped at by no less than three American companies. Foremost among these stands, to the great joy of all New-Yorkers, that solitary line of ocean steamers to which we owe it that the American flag has never ceased to be seen in the steam-navigation of the Atlantic. The Havre and Southampton steamers of the "Livingston" line have continued, through good and ill report, to maintain not only the name but the fame of the national steam navy in foreign ports. In an article on merchant steam marines, which appeared not long since in the French Moniteur de la Flotte, this line was deservedly credited with all the best attributes of being a passenger navy; and being expressly excepted from the rather sweeping criticisms bestowed upon the management of American steamers in general, was recommended as a model, in all essential respects, to the attention of the new French Company now engaged in organizing a transatlantic steam line between the west coast of France and the Brazils.

abstract: MR. JOHN M. KOPPER, for some time past General Superintendent and out-door Manager of the Weehawken Ferry Company, came to his death on Thursday morning last, under the following circumstances: He had been in the habit, on Sabbath evenings, of going down to the Ferry for a short time to assist in getting over the crowds that usually fill the boats at such times.
lead_paragraph: MR. JOHN M. KOPPER, for some time past General Superintendent and out-door Manager of the Weehawken Ferry Company, came to his death on Thursday morning last, under the following circumstances: He had been in the habit, on Sabbath evenings, of going down to the Ferry for a short time to assist in getting over the crowds that usually fill the boats at such times. On pursuance of this custom he walked to the Ferry on Sunday evening last, and crossed to the Weehawken side. While sitting in the office there, a half-dozen ruffians from the desperate gangs that infest our City came upon the premises and commenced an indiscriminate assault upon a number of peaceable and well-behaved excursionists, who were awaiting the crossing of the last boat. The attack, as we learn, was entirely without provocation, and seemed to be indulged in from mere love of crime and violence.

abstract: Catharine N. Forrest vs. Edwin Forrest. -- This was a motion for a stay of proceedings until an appeal could be perfected. It was also asked that the usual security required in such cases be dispensed with. The ground of this application was that the defendant is abundantly solvent, and therefore no security is seeded. Counsel also asked, if the Court still required security, for leave to unite more than two persons on the undertaking, the parties to justify collectively in an amount equal to the sum required by law.

abstract: Mrs. Blount, of No. 27 Twenty-seventh-street, identified a portrait in the Rogues' Gallery as that of Wesley Allen, a well-known pickpocket, who had stolen $17 from her, as she was riding in a Fourth-avenue stage. Allen was arrested by Detective Roach, and subsequently another complaint was made against him by Mrs. Deyner, of No. 276 Lexington-avenue, who says that he picked her pocket of $70 worth of valuables, whilst she was going up town in an Eighth-avenue car. The accused was remanded for examination....Detectives Slowey and Wilson arrested John P. Bigelow, a gentlemanly-looking young man, at his house in Williamsburgh, on a charge of having falsely represented himself to be a collector for Wilson's City Directory, to Mr. B.F. Cook, of No. 42 John-street, who gave him $35 in payment for an advertisement in the publication. He was required by Justice CONNOLLY to give bail for his appearance to answer....The same magistrate entertained a complaint for reckless driving, against Jas. Hart, a dirt-cartman, who drove his vehicle over Mrs. Mary Ann Muir, as she was passing through Greenwich-street, near Desbrosses. The lady was seriously injured.

abstract: Mayor WOOD has taken the first step towards plunging the City into the same labyrinth of legal controversy in which it was involved by his attempt to defeat the State law creating the Metropolitan Police Department. Whatever professions he may make -- and no man during a canvass is more lavish of them -- he has but one ruling passion in office -- and that is, a determination to use all the power of the City Government, and all the money of the City treasury, for the promotion of his personal purposes and the advancement of his political schemes. To this, everything is made to bend. Ordinances, charters, the decisions of Courts, are regarded by him only as obstacles to the accomplishment of his plans, and to be removed by any means which the emergency may require.
lead_paragraph: Mayor WOOD has taken the first step towards plunging the City into the same labyrinth of legal controversy in which it was involved by his attempt to defeat the State law creating the Metropolitan Police Department. abstract: Last Monday morning rose tolerably brilliantly, considering the awful time of cutting east winds and snow and hail-storms we had recently experienced, and by ten o'clock Pall Mall was well filled with scattered groups, wending their way to the exhibition of the Royal Academy. It was the opening day; the Queen had been in the previous Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Opening of the Royal Academy -- A Good Story of Thackeray -- Anthony Trallope -- Large Income made by him -- Charles Dickens -- E.M. abstract: The House Post-office Deficiency bill was reported to the Senate with various amendments. The Overland Mail bill, after remarks by Senator GWIN, was laid aside in company with the private calendar, to make way for the debate upon the Davis resolution.
lead_paragraph: The House Post-office Deficiency bill was reported to the Senate with various amendments. The Overland Mail bill, after remarks by Senator GWIN, was laid aside in company with the private calendar, to make way for the debate upon the Davis resolution. Mr. CRITTENDEN, in continuation of his remarks of Thursday, saw no call for Congressional intervention in behalf of Slavery; discovered no disposition on the part of any Territorial Government to interfere with Slavery; and deprecated any anticipation of the future to make mischief in the present. The question was taken on Mr. BROWN'S amendment, that intervention is now needed, and it was lost, yeas 5, nays 43. Mr. HALE, of New-Hampshire, was among the yeas. An amendment offered by Mr. COLLAMER, that intervention would never be required, was lost. Mr. CLINGMAN'S resolution that no necessity now exists for intervention was carried, yeas 26, nays 23; but was subsequently reconsidered and lost. The fifth resolution coming up, Messrs. CLINGMAN and BROWN both offered amendments, which were lost. Mr. TOOMBS moved as an amendment that the action of Congress shall be restricted within constitutional limits, which was accepted. The fifth resolution was adopted, yeas 35, nays 2. The sixth resolution, which declares the right of a State in organizing for admission to the Union to admit or exclude Slavery, was also adopted, yeas 33, nays 12. The seventh resolution, relative to the Fugitive law, was the topic of an animated discussion, in which Messrs. HALE and MASON participated. At its close the Indian Appropriation bill was taken up, and the Senate adjourned. An attempt to bring up in the House the bill for the adjustment of Revolutionary claims failing, the House considered the private calendar, when a score of bills were passed. The Senate bill relative to the recaptured Africans was taken up. Mr. UNDERWOOD, of Georgia, moved as an amendment, that the negroes be either sold in Florida or set free in Massachusetts, a proposition which elicited an indignant rejoinder from Mr. DAWES, of the latter State, for which the latter was called to order. The bill was referred to the Judiciary Committee.

abstract: The Messrs. LELAND are vigorously prosecuting their arrangements for the reception of our Japanese guests, the Common Council having determined, as has already been announced, that the Metropolitan Hotel shall be their stopping-place during their stay on the City. It was originally intended to appropriate the first floor of the Hotel to the use of the ...
lead_paragraph: The Messrs. LELAND are vigorously prosecuting their arrangements for the reception of our Japanese guests, the Common Council having determined, as has already been announced, that the Metropolitan Hotel shall be their stopping-place during their stay on the City. It was originally intended to appropriate the first floor of the Hotel to the use of the Embassy, but study of the habits of those composing it, as developed by their stay in Washington, proved that such an arrangement would not insure them the privacy which they seem to covet, and it has been determined to assign the guests the other apartments. The principal Ambassador will occupy the rooms upon the second floor which look out on the corner of Prince-street and Broadway. This will afford his Excellency a fine opportunity for inspecting the moving multitude which throngs Broadway, for there are few points de vue where a better prospect can be had of this thoroughfare. Immediately adjoining these apartments will be those of the three Princes next in rank. Then come the rooms for the sixteen officers of equal rank. The fifty-two attendants of the Embassy are assigned apartments on the same floor along Prince and Crosby streets. Meals will be served to the Ambassadors of second rank in their rooms. For those of the third rank dining rooms have been superbly fitted up and ornamented by DELAMANO, in the Japanese style. The attendants will also have dining apartments devoted exclusively to their use. Baths, dressing-rooms, and every convenience which ingenuity could devise or luxury suggest are attached to the different suites of rooms.

abstract: The last few weeks I have been traveling mostly in Southern Kansas, and a few way-notes may be of interest to those beyond our boundaries. As much as the people of Kansas have long desired admission as a relief for their Territorial vassalage, there are still other important matters, of a local character, that more interest them at present than the wily moves upon the Washington checker-board.
lead_paragraph: LAWRENCE, Friday, May 18, 1860.

abstract: According to the tenor of recent advices from Mexico, per steamer Pocahontas at New-Orleans, it appears that a crisis in the affairs of that country, which promises to result in favor of the Liberals, is close at hand. Some days since we published the account of a battle near San Luis, between the Second Division of the Church forces, under Gen. DE LA VEGA, and the Liberal Army, under Gen. URAGA, in which the latter was completely victorious. From more recent advices it appears that Gen. [???]RAGA, at the head of 6,000 Liberals, had occupied the city of Guanajuato, and was about to march upon the City of Mexico, which it is stated had declared against MIRAMON and placed ZULOAGA in power.

abstract: That perennial descendant of Ham is still engaging the attention of the members of the Conference and, taking an observation from the latitude allowed the orators, is likely to continue so until this latitude becomes too warm for public speaking. abstract: On Saturday the hundreds of foremen, laborers, contractors and inspectors who assembled at the office of this Department, were somewhat surprised by the appearance of an order which was posted on the desk of the Contract Clerk, Mr. DODGE, requiring all inspectors on sewers or paving jobs to appear before the Mayor, and take the oath of office. The notice was not otherwise remarkable than that it closed with the intimation, that "no warrants would be signed by the Mayor unless this direction is complied with" This order, the first of its character ever issued since the Croton Board was organized, evidently means something.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday the hundreds of foremen, laborers, contractors and inspectors who assembled at the office of this Department, were somewhat surprised by the appearance of an order which was posted on the desk of the Contract Clerk, Mr. DODGE, requiring all inspectors on sewers or paving jobs to appear before the Mayor, and take the oath of office. abstract: The cry of Religious Freedom, always so captivating, has been raised by a great number of the so-called Anti-Sabbatarians, who insist on ignoring the real character and basis of the laws protecting the Sabbath.
lead_paragraph: The cry of Religious Freedom, always so captivating, has been raised by a great number of the so-called Anti-Sabbatarians, who insist on ignoring the real character and basis of the laws protecting the Sabbath. Instead of accepting the obvious and uniform interpretation given by their supporters, and recognized by our Courts, or of discriminating as to their practical operation, it has been maintained by both American and German journals, within a week, that "the Sabbath is not a political, nor a civil, but a religious institution;" and that "the Sabbatarians intend to make the civil power subservient to the Church, and will soon compel every man to go to church on that day, or mulct him in a penalty for his disobedience." Reams of paper have been spoiled in asserting the "unconstitutionality" of all such statutes. Were the laws what they are represented to be, or were the Constitution the mutilated, perverted thing claimed, there might be ground for the clamor against both. But in truth, both the laws and the Constitution have been shamefully misrepresented. And in point of fact, the constitutional objection has been almost universally based on the first clause of Art. I., sec. 3 -- "The free exercise and enjoyment of religious professions and worship, without discrimination or preference, shall forever be allowed in this State to all mankind;" -- -- without any reference to the concluding clause of the same section, which, of itself, nullifies every claim for Sunday license on the score of religious freedom. One honorable exception to this rule we find in the able leader of the Staats Zeitung of a recent date; and this leader is worthy of examination, both as a specimen of German logic, and because of its relation to the conflict of the Sunday theatre gentry with a recent law of this State.
headline: {'main': 'The Sunday Law and the German Press.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Sunday Law and the German Press.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: EDMUND DESMOND, a brakeman on a gravel train of the Harlem Railroad, fell from his position between the cars as the train was approaching Fordham, on Friday last, and the wheels having passed over him, nearly separated his legs from his body. The poor fellow died on his way hack to the City. He was 19 years of age....A fluid-lamp exploded in the hands of FRANCI[???]CA NICKIENBER, a German, 33 years of age, residing at No. 18 Leonard-street, on Friday night, and burned her so badly that her death yesterday resulted. Coroner SCHI[???]MER held inquests in both cases, and he was also called upon to investigate the circumstances attending the death of DANIEL HU[???]LY, an Irishman, 40 years of age, who wa[???]atally scalded on Saturday evening from having fallen into a va[???] of boiling fat at the boiling establishment, No. 10 Thirty-ninth-street, between Tenth and Eleventh avenues.

abstract: We publish in another column two "opinions " emanating from Messrs. O'CONOR and BRONSON, touching the validity of Mr. STOUT'S removal from the Chamberlaincy.
lead_paragraph: We publish in another column two "opinions " emanating from Messrs. O'CONOR and BRONSON, touching the validity of Mr. STOUT'S removal from the Chamberlaincy. The Supreme Court is the proper place to discuss the question of their soundness; but touching "His Honor's" judgment in getting them and publishing them, the public can come to a conclusion without the aid of any tribunal whatever. There could hardly be a better argument in favor of the utter annihilation of the whole system of which "His Honor" is the head than these two expositions of the law furnish, if correct.

abstract: Mr. ASHMORE, of South Carolina, (Dem.,) offered a resolution that the Sergeant-atArms be instructed to withhold the further payment of salary from such members as have neglected or refused to report their mileage to the Committee on Mileage. Mr. ASHMORE said that forty or  more members were interested in this subject. Until members so report, it is impossible for the Sergeantat Arms to balance his accounts.

abstract: The Northern Light, from Aspinwall on the 19th, with the mails and treasure, which left San Francisco on the 5th inst., arrived at this port on Saturday evening. Her California advices have been anticipated by the overland telegraph and mail.
lead_paragraph: The Northern Light, from Aspinwall on the 19th, with the mails and treasure, which left San Francisco on the 5th inst., arrived at this port on Saturday evening. Her California advices have been anticipated by the overland telegraph and mail. Affairs in New-Granada indicate anything but continued tranquility. In the State of Buenaventura, the Custom-house had been seized by one of the insurgent chiefs, and an officer in his own interest substituted. MOSQUERA remains in a menacing attitude, threatening, unless the obnoxious electoral law be repealed, to declare Cauca independent. The Federal Government, in the meantime, was strengthening its military arm in preparation for conflict, the idea of concession to the malcontents being finally repudiated. The Northern Light brings nothing later from Central America or the western coast of South America. The United States steamer Wyoming had been ordered to Callao, to aid our Minister, Mr. CLAY, in his demands upon Peru, in the case of the ships Lizzie Thompson and Georgiana. The Powhatan sailed from Panama on the 16th inst. for Philadelphia, via Cape Horn. The Sabine was at Aspinwall, all well.

abstract: THE STORM The rain storm on Saturday caused considerable damage in this city. The water ran with great volume down the steep grade of Hicks into Fulton-street, doing much damage to the sewer being constructed on the former street.
lead_paragraph: THE STORM -- The rain storm on Saturday caused considerable damage in this city. The water ran with great volume down the steep grade of Hicks into Fulton-street, doing much damage to the sewer being constructed on the former street. The contractor for this sewer, Mr. PATRICK DILLON, has excavated for a distance of nearly four blocks to a depth of fourteen feet. The water very speedily washed the dirt away from the bracos erected to prevent the banks from caving in, when at several points the earth caved in, carrying with it and breaking the water-pipes -- at this point nine or ten inches in diameter -- and with this additional supply, the sewer, street and many basements of houses were soon flooded. The Superintendent of the water-pipes in this district was promptly on the spot, and in a short time had the water shut off, the disjointed pipes suspended by means of derricks and readjusted, and the water was turned on again yesterday morning. So that the residents in the district experienced no great inconvenience from the accident. The sewer contractor's loss is estimated at between one and two thousand dollars. No serious damage eras done by the rain on sewers constructing in other districts; but the new streets, exposed to a sweep of water from the hillsides, were all more or less injured.

abstract: We published a communication on Saturday which exposes the hypocritical pretences by which the majority in the Board of Trustees of the Fourth Ward are endeavoring to hide the real motives of their conduct towards the teachers of their public schools.
lead_paragraph: We published a communication on Saturday which exposes the hypocritical pretences by which the majority in the Board of Trustees of the Fourth Ward are endeavoring to hide the real motives of their conduct towards the teachers of their public schools. We are a little surprised to find men capable of such conduct sufficiently sensitive to public opinion to make for it any excuses whatever: -- but we are not surprised that such apologies as they can offer should prove to be false, or utterly inadequate as a palliation for their action. Men capable of dismissing public teachers, who have taken special pains to qualify themselves for their duties, who have performed them with conscientious fidelity and success, and who are entirely dependent upon them for their living, must be expected to cloak their proceedings under whatever pretext promises to be most plausible. One of them has hinted incapacity, -- but has not ventured to allege it. Another said they were removed because they were behind the age, -- because they had become independent, and because their places were wanted by other teachers in the Ward. Our correspondent exploded all these incongruous falsehoods by showing that they were all young and in the full vigor of life, -- that none of them had any resources except their profession, and that, in some instances, teachers were brought from other Wards to fill their places.

abstract: One of the advantages of competing for the Presidency of the United States, even if failure be the result, is that the unsuccessful candidate at least has nothing more to fear from the envy, hatred, or malice of his enemies.
lead_paragraph: One of the advantages of competing for the Presidency of the United States, even if failure be the result, is that the unsuccessful candidate at least has nothing more to fear from the envy, hatred, or malice of his enemies. He undergoes, in the three or four months which elapse between the nomination and the election, that thorough and searching examination which would otherwise have been protracted over a whole lifetime; and the results of the scrutiny which, under other circumstances, would not reach anybody outside a small circle of curious or malignant gossips, is spread before the eyes of an entire nation. An investigation so trying, it may safely be said, no human being is on any other occasion ever called upon to undergo. The " Devil's Advocate," who appears before the Sacred College at Rome, when the canonization of a departed worthy is in contemplation, to urge every peccadillo or shortcoming that can be raked up in the holy man's career, against his claims to promotion, does not labor in his vocation with, half the zeal and energy which the American Press and politicians put forth against the candidate of the opposite party.

abstract: This match was played, on Saturday, at East New-York, and terminated in a victory for the Red Cross Knights of the Willow by the result of the first inning, it being a one-day match, and the rain preventing any further play than one innings on each side. Quite a number of cricketers were present, and...
lead_paragraph: This match was played, on Saturday, at East New-York, and terminated in a victory for the Red Cross Knights of the Willow by the result of the first inning, it being a one-day match, and the rain preventing any further play than one innings on each side. Quite a number of cricketers were present, and all the parties dined at REED's Hotel on a substantial repast. The St. George's Club were barred from playing their professional bowlers, and some of their other first-rate men were also absent. As it was, the batting of Messr. Gibbes, Waller, Walker, Lang, and Vinten, gained them the victory, some of their other bats being unfortunate. The bowling of Waller and Gibbes, as well as their fielding, the wicket-keeping of Lang, longstopping of Mr. Burnett, and the fielding of three American Cricketers, the brothers Robinson and F. Van Buren, were very superior. Mr. Tilt's fielding was also very effective. East New York were very unfortunate at the bat, as some of their best[???]men went out for small scores or nothing. Messrs. Beach. North, Stokes, and Cuyp played remarkably well for their scores. Messrs Wat[???]on, Shaw and Vanny, who are Americans, made their scores in dashing style. Cuyp's bowling was splendid, as was Watson's longstopping. Dr. Andrews also bowled finery, and the fielding of Messrs. Van Sic[???]en, Morris, Bedford and Shaw was excellent. Andrews, Morris and Van Siclen are also Americans. The ball was presented by the President of the East New-York Club. Mr. Davis, to Mr. BAGE, President of the St. George's Club. Complimentary and friendly remarks were interchanged on parting, and the parties separated with mutual good wishes. The following is the score:

abstract: The arrival of the Palestine at Quebec, and of the Arabia at Halifax, furnished us last evening with news from all parts of Europe to May 20, making the unusual, though not unprecedented time for the transmission of transatlantic news, of eight days. The intelligence is of the utmost importance. GARIBALDI, with his volunteers, had effected a landing at Marsala, in Sicily, leaving his vessels in the hands of pursuing Neapolitan frigates, but securing his arms and munition. Other arms and aids for the insurgents had been previously landed at another point. All the important points of Sicily were reported to have already fallen into the hands of the gallant leader, who had rallied all the disaffected to his ranks, and was quite sure to sweep the royal troops from the Island. A subsidiary expedition had effected a landing in Calabria, and Naples itself was threatened with insurrection. So great was the consternation of the King of Naples that he had invoked the aid of foreign Governments. There were also rumors of a treaty of alliance, offensive and defensive, just concluded between the Courts of Vienna, Rome and Naples, with the adhesion of the exiled Dukes. In Central Italy affairs were also assuming threatening appearances. Gen. LAMORICIERE was concentrating his forces on the frontier of the Romagna, and to oppose him Sardinia was throwing additional troops into the AEmilia. Austria, yielding to the pressure of events, has at last met the demands of the Hungarian Protestants with liberal concessions. From Prussia, we learn that the Chambers by a vote nearly unanimous, had sanctioned the Ministerial project of a war budget; while from Russia we have the official announcement that the demands of that Power upon Turkey, which provoked the war of the Crimea, are to be renewed and urged with unrelaxing importunity. The news from France is not important. The adjustment of the prize-fight difficulty is the principal topic of English news; the champions having fixed upon a compromise, in accordance with which SAYERS surrenders the existing belt, which is to be hung up at the office of Bell's Life, subject to the demand of any worthy champion; while two new belts are to be made for the present contestants; and SAYERS, to close the negotiation, is to retire at once from the Prize Ring. Of personal tidings, we regret to have to announce the death of Rev. THEODORE PARKER, the distinguished rationalist and philanthropist, and of Sir GEORGE BARRY, noted as an architect.
lead_paragraph: The arrival of the Palestine at Quebec, and of the Arabia at Halifax, furnished us last evening with news from all parts of Europe to May 20, making the unusual, though not unprecedented time for the transmission of transatlantic news, of eight days. The intelligence is of the utmost importance. GARIBALDI, with his volunteers, had effected a landing at Marsala, in Sicily, leaving his vessels in the hands of pursuing Neapolitan frigates, but securing his arms and munition. Other arms and aids for the insurgents had been previously landed at another point. All the important points of Sicily were reported to have already fallen into the hands of the gallant leader, who had rallied all the disaffected to his ranks, and was quite sure to sweep the royal troops from the Island. A subsidiary expedition had effected a landing in Calabria, and Naples itself was threatened with insurrection. So great was the consternation of the King of Naples that he had invoked the aid of foreign Governments. There were also rumors of a treaty of alliance, offensive and defensive, just concluded between the Courts of Vienna, Rome and Naples, with the adhesion of the exiled Dukes. In Central Italy affairs were also assuming threatening appearances. Gen. LAMORICIERE was concentrating his forces on the frontier of the Romagna, and to oppose him Sardinia was throwing additional troops into the AEmilia. Austria, yielding to the pressure of events, has at last met the demands of the Hungarian Protestants with liberal concessions. From Prussia, we learn that the Chambers by a vote nearly unanimous, had sanctioned the Ministerial project of a war budget; while from Russia we have the official announcement that the demands of that Power upon Turkey, which provoked the war of the Crimea, are to be renewed and urged with unrelaxing importunity. The news from France is not important. The adjustment of the prize-fight difficulty is the principal topic of English news; the champions having fixed upon a compromise, in accordance with which SAYERS surrenders the existing belt, which is to be hung up at the office of Bell's Life, subject to the demand of any worthy champion; while two new belts are to be made for the present contestants; and SAYERS, to close the negotiation, is to retire at once from the Prize Ring. Of personal tidings, we regret to have to announce the death of Rev. THEODORE PARKER, the distinguished rationalist and philanthropist, and of Sir GEORGE BARRY, noted as an architect.

abstract: THE PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS. -- A public meeting of those in favor of taxing the first twelve Wards, instead of the whole city, for the cost of opening Prospect Park and several other improvements provided for by the last Legislature, was held in the Supreme Court Room, City Hall, last evening, Mr. JOHN D. COCKS in the Chair.
lead_paragraph: THE PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS. -- A public meeting of those in favor of taxing the first twelve Wards, instead of the whole city, for the cost of opening Prospect Park and several other improvements provided for by the last Legislature, was held in the Supreme Court Room, City Hall, last evening, Mr. JOHN D. COCKS in the Chair. A report in favor of proceeding with carrying out the proposed improvements was adopted; after which, some remarks upon, the general question as to the policy of making such improvements -- which but few, if any, deny -- were made by J.W. GILBERT, L.W. LIBBY, and others, when the meeting adjourned. In the Board of Aldermen, last evening, the subject of these improvements was referred for consideration to the Committee on Opening Streets, with two Aldermen to be added.

abstract: Since the Legislature has taken the Sword from the Mayor, by transferring the control of the Police to a Board of Commissioners, he has endeavored to console himself by securing more absolute command of the Purse. The independent organization, and the admirable administration of the Finance Department, have hitherto been found embarassing obstacles to the gratification of this fond wish to which he has constantly directed his "single eye," so ostentatiously dedicated to the public service. Notwithstanding the convenient facilities afforded by a Board of Aldermen, who discover in the "almighty dollar" a sufficient "cause" for anything which they find it for their interest to do, it seems that the Comptroller has wisely determined to save the City from the endless complication which would result from recognizing the Mayor's Chamberlain PLATT, who has no money to pay a warrant, and ignoring the actual Chamberlain STOUT, who has the City funds in his possession. The Comptroller declining to approve the bonds tendered by Mr. PLATT, or in any way to become a party to the outrageous scheme of usurpation by which the Mayor seeks to gain unchecked control of every branch of the City Government, the controversy must now go before the Courts for adjudication.

abstract: The affairs of Europe can hardly, with truth, any longer be called "foreign affairs" to the people of America. The enormous tide of European emigration which, after flowing steadily to our shores in a Mississipian stream for the last six years, has suddenly widened and deepened; the increase of business relations and commercial exchanges which has followed and attended upon this emigration, making New-York another London for the cosmopolitan influence of its markets, and knotting together the smallest inland Duchies of Germany with the prairies of the Far West; and, finally, the amazing development of steam communication, which has grown upon us so silently and swiftly that we have scarce marked its advances, till now the centres of European life and activity are actually nearer to our shores than a few years ago Boston was to New-Orleans, or New-York to St. Louis; all these things combine to make the great republic part and parcel of the European family of nations. It is childish to babble over the dreams of JEFFERSON in the face of these facts. For good or ill they are facts; and every man who has an interest to care for, or a hope to cultivate in the busy world of America to-day, from the broker in Wall-street to the farmer in Minnesota, may as well understand by the use of his own faculties that his fortunes are involved in the fortunes of the Eastern Continent, as wait to have the truth forced home upon him in some sudden and perhaps not altogether satisfactory shape.
lead_paragraph: The affairs of Europe can hardly, with truth, any longer be called "foreign affairs" to the people of America. lead_paragraph: A Vienna telegram of the 14th states on reliable information that part of GARIBALDI'S expedition disembarked at Marsala on the 11th from two vessels. The Royal ships were obliged to cease firing, during two hours being, it is asserted, prevented by English steamers. The firing could not be resumed until the English officers had returned from the shore to their vessels. The volunteers who landed were fighting with the Royal troops at the moment of the mail's departure.

abstract: Bell's Life of the 19th inst. announces that a meeting took place between SAYERS and HEENAN, at that office, yesterday, to discuss the means of terminating the dispute between them, and as to the possession of the champion's belt. It was ultimately agreed that two new belts, exact counterparts of the one so much coveted, should be made, the money for the purpose to be raised by public subscription. Each of the candidates is to head the list for that held by his opponent. The old belt will remain in the possession of the proprietor of Bell's Life, to be fought for by whoever may aspire to the honor of wearing it.

abstract: LUCIUS H. HALL, a young gentleman employed in the office of JOHN H. BODIE, Secretary of the At lantic and Pacific Ship Canal Company, was found dead at No. 28 Broadway, under circumstances which induced the belief that he had taken poison.
lead_paragraph: LUCIUS H. HALL, a young gentleman employed in the office of JOHN H. BODIE, Secretary of the At lantic and Pacific Ship Canal Company, was found dead at No. 28 Broadway, under circumstances which induced the belief that he had taken poison. When he came to the office in the morning, Mr. BODIE noticed a strange excitement in his manner, which led to the supposition that he had been indulging too freely in the use of intoxicating liquor. He accordingly advised him to walk in the open air, by which Mr. BODIE supposed he would be relieved. Mr. HALL left the office, apparently with the intention of following the kind suggestion of his employer. In about one hour afterwards Mr. BODIE found deceased lying in the hallway, apparently dead. He immediately sent for a physician, but the unfortunate man breathed his last before medical aid arrived. Mr. HALL is about 30 years of age, slightly built, and of genteel appearance and address. He was a student or graduate of the Law School at Cambridge, and has respectable connections in Massachusetts or New-Hampshire. He has spent considerable time at the West, where he contracted fever and ague, from which he suffered much. A small paper was found in his bosom containing a few blades of grass, and bearing the inscription: "From her dear grave, for LUCIUS." This simple tribute of affection probably sent to him from a distant friend, has suggested sudden grief as the cause of the act of self-destruction. It is believed that deceased has an acquaintance in Flushing. Coroner O'KEEFE adjourned the inquest to this morning; meantime the body remains at the dead-house of the Bellevue Hospital.

abstract: At the regular meeting of the Commissioners of Police, yesterday, Sergeant Cass, of the First Precinct, resigned. The Sanitary Squad, of Brooklyn, made a report of some fifteen very objectionable places in Brooklyn. A resolution was adopted that honorable mention be made in the records of the Department of the gallant conduct of Harbor Police boat No. 2, in repressing the mutiny on board of the ship Wm.F. Storer. Adjourned to Tuesday.

abstract: The recurrence of the German May festivals was hailed this year with unusual enthusiasm, and observed with a unanimity rarely equaled. The day was quite fair, and its coolness amply compensated for the dampness of the ground form the recent violent rains. At an early hour the busy mustering of the celebrants in all quarters of the City presented a busy spectacle, and before mid-day the vast body of our German population was on the way to the suburbs for the enjoyment of their national recreations.

abstract: Three more arrests were made yesterday of parties connected with the City lot swindlers. Their names are Wm.A. Hyde and Wm.S. Edricks, keepers of a public house at the corner of Eighty-sixth-street and Fourth-avenue, and Honeywell Vincent, who has an office at the corner of Nassau and Cedar streets. Detectives Sampson and De Voe made the arrests, and Henry C. Allen, of the District-Attorney's office, made the complaint, charging that on the 5th inst. Hyde and Edrick called on Messrs. Robinson, Ward & Co., No. 9 Morris-street, and negotiated for the purchase of wines to a large amount, and, as security for the purchase-money offered Mr. Robinson a bond and mortgage purporting to be executed by Sarah J. Lyons, to one H. Vincent; the said bonds and mortgages not having been executed by any real person; and, furthermore, that the documents are made out in fictitious names; that the name of the Commissioner, Abram W. Kennedy, of No. 153 Bowery, is forged; and that the property described in the mortgage could not, and did not, belong to any person by the name of Sarah J. Lyons, the same being, at the time the mortgage purports to have been executed, and for a long time previously, owned by the City, and comprises a portion of the Central Park. The prisoners were taken before Justice CONNOLLY and committed to the Tombs for trial for forgery, in default of $2,000 bail. The Police report that Vincent has already served one term in State Prison, on a conviction for false pretences.

abstract: Resolutions were adopted last evening at the meeting of the Association, expressive of its confidence in the capacity and patriotism of the nominees of the Chicago Convention, as statesmen who can redeem the national reputation from the disgrace which the present Administration has heaped upon it; and although admitting that WM.H. SEWARD was their first choice for President, yet pledging themselves to lend all their efforts to secure the election of Mr. LINCOLN. No other business was transacted.

abstract: The intelligence of the death of Rev. THEODORE PARKER, which occurred at Florence, on the 10th inst., will occasion no surprise to his friends or the general public. Accounts, mostly communicated in private letters from intimate associates who affectionately discharged the duty of ministering to his comfort, have reached us, from time to time, for the past two years, from the West Indies, and from various countries in Europe, but mostly from Italy, whose warm skies and genial climate it was fondly trusted would restore the health the loss of which drove him from his native shores. At one time these letters were of a cheerful nature, but latterly the writers evidently considered his condition to be growing so serious that they could give little hope of his recovery. An extract from a communication to a Boston journal, published a few days since, must have fully prepared all its readers for the tidings of his decease which we now announce.

abstract: We owe a new debt to the Covode Committee. Thanks to their investigations, the world at last possesses Mr. BUCHANAN's idea of a good Democrat? It will be remembered that Hon. R.J. WALKER was sent to Kansas in 1857, as Governor, by our venerable President, to do justice, in mercy -- the "old public functionary" invoking the Divine blessing on his own head as he dispatched his representative to the scene of his duties. An election occurred shortly after in Kansas, and returns from two counties -- Oxford and McGee -- notoriously false and fraudulent, were presented, the voters' names having been taken by wholesale from the Cincinnati Directory. Gov. WALKER, like a good citizen and an honorable man, refused to receive these returns, and thereupon followed a difficulty between himself and his Chief. Mr. BUCHANAN did not care how the returns were made up, so that the majority was on his own side, and accordingly sent Gov. WALKER his letters of leave.
lead_paragraph: We owe a new debt to the Covode Committee. Thanks to their investigations, the world at last possesses Mr. BUCHANAN's idea of a good Democrat? It will be remembered that Hon. R.J. Gov. WALKER, like a good citizen and an honorable man, refused to receive these returns, and thereupon followed a difficulty between himself and his Chief. abstract: The Sisters of Charity have fairly captured the coy month of May, and compelled her to show herself in behalf of the sacred cause to which they give their lives. In the streets, and parks, and public places, the willful month behaves badly enough; but in the Palace Gardens she is a captive, caged and bound with flowers, and forced to smile, whether she will or no, on thousands of admiring human faces. If ever there was a just cause for such violent measures, it is the cause of the truly Catholic (because truly impartial) charity in aid of which they have now been taken. The Hospital of St. Vincent de Paul in this City has for years been open to the suffering of every creed and every name; and through its quiet wards mercy and gentleness have done their blessed work, unobserved and untrumpeted of men. The Sister of Charity may be the daughter of Rome, but she is the recognized sister of all mankind, preaching a gospel over which no controversy can arise, and which no hardness of heart can resist. To say that this true order of Christian nobility is now appealing to the public of New-York for aid in its self-imposed task of unflagging humanity, is to offer our readers the opportunity of giving themselves a pleasure in which they may safely indulge to the top of their bent. The Fair and Floral Festival of St. Vincent now open, will not be closed until Friday next.

abstract: The reappearance of the "Turkish difficulty" upon the political stage in Europe, with an aspect almost as menacing as that which it wore when MENSCHIKOFF displayed his paletot at the Porte, in 1853, is a signal illustration of the folly of trying to mend or patch up political organizations that are not founded either on justice or on the popular will. If the relations of the Turkish Government with its Christian subjects had been settled finally at the close of the Crimean war, so as to prevent the recurrence of fresh complications, instead of being settled temporarily for the mere purpose of making peace, we should not have, as at present, commerce deranged and manufactures half paralyzed, by the imminent renewal of a quarrel which has, for half a century, kept the three greatest Powers in Europe in hot water. The remonstrances made by Russia, on behalf of the Turkish Christians, were, as the world knew, perfectly well founded. The grievances she complained of were substantial and notrious. They were disregarded by the Sultan and by France and England, from a very reasonable conviction that they were put forward as a cover for schemes of territorial aggrandizement on a great scale. Russia asked the Porte for justice for her co-religionists in order that she might herself take the place of the Porte as their ruler; and the Allies aided the Sultan in resisting them through fear of seeing the Czar enthroned at Constantinople. There is nothing in the least unreasonable on the part of the Western Powers, in deprecating the addition of 30,000,000 subjects to an Empire already so powerful as that of Russia. The fear that a power which would stretch from Lapland to the Bosphorus, over some of the finest countries in Europe, and would add the command of the Mediterranean to the complete possession of the Black Sea, and support a navy manned by the maritime population of the Archipelago and Dalmatia, by an army of nearly a million and a half of regular soldiers, would prove dangerous to the liberty and independence of other European nations, is not a fear that can be fairly called chimerical. Neither France nor Italy nor England could witness the apparition of such a giant in the Levant without the gravest misgivings.

abstract: POLITICAL. -- The Republicans of this City have found by practical experience that the "Wigwam" recently erected in Fulton-street, opposite the City Hall, is entirely too small for the purposes designed. To afford additional accommodations, they are making arrangements to erect a gallery, to extend around the building, which will make room for some five hundred more persons. The Ashland Club are about buying a six-pound cannon to use during the campaign. The Republicans in the Seventh Ward propose to erect two Wigwams -- one on Myrtle and the other on Fulton-avenue.
lead_paragraph: POLITICAL. -- The Republicans of this City have found by practical experience that the "Wigwam" recently erected in Fulton-street, opposite the City Hall, is entirely too small for the purposes designed. The Ashland Club are about buying a six-pound cannon to use during the campaign. The Republicans in the Seventh Ward propose to erect two Wigwams -- one on Myrtle and the other on Fulton-avenue.

abstract: Senator HAMMOND, of South Carolina, in a letter which was published in the TIMES a few days since, insists upon the necessity of a compact union among the Slave States, and advises the sending of delegates to Richmond clothed with absolute power to take such action as the emergency may require. He represents the people of the North as bent on the destruction of the slaveholding States -- ignorant of the fact that it involves their own. He adds:

abstract: The Homestead bill, as amended by the House, was called up in the Senate, when, on motion of Mr. JOHNSON, of Ark., the amendments were not concurred with. The Pacific Telegraph bill and the Post-office Deficiency bill were successively and briefly considered, when Mr. SLIDELL, of Louisiana, was permitted to make an explanation of his connection with the Houmas Land Claims. Mr. BENJAMIN followed with a detailed statement of the same subject, in support of Mr. SLIDELL, and was encountered by Mr. TOOMBS, who contended that the lands now claimed under the Houmas patent, have been for a half-century in possession of other parties, whose rights have not hitherto been disputed. Without action, the Senate adjourned. The Pacific Railroad bill engaged the attention of the House; Southern members arguing in a blustering way for a Southern route; and the parents of the bill defending the one selected. Mr. DAVIS, of Maryland, raised a legal objection to the bill, in the fact that the parties named in it constituted not a corporation, but a partnership; and that the death of any one of them would throw the whole subject into chancery. Other technical objections were made by Mr. MILLSON, and the bill, by a vote of 100 to 87, was recommitted. In Committee of the Whole, Mr. WASHBURNE delivered a campaign document by way of a speech embodying an account of the life, public services, and private character of ABRAHAM LINCOLN, the Illinois candidate of the Republican Party for the Presidency. Other members, not obtaining a hearing, obtained leave to print speeches intended for electioneering purposes.

abstract: The mass of information from Mexico that has appeared in the TIMES this week, cannot fail to make apparent the peculiar and extraordinary character of the revolution and civil strife that have been in progress throughout the neighboring Republic since the latter part of 1857.
lead_paragraph: The mass of information from Mexico that has appeared in the TIMES this week, cannot fail to make apparent the peculiar and extraordinary character of the revolution and civil strife that have been in progress throughout the neighboring Republic since the latter part of 1857. We have the account that MORS. GABRIAC, who has been the official representative of France and Spain in Mexico for several years, and one of the principal supporters of the Church or monarchical faction, has been recalled; and it is stated that this high functionary, the representative of two of the European Powers in Mexico, has so outraged public opinion, so violated his duty towards his own countrymen even, in his official and private acts, that he is obliged to proceed from the city of Mexico to Vera Cruz by circuitous routes, and embark by stealth on board a French man-of-war at Sacrificios, to avoid insult, and perhaps the hanging he so richly deserves. It is also stated that the French and Spanish Minister has accumulated, during his five years' residence in Mexico, the sum of $1,000,000 -- having been interested in the iniquitous financial schemes of the Church Government, the importation of French goods under the seal of the Legation, &c., &c.

abstract: The auction sale of the Brooklyn ferry leases, which has been advertised to come off at various times during the last six months, but has been postponed through the action of the Courts in this City and Brooklyn, finally took place yesterday, in Room No. 20, City Hall, under the hammer of W. S. Duke, Auctioneer.
lead_paragraph: The auction sale of the Brooklyn ferry leases, which has been advertised to come off at various times during the last six months, but has been postponed through the action of the Courts in this City and Brooklyn, finally took place yesterday, in Room No. 20, City Hall, under the hammer of W. S. Duke, Auctioneer. There were but few persons present, and only three took part in the bidding. These were Mr. Cyrus P. Smith, the President of the Union Ferry Company, Mr. Hays, President of the Dry Dock Bank, who was understood to act for Geo. Law, and Mr. C.K. Garrison. The lease is for ten years from the 1st of May, 1861, and includes all the ferries now owned by the Union Ferry Company, viz.: Fulton, Catharine, Wall, South and Hamilton-avenue. The price paid now is $56,000 per annum, and, according to the terms of the advertisement, no bid was to be received less than the present rates. The first bid -- $56,000 -- was made by Mr. Smith, and from this point they ran up rapidly at an advance of $5,000 each bid, to $85,000. Mr. Hays here stopped bidding, and from this figure the advance was $1,000 each bid, until it reached $103,000, when it was knocked off to Cyrus P. Smith, who acted on behalf of the Union Ferry Company. A man named Blake, who claims to own the landing of the Hamilton-avenue Ferry on the Brooklyn side, was present, and gave formal notice that the purchaser would not be allowed to use that landing without his consent.

abstract: The schooner Josephine, Capt. Wm. F. Carter, cleared from this port for the West Coast of Africa on the 17th of May, and was compelled to return on account of being dismasted. Information having been made of her suspicious character, Mr. Dwight, Assistant District-Attorney, and Mr. Thompson, from the United States Marshal's Office, proceeded to Red Hook, where the vessel was lying, and seized her.
lead_paragraph: The schooner Josephine, Capt. Wm. F. Carter, cleared from this port for the West Coast of Africa on the 17th of May, and was compelled to return on account of being dismasted. Information having been made of her suspicious character, Mr. Dwight, Assistant District-Attorney, and Mr. Thompson, from the United States Marshal's Office, proceeded to Red Hook, where the vessel was lying, and seized her. After a partial inspection of her papers, she was placed in the custody of a number of men sent on board by Capt HUTCHINS, from the United States Revenue Cutter McClelland. A warrant was also issued for the arrest of Capt. CARTER, who was found, and required to give $3,000 bonds to appear and answer. It is reported that CARTER is the same man who commanded the Rebecca, which was chartered by the Colonization Society to convey to Africa forty-one negroes belonging to the McDonough estate of New-Orleans; that he landed the negroes, and then proceeded to the Congo River, took in a load of slaves, carried them to Cuba, and afterwards sunk the vessel. The Josephine is still at Red Hook, but she will soon be brought up and discharged.

abstract: The Grand Jury yesterday brought forty indictments into this Court, including one against Lawson,  Wells, Totten, and the two Thompsons, for forging deeds. These parties were arrested through the agency of Mr. W.H. Allen, of the District Attorney's office, and held to bail. The Grand Inquest also indicted 53 persons, charged with having sold liquors.
lead_paragraph: The Grand Jury yesterday brought forty indictments into this Court, including one against Lawson, Wells, Totten, and the two Thompsons, for forging deeds. These parties were arrested through the agency of Mr. W.H. Allen, of the District Attorney's office, and held to bail. The Grand Inquest also indicted 53 persons, charged with having sold liquors on Sunday. The proprietors of the German gardens are largely included; among them are the Volles Garten, Lindenmuller's and the Stadt Theatre. The penalty, on conviction, will be punishable by six months in Penitentiary and a fine of $250.

abstract: The celebration of the Fifty-fourth Anniversary of the New-York Orphan Asylum, yesterday, was an occasion of unusual interest, and drew together a large number of the friends and patrens of the institution. The exercises commenced at noon, at which time the rooms were crowded with spectators. The children in their neat and uniform attire, presented a pleasing spectacle, each one appearing to take a deep interest in the proceedings. They began by chanting the "Jubilate," after which Rev. JOHN COTTON SMITH read the Scriptures and offered prayer, in which the children joined. After a song, entitled "Pleasant Weather," Rev. Mr. SMITH read the annual report, of which the following are extracts:

abstract: The Young Men's Republican Union, having their headquarters at Stuyvesant Institute, held its regular weekly meeting last evening, the President,  Mr. CHARLES F. ROGERS, in the Chair. The room was well filled, and the Lincoln and Hamlin Glee Club.
lead_paragraph: The Young Men's Republican Union, having their headquarters at Stuyvesant Institute, held its regular weekly meeting last evening, the President, Mr. CHARLES F. ROGERS, in the Chair. The room was well filled, and the Lincoln and Hamlin Glee Club sang several animating songs to swell the enthusiasm. Hon. ABRAN WAKEMAN made the principal speech of the evening, in which he ventilated the doctrine of Squatter Sovereignty, and demonstrated the absurdity of the assumption that the Constitution of the United States guarantees Slavery, in the territories or anywhere else. It was the creature of municipal law only, and slave property once removed from the State where it was recognized, possessed no validity whatever, the common law and the united voice of civilization declaring that man cannot hold property in his fellow man. He concluded by eulogizing the candidates of the Republican Party, and predicting their triumphant election. The speech elicited frequent applause.

abstract: Within a very few weeks this country will become the theatre of a Congress of Princes' almost as remarkable as that curious meeting of ex-monarchs in a Venetian coffee-house, of which ROUSSEAU has left so quaint an account. Those who believe that the Great Republic is now, or is destined at no distant day, to become, the pivot on which the world's most important affairs must revolve, may find confirmation of their creed in the singular and simultaneous arrival upon our shores of all these royal and noble visitors from lands the most unlike to each other and to our own.
lead_paragraph: Within a very few weeks this country will become the theatre of a Congress of Princes' almost as remarkable as that curious meeting of ex-monarchs in a Venetian coffee-house, of which ROUSSEAU has left so quaint an account. abstract: Under the caption of "whistling them back" the New-Orleans Delta discusses the address to the Charleston bolters. It styles the signers "apostles of all faction, disorganization and affliction," and proceeds to enumerate the delegates from the Free States upon whom the South could rely in case her delegates returned to the Convention. After giving the list it says: "We invite the attention of every Southern man to it, and we leave to his own high sense of honor to say whether anything so loathsome and filthy was ever heretofore offered as bribe to high-minded, dignified, and magnanimous Southern gentlemen." The Delta concludes as follows: "Much as we deplore the secession that has occurred, disastrous as we would esteem it, were it approved by the people, calamitous as would be, to our mind, a disruption of the great national party of this glorious Union, we really are in doubt whether all these direful consequences should not be incurred, rather than witness the degradation and abasement the congressional appeal of the ignoble eighteen would counsel the Southern secessionists from the National Democratic Convention to accept."

abstract: The Malta correspondent of the London Times, under date of May 12, announces the arrival on that morning of Her Majesty's steamer Intrepid, from Marsala, with intelligence of the landing thereat on the 11th of a band of 2,000 Italians, under GARIBALDI, who immediately pushed on to Canata Fimi and Alcomo, where the insurgents are concentrated, and will, it is hoped, hold their ground.

abstract: The fair-weather political moralists of Europe in general, and England in particular, have been put by GARIBALDI into a very distressing position. They have been forced to judge the conduct of the Italian patriot, in taking by force the steamers necessary to convey his gallant companions to the rescue of Sicily, and in violating the express law of Sardinia by setting on foot within her dominions a hostile expedition against a "friendly Power;" by a very different standard from that which they keep comfortably laid away for the humiliation of America whenever a Lopez sails from the Gulf for Cuba to prostrate the tyranny of Spain, or a Walker flits by night from the Mississippi to deliver the Nicaraguans from their own incapacity.
lead_paragraph: The fair-weather political moralists of Europe in general, and England in particular, have been put by GARIBALDI into a very distressing position. They have been forced to judge the conduct of the Italian patriot, in taking by force the steamers necessary to convey his gallant companions to the rescue of Sicily, and in violating the express law of Sardinia by setting on foot within her dominions a hostile expedition against a "friendly Power;" by a very different standard from that which they keep comfortably laid away for the humiliation of America whenever a Lopez sails from the Gulf for Cuba to prostrate the tyranny of Spain, or a Walker flits by night from the Mississippi to deliver the Nicaraguans from their own incapacity.

abstract: A DISCUSSION IN THE HOUSE OF COMMONS.  In the House, Commons on the 17th inst., Mr. MONSELL wished to know what course Government intended to take with respect to the parties raising the subscriptions. He called upon them to act fairly and repress this attempt, as they would com- plain if a similar attempt was made to aid a rebellion in Ireland or in the Ionian Islands.

abstract: DOGS AT HALF PRICE. -- If Sir WALTER SCOTT, CHRISTOPHER NORTH and Mr. JESSE may be relied upon, the dog is a grateful animal. In profound gratitude should all Manhattan dogs "bow-wow" to Mayor WOOD and City Marshal BURNHAM, who have reduced their value, as captives for the dog pound, to twenty-five cents each, instead of fifty cents, which has hitherto been the bribe for canine slaughter in the dog-days. Yesterday the annual notice was issued from the Mayor's Office, to the owners of dogs, that on and after June 4 the ordinance respecting such animals found running loose in the streets, without being properly muzzled, will be strictly enforced." But only half the temptation for their capture is now held forth to the boys, and no dogs are any longer permitted to be received from boys. The former premium of fifty cents was considered too liberal, many dogs having been captured beyond the City limits, and even in New-Jersey, quite unoffending dogs they were -- and conveyed to the ponud for the sake of the half-dollar per canem which the captors were to receive therefor. Twenty-five cents is a diminished inducement, and therefore let dogs be glad. We may mention, in this connection, that the "pound" is removed to a barge, stationed at the foot of Twenty-sixth-street, North River, where the "water of sacrifice" can be let on easily and without stint.

abstract: THE COURTS. -- City Court Calendar for this day Nos. 28, 45, 70, 27, 48, 58, 66, 71. In the Court of Sessions yesterday, Peter Vogel, indicted for larceny, in stealing a cow, in March last, from a Mr. Stevenson, was tried and found guilty. Felix McCluskey and John McKenna were convicted of assault and battery upon Deputy-Sheriff J.Q. Adams, while in the discharge of duties pertaining to his office, and sentenced each to pay a fine of $25. James McCluskey, the leader in the assault upon Mr. Adams, and who used a slung-shot, was convicted at the commencement of the present term of the Court, and sentenced to two years' imprisonment in the State Prison at Sing Sing. Thomas Kelly and Valentine Roth, for selling liquor without license, were sentenced to pay a fine of $10 each. John McManon and Thomas Martin, indicted for assault and battery upon Officer Utter, of the Fourth Precinct Police, were convicted, and sentenced to pay a fine of $25 each, or be imprisoned for 35 days. Justice WALTER, on Tuesday evening, sentenced Alexander Dunbar to imprisonment in the Penitentiary for six months, for robbing the till of a lagerbier-saloon, at No. 13 Union-street.

abstract: "Oh, for a good spirit, who would take the house-tops off, with a more potent and benignant hand than that of the lame demon in the tale, and show a Christian people what dark shapes issue forth from amid their homes, to swell the retinue of the destroying angel, as he moves forth among them; for only one night's view of the pale phantoms rising from the scenes of our too long neglect, from the thick and sullen air, where vice and fever propagate together; raising the tremendous social retributions which are ever pouring down, and ever coming thicker!

abstract: We sincerely trust that the death of Lady BYRON may not be followed by a sudden revival of the odious and disgraceful controversy over her domestic relations with her illustrious husband. Whatever the secret causes may have been which dissolved the ill-starred union between one of the most passionate of English poets and one of the most "proper" of pious English ladies, almost as soon as it was formed, there can be no doubt that the conjugal misfortunes of the BYRONS were scandalously seized upon at the time of their occurrence, by the enemies, both personal and political, of the reckless poet and radical peer, as an admirable opportunity for blackening his character, and making his position in England intolerable. These worthy persons hoped thus to drive him into Coventry and obscurity. It was not their fault that they drove him, instead, into Italy and immortality.
lead_paragraph: We sincerely trust that the death of Lady BYRON may not be followed by a sudden revival of the odious and disgraceful controversy over her domestic relations with her illustrious husband. These worthy persons hoped thus to drive him into Coventry and obscurity. It was not their fault that they drove him, instead, into Italy and immortality.

abstract: FUNERAL OF HON. WM.C. PRESTON. -- The funeral of Hon. W.C. PRESTON, of South Carolina, took place at Columbia, the capital of that State. An immense concourse of people, including friends and connections of the deceased, assembled to do honor to the dead. Among them were the venerable Judge KING, of Charleston, and Gen. WADDY THOMPSON, of Greenville, and others. The body was conveyed to Trinity Church, where the funeral services were conducted. In Charleston, on the same day, a meeting of the Bar was convened in the Equity Court-room, for the purpose of paying a tribute to the memory of the deceased. Attorney-General HAYNE moved the organization of the meeting by calling Hon. H.A. DE SAUSSURE to the Chair, when appropriate addresses were made by Messrs. HAYNE and JAMES L. PETIGRU.
lead_paragraph: FUNERAL OF HON. WM.C. PRESTON. -- The funeral of Hon. W.C. PRESTON, of South Carolina, took place at Columbia, the capital of that State. abstract: -- The demise of Russell's Magazine, a Southern periodical which has enjoyed but a short lease of life, affords the text of a melancholy article in the Charleston Mercury. The sad destiny of Southern magazines, the utter lack of Southern sympathy for home productions of a literary character, the difficulties that environ the most enterprising publishers, wring from the Mercury this candid confession: "We are briefly reduced to the alternative of acknowledging that we have no adequate number of writers, or no adequate number of readers, for the maintenance of such a work, or the subscribers do not pay, even if they read." The magazine in question was never very brilliant. The Mercury, however, finds consolation in the fact that, although dead and buried, the magazine planted good seed, and it is hoped that "that seed may fructify."
lead_paragraph: -- The demise of Russell's Magazine, a Southern periodical which has enjoyed but a short lease of life, affords the text of a melancholy article in the Charleston Mercury. abstract: The Hon. W.H. SEWARD appeared in his seat yesterday in the Senate, and was warmly received by Senators of both parties. Mr. SLIDELL, in the Senate, reported back the bill for the acquisition of Cuba, and gave notice that he should call it up at the next session. Mr. LATHAM offered an amendment to the Overland Mail bill, authorizing the Postmaster-General to contract with the contractors on the routes between St. Joseph, Mo., and Great Salt Lake, and between Salt Lake and Placerville, for a semi-weekly, the distance to be done in twenty days, at not more than $462,000 annually; also, to contract for a daily mail by coaches from April 1 to Dec. 1, and tri-weekly for the rest of the year, from Sacramento to Portland, Oregon, at not more than $100,000 per annum; also, to contract for a weekly mail from St. Paul, Minnesota, to the falls of Oregon, at not over $200,000. Mr. LATHAM referred to the great interest felt in this subject by the people of California, which was of more importance to them than the Pacific Railroad. In reply to objections as to the cost of this Overland Mail-service, he remarked that if the postal system was to be considered solely with a view to the amount of money received by it, it would be better for the Government to abrogate the entire Post-office Department, and surrender the carriage of the mails to private enterprise. The House bill for admitting Kansas being taken up, Mr. COLLAMER, of Vermont, spoke at great length in favor of the admission of that Territory; there was 100,000 inhabitants there. Was there ever before a Territory with so large a population? Oregon was admitted when she had only 50,000 inhabitants. Kansas, he was assured, would before this have been admitted, if she could have come in as a Slave State. But the question would always be a bone of contention till it was settled. On motion of Mr. LANE, the bill was postponed till Monday. The Oregon war debt was taken up, and an amendment by Mr. HUNTER, authorizing a loan to pay the amount was lost. In the House, yesterday, Mr. HASKIN, of New-York, called up the special order, providing that hereafter no person shall be elected Printer, either to the Senate or the House, who is not a practical printer of skill and ability; that he shall give bonds as security for $25,000; and that the present prices shall be reduced 40 per cent. He spoke of the gross abuse of the present contract system, which had proved a complete failure. Considerable debate ensued. The minority report, signed by Messrs. HINDMAN and CLOPTON, was read, declaring that the office of Printer to the House was vacant. Mr. CLOPTON, of Alabama, was opposed to a public printing-office, because he thought it would increase the Executive patronage, and not effect a saving of money. Millions would have been saved to the public treasury if years ago the public printing had been let to the lowest responsible bidder. He defended the President from the charge of usurpation of power and violation of law, and thought the charges of corruption against the President and Attorney-General came with bad grace from the party who supported for Printer a man who offered, if elected, to give half the profits of the printing for Republican electioneering purposes. No question was taken on the subject when the House adjourned.
